HEADLINE: Excerpts From Speech Of Rowland to Legislature

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the State of the State address delivered today by Gov. John G. Rowland to a joint session of the Connecticut General Assembly as recorded by The New York Times:
A few moments ago, I took the oath of office to serve as your Governor, an honor that humbles me and an honor that challenges me to build upon the successes that we've all had together during the last four years. As our state of Connecticut approaches the next century, we are poised for continued and expanding prosperity. Ladies and gentlemen, this will be Connecticut's century. I guarantee you of that. 
 The world economy has changed dramatically over the last 10 years, and for much of that time Connecticut was in a period of adjustment. But we've adapted to the changing times, and now Connecticut is on the field and we are a first class competitor.
Our job -- all of our jobs, working together in state government -- is to create an environment which allows for continued economic growth. A vibrant, growing economy is the only factor that guarantees more Connecticut residents will share in this period of prosperity that we all enjoy. And it's important that we not lose sight of the fundamental policies that have put us into such a strong position. . . .
There is a new spirit in this state. There is a new optimism. There is a new hope. Four years ago, I called it "Connecticut's Comeback." Well, today we are back. We're back. We're stronger and more vibrant than ever, ready to make the next 100 years Connecticut's century.
But to do so, we must have the vision to look beyond the status quo. To raise expectations for our government, to raise expectations for our schools, for our cities, for our families, to raise expectations for ourselves -- always making our state more attractive to the next generation. That's what this is all about.
Over the last four years, we have proven that government can be prudent and it can be compassionate. We have proven that we can act with our hearts and our minds.
These may be dark days in our nation's capital, but they are not dark days in Connecticut's capital. Together, we have rejected the politics of personal attack that has paralyzed our Federal Government. And you know what we've practiced? We've practiced what I call the politics of results. The people of this state deserve nothing less. We were not sent here to do personal or partisan battle with each other. We were sent here to do the people's business.
If we can always keep that in mind, there is no limit to what we can achieve on behalf of the people of this state. Let's build on this record of the last four years. Let's use the offices that we've been elected to to set a leadership example for all to see -- and for all of us to be proud of. Thank you -- thank you all so very much. And God bless the great state of Connecticut.

HEADLINE: Rowland Vows to Rein In State Spending

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 6

 BODY:
John Grosvenor Rowland showed two political faces as he was inaugurated today for a second term as Governor of Connecticut, calling for civility and moderation in government even as he vowed to rein in state spending despite the economic boom.
Mr. Rowland, a Republican who at 41 is the nation's youngest Governor, used his inaugural address to project the more inclusive air that several Republican governors have urged their national party to adopt. Then, after a 19-howitzer salute, he took a ceremonial stroll across the Capitol to a joint session of the General Assembly and delivered a State of the State address stressing the conservative touchstones that characterized most of his first term. 
 "Yes, we've had some great economic times," he told the legislators, several of whom wore corsages and boutonnieres for the big day. "But that is no reason for us to return to the days of big spending and tax increases. Our greatest challenge, over the next four years, will be to continue to control the cost and the growth of state government."
Aides said that his budget, to be presented early next month, would not grow much over last year's and that the rise was likely to be less than the inflation rate, now about 2 percent. That would leave little room for new programs proposed by legislators as they contemplated a budget surplus of as much as $500 million.
"A lean government, free of excess programs, excessive rules and regulations, helps us keep our budget in balance," the Governor said. "It helps us provide tax relief. It helps us create economic opportunities. Keeping a lid on the growth of government also gives us the option to invest wisely when the opportunity presents itself."
He also called on Connecticut to resist "the politics of personal attack that has paralyzed our Federal Government," and offered instead a "politics of results."
"When legitimate differences over policy descend into bitter partisanship, the result is inaction, gridlock and the failure of leadership," he said. "The winner in such a power struggle wins control of a government that is powerless to do any public good."
Choirs lined the escalators and spectators jammed five floors of balconies as Governor Rowland took the oath of office in the atrium of the Legislative Office Building, which adjoins the Capitol. The ceremony had been moved from the traditional location outside the Capitol in the hope that Mr. Rowland's father, Sherwood Rowland, who has liver cancer, would be able to administer the oath, as he had in 1995, but he had to stay home in Waterbury.
Mr. Rowland's voice cracked as he dedicated "this historic day to my father."
The Governor's message today was softer than his first inaugural address, in which he warned against "the notion that the state government is the fountain of endless favors." Today, he emphasized the more moderate themes that helped him easily win re-election in November.
"As we look forward to the next century, our responsibility is to redefine the role of state government," he said. "Policies of inclusion must be practiced at every level of government."
Declaring that Connecticut "leads the nation in public civility," he said, "The most important example we can set for ourselves and future leaders is to continue that spirit of cooperation and mutual respect."
In his speech to the legislature, the Governor Rowland reiterated his plans to redevelop the downtowns of the state's largest cities and said he hoped to "cut additional taxes, whenever and wherever possible."
Democrats, who control both houses of the legislature, gave the Governor generally good, if guarded, reviews. "He seems comfortable, both as a matter of politics and policy, governing from the center," said George C. Jepsen, the Senate majority leader.
Representative William R. Dyson, who is co-chairman of the Appropriations Committee, said it would be difficult to finance all the programs the Governor mentioned and still hold back spending. "He's going to have to be the wizard, or we're going to have to be the wizards," Mr. Dyson said.
Mr. Rowland, the state's 86th Governor, is the first Republican to be sworn in for a second term since Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin in 1945. Governor Rowland and his wife, Patty, were bundled up and rosy-cheeked as they led a parade from the Old State House, a brick-and-granite landmark in downtown Hartford that once was the Connecticut Capitol and calls itself the nation's oldest surviving seat of government. The parade included 15 bands and military marching units, along with a 1936 Dodge Phaeton.
Carlos Ortiz, 11, a sixth grader from Hartford, may have taken the day's message of outreach a little more to heart than Governor Rowland would appreciate. Apparently mixing up his stocky authority figures, he blurted as the Governor passed by, "It's Bill Clinton!"

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The President's plan on tax credits for the disabled has new ideas but also serious problems.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
President Clinton's proposal to use tax credits to help about two million disabled Americans, many of whom depend on relatives for long-term care, includes some innovative ideas, but it also has some serious problems.
John Rother, public policy director of the American Association of Retired Persons, applauds the program for "providing overdue recognition and support for caregivers." 
 Stuart Altman, a health economist at Brandeis, agrees, praising the White House for "making a real start on a real problem."
But even they recognize the plan's serious limitations. Critics say the proposal skips over most of the poor, provides small financial protection for middle-class families and largely overlooks the potential for private insurance to handle the problem.
Mr. Clinton's advisers fully recognize the problems with their proposal. But they operate under rigid budget rules that make it nearly impossible to solve social problems the old-fashioned way, through Government spending.
Tight caps on discretionary spending for next year leave little room for new programs. Instead, Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution says, "the proposal is testimony to a budgetary staitjacket that forces the Administration to cast social policy as tax cuts -- the only budget idea Congress will take seriously -- even when, as is true in this case, the tax code is poorly designed to deliver the needed relief."
The Administration estimates that five million Americans receive long-term care for a disabling physical or mental ailment. About two million of them live in nursing homes. The rest live in their communities with the help of relatives or other care providers. The cost can be crushing. Nursing homes can charge $60,000 a year or more. If the disabled stay home, then children or spouses are often forced to leave work and suffer the grinding stress of caring for desperately ill loved ones.
There are few sources of financial relief. Medicare provides nearly none, and Medicaid pays for nursing homes but only after patients run through nearly all of their assets. That is not the worst of all possible systems -- it takes care of poor families from the beginning and tells middle-class families that they must spend their own money before calling on taxpayers to pick up the rest of the tab. But the system turns medical catastrophe into financial catastrophe unless the patient can figure out, legally or otherwise, how to transfer assets to family and friends before applying for Medicaid.
One solution is for adults to buy insurance to cover the costs of long-term care. But private insurance barely exists. The problem is that 60-year-olds have no way to know how much protection they are buying when they take out a policy that covers, say, $150 a day -- even if adjusted for inflation -- of nursing home care. That might look good in 1999, but how much care will it buy 10 or 20 years from now?
The Administration's solution is to cut the taxes of chronically disabled patients or their family care providers by up to $1,000. The tax cuts will cost a modest $5.5 billion over five years and will probably be paid for, the Administration says, by closing an unspecified list of tax loopholes. The proposed tax credit is based on the patient's need, not expenditures, so the program does not steer the elderly into nursing homes in order to qualify for reimbursement.
The most interesting part of the plan would have the Federal Government offer long-term care insurance to its employees. The idea is for the Government to create model policies that could then spread through the private economy.
The problem with the plan starts with the tax credit. It only helps families who pay taxes, thereby eliminating the poor. And, Mr. Aaron points out, many elderly fall into the no-tax category because Social Security income is largely untaxed. The Administration hopes it has improved the problem by offering the credit to family care providers, thereby expanding the pool of eligible people. Still, the proposal shuts out many poor families.
The Administration's strategy is to focus on a big expense of middle-class families and tee up a tax cut that Republicans find hard to resist. The White House calculates that tax cuts do a little good and blunt Republican fervor for big across-the-board cuts that would threaten spending on programs dear to Democrats.
The political tactic is understandable but comes at great cost. In the case of long-term care, Mr. Clinton steered clear of readily available and potentially effective solutions. New York and several other states have created, with the help of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, a marvelously designed answer. New Yorkers can buy a state-approved insurance policy, typically costing about $2,000 a year, that reimburses the policyholder for three years of nursing home expenses. If patients who buy the coverage eventually enter and stay in a nursing home for more than three years, then the state Medicaid program pays whatever bills the patient cannot handle based on income. In other words, the state does not invade the patient's savings. The families win protection of their assets. The state wins, too, because few patients actually stay in nursing homes for more than three years.

HEADLINE: Pataki Offers Light Agenda, Setting Aside Budget Surplus

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Treading cautiously as he begins his second term, Gov. George E. Pataki today delivered a State of the State Message notably light on new initiatives, while proposing that the state's budget surplus be set aside to pay for the ballooning tax cuts already enacted.
The Governor's plan to salt away most of a budget surplus that is expected to reach $2 billion is certain to be a flash point in his relations with the Senate and Assembly, because it would deny the Legislature one of its favorite roles, dividing up the spoils of a healthy economy. While legislators might balk at creating a reserve fund, they also realize that Mr. Pataki can achieve the same end by vetoing spending they approve, as he did last year. 
 Mr. Pataki's annual speech to the Legislature, his first major policy address since his re-election two months ago, was heavy on criminal justice proposals: abolishing parole, logging the DNA of all felons into a computer database and increasing penalties for underage offenders.
But he paid little attention to an issue that he had pledged in October to make one of his priorities, reforming the state's campaign finance laws. He had refused before the election to say what those changes might be, and today he devoted only half a sentence in his hourlong speech to the topic, saying that he would like to see the system changed, but not how.
After two years in which conservative groups have accused him of runaway spending, the Republican Governor pledged a return to the budget stringency he brought to Albany four years ago, proposing an amendment to the State Constitution to require a two-thirds vote of both houses of the Legislature to increase taxes. "The act of raising taxes is a destructive act, and should therefore be a difficult act," he said.
He promised that his budget would increase spending at less than the rate of inflation. And he proposed requiring that two-thirds of the voters, rather than the current simple majority, approve local school districts' property tax increases.
"We must take bold steps to insure that this government continues to live within its means," he said in the newly renovated Assembly chamber. "To protect taxpayers now and in the future, we must make lower taxes and fiscal integrity the law of the land in New York State."
But the speech was most striking for what it omitted, as the Governor avoided the most divisive issues facing the state. And for the first time since he took office, he did not use the address to propose tax cuts.
Health care was a major issue in last year's campaigns, and it promises to be one of this year's legislative battlegrounds, with New York facing a rapid rise in the number of uninsured people, the expiration of its law governing hospital charges and growing calls to regulate health maintenance organizations. Yet Mr. Pataki said little about health care.
Nor did he repeat his call for a law guaranteeing women's access to family planning clinics, first made after a Buffalo doctor who performed abortions was murdered. And he did not repeat his frequent call to restrict late-term abortions.
Legislators on both sides of the aisle were in agreement that the speech had almost as much to do with Mr. Pataki's ambitions for national office in 2000 as with New York's concerns. Democrats accused the Governor of showing his most conservative face to appeal to Republican voters in other states.
Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said New Yorkers "don't want to know if in Arizona they're impressed with a two-thirds vote" to raise taxes.
More surprising was the response of Republican legislators, who had unanimously refused to discuss openly the Governor's national prospects when he was running for re-election. Today, the script had obviously changed, as they sought out reporters to crow that Mr. Pataki had demonstrated his presidential bona fides.
"It was an eminently presidential speech," said Senator Roy M. Goodman, a Manhattan Republican. "It touched on a number of areas which make New York a national model."
Nearly all the Governor's proposals seemed aimed for rocky shoals. The Democrats who control the Assembly objected to nearly all of his criminal justice plans and said his budgeting notions would hinder their plans to spend money on schools.
The Republican leaders of the Senate objected that Mr. Pataki's plan to save the surplus would stand in the way of lower taxes. "We see it as a pot for tax cuts," said Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader.
The icy relations Mr. Pataki has with the Democrats were amply on display today. His speech drew lusty applause and cheers from the south side of the Assembly chamber, where the Republicans were seated, while the Democrats made barely enough noise to scare off a flock of birds. They later criticized the address as shallow. "It was a speech for speech sake," Mr. Silver said.
The Governor spent far more time dwelling on the accomplishments of his first term, particularly the deep tax cuts, than laying out a vision for the second. And he continued to slay the dragons of 1994, when he was first elected. "In New York," he said, "government had become that uninvited dinner guest, who arrived too early, ate too much and stayed too long." Later, he referred to the bad old days before his ascension, when "New York was leading the nation in violent crime."
Mr. Pataki revived a number of proposals he has made in the past, including tougher penalties for juvenile criminals, a law against hate crimes, eliminating tenure for school principals, giving teachers the right to expel chronic trouble-makers from their classrooms, and sending immigrant children to summer school to learn English.
Among the new ideas in the speech was one long advocated by environmentalists: expansion of the state's Superfund program for cleaning up toxic waste sites to include hundreds of less severely polluted tracts.
He also called for the creation of a biotechnology research center in Buffalo, to be run by the State University of New York and the Roswell Park Cancer Institute.
The Governor's only proposals on health care were to have schools take a greater role in caring for children with diabetes, and a pilot project for more aggressive treatment of childhood asthma.
The plan to save this year's surplus for future use was a nod to the independent fiscal monitors who warn that the state will have trouble paying for the tax cuts it has already enacted, but which have not yet come due -- more than $4 billion a year. The tax cuts, including reductions in property and business taxes, and ending the sales tax on clothing, are being phased in over five years.
Enacting a requirement for a two-thirds vote to raise taxes is an even taller order. To change the State Constitution, both houses of the Legislature would have to approve the amendment, in two consecutive two-year sessions, and then it would have to be approved by the voters. Today, many Democrats in the Assembly were declaring the idea dead on arrival.
"What he's trying to do is limit the ability to legislate," said Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Manhattan Democrat who chairs the Ways and Means Committee. "I'm opposed to that."
The Democrats were also lukewarm to the Governor's ideas on crime. Mr. Silver said he would not object to expanding the DNA database -- which now collects samples from people convicted of certain violent felonies -- but saw no reason to include, for instance, tax evaders.
And the Democrats were especially wary about the proposal to end parole, saying they could not react until they saw detailed legislation. In general, the proposal would end the longstanding practice of sentencing criminals to a range of time in prison, with the possibility of early release by the Parole Board, and replace that with specific sentences.

Following are proposals made by Gov. George E. Pataki in his State of the State Message:
 
TAXES -- A reserve fund to assure that the state will deliver on tax reductions that have been enacted.
 
An amendment to the State Constitution that would require a two-thirds vote of the Legislature to increase any state tax.
 
EDUCATION -- Creation of a state task force on school violence, led by Lieut. Gov. Mary O. Donohue.
 
ENVIRONMENT -- Replenishment of the state's environmental Superfund.
 
CRIME -- A requirement that judges impose definite sentences, making New York one of nearly two dozen states to have effectively eliminated parole for felons.
 
A requirement that felons submit a DNA sample to a state database.
 
JOBS -- Creation of a biotechnology research center at the State University of New York at Buffalo.
 
Tax incentives for businesses that choose to settle in state-designated job development sites. (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow and the Other Leading Gauges Advance to Highs

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices rocketed to new heights yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average breaking the 9,500 mark as it climbed 233.78 points, the biggest gain since Oct. 15, to pass its previous record set just before Thanksgiving.
The blue-chip gauge joined the Standard & Poor's 500-stock and Nasdaq composite indexes in uncharted territory as investors threw bonuses, dividends, holiday gifts and retirement and reinvestment money into the market at the beginning of the new year. 
 Overseas markets also powered ahead, with gains in Europe, the Far East and Brazil mostly equaling the American performance. Mexico, however, fell slightly.
"This new-year rally has got real legs," said David G. Dietze, president of Point View Financial Services in Summit, N. J. "Instead of just big-cap and tech stocks doing well, the sectors broadened out to include financials, energy and some deep cyclicals."
The Dow, which rose 2.51 percent, to 9,544.97, was paced by American Express, up 4 5/16, to 103 5/8, and J. P. Morgan, up 3 7/8, to 111 1/4. But four other components surged more than 3 points, six rose 2 or more and only I.B.M., off 7/8, at 188 3/4, was lower.
Even steel stocks, which by some measures are at their lowest point in a generation, caught fire yesterday after an analyst at Merrill Lynch raised his ratings and price targets for various companies. USX-U.S. Steel jumped 2 15/16, to 27 7/16, and Bethlehem Steel added 1 5/16, to 10 9/16.
Dollar Tree Stores, which paced the retail group, soared 5 5/16, to 48 1/2, after the discounter reported a big gain in sales.
Among the stocks benefiting from the settlement of the National Basketball Association labor dispute, which will salvage more than half the season, were Boston Celtics, up 4 1/8, to 14 5/8, and Nike, up 2 15/16, to 43 5/8.
Trading was heavy as the market started strong and worked steadily higher until just after 3 P.M., when it reached a Dow peak of 9,608.05 before plateauing to the close.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 986.9 million shares, the fifth-busiest day on record, while 1.2 billion shares changed hands on Nasdaq, the most in a month.
Advancing issues on the Big Board, whose own composite index also set a record at 611.01, outnumbered declining issues by 2,009 to 1,120, with 154 stocks making new highs and 15 new lows.
The gain for the S.& P. 500 was 27.56 points, to a new high of 1,272.34, or 2.21 percent, somewhat less than the blue-chip Dow industrials. But the Nasdaq gain was 69.59, to a new high of 2,320.86, or 3.09 percent. Microsoft, up 4 3/4, to 151 1/4, and Intel, up 6 1/4, to 129 1/2, contributed to the jump, but Yahoo, up 33 1/8, to 291, and Amazon.com, up 13 1/2, to 138, had the more eye-popping moves.
Airlines also saw prominent gains as Delta Air Lines climbed 5, to 59 1/2; UAL rose 4 3/8, to 68, and AMR added 3 13/16, to 67 7/8. Brokers also thrived, the biggest gains being 4 7/16, to 53 5/8, for Lehman Brothers; 4 5/8, to 58 7/8, for Charles Schwab, and 4 9/16, to 41 15/16, for Paine Webber.
Gains in leading foreign markets amounted to 3.41 percent in Frankfurt, 3.20 percent in London, 2.24 percent in Paris, 3.09 percent in Sao Paulo, 3.47 percent in Hong Kong and 1.78 percent in Tokyo.

Bond Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Bonds rose for the first time in four sessions yesterday as the highest yields in six weeks and a rally in the dollar lured investors to Treasuries.
After bonds slumped in recent days, "yields became attractive," said Alan Day, who helps oversee almost $4 billion at Stratevest Group in Burlington, Vt. "They're a better deal right now."
The 30-year bond rose 22/32, to 101 12/32, pushing yields down 4 basis points to 5.16 percent. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
Bonds also derived strength from a gain in the value of the dollar, which enhanced the appeal of dollar-denominated investments to foreign investors who must convert their proceeds to other currencies. Treasuries "are following the dollar," said John Burgess, who oversees about $90 billion at Bankers Trust.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction yesterday of 10-year inflation-indexed notes:

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: THE PLAYERS;
Return to Work Prompts General Feeling of Relief

BYLINE: By JUDY BATTISTA 

 BODY:
For Jalen Rose of the Indiana Pacers, there were no high-fives in the elevators or chest-thumps in the lobby of the GM Building as scores of National Basketball Association players, grimaces chiseled on their faces, made their way from yesterday's meeting to ratify the new collective bargaining agreement.
"I'm upset," Rose said. "I just spent $2,000 on a plane ticket, and I'm getting dressed and I hear they got a deal done and I'm like, 'Why did I come?' " 
 The emotions that dominate so many games were nowhere to be found as players -- who had traveled to New York expecting to vote on whether they supported the union's negotiating committee -- instead learned that a deal had been struck early yesterday morning, ending the 191-day dispute. Many left the building with little or no comment, wending through a horde of autograph seekers.
Most players were more relieved -- and resigned -- than angry.
"I'm glad they came to an agreement," the San Antonio Spurs' David Robinson said after the players' two-hour meeting. "The whole issue is, we were going to take a pay cut no matter what. We knew we were going to go backward. Most guys understand this is business, not personal.
"We don't have anything against David Stern," Robinson added, referring to the N.B.A. commissioner. "He's obviously done a great job building up this league. The players have done a great job building up this league. And it's now time for us to get back together and re-establish some confidence with the fans.
"This thing was really ugly; not just ugly for us, but for fans, for the people who work at arenas, for all the people who love the N.B.A. It's time for us to show them how much we do care about playing this game."
But it was obvious that the tension that had permeated the lockout lingered at the meeting. In the days leading to the tentative settlement, an increasing number of players had expressed discontent with the negotiations. Terry Cummings of the Knicks said that players, many of whom he thought were ill informed about the negotiations, would have been divided if the vote to endorse the negotiating committee's actions had been taken.
"We weren't that far apart, and every time we got off the issues, we got more involved in ego and pride, and that was hindering the process," Cummings said. "The fans deserve better. The game is more important than the players and the owners. The owners pay the players to play the game, and the fans pay the salaries for players to play.
"We have to understand the economics of the game. We can't afford to let something like this happen to our game. Our game is not as old as baseball, and we can't afford a lapse like baseball had. We have to be more concerned about the overall perception of ourselves and our game."
The Nets' Jayson Williams had been one of the most outspoken critics of the way negotiations had progressed, and had repeatedly suggested that an arbitrator be brought in to expedite a settlement. Last week, the Knicks' Patrick Ewing, the union president, criticized Williams for making his complaints public. In yesterday's meeting, Williams -- who had not attended earlier gatherings -- came face to face with Ewing, an encounter Williams said was intense.
"I'm not taking credit for this thing," Williams said when asked if he thought his comments had led the union to make a deal. "Give it to the guys on the executive board. I just did what I had to do to get them to play basketball. I wasn't going against the union. I'm 100 percent union the whole time. I'm proud of David Stern and I'm proud of Patrick Ewing. They'll probably hate me for the next two or three weeks, but I'll make them love me again."
If Williams was in his usual mood to joke, few others were.
"It was scary," the Boston Celtics' Kenny Anderson said. "The last two nights I couldn't sleep."
Even Charles Barkley, who is never at a loss for a quip, seemed somber as he made his way to the meeting.
"It's fair enough and we have to accept it," said Barkley, a free agent. "We couldn't cancel the season. Obviously, there's been some damage done to the game. Both owners and players have done a disservice to the game. Some of the fans are going to be mad. But you can't worry about that. I'd say to the fans: 'If you want to come to the game, come. If you don't, we still have to do our jobs.' "
And in the end, it seemed, players were grateful that at least they had a job for the next few months. The Toronto Raptors' Kevin Willis, who had been critical of the union recently, said he expected the animosity that had driven this lockout to end.
"My thing is to start playing basketball again," Willis said. "Forget about the nonsense, the greed, and seeing how much money you can get. If we can split the money, so be it. Anything else is absolutely ridiculous."

HEADLINE: A Pataki Reprise

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Rather than seeing his convincing re-election victory as a mandate for daring new initiatives, Gov. George E. Pataki seemed determined today to give New Yorkers more of what so many of them liked the first time around.
He could have used his annual address to the Legislature to try and set his second term apart from his first. He could have made bold promises and electric commitments. But the Governor instead hewed to his longstanding priorities: curbing state spending, cutting taxes and toughening the criminal justice system. 
 "We've laid a solid foundation on which to build," he said in a speech so narrowly focused that it at times sounded repetitious.
His stance had some of the Capitol cognoscenti griping about an uninspiring performance and neglected opportunities. But Mr. Pataki believes that with a disciplined agenda, he will preserve the successes of his first term, allowing him to cement his legacy in New York and giving him a platform to broaden his reputation nationally, his advisers say.
In a sense, the speech showed how much he has staked his political future on a handful of landmark changes that he has wrought in New York as the first Republican governor in a generation. It suggested that Mr. Pataki feels that if these policies are imperiled, then so is he.
"In four years, we have cut taxes and created a stronger economy by suppressing government's built-in tendency to grow and spend," he said, calling for a "continued commitment to fiscal prudence."
The Governor, an erstwhile legislator who fancies himself a student of Albany, recognizes that successes here can be short-lived. Democratic lawmakers tried to block most of his first-term accomplishments, particularly his effort to impose more fiscal restraint. They largely failed, but would no doubt like to scale back some of Governor's big-ticket items, like a big income tax cut and stiffer criminal sentences. Even Republicans in the Legislature have not always been the Governor's most reliable backers.
Mr. Pataki's two centerpiece fiscal proposals today -- to squirrel away the state's surplus of about $2 billion, and to require a two-thirds majority of the Legislature to approve tax increases -- seem intended to thwart any legislative attempt to undermine his fiscal record.
If the state spent the surplus, and then the economy slumped, the Governor might have to choose between steep, unpopular spending cuts or repealing his beloved tax cuts -- a damaging fate that befell his predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo.
Maintaining his fiscal record, and therefore succeeding with his new proposals, could have an important impact on the Governor's future; if he decides to run for national office in 2000, his handling of the state budget would be important evidence of his Republican bona fides.
"There has been a succession of initiatives that he can dutifully herald," said Senator Stephen M. Saland, a Poughkeepsie Republican, who, like many of the Governor's allies, was eager to talk about Mr. Pataki's future outside of the state. "Certainly, I believe that he was talking to a national audience."
The Governor is expected to use these achievements to try to fend off attacks from more conservative national Republicans over his support for abortion rights and other moderate positions on social issues. Mr. Pataki's advisers contend that the way to succeed nationally is to get across the message that the party will flourish by concentrating on such fundamental issues as as tax cuts or welfare -- and avoiding contentious social matters.
And who better to lead that charge than Mr. Pataki, who tamed the liberal Empire State?
Some of the advisers also think that it would be foolish to interpret the Governor's landslide in November as a signal that the public wants him to venture into new areas. People voted for Mr. Pataki, these advisers contend, because they are pleased with his record on crime, welfare and taxes, and to divert from this path will only disappoint them.
The risk is that New Yorkers will chafe at the Governor's reluctance to take on other issues, and some Democrats today repeatedly brought up matters that they thought he had ignored in his speech. Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried of Manhattan, chairman of the Assembly Health Committee, reeled off a list of major health-care matters that Mr. Pataki did not mention, from the problem of people without health insurance to regulation of H.M.O.'s.
"If you listened to his speech, you would think that the issues didn't exist, let alone any plan to solve them," Mr. Gottfried said.
Of course, Mr. Pataki will tackle many matters in the coming months that he did not discuss today. Governors typically use their addresses to the Legislature to establish themes for their dealings with lawmakers, not to present lists of proposals.
Even so, Democrats criticized the Governor's vision. "He missed a golden opportunity to reach out and talk about areas that need job development in the city of New York and which really did not support him last time," said Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic leader.
But by doing it his way, Mr. Pataki sought to insure that the battle between lawmakers and the Governor -- an annual inevitable event -- would be fought on his terms, not theirs.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
PHILLIPS PETROLEUM TOCUT 1,400 JOBS FOR COST SAVINGS

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
In the latest sign of trouble in the oil industry, the Phillips Petroleum Company is cutting 1,400 jobs worldwide to save money in the face of low oil and chemical prices. Most of the eliminated jobs will be in exploration and production. Phillips, which employs 17,200 workers worldwide, plans to eliminate 550 jobs from its foreign operations and 850 positions in the United States. About 400 jobs are to be cut at its headquarters in Bartlesville, Okla. W. Wayne Allen, chairman and chief executive, said the plans were expected to produce annual cost savings of about $230 million. Shares of Phillips rose $1.1875, to $43.8125.

 BODY:

Cone Mills also said earnings for the fourth quarter of 1998 would be lower than analysts' expectations as a result of the cutbacks along with reduced shipments of denim and yarn-dyed sportswear fabrics. The company's shares fell 56.25 cents, to $4.875.

HEADLINE: A Diplomatic Look Back at a Met Career

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
In more than a dozen years as president and chief executive of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, William H. Luers never really spoke out about the nation's biggest art museum or his tenure there. That was the deal he cut with the museum's director, Philippe de Montebello.
Mr. de Montebello, though technically his subordinate, rules over the Met's art, and has always aspired to hold both jobs one day, as most museum directors do. "We agreed it was essential that he be the voice of the museum," Mr. Luers said. 
On Jan. 31, Mr. Luers, a tall, tweedy former career diplomat, will be handing over the chief executive's post to Mr. de Montebello. On a recent day, sitting at the big round table in his office, he offered his thoughts as he prepared to depart for his new job as chairman and president of the United Nations Association of the U.S.A.
In a wide-ranging interview, Mr. Luers took credit for professionalizing the Met's staff and for being -- if not the public "voice" -- at least "Mr. Outside" to city and state administrators. He predicted that the museum would grow in importance if it tapped into new media like the Internet. And he recalled his fondest moment as the day that Met officials, courting Walter H. Annenberg, showed him a model of the galleries they had designed in hopes of gaining his huge trove of Impressionist paintings. By the look in Mr. Annenberg's eyes, Mr. Luers knew the museum had clinched his bequest of the works.
Mr. Luers said that the Met was bursting at its seams and working hard to expand bathrooms and other amenities for crowds that often reach 30,000 to 40,000 on Saturdays and Sundays. "Whether there's an outside limit that says on a Sunday you can take only 50,000, I don't know," he said.
Ever the diplomat, Mr. Luers said his sharing of power with Mr. de Montebello, however strained their relationship sometimes was, served its purpose. "I think it worked because the trustees wanted it to work," he said. Mr. Luers had only a mild warning for Mr. de Montebello, who is assuming the chief executive's post as well as remaining director, a job he has held for 21 years. "There are a lot of very complicated management issues," Mr. Luers said. "And he has 18 curatorial departments. It just places a tremendous strain on the director. But I think he will be fine."
Putting his best spin on their relationship, Mr. Luers said, "Inevitably, we had moments of disagreement because of our positions." He declined to discuss specifics but characterized them as things like the pace of upgrading administrative systems and computerization.
"But we worked it out, and I think he's comfortable with the pace now and he's behind it," Mr. Luers said. "There have also been some disagreements about individual people who would be hired. But these were momentary differences."
On some occasions, he said, when the two disagreed, they relied on other executives at museum."When they saw us talk about an issue, they made sure we faced issues together," he said.
Mr. de Montebello, noting that "identical twins and married couples have moments of disagreement, too," also played down their differences. "We have become a very large museum with a big budget, and he has put a structure in place and a staff and an overall administrative complex that runs very smoothly," Mr. de Montebello said.
The Met has a $116.5 million annual budget and 1,800 full-time employees.
Mr. Luers had agreed to retire when he turned 70 this year, on May 15. He accelerated his departure after he was asked o to lead the United Nations Association, which does research and organizes chapters of United Nations supporters.
Museum trustees and other Met-watchers agree with Mr. Luers's assessment of his contributions and add another: his nonstop entertaining of donors, potential donors, well-placed politicians and other powers that might be able to help the Met. Much of that took place at the Met-owned apartment he occupies with his wife, Wendy.
"He's indefatigable," said Carl Spielvogel, a trustee. "I don't know many people willing to be out at breakfast, lunch and dinner seven days a week, but he was. And he was very good at it."
No one expects Mr. de Montebello, who is far less outgoing, to pick up that particular mantle (although Mr. Spielvogel, who used to head the museum's business committee, said, "Philippe said to me at one point, 'Carl, any place you want me to go to raise money, I will go.' "). Rather, many Met social activities are likely to revert to its development office, headed by Emily K. Rafferty.
The Met is now returning to a management structure employed by most museums. "The flaw in splitting the job is that nothing is clearly an artistic decision -- it's always a combination of artistic and economic issues," said Richard E. Oldenburg, a former Museum of Modern Art director who is now chairman of Sotheby's North America.
In leaving, Mr. Luers will have to give up that fancy apartment, but he said he would most miss working at the Met and being able to roam the galleries when they are closed to the public. "There's nothing like this place," he said.
Mr. Luers said he had come to the job with a longstanding love particularly of the Old Masters and 19th- century European art. He leaves with broader taste, especially a new appreciation for ancient art.
"Every exhibition here opened my eyes to ancient civilizations," he said. "There are commmon fundamental ideas, and the one thing I've thought of is that I would create a curator of the whole, a department of curators who would spend their time relating the collections to each other. It is fascinating to me how much we can learn from juxtapositions of the way different civilizations have dealt with the same subjects."
On Tuesday, the Met will hold a dinner honoring Mr. Luers, along with Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the museum's outgoing board chairman and the chairman emeritus of The New York Times Company; James R. Houghton, the incoming chairman, and David E. McKinney, a former I.B.M. executive who is becoming the chief operating officer, with the title of president, reporting to Mr. de Montebello.
In his new position at the United Nations organization beginning on Feb. 1, Mr. Luers returns to his first love, international affairs. It seems revealing that in a recent speech at Hamilton College, his alma mater, he cited as the highlights of his Met career the visits of Vaclav Havel, Andrei K. Sakharov and the Emperor and Empress of Japan.
Showing a trace of emotion in his voice and invoking a custom of the Foreign Service, Mr. Luers said he would return to the Met often to see its displays, but not to attend its parties. "You don't return," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 8, 1999, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about William H. Luers, the departing president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misstated the relationship between his position and that of Philippe de Montebello, the museum's director. The two have been equal, both reporting to the chairman; the director is not subordinate to the president. As the article noted, Mr. de Montebello will assume the additional title of chief executive on Jan. 31.

HEADLINE: Auto Industry Finds Surprises At the End of a Rainbow Year

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Last month was the best for auto sales since December 1986, lifting the industry's sales for 1998 to the highest level in a dozen years despite a nearly eight-week strike last summer from which the General Motors Corporation has not fully recovered.
With the last auto makers reporting their results today, the industry's sales in the United States rose 7.1 percent last month from December 1997. For the year, a total of 15.55 million cars, sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and vans were sold, a 2.8 percent increase from 1997. 
 In 1986, sales soared when the impending expiration of certain tax provisions for auto loans produced a race to dealerships late in the year. By contrast, auto executives at the North American International Auto Show here today offered several reasons for the sales surge last month, which followed brisk sales throughout the autumn. The explanations included the popularity of sport utility vehicles and other light trucks, for which sales rose 10.5 percent last month, as well as high consumer confidence, rising disposable incomes and car prices flat or edging down.
But even while citing these factors, executives seemed a little surprised by how vigorous their business has been. "The market is stronger out there than anyone anticipated," said Robert J. Eaton, co-chairman of DaimlerChrysler A.G., adding that the company might raise its forecast of industry sales this year, from 15.2 million vehicles.
While DaimlerChrysler, the Ford Motor Company, Toyota, Honda and even struggling Nissan all posted big gains last month, G.M. reported a gain of only 3.1 percent as its market share fell to 30.2 percent from 31.3 percent a year earlier. G.M. sales for the entire year tumbled 3.3 percent.
Top G.M. executives at the auto show acknowledged that the company, the world's largest auto maker, had not recovered from the strike, which cost it close to $12 billion in lost production. During the strike the company took a hard line that was based partly on an assessment that sales could not maintain the brisk pace of last spring. The continued strength of sales has left the company's factories unable to catch up.
"We're still short of product, there's no doubt about that, but that gap is beginning to close," said John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive. Roy Roberts, the group vice president for North American sales and marketing, said that G.M. dealerships now have 84 percent of their optimal inventories, barely up from 81 percent at the start of December.
A few pockets of strength showed in G.M.'s figures today. The company's GMC division, which sells premium light trucks such as the GMC Yukon full-size sport utility vehicle, posted a sixth consecutive year of record sales last year as the industry's overall sales of light trucks rose 8.1 percent and car sales fell 1.6 percent.
G.M.'s Saturn division, which plans to introduce a midsize car next summer but remains stuck in the shrinking market for small cars, managed to eke out a surprising 6.4 percent increase. Mark Hogan, the company's vice president for small cars, said the division's showrooms had been busier since Thanksgiving, when it introduced a car that looks like a traditional two-door vehicle but has a small third door that folds open on the driver's side to make it easier to load groceries or briefcases into the back seat.
Mr. Hogan warned that the severe weather of the last week, particularly in the Midwest, might reduce the number of people visiting dealerships. But Mr. Eaton predicted that the robust sales in November and December would spill over into January. Industry sales in December were calculated at a torrid seasonally adjusted annual rate of 17.3 million vehicles, according to Ward's Auto Info Bank, a data service.
Ford reported on Tuesday that its sales climbed last month by 1.2 percent, as a 6.4 percent gain in light- truck sales more than offset a 4.3 percent drop in car sales.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1416 words

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: THE SETTLEMENT;
With Little Time on Clock, N.B.A. and Players Settle

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE

 BODY:
National Basketball Association players and owners brought an end to the most calamitous and costly labor dispute in league history yesterday, agreeing to an 11th-hour deal that saved the season only a day before the owners were to vote on canceling it.
Negotiating for 12 hours and trading concessions until 6 A.M. yesterday at the league offices in Manhattan, Commissioner David Stern and Billy Hunter, the union's executive director, worked out a new collective bargaining agreement that ended the six-monthlong impasse. 
 An abbreviated regular season of about 50 games -- there are 82 games in a full season -- was expected to begin in early February, with a full complement of playoffs beginning in early May. The regular season could be extended by one to two weeks, but the playoffs were not expected to last into July and would certainly end before July 4.
The lockout by the owners will not officially end until after the deal is made final by lawyers for both sides and then signed. Training camps and the signing of 200 free agents would then begin, probably around Jan. 18. The games lost this season translate into total player salary losses of about $400 million; leaguewide revenue losses also ran into the hundreds of millions of dollars.
The crux of the disagreement for the past six months has been how to divide the $2 billion in annual revenue that the league generates. Although both sides made some concessions at the end, the league achieved its main goal of containing the contracts of high-salaried players, and received some unprecedented concessions from the union.
It insisted on and received a maximum salary provision, and no other professional sport has a limit on individual salaries.
It also eliminated some of the crippling loopholes to its salary cap that had sent salaries skyrocketing in the last five years.
In the end, the union was left to try to hold onto some of the terms that had provided its players the highest average salary in pro sports, $2.6 million. It also achieved its stated priority of significantly bettering the economic position of its players with mid-level salaries, those making around the median salary of $1.3 million.
The crucial round of discussions began early Tuesday evening and continued through the night at the league offices on Fifth Ave. As they negotiated through the night, snacking on pizza and chocolate, the two sides hammered out the details of an agreement that kept the N.B.A. from becoming the first professional sports league to lose a full season to a labor dispute. Page D4.
The union will receive 55 percent of total revenue toward salaries in the last three years of the deal. That was less than the players had hoped for, and the feeling among many of them was that they had given in to many of the league's demands at the last moment.
Still, it was better than the prospect of no season and many more millions of dollars in lost paychecks. Given that the N.B.A. came perilously close to becoming the first major sports league to lose an entire season to labor strife, many players considered yesterday morning's surprise announcement fortunate.
"I got a call at 6 A.M. in my hotel room this morning and I couldn't believe it," said the free-agent center, Joe Kleine. "We will finally play again. Now we have a bigger job ahead of us: getting our fans back."
Kleine was one of the 184 players who came to Manhattan yesterday for a vote called by the union's negotiating committee. On Monday, Stern had rejected the union's final proposal, and Hunter, succumbing to internal and external pressure to hold a vote on the owners' offer, summoned the players to Manhattan.
Though he said he still considered the owners' offer inadequate, Hunter said he would put the issue before the general membership. It was a risky move that may have led to uneasiness in the union. There was already talk of mounting displeasure among the players, and the fear that a bitter debate among players could further divide the union.
But what was supposed to result in a tense and potentially divisive debate on the union's position instead turned into scenes of relief in and around the GM Building on Fifth Avenue, where the players had gathered at the offices of the union's law firm. Hundreds of reporters and fans mingled inside and outside the buildings, fighting to talk to the players as they exited the building after voting, 179-5, for the deal.
"This is crazy," said Steve Kerr, the Chicago Bulls guard. "I never expected this. Of course, at times I never expected a season, either."
The decisive talks began on Tuesday night after Hunter asked one of the union's outside counsels, Jim Quinn, to go over to the league's offices at 6 P.M. to meet with the deputy commissioner, Russ Granik, and present several concessions to the league.
Quinn and Granik were eventually joined by Stern, Hunter and several other members of the bargaining teams. Negotiating secretly in a conference room at the league's Olympic Tower offices on Fifth Avenue, the two sides gave each other a list of their desires. When they came across a disagreement, Hunter said, they moved on.
In the end, the owners were given the unprecedented concession of a maximum limit on individual salaries. No player with 10 years or more experience can make more than $14 million in the first year of his contract. The figure falls to $11 million for players with less than 10 years experience and $9 million to players with less than six years experience. Gone is the potential for a record $126 million deal over seven years, like the one signed by Minnesota's Kevin Garnett in October 1997.
Under terms of the new agreement, however, a grandfather clause allows any player to re-sign with his team for 105 percent of his previous salary. Michael Jordan, who made more than $33 million last year, could secure a pro-rated deal of $34.7 million from the Chicago Bulls. But he could not make more than $14 million from any other team.
The deal was drawn up for six seasons, with a league option for a seventh year.
Though the union had wanted 56 or 57 percent of revenues to go toward salaries in years four, five and six of the contract, the league held fast at 55 percent. Players would receive 57 percent if the league exercises its option. In the first three years, there is no limit on the percentage of revenues players can receive.
The two sides also stiffened the drug agreement and the player-conduct rules, agreeing to a ban on marijuana. All players will undergo drug testing once per season.
*The union also agreed to a three-year rookie scale with teams holding an option for the fourth year and the right of first refusal in the fifth year. Previously, players became free agents after their third year, but the league pushed for five years, because it was concerned over widespread movement by young players that made it virtually impossible for teams to keep their rosters intact.
*The league accepted the union's proposal for an "average" salary exception and "median" salary exception, with both being phased in during the next three years. As a result, every team will have the right to sign two additional players each season, even if it is over the salary cap.
"Did we blink?" Hunter said. "I guess we both blinked."
With the deal to be made final in less than two weeks and the lockout officially lifted, a flurry of activity is expected as teams make harried attempts to fill rosters while holding training camps. The task will be daunting, but not nearly as arduous as saving the season.
And the damage of this labor dispute could linger. Aside from division among players, the sport will have to recapture a public that polls said was increasingly apathetic about the absence of the game. Major League Baseball suffered a drop in attendance and some resentment from fans following a strike in 1994, and it wasn't until this past season -- with a dramatic home run race and a record-breaking season by the Yankees -- that the sport had fully recovered.
"It's about time," said the Knicks' Terry Cummings. "The fans deserve better. The game is more important than players and owners. Owners pay players to play game, fans pay the salaries for players to play. We can't afford to let something like this happen to our game. Our game is not as old as baseball, and we cant' afford a lapse like baseball did. We have to be concerned about the overall perception of ourselves and our game."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marty Anderson was a happy man yesterday. He had been living on this billboard in Portland, Ore., for 65 days in support of ending the lockout. (Associated Press)(pg. D2)
 
Chart: "The Deal"
The N.B.A. owners and players have agreed o terms to end the six-month locout. Exact details of the revamped season are still being worked out.
THE NEW SEASON
GAMES PER TEAM - About 50
SEASON STARTS - Early Feb.
SEASON ENDS - Late April
PLAYOFFS END - Before July 4
 
LENGTH OF CONTRACT
Six years, with the owners having an option for the seventh.
MAXIMUM SALARY
Ranging from $9 million for players with 1 to 6 years' experience to $14 million for veterans with 10 years of experience. No other sport has a cap on individual salaries.
PERCENTAGE OF REVENUE
The players will receive 55 percent of revenues toward their salries in years 4, 5 and 6 of the contract. There is no fixed percentage for years 1 through 3.
SALARY INCREASES
The maximum salary increase will be 10 percent. Free agents who re-sign with their own team can receive up to 12 percent.
SALARY-CAP EXCEPTIONS
The union wanted, and was granted, the right for each team to exceed its salary cap to sign two players each season with mid-level salaries.
WILL HE BE BACK?
Michael Jordan's agent said Jordan would review the deal, then make a decision.

PUB-DATE: January 8, 1999

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 22; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 3302 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 6.
 
Now Playing
 
 * "AFFLICTION," starring Nick Nolte, James Coburn, Willem Dafoe, Sissy Spacek and Mary Beth Hurt. Directed by Paul Schrader (R, 114 minutes). Mr. Nolte is devastating in the performance of his career, as Wade Whitehouse, a New Hampshire loner fighting a losing battle with demons from his past. Foremost among them: Mr. Coburn, terrifyingly authentic as the drunken, abusive father who long ago cowed his sons into submission. As directed by Mr. Schrader, this pure, unfettered adaptation of Russell Banks's novel starts on a deceptively ordinary note, then escalates into inexorable fury. Every little detail matters. Ms. Spacek and Ms. Hurt expertly play the women who trigger Wade's crisis (Janet Maslin).
 
 * "A BUG'S LIFE," featuring the voices of Dave Foley, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Kevin Spacey. Directed by John Lasseter and Andrew Stanton (G, 94 minutes). The best animated ant-colony movie of the year. And this is a more clearly defined family film than the verbally adult "Antz." With the same anthropomorphism that gave Mr. Lasseter's "Toy Story" so much spark, this pastel-hued, visually ingenious feat of animation tells a tale of ant courage while incorporating lively wit and an enchanting sense of nature. And it's a showcase for the incredible range of facial expressions that make this type of animation more and more invitingly lifelike all the time (Maslin).
 
 * "CENTRAL STATION," starring Fernanda Montenegro, Vinicius de Oliveira and Marilia Pera. Directed by Walter Salles (R, 115 minutes). In this quiet, luminous Brazilian gem, a joyless older woman crosses paths with an orphaned young boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling. As these characters develop a fractious bond, then embark on a road trip that takes them vividly to Brazil's hinterlands in search of the boy's father, Mr. Salles brings great tenderness and surprise to the events that punctuate their journey. Ms. Montenegro's tough bravura performance was one of 1998's very best (Maslin).
 
 * "A CIVIL ACTION," starring John Travolta, Robert Duvall and William H. Macy. Directed by Steven Zaillian (PG-13, 120 minutes). This story of a David-Goliath lawsuit against industrial polluters, with Mr. Travolta first rate as an ambulance chaser who develops a conscience, could have been business as usual in the legal thriller genre. But Mr. Zaillian's keenly observed, beautifully acted film, based on Jonathan Harr's nonfiction best seller about a case in Woburn, Mass., doesn't follow familiar formulas. It follows all the surprises and frustrations of a story that was never black and white, and is all the better for its shades of gray. Mr. Duvall is outstanding as a corporate lawyer full of wily tricks (Maslin).
 
 "ELIZABETH," starring Cate Blanchett, Joseph Fiennes, Geoffrey Rush and Christopher Eccleston. Directed by Shekhar Kapur (R, 124 minutes). In this lurid costume drama depicting Elizabeth I as a royal rookie, the impressive Ms. Blanchett plays the Queen as if her principal responsibilities were being bejeweled, selecting consorts and saying "Leave us!" with a wave of the hand. For all its putative concern with Roman Catholic-Protestant strife at the start of Elizabeth's reign, this is historical drama for those whose idea of history is back issues of Vogue. Intent on spectacle, complete with burning at the stake and one dance scene reminiscent of "Saturday Night Fever," it winds up imagining the Queen as a glamorously stressed-out modern woman afflicted by a super-intense case of having it all (Maslin).
 
 "THE FACULTY," starring Jordana Brewster, Clea DuVall, Laura Harris and Josh Hartnett. Directed by Robert Rodriguez (R, 111 minutes). Like Frankenstein, "The Faculty" plunders the crypts of cinema for its body parts. Here are the paranoia and parasitism of "Invasion of the Body Snatchers." There are the slimy, sharp-toothed creatures of "Alien." And over there are the movie-wise teen-agers of "Scream." The list could be extended, but the point is clear: This mediocre sci-fi horror film about an Ohio high school being taken over by thirsty space aliens intent on world domination breaks no new ground. But the movie, written by Kevin Williamson, has an engaging cast, with half a dozen appealing young actors playing the roles of teen-agers who are all that stand between the Midwestern monsters and the end of the world as certain moviegoers know it (Lawrence Van Gelder).
 
 * "THE GENERAL," starring Brendan Gleeson and Jon Voight. Directed by John Boorman (not rated, 125 minutes). Mr. Boorman's best and most stylish film in years is the deftly told story of Martin Cahill. Nicknamed "the General" for his crime-plotting strategies, this Irish gang leader and master thief is played with splendid brio by Mr. Gleeson. Photographed gorgeously in black and white, the film tells of his elaborate art and jewel heists, his unusual domestic arrangement with his wife's sister and his singular difficulties with the I.R.A. and the law. Mr. Voight is outstandingly good as the police detective who knows all of Cahill's tricks (Maslin).
 
 * "GODS AND MONSTERS," starring Ian McKellen and Brendan Fraser. Directed by Bill Condon (not rated, 105 minutes). In a performance that well deserves to be remembered at Academy Award time, Mr. McKellen becomes the deliciously urbane James Whale, depicting the gay "Frankenstein" director late in life. Shaken by the aftereffects of a mild stroke, this Whale finds his past coming back to greet him just as the present offers new fascination in the Adonis-like form of the gardener (Mr. Fraser, also fine), whom Whale finds mowing his lawn. This beautifully acted, witty and heart-tugging film, from a Christopher Bram book, imagines what Whale's final days might have been like while shaping a splendid character study and a droll portrait of closeted gay Hollywood. Lynn Redgrave provides ballast and comic relief as Whale's perpetually scandalized housekeeper (Maslin).
 
 * "HILARY AND JACKIE," starring Emily Watson and Rachel Griffiths. Directed by Anand Tucker (R, 121 minutes). The parallel biographies of the brilliant cellist Jacqueline du Pre (Ms. Watson), who contracted multiple sclerosis at the height of her career, and her slightly older sister, Jackie (Ms. Griffiths), a talented flutist who gave up a professional career to marry and be "ordinary," is one of the most insightful studies of sibling rivalry ever filmed. Jacqueline may have won fame and glory, the movie says, but she remained a desperately needy emotional child who had to have everything Hilary had (including Hilary's husband). The film is structured like a concerto, in three movements, the last of which ends with Jackie's harrowing death in her sister's arms. The drama is deepened by a soundtrack that makes expert use of Jacqueline's signature piece, the Elgar Cello Concerto in E minor. Ms. Watson's Jacqueline flames with an almost scary intensity (Stephen Holden).
 
 "THE HI-LO COUNTRY," starring Billy Crudup, Woody Harrelson, Sam Elliott and Patricia Arquette. Directed by Stephen Frears (R, 114 minutes). Mr. Frears, the British director, makes a bold but unsteady leap into classic western territory with this story of a friendship between two cowboys who go into the cattle business together after returning from World War II. Mr. Crudup is the shy, laconic Pete, who secretly covets the married girlfriend of his idol, Big Boy (Mr. Harrelson). A movie that wants to be a hybrid of "Giant," "Red River" and "The Last Picture Show" loses its bearings and becomes a laborious soap opera whose red-headed bad girl (Ms. Arquette) lacks the magnetism to make the drama sizzle. But Mr. Harrelson is a live wire as the rootin'-tootin' last of a breed (Holden).
 
 * "HURLYBURLY," starring Sean Penn, Kevin Spacey, Robin Wright Penn, Chazz Palminteri, Garry Shandling, Anna Paquin and Meg Ryan, Directed by Anthony Drazan (R, 122 minutes). David Rabe's screen adaptation of his 80's play about macho mind games in a cocaine-infested Hollywood is a nasty but powerful piece of work made all the more disturbing by the film's close-up view of its troubled characters. Mr. Penn as Eddie, a Hollywood casting director on the skids, eviscerates himself in a stunning performance full of tears, snarls and dripping nostrils. Mr. Spacey, as Eddie's slick, ruthless housemate Mickey, is appropriately reptilian, and Mr. Palminteri and Mr. Shandling are creepily convincing as two of their friends. Ms. Penn, Ms. Paquin and Ms. Ryan are the women they abuse and pass around like trading cards. The movie, like the play, isn't so much about sex as it is about the male incapacity for genuinely selfless friendship (Holden).
 
 * "LIFE IS BEAUTIFUL," directed by and starring Roberto Benigni (PG-13, 122 minutes). Italy's most antic funnyman dares to find humor and tenderness in the midst of the Holocaust, and his risk pays off. This Cannes prize winner is as stubbornly entertaining as its central character, a Jewish waiter named Guido who jokes his way through the nightmare for the sake of his loved ones. Daring also to combine an opening hour of romance and pranks with a more somber second act, Mr. Benigni avoids all traces of the maudlin and effectively creates a situation in which comedy is courage. In this unpretentious, enormously likable film, he shines as a father whose fibs and hilarious buffoonery know no bounds, and no fear (Maslin).
 
 "PATCH ADAMS," starring Robin Williams and Monica Potter. Directed by Tom Shadyac (PG-13, 110 minutes). As a maverick doctor intent on making terminal patients laugh, Mr. Williams delivers a little clowning and a lot of maudlin feel-good sentiment, along with vulgarity left over from the filmmaker's "Ace Ventura" days. He also spends a lot of time being congratulated for his good works, as the film's minor players are kept busy marveling at his antics. The real-life story of this doctor may sound like a fine occasion for Mr. Williams to cut loose, but the film version proves narrow and predictable. Ms. Potter, with a nostrilly resemblance to Julia Roberts, figures in a romantic subplot with a bizarre twist (Maslin).
 
 * "THE PRINCE OF EGYPT," starring the voices of Val Kilmer, Ralph Fiennes, Sandra Bullock and Michelle Pfeiffer. Directed by Brenda Chapman, Steve Hickner and Simon Wells (PG, 93 minutes). First came the great expectations for this animated magnum opus from Dreamworks. Then came reality, in a film struggling mightily to balance animated whimsy and biblical stature. The upshot is an admirably worthy rendering of the Exodus story, even if Moses must initially be seen as a playful young scamp. Biblical plagues and miracles serve as special inspiration for the animators' reality-bending ingenuity (Maslin).
 
 "THE RUGRATS MOVIE," starring the voices of E. G. Daily, Christine Cavanaugh, Kath Soucie, Tara Charendoff and Tim Curry. Directed by Norton Virgien and Igor Kovalyov (G, 90 minutes). Dil Pickles is not the first baby whose resentful older sibling wanted to return him to the hospital, but he's probably the only one who has such an interesting trip back. Dil (full name: Dylan Preston Pickles) is the newborn hero of the first film starring the five talking babies of Nickelodeon's hit children's series "Rugrats." The pleasant surprise is that the film is a delight, from encounters with wolves, wizards and circus monkeys in the forest to musical numbers at the "baby store." There's material for grown-up moviegoers, too, including a scene with some pathetic reporters who turn up at the Pickles house when the children disappear, getting everybody's name wrong and asking, "Is it true a dingo ate your baby?" (Anita Gates).
 
 * "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE," starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow, Geoffrey Rush, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench. Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile this tirelessly inventive comedy also envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today, and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
 * "A SIMPLE PLAN," starring Bill Paxton, Billy Bob Thornton and Bridget Fonda. Directed by Sam Raimi (R, 120 minutes). This onetime cult horror director makes a flawless transition to mainstream storytelling with a quietly devastating thriller. And its fine cast plays out the consequences of a harmless-sounding error in judgment that winds up leveling everything in its path. The catalyst is $4.4 million that literally falls out of the sky, and Scott Smith's story proves how deadly the morality of expediency can become. When you get the shivers watching this wintry tale, which features an especially memorable performance from Mr. Thornton, it won't be from the cold (Maslin).
 
 "STAR TREK: INSURRECTION," starring Patrick Stewart, Jonathan Frakes and Brent Spiner. Directed by Mr. Frakes (PG, 105 minutes). The latest movie episode of the series that will not die finds Captain Picard (Mr. Stewart) and the crew of the Enterprise saving a tribe of utopian space pioneers who live on a planet where everyone enjoys eternal youth. The bad guys want to relocate the people forcibly and exploit the planet's life-giving properties. Picard, standing up against the admiral of Starfleet and risking court-martial, delivers impassioned speeches about the ugly history of forcible relocation and also falls in love with a 309-year-old beauty (Donna Murphy). Although in its ninth movie episode, the series has retained its sincerity and multicultural right-mindedness. It's hokum, but executed deftly and with a warm heart (Holden).
 
 "STEPMOM," starring Susan Sarandon, Julia Roberts and Ed Harris. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG-13, 120 minutes). A man's ex-wife and new girlfriend lock horns over who can be nicer to his two children, in a sudsy story made livelier by its two female stars, both in appealingly high gear. Ms. Roberts plays the nicest person ever to wear black to a downtown photo shoot, while the especially fiery Ms. Sarandon plays the suburban mother as mama lion. Even when the prospect of mortality looms, the story manages to maintain its big, lavish look and peculiar (under the circumstances) sense of fun. As in "Home Alone," Mr. Columbus directs with sunny indifference to reality, medical, economic or otherwise (Maslin).
 
 "THE THIN RED LINE," starring Jim Caviezel, Ben Chaplin, Nick Nolte and Sean Penn, and Woody Harrelson. Directed by Terrence Malick (R, 166 minutes). From the first frame of this huge, drifting war epic loosely derived from James Jones's Guadalcanal novel, it's viscerally clear that Mr. Malick is back. The exquisite, oddly detached visual style that made "Badlands" and "Days of Heaven" the most beautiful films of the 1970's is instantly apparent here, even if the narrative vagueness and brooding voice-overs are also familiar. The film sprawls, gets lost and occasionally delivers visual poetry, the kind that could have been greatly helped by tighter editing. Bottom line: no one who admired Mr. Malick's early work should miss this. But those expecting anything simple will not find it here (Maslin).
 
 * "TOUCH OF EVIL," starring Orson Welles, Charlton Heston and Janet Leigh. Directed by Welles (not rated, 108 minutes). Anyone familiar with Welles's 1958 film-noir landmark knows that it could just as well have been called "Truckload of Evil," and that its crazily sinister plot turns and breathtaking camera work remain astonishingly fresh. "Touch of Evil" is, among so many things, the other film to find Janet Leigh at a lonely motel under strangely menacing management, and the one in which Welles gave one of his most droll, swaggering performances as a corrupt police captain in an American town on the Mexican border. As visually thrilling as it is sin-soaked, this artfully reconstructed version of "Touch of Evil" remains one of the brightest lights on the cinematic landscape this season (Maslin).
 
 * "WAKING NED DEVINE," starring Ian Bannen, David Kelly and Fionnula Flanagan. Directed by Kirk Jones (PG, 91 minutes). Delightful shenanigans greet the news of a winning lottery ticket in a tiny Irish village. Especially after the winner turns out to be dead. Mr. Bannen and Mr. Kelly are wonderfully funny as two old coots who concoct a plot to claim the winnings and unite the town's cast of hearty characters in the process. Mr. Jones's prize-winning career directing television commercials means that everyone here is an amusing eccentric with colorful quirks, and that the septuagenarian stars' naked motorcycle-riding scenes are played for all they're worth. This comedy doesn't have the tart edge of "The Full Monty," but it knows how to coax laughs from making a spectacle of elderly gentlemen in the buff (Maslin).
 
 * "YOU'VE GOT MAIL," starring Meg Ryan, Tom Hanks, Greg Kinnear and Parker Posey. Directed by Nora Ephron (PG, 110 minutes). This cozy, inviting comedy romanticizes the rivalry between two bookstore owners, while also finding time to fall in love with books themselves, the instant intimacy of E-mail and a picture-perfect rendering of Manhattan's Upper West Side. With a feel-good ambiance much less forced than that of "Sleepless in Seattle," Ms. Ephron borrows adroitly from "The Shop Around the Corner" while making this knowing, urbanely funny film very much her own. Ms. Ryan is fresh and adorable without trying, while a ruefully lovelorn Mr. Hanks proves that he can do anything. Again (Maslin).
