HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW;
Steel Dreams That the Eye Can Cherish

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
People often complain that buildings seldom look as good as the renderings artists make of them. But whose fault is that? The truth is that few people are born with sharp eyes. When vision is not cultivated by memory, shock and enthusiasm, the world can look remarkably dull.
Eye-training class is now in session at the Museum of the City of New York, where a trio of shows offer startlingly different ways of looking at the evolution of 20th-century New York. All three shows focus on building as both noun and verb. They depict buildings and building: the process and the artifacts in the making of the modern metropolis. Collectively, the three shows demonstrate that looking is itself an architectural act. A city is constructed daily by the glancing perception of its parts. 
 Two of the shows seduce us into subliminally intimate relationships between consenting adults and our magnificent city. "New York Horizontal" features panoramic views taken by William Hassler, a commercial photographer who captured sweeping images of the city in the years just before and after World War I. "New York Vertical" presents large-format versions of photographs by Horst Hamann, a photographer who had the happy inspiration to turn a panorama camera on its side and train it on slender fragments of the Manhattan skyline.
The third exhibition, "New York on the Rise," features glamour portraits: images of early skyscrapers painted by Hughson Hawley, the most sought-after renderer in the United States from the turn of the century to the advent of the Great Depression.
The combination of the shows gives each an added richness, but some may find Hawley's the most vibrant work on view. Born in England in 1850, he first worked as a scenic designer for the stage, and his renderings have a theatrical glamour that largely stems from his depiction of light.
Typically, he sets his buildings against skies divided into horizontal bands of mottled clouds, intense blue and luminous white. Building facades are streaked with cloud shadows. These effects bring to mind Fitzgerald's description of New York in the 1920's as a city that had all the iridescence of the beginning of the world.
It is a new world that we see taking shape in Hawley's renderings: a continent that, thanks in great part to New York's exploding skyline, has begun to cast off its sense of cultural inferiority to Europe and grow into its own strength. Buildings like the Woolworth Building and the Singer Tower provided the scenic backdrop against which Paul Rosenfeld, in his groundbreaking 1925 book "Port of New York," declared that the city had ceased to be a city artists wished to flee and had instead become their major destination.
"Come back, come back, O glittering and white!" The Hawley show offers ample opportunity to echo Fitzgerald's lament for the lost city of his early years. The artist's huge, rosy rendering of the original Waldorf-Astoria Hotel is enough to make you loathe the Empire State Building, which now occupies the fabled hotel's site. A masterwork of Henry Hardenbergh, who also designed the Plaza and Chelsea Hotels and the Dakota apartments, this palace for the people stood for just over 30 years before it was torn down.
No one needs additional reason to dislike 1515 Broadway, the fin-topped office building between 44th and 45th Streets that replaced the legendary Astor Hotel. But Hawley's rendering of the Astor helps to explain why this vanished landmark helped to anchor Times Square in a way that the Marriott Marquis, for example, does not. The Astor sits squarely on the street, throws open its grand doors to it and enlivens the sidewalk with the tall arched windows of its ground-floor public rooms. Had the place been allowed to stand for 20 more years, Ian Schrager would probably now be fitting its windows with billowing white curtains.
But the masterpiece in the Hawley show is his rendering of a building that still stands: Cass Gilbert's Broadway Chambers Building just east of City Hall. This speculative office building was Gilbert's first New York commission, and it's not an exaggeration to regard it as the Lever House of its day, a building that was widely regarded as the ultimate refinement of the early skyscraper type. When models and drawings of the building were presented at the Paris Exposition of 1900, Europeans rubbed their eyes. Here was an eminently refined version of a building type made possible by elevators, ingenuity, steel and greed.
Yet many people now pass by this building daily without giving it a glance. The ground floor houses a costume-jewelry shop, but the building itself is as beautiful as ever, though now it's we who must rub our eyes to see it. The fading of alertness can be a more tragic loss than the demolition of a building. Disenchantment is the heavy price we pay for novelty.
Hassler's panoramic views in "New York Horizontal" bring to mind the children's game of moving statues. (Stop. Don't Stop.) The pictures, up to four feet long, were taken with a No. 8 Cirkut Outfit camera, which came equipped with a rotating body capable of producing 360-degree views. With some of them, the effect is of a person whirling around, arms outstretched, as if to possess the city by sheer exuberance.
Possession, in fact, was Hassler's stock in trade. He worked for real estate developers, most often for Joseph D. Day, and a number of Hassler's pictures were made on assignment to document sites for future development. His panoramas deserve to stand with the paintings of Church and Burchfield as enticements for people to settle in Arcadian settings that their settlements will ruin.
"New York Vertical" is a blown-up, walk-through version of Mr. Hamann's excellent book of that same title. Unfortunately, his black-and-white photographs do not gain from being removed from their binding and enlarged to many times their size.
The problem here is scale. The book establishes a tactile immediacy between the city and the body. It supports the illusion that you hold the city in your hands. Your eye takes in each image with a single scan. The blown-up versions, though handsomely installed, negate the intimacy between image and viewer and leave an unfortunate impression of trade-show hyperbole. But groups of them would do wonders for subway platforms.
Mr. Hamann used a Linhof Technorama, a panoramic camera that makes exceptional demands on the photographer's vision because the format does not permit the framing that draws on the vision of the complete image.
Spring for the book. Mr. Hamann is a genius at composition, not only in his framing of architectural forms but in his treatment of light as well. His gradations of gray, the deluxe velvet of his blacks, combined with the unexpected angles from which he often shoots, bring an oddly abstract quality to these sharply focused renderings of urban texture.
Only a few of Mr. Hamann's pictures include people, and these figures tend to appear solitary, isolated, as if weighted down by the enormous volume of space pressing from above. Montgomery Schuyler once described the skyscrapers of lower Manhattan conversing among themselves at their summits like a race of giants. Mr. Hamann's pictures show what it's like to stand in the middle of the conversation without the elevation to make yourself heard. But I have a feeling that our lowly gossip is juicier than theirs.
In Plato's ideal city, the height of buildings was to be determined by strength of voice. A person standing in the street should be able to understand what someone standing atop a building is shouting. So how did it happen that in the world's most democratic city, we hear nothing but fire engines, ambulances, police cars and jackhammers raising the skyline to ever more improbable heights?
Telephones had much to do with it, and in 1882 Hawley prepared a stunning rendering of what was then the new New York Stock Exchange, a small classical temple festooned with telephone wires. It's an uncharacteristic drawing, created for publication in the rotogravure. With its sculptural massing and severe coloration, the rendering points in the direction of Leger. But now, at a time when the Stock Exchange is demanding larger quarters, it's evident that Hawley foresaw what Manuel Castels would later call the space of flows -- the displacement of architecture by the communications technology that now keeps the global economy humming round the clock.
An aura of melancholy permeates these three shows: the sensation that artists who relate best to buildings have difficulty engaging with people. In no way am I suggesting that these three artists have flawed characters. I mean, rather, that their work discloses an essential truth about the art form they record.
Architecture is a social art. It brings people together in space. But these images remind us that architecture originated as a means of reckoning with mortality. In an era of festival marketplaces, convention hotels and overly calculated ho-ho-ho, it is useful to recall that the history of architecture leads fantastically back toward death.
 
"New York Horizontal: Cirkut Camera Views by William Hassler" remains at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, through May 2. "New York Vertical by Horst Hamann" remains there through April 18, and "New York on the Rise: Architectural Renderings by Hughson Hawley, 1880-1931" through April 4. "New York in Focus: Hughson Hawley and the Art of Architectural Rendering," a conversation with the architectural historians Mary Beth Betts, Sarah Bradford Landau and Thomas Mellins, will be held at the museum tomorrow at 3 P.M. Advance registration suggested: (212) 534-1672, extension 257.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 42; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Inside-Out Meditations On the Poison of Racism

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
The subject of race has prompted some of the most mettlesome American art in the 1990's. And much of that work owes a debt to Adrian Piper, an artist who helped introduce identity politics into Conceptualism nearly 30 years ago.
Ms. Piper, 50, came to the theme as both insider and outsider. A light-skinned black woman from a middle-class background, she was raised in Harlem but educated in private integrated schools. She is usually taken for white in social encounters, and this "passing" status has been the springboard for much of her art. 
 From this vantage, she has experienced racism firsthand: she remembers being regarded with suspicion by other black children as a child, and later by white adults when she had made her background clear. Her response has been to explore the peculiar dynamic of the in-between.
In her art she plays the dual role of cultural eavesdropper and provocateur. And she has tenaciously prodded and dissected the concept of race itself to suggest its contradictory guises, whether as a pretext for economic oppression, as a source of psychological challenge or as a resistant, divisive fact of everyday life.
Two traveling retrospectives of Ms. Piper's career are to appear later this year, one in March at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, the other in October at the University of Maryland in Baltimore. But a compact mini-survey of some of her earliest and most prescient work can be seen now at Thomas Erben Gallery in SoHo.
Under the umbrella title "Mythic Being: 1972-1975," the show brings together a group of hand-altered black-and-white self-portrait photographs that represent a breakthrough moment for the artist.
In the 1960's, after attending the School of Visual Arts, she was producing and exhibiting abstract Conceptual work, inspired in part by the example of Sol LeWitt. It was only in 1970, when she was studying at City College, that she seems to have made an emotional connection to the black power movement, which led to a change of direction in her art.
This produced a series of politically charged performance pieces, staged in private and in public and documented in photographs, in which she played the central role. Disguising herself in dark glasses, a spectacular Afro wig and a handlebar mustache -- a kind of 70's version of blackface -- she created an alter ego as a young, working-class black or Latino man.
To the earliest shots of herself in male drag she added cartoon-style speech balloons filled with quotations from diaries she had been keeping since she was in her teens. She then paid to have the pictures published among the advertisements in the art pages of The Village Voice.
The images, with their scrambling of race and gender, are hilarious and weird. The Mythic Being seems to be visually based on the day's icons of racial militancy, like the Black Panthers and Angela Davis. But the chatty diary entries, which include breathless reports of adolescent crushes, diffuse any sense of macho threat and underscore the androgynous nature of the performance.
The work toughens up in the 10-part series "I/You (Her)" from 1974. Here her face is joined by the collaged face of another woman, a white friend with whom she had quarreled. The harsh, bitter words Ms. Piper assigns herself announce the end of the friendship and imply that racism was a factor in the estrangement. Significantly, she gradually transforms her face (with the help of a felt-tip pen) into that of the Mythic Being as the piece progresses.
Thereafter, race became the main focus of the work. In 1975, while a graduate student in philosophy at Harvard, Ms. Piper took her performances into the street and had herself photographed in male guise "cruising" white women in Harvard Square, staging a fake mugging in a nearby park, and walking through crowds of unheeding pedestrians thinking murderous thoughts and itching for a fight.
The pictures suggest a certain style of 1960's guerrilla theater that blended klutzy absurdist humor and goading ideological contempt. Its flavor is perhaps best distilled in a single 1975 photo piece in which the Mythic Being, seen in dramatically shadowed close-up, seems to exhale the words "I embody everything you most hate and fear," written in a puff of cigarette smoke.
By this point, artist and alter ego had effectively merged. In the later images in the show, the Mythic Being sits at a typewriter surrounded by quotes from Immanuel Kant, the subject of Ms. Piper's dissertation. (She now teaches philosophy at Wellesley College.) Her use of blackface -- as a means both to distance herself from and to claim a racial identity -- had, one suspects, served its psychic purpose.
Much has happened in art and in politics since 1975, though certain things remain little changed. Racism, despite some contrary signals, just won't let go, inside or outside the art world. Surely that's why Ms. Piper's work from the early 70's makes almost as much sense now as it did then, and why her link to younger artists seems so evident and immediate. The "Mythic Being" series anticipates much contemporary art, from the text-intensive paintings of Glenn Ligon, to the emblematic photographs of Lorna Simpson, to the smart, sharp cross-gender work of Lyle Ashton-Harris. And it clearly has a place in the current, often rancorous debate on use (or misuse) of black stereotypes in art.
Such questions of precedence and influence will be easier to evaluate when the retrospectives appear. But much of what makes Ms. Piper an important figure can be found in bud in the Erben show. It reveals an artist who has been from the start a witty and aggressive controversialist, one who believes that art can be an effective vehicle for ideas, and that ideas can spark self-examination and social change.
 
"Adrian Piper: The Mythic Being, 1972-75" remains at Thomas Erben Gallery, 476 Broome Street, SoHo, through Jan. 16.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 43; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1165 words

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Much More Than Meets The Eye

BYLINE: By Wendy Moonan 

 BODY:
In Modernism, form is supposed to follow function. In antiques, form often hides function, which is much more fun.
This year some dealers at the 45th annual Winter Antiques Show, which opens on Jan. 15 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, on Park Avenue and 66th Street, will be selling rare examples of metamorphic furniture, pieces with two distinct functions, one of which is usually disguised in the other. For example, the Manhattan gallery L'Antiquaire and the Connoisseur Inc. will be exhibiting a 34-inch-wide "tavolo-scrivania" made in Venice around 1760. It is a card table that turns into a desk when you push the top of the table back and pull the next layer forward; a reading stand pops up, with inkwells on the side and drawers underneath. 
 "Mechanical tables were extremely rare then, especially ones made in Venice this early," said Helen Fioratti, president of the gallery. "You have to remember, this is the century of charm and amusement. Think of Casanova. This table is a fine example of the kind of things that interested people then."
The table is walnut, with cabriole legs. The top is inlaid with marquetry fruitwood and bone, depicting the Three Graces. It costs $105,000.
The table is not much smaller than a famous metamorphic desk made in Italy for Napoleon's sister, Elisa Bonaparte, which is now at Fontainebleau. Elisa was the Hillary Clinton of her day: intelligent, educated and strong willed. Madeleine Deschamps, a furniture expert, wrote in her book "Empire" (Abbeville, 1994) that after Elisa married Felix Bacciochi, a Corsican officer, Napoleon made her Princess of Lucca. Later she became Grand Duchess of Tuscany, and, Ms. Deschamps wrote, "she showed much interest in the economic development of both those states, energetically improving the legislation and administration as well as the hospital system."
The London craftsman David Linley discussed Elisa's desk in his book "Extraordinary Furniture" (Reed Books, 1996). He wrote that the desk was designed by Giovanni Socci of Florence (1807-39), a leading cabinetmaker of the Empire style, to look like a plain oval mahogany commode with saber legs and a marble top. In fact, the "drawers" on the front are the back of a chair. When they are drawn back, out comes a three-legged chair.
Viscount Linley wrote: "When the chair is pulled out, the central leg has to slide through a groove in the main central platform, and so is of a simpler turned shape than the other two. The marble top is made in two halves, which part to reveal a leather-covered writing slope and a small writing box that pops up and takes stationery, ink and pens."
Elisa liked the desk so much that she took it with her into exile after the fall of Napoleon. Her daughter Napoleone inherited it, as did Napoleon III later on, and it finally became part of the French National Collections.
Dual-purpose furniture probably started in ancient times, when someone created a table by placing a board on two sawhorses. In the Middle Ages and through the 17th century, the English made oak chair-tables, sometimes called monk's chairs. In these pieces, the armchair back pivots so that it can be lowered to become a table.
Metamorphic furniture became particularly fashionable in England during the Regency period (1805-25). At the armory show, the Kentshire Galleries, a Manhattan dealer in English antiques, is selling, for $24,000, a mahogany library chair, circa 1815, with scrolled arms, a leaf-carved back splat with a lion's mask, and an ebonized crest rail. The chair back tilts backward on hinges to become a set of library steps.
"Most pieces of dual-function furniture were commissioned for private libraries," said Robert I. Ballinger, the manager of the Philadelphia antiques shop Alfred Bullard Inc., another exhibitor at the armory show. "Books were rare. After Englishmen went on their grand tour, they built libraries to showcase their knowledge and wealth. With the advent of the library came the ladder chair, the ladder stool and ladder pole: all means to reach the upper tiers of the bookcases."
Metamorphic furniture was also meant to be fun. "These were toys for rich men," Mr. Ballinger said. "They were costly when they were made. They were always of the finest materials and craftsmanship, because only the rich had libraries. I have never seen a library chair in a secondary wood or done with second-rate craftsmanship."
Bruce Newman, owner of Newel Art Galleries, a Manhattan to-the-trade dealer that is not in the armory show, said he had several metamorphic antiques in stock, including two revolving bookcases, 27 inches square, that can be used as lecterns, and a pair of what he called "pote" tables, 19th-century hollow mahogany fluted columns that can be used as pedestals or opened up for storage. The pair costs $12,000.
Mr. Newman also said he had a Regency library table with a top that folded up and becomes a ladder and a pole you can hold on to as you mount the steps. This costs $60,000. He said these and some 20,000 other items can be seen at his Web site, www.newel.com.
Sotheby's New York has a sale of English furniture on Jan. 22 that includes a William IV library table-steps with gilt-tooled leather inset steps (estimate: $12,000 to $15,000) and a brass-bound and leather-covered library pole-ladder (estimate: $3,000 to $5,000).
The French were masters at hybrid furniture designs. Dalva Brothers, a Manhattan gallery that specializes in French antiques, has several, including a rare bonheur-du-jour, a lady's writing desk ingeniously fitted with compartments, that has been owned by an array of Americans (Joseph C. Widener, John L. Severence, the Cleveland Museum and John Dorrance, the founder of Campbell's Soup).
The desk, by the leading Paris cabinetmaker Pierre Rousel, is Transitional Period, between Louis XV and XVI. It starts as a writing table with a hinged central panel that lifts backward. A mirror flips up, and the piece becomes a poudreuse, or dressing table. It compresses a lot of storage areas into a minimal space, while remaining quintessentially feminine. It costs $350,000.
Apartment dwellers who can't afford a guest room will like the 18th-century beds hidden in pieces of furniture. "Beds in the form of bookcases, writing desks, cupboards and sideboards were probably found in many well-to-do homes," Viscount Linley wrote in his book. "The inventory made of Madame de Pompadour's possessions mentions three."
His favorite is a commode bed designed about 1780 by the Swedish cabinetmaker Georg Haupt. The entire front slides out from the back, extending like a telescope. Folding legs swing down to support the mattress, which is rolled up inside. The bed was made for the private bedroom of Gustavus III of Sweden, as a place for his page-bodyguard to sleep. The King was assassinated anyway, in 1792, but at least it wasn't in his bedroom. Come to think of it, that commode bed could be useful in a lot of situations.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 40; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1554 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
A Loving Home Life, Right Down to the Nits

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
A mother delousing her child's hair may not be the most appealing subject, but the Dutch painter Pieter de Hooch (1629-1684) saw it as a labor of love. In "A Mother and Child With Its Head in Her Lap" (1658-60) he conjures up a convincing scene of domestic felicity.
The subject is not unfamiliar in Dutch painting; combs and hair-cleaning symbolized godliness, and earlier artists had depicted delousing scenes. But de Hooch (pronounced de-HOAK) brought it home, so to speak, creating a "real" setting carefully anchored in specifics. A well-dressed mother dexterously plows her kneeling child's scalp in a room whose properties are seen in exquisite detail, from beamed ceiling to mellow tiled floor. 
 Sunlight pours through a doorway leading to a smaller chamber, whose open window presents an outdoor view. The light casts a precise pattern on the floor between the doorway and the window. Also coming from a high window at right, it brings alive the texture of the striped bed curtains flanked by a brass bed warmer on the wall beside them. A small pooch (pronounced POOCH) -- dogs are a staple of de Hooch paintings -- is silhouetted in the doorway.
The scene is, in short, a cozy one in which the intimate details of domestic life and the play of light and color on surfaces and textures give the viewer the sense of a comfortable, nonthreatening world in which all is as it should be. Like the best of de Hooch's Delft period, the painting conveys the solid values of prosperous Dutch burgherhood: tidiness, both moral and physical; tranquillity and, not least important, parental skills. Perhaps, too, the aftermath of the Thirty Years' War (1618-48), in which the Netherlands was engaged, encouraged an audience for an art of peace and domestic harmony.
De Hooch did not invent genre painting, but he literally gave it a new dimension. Space and perspective played roles as charged as color in his work; one of his favorite devices is that of a dark foreground with an open door leading into a brightly lighted second space that in turn reveals another view. Although skilled in the use of mathematical perspective, he was also adept at creating a sense of it by the time-honored use of color, light and atmospheric effects. Small wonder that he was considered a star of the Delft School, outshone only by his contemporary Johannes Vermeer (1632-75).
Yet the show at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, simply titled "Pieter de Hooch, 1629-84," is the first retrospective ever given to this masterly recorder of everyday life. It was organized by Desmond Shawe-Taylor, director of the Dulwich Picture Gallery in London, and Peter C. Sutton, director of the Wadsworth Atheneum, a de Hooch scholar who produced the catalogue raisonne of his work in 1980. In 40 or so paintings, the artist's development is tracked from early renditions of soldiers disporting in taverns and guard rooms through the atmospheric interiors and courtyards of his Delft period to the elegant but stilted and sometimes bizarre canvases he turned out after moving to Amsterdam. But the work done in Delft is far and away the best.
De Hooch's biography is short on facts, long on supposition. He was born in Rotterdam, the son of a bricklayer and a professional midwife. He probably studied in Haarlem with the Italianate landscape painter Nicolaes Berchem (1620-83), was married and left in 1652 for Delft, where he seems to have worked as both a painter and a servant for a linen merchant. In 1655 he joined the artists' guild there (which Vermeer later led), moved to Amsterdam between 1660-61 and died in a madhouse at the age of 55.
Nothing is known about his relationship with Vermeer, with whose work his own shared many traits. Even scholars are hard put to say who influenced whom; occasionally they have had trouble telling their works apart. The two artists were in Delft at the same time, but whether they knew each other is not certain. Yet they must have been aware of each other's paintings. If de Hooch's palette is warmer than Vermeer's and he uses more complex perspective systems and multiple sources of light, Vermeer's subjects are more subtly portrayed, compositionally more harmonious and convey a sense of enigma foreign to de Hooch's straight-on approach.
De Hooch started out in a cliched Dutch genre tradition, doing scenes of soldiers and peasants carousing in barrooms and barracks, including "A Seated Soldier With a Standing Serving Woman" (1652-55). A tavern vignette, it depicts a soldier wearing a broad-brimmed hat and armored chest protector sitting with his back to the viewer in front of a woman who raises a tall glass of beer. In the shadowy background two men play cards on a military drum. The interior space is shallow, and there's not much evidence of the artist's later achievements, save for the careful attention given to rendering surfaces.
By 1655 he had produced one of the first of his Delft interiors, "Mother and Child With a Servant Woman Sweeping" (1655-57). A mother sits near a fireplace with a dozing infant in her lap watching the sweeper. Leaded windows above give a view of a tiled roof. A lighted doorway leads to a back room, but the perspective is somewhat distorted. Still, it represents a better attempt to create receding pictorial space than the tavern scenes. But by 1658, Mr. Sutton writes, de Hooch had created "a new type of genre painting with unprecedented spatial order and naturalism." He had not left the drinking themes behind but now they, like his domestic scenes -- peopled mostly by women, children and servants -- were set in respectable courtyards, interiors and gardens, with well-ordered, psychologically pleasing progressions of spaces.
One highlight of the show, from the fertile year 1658, is a painting that brings into play all de Hooch's special talents: his brilliant use of perspective and his great skills at conveying light, color and surfaces. It depicts the courtyard of a brick house in Delft, with two women and a child. One of the women stands, back to the viewer, in a narrow arched passageway framed in brick that gives at the far end a glimpse of another building. The other woman leads a little girl down a low flight of steps out of a crude wooden shed that abuts the archway. The courtyard floor is neatly paved in yellow bricks that complement the red bricks of the arch; a patch of blue sky and the top of a tree appear over the shed.
In this startlingly structured picture, the eye is caught up in a lively bustle of doorways and other architectural framings, open and closed spaces and wood and brick surfaces that the figures vividly animate. The artist's game seems to be how much you can pack into a painting and still make it read. The multiple architectural elements of the busy canvas, done in two-point perspective, are nearly all fictitious, yet their artful assemblage gives the impression of repertorial accuracy.
The painting is paired in the show with one done at the same time using a very similar architectural composition but a different orchestration; for example, the shed on the right has given way to an arbor in which two men and a woman are drinking. But all the varied elements of color, texture, space and light are there again, and this painting, so much the same and yet so different, is no less a smash than the first.
Around 1661, with the decline of Delft as an art center, de Hooch -- like many other artists -- moved with his family to arriviste Amsterdam, the prosperous banking center of northern Europe. There, his style changed again, and not for the better. A foppish elegance descended on his paintings; the interiors became ornate, the figures elongated, almost Mannerist in style, and an atmosphere of overripe luxury prevailed.
Compare the plain but elegant portrait of a Delft clan he did in 1657-60 with his 1670 account of a wealthy merchant's family in Amsterdam. The first is a beautifully orchestrated view of three generations dressed in their somber Sunday best but informally assembled in an airy courtyard with a backdrop of city buildings. It is the largest of de Hooch's works and is, in short, a masterpiece. But the Amsterdam family, a group of stiff and oddly distorted figures garbed in sumptuous finery, is deployed in a stilted arrangement in a stuffy manorial room, the only real-looking body in it that of a squirming dog.
De Hooch also used Amsterdam's grandiose new City Hall as a setting for invented compositions, including family groups involved in such pastimes as music-making. And he pursued his old themes of card players and merrymakers along with domestic interiors. But many of these paintings, while virtuoso in performance, come off as rather stale stereotypes lacking the magical sweetness and simplicity of his work in Delft.
With its well-assembled group of paintings from important lenders all over the world, this one-and-only show is in itself something of a masterpiece, highly instructive and a lot of fun besides. And its impressive catalogue gives a good reading of the social, economic and political climate of the times. Too bad it won't come to New York, but Hartford's not very far.
 
"Pieter de Hooch, 1629-1684" remains on display at the Wadsworth Atheneum, 600 Main Street in Hartford, through Feb. 28.

HEADLINE: Ford's Idea for Safer Safety

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
IN an effort to reduce injuries caused by air bags and safety belts, the Ford Motor Company plans to add computer controls to its cars and light trucks that would activate safety devices in different ways, depending on the severity of a crash, the size of the car's occupants, the position of the driver's seat and whether safety belts are being used.
Ford's advanced restraints system, which will be phased in as vehicle designs are updated, would use a system of sensors to relay information to a central computer in the car, which could adjust the deployment rate of an air bag based on such factors as the force of a crash or how close the driver is to the steering wheel. It would prevent the bag from deploying at all in a minor crash that would be unlikely to cause serious injuries or if the passenger seat was unoccupied or being used by a small child who might be injured by the bag itself. 
 The system will include the seat-belt pretensioners, which are devices in the front belt mechanisms that tighten forcefully in a crash to hold occupants tightly and prevent them from bouncing around after impact. If sensors detect that the crash is quite severe, a metal bar in the spool of the belt retractor twists like a wrung-out rag to release the belt in a controlled manner, reducing the risk of chest injuries caused by a belt as it forcefully tightens.
About 20 traffic deaths a year among children and smaller women have been attributed to injuries caused by air bags.
Ford said its system would shut off the passenger bag completely if a weight sensor in the seat determined that the occupant was a child weighing less than 45 pounds. If the occupant weighed roughly 45 to 105 pounds, the bag would deploy at a lower inflation rate than if he or she weighed more than 105.
Ford announced its plan this week at the North American International Auto Show. Most components of the system will first appear on the 2000 Taurus later this year and will then be phased in on future models of all Ford cars, pickups, vans and sport utility vehicles. JAMES G. COBB

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazilian Stocks Fall Sharply After State Threatens Default

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Brazilian stock market tumbled yesterday after the Governor of one of the country's largest states said he would not make debt payments to the central Government for 90 days.
The announcement by Itamar Franco, the newly installed Governor of Minas Gerais and an interim President of Brazil from the end of 1992 to 1994, surprised investors and reminded them how bumpy the road to spending and tax reform will be here and in other emerging nations. "It is a demonstration that the Brazilian stability adjustment reform effort is a two-step-forward-and-one-step-backward process," said Arturo C. Porzecanski, chief economist for the Americas at ING Barings. 
 In Sao Paulo, the benchmark Bovespa stock index fell 5.1 percent, to 6,954.17. Traders and analysts said the threat of problems in Brazil also pulled the dollar lower and weighed on United States stock markets.
In the fall, Brazil was regarded as a bastion against the deepening of world financial crises that pushed some key stock indexes in the United States down 20 percent. Economists feared that a devaluation of Brazil's currency then, soon after Russia had defaulted on some of its debt, could lead to a worldwide recession.
The International Monetary Fund, and the the United States and other countries, assembled a $41.5 billion rescue package, which helped calm things down. In a positive note yesterday, the World Bank approved the distribution of two loans that are part of the package.
But the threatened default could make it even more difficult for Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, to reach the spending and deficit goals the country must meet to qualify for more payments from the rescue package. Even if the reform plan succeeds, many economists think that Brazil is headed into the sort of recession that will still require a currency devaluation.
"I think this is worrying, but it is good that we get it out of the system right now and that Cardoso appears to be strong," said Susan Gilbertson, head of Latin American research at Paribas.
In other emerging markets, the Philippine Government sold $1 billion of a global bond issue yesterday. Investors eagerly snapped up the bonds because their interest rates were so high. For example, the 10-year note had a yield of 9.123 percent, almost twice that on the 10-year United States Treasury note. The lead underwriters were J. P. Morgan, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Warburg Dillon Read.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Brooklyn Project Aims At People 75 and Older

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Work began last month on transforming an empty lot along Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, into a 104-unit apartment building that will provide elderly tenants with meals, services and personal care.
When completed in 12 months, the $22 million project, called Sunrise on the Bay, will have studio to two-bedroom apartments with 300 to 700 square feet of space in a four-story brick building framing an interior courtyard. There will also be 10,000 square feet of first-floor medical office space in the building at 2211 Emmons Avenue, between Dooley and East 21st Streets. 
 The project, for people age 75 and older, is another indication of the growing demand for specialized housing for the elderly. Over the last 22 months, residences for older people who need help with daily chores but do not require constant medical care -- called assisted-living residences -- have begun to appear in New York City, which developers had avoided because of high costs and tough regulations.
Until recently, most New Yorkers who needed such housing had to turn to nursing homes or adult homes, which must be licensed by the state to provide personal and medical-related services. Under the state regulations, it would be difficult for large publicly owned companies to become providers of medical services.
The new projects have found a way around the regulations by separating the housing from the health care. Under this arrangement, developers and operators of the housing do not need any state licenses as long as the personal care is provided through an agency licensed by the state.
Sunrise on the Bay is being developed by the Atlantic Development Group of Manhattan in partnership with Sunrise Assisted Living Inc. of Fairfax, Va., one of the nation's larger assisted-living operators, which will manage the project. Dignity Home Care Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Sunrise and a licensed service provider in New York State, will provide the personal care. Financing is from Fleet Bank and the partners' own equity.
Though the Sheepshead Bay project is a first in southern Brooklyn, there are now at least eight other such developments under way or recently completed in New York City. Among those completed are a 126-unit project at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn and a 143-unit development at 117th Street and 84th Avenue in Kew Gardens, Queens. And a 206-unit development on Henry Hudson Parkway at West 239th Street in Riverdale in the Bronx is to be completed in June.
Demographics is a major reason that the partners at Atlantic Development Group, Marc Altheim and Peter Fine, turned their attention last year to New York City. Since 1995, they and other major assisted-living operators have developed a 122-unit project in Ossining in Westchester County and another with 100 units in Stratford, Conn.
"There's a tremendous demand for this type of housing in the New York City boroughs, where we believe the market is three to four times larger than in the suburbs, where we successfully have built such projects," Mr. Fine said. About 6,000 people 75 or older live within a three-mile radius of Sunrise on the Bay, he said.
John E. Nikas, chairman of Community Board 15, which helps guide growth in the area, said of the project: "Any additional services for the elderly are welcomed. But I don't know if Emmons Avenue is an appropriate location for such a development."
Emmons Avenue, a commercial corridor, has undergone a resurgence in recent years. The opening of a new shopping center anchored by a Loehmann's department store and the reopening of a Lundy's restaurant, which had been dark for over a decade, have helped turn around the area.
That new investment and "the buzz of activity" are what Mr. Fine said drew Atlantic to the nearly two-acre site, which had been used for parking and is among the last vacant tracts in the community. Its location adjacent to the shopping center and close to the water were also factors, as was its proximity to the middle-class and upper-middle-class residential neighborhoods of Sheepshead Bay and Manhattan Beach.
Last summer, the partners bought the site, on which zoning rules permitted a residential building to be constructed. They then teamed with Sunrise, which after acquiring Karrington Health, an assisted-living developer in Columbus, Ohio, last fall, now operates 115 projects in 20 states, including 5 developments in Westchester County and on Long Island.
"It is an opportunity at a time when we were ready to enter New York City," said John J. Noone, a senior vice president at Sunrise. "It is a grossly underserved market."
Sunrise on the Bay will offer apartment living with hotel-style services, including meals, housekeeping and social activities. Monthly rents, including services, are expected to be $2,200 to $3,800, plus an added fee of $600 for a second person. Personal care, like assistance with bathing and dressing, will be provided at an extra cost.
At those prices, Mr. Nikas, the community board chairman, questions how many local residents will be able to afford to live there.
Mr. Fine countered that "every community thinks the numbers are high because they equate them with monthly rents." But given that meals and services are included, "it becomes economical," he said, noting that tenants were expected to have an average income of $40,000 a year, excluding investments or real estate assets.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Labor Deal Improves Odds of Keeping Nets' Core Intact

BYLINE: By CHRIS BROUSSARD 

 BODY:
Perhaps the time has come for the Nets to experience prosperity. Equipped with a talented roster, in the possession of new, philanthropic ownership, and outfitted with a fresh, state-of-the-art practice facility, the long-suffering franchise received more good news yesterday when the National Basketball Association's new collective bargaining agreement was ratified.
While the Board of Governors' unanimous acceptance of the deal signifies that all teams were pleased with the terms, the Nets are one of a handful of clubs with extra reason to celebrate. Like the Minnesota Timberwolves, the Los Angeles Lakers and the Cleveland Cavaliers, the Nets have a nucleus of exciting young players that would have been almost impossible to keep together under the former agreement. 
 But because individual salaries will now be capped for at least the next six years, the team's chances of keeping center Jayson Williams, guard Kerry Kittles and the swingman Keith Van Horn for several years have gone from so-so to very good. With limited maximum salaries, no competitor will be able to outbid the Nets for those players, and the Nets will not have to pay the roughly $300 million it might have taken to retain their services.
"Any team that truly wants to be significant in the N.B.A. has to be together for a period of time," Coach John Calipari of the Nets said. "If you look at Utah, Indiana and Chicago, the core of their teams have been together for seven, eight years, and that's why they're the best three teams in the league."
Minnesota, with its All-Star forward, Kevin Garnett, having signed a six-year, $126 million contract in 1997, had become the greatest example of how uncontrolled salaries could destroy a potential championship contender well before maturation. It would have been incredibly difficult, and perhaps financially perilous, for the Timberwolves to keep the All-Stars Stephon Marbury and Tom Gugliotta with Garnett making so much money. But under the new agreement, they have a legitimate chance to sign all three without ruining themselves economically.
The Lakers would probably have been forced to exceed Shaquille O'Neal's seven-year, $120 million contract to re-sign Kobe Bryant either this year or next -- a reality that might have put a strain on the team's chemistry -- but now Bryant can earn no more than $87 million over seven years. And competing teams can offer him no more than a six-year, $67.5 million deal.
In Cleveland last season, Zydrunas Ilgauskas, Derek Anderson, Brevin Knight and Cedric Henderson brightened the future of the Cavaliers by making the all-rookie team, and now the Cavs have a chance to keep them around All-Star Shawn Kemp for the several years.
The priority for the Nets is to re-sign the charismatic Williams, who is among the league's most coveted free agents. While Williams's well-known desire to stay in New Jersey gave the Nets the advantage all along, Seattle, Phoenix, Detroit and Charlotte were ready to tempt him with hefty offers that might have surpassed what the Nets wanted to pay. But now those clubs cannot push Williams's market value past $83 million over six years, while, because of the Larry Bird exception, the Nets can pay Williams nearly $106 million over seven years.
Under the former rules, it might have taken at least that much money to get him back. Williams, who has been outspoken about keeping the Nets' nucleus intact, said he did not mind making a little less money. "I think I lost a lot of money on this, but how much does one person need?" he said in reference to the new labor agreement.
Van Horn, who could have become the game's highest-paid player next summer, agreed with Williams. "If the most I can make is x amount of dollars, that's fine," said Van Horn, a second-year forward. "I'm not trying to break the bank. Once you get over a certain amount of money, there's not a whole lot of difference."
With the powerful agent David Falk representing him, Van Horn would have obliterated the bank as a free agent. While whispers of his becoming the league's first $200 million man were overstated, he probably would have commanded about $150 million on the open market. Now, he will have to settle for about half that.
Though Kittles, another Falk client, has one year remaining on his contract, the Nets could extend his deal when the league allows the free-agent bidding to begin on Jan. 18. A team executive said the Nets wanted to sign the shooting guard to a long-term deal but did not feel the urgency to do it before the season began.
"Anything that keeps our team together, I'm happy about," Calipari said of the long-term implications of the new labor agreement.
Keeping Williams, Kittles and Van Horn could enable the Nets to be one of, and remain among, the elite N.B.A. teams for the next decade.
REBOUNDS
In addition to re-signing JAYSON WILLIAMS, Coach JOHN CALIPARI said he wanted back the free-agent point guard SHERMAN DOUGLAS. The Nets paid Douglas the league minimum, $275,000, last season, and can offer him the median salary exemption of $1.75 million this year. . . . Since the Nets have 10 players signed who know Calipari's system, they will focus mainly on conditioning in training camp. Calipari's chief concern is injuries. "Something as small as a blister could keep a guy out for a week," he said. "But a week could be five games."

HEADLINE: Prosecution Almost Rests in the Microsoft Trial

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
As the last Government witness nears the end of his testimony, it is increasingly clear that the Government's antitrust case against Microsoft is an indictment not only of the business practices of the world's dominant software maker but also of its corporate character.
Witness after witness -- an executive roll-call of companies that drive today's economy, including Intel, I.B.M., Netscape Communications, America Online, Sun Microsystems and Apple Computer -- has portrayed the Microsoft Corporation as a bullying monopolist. The Justice Department charges that Microsoft is guilty of a litany of misconduct, including illegally using its market muscle to impose restrictive contracts, to engage in predatory pricing and to attempt to divide markets. 
 Microsoft took each step, the Government contends, to stifle competition and thwart the challenge that Internet software posed to its monopoly product, the Windows operating system, the computing equivalent of the telephone dial tone. On its face, the Government's case seems sweeping and persuasive. Yet as the trial has plodded since October through lengthy cross-examination of each witness, with both sides presenting mountains of E-mail and documents to support their arguments and counterarguments, there is certainly room for doubt. Each disputed meeting, contract and product strategy is open to interpretation.
There is no jury in this trial; Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson must wade through all the conflicting evidence and decide whether Microsoft's motives were mainly to impede competition or to improve its products. In determining which side to believe, he will inevitably be guided by his own judgment of whether Microsoft is a vigorous competitor or predatory monopolist.
That is why the Justice Department has gone to such lengths to depict Microsoft as a corporate bad guy and its chairman, William H. Gates, as evasive, uncooperative and less than truthful in the videotaped excerpts of his deposition testimony shown repeatedly in court.
The Microsoft E-mail and strategy documents show, at the least, a no-holds-barred approach to competition. In colorful language, they outline plans to "kill," "pollute" and "subvert" the products of rivals. Marketing campaigns are referred to as jihads.
Microsoft's world view seems tinged with paranoia. Close partners like the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Intel Corporation are at times painted as enemy conspirators. Nor are all the threats, apparently, outside the corporate campus in Redmond, Wash. In a 1997 E-mail to Mr. Gates, a senior Microsoft executive, warned, "In my opinion, Windows is in the process of being exterminated here at Microsoft."
Other Government evidence seeks to show that Mr. Gates remained dismissive of a long-running antitrust investigation, even after Microsoft signed a consent decree with the Justice Department in 1994. At a 1995 meeting with Intel, he said, according to an Intel executive: "This antitrust thing will blow over. We haven't changed our business practices at all."
Microsoft insists that its corporate culture is one of "constructive paranoia," insuring that it does not lose its competitive edge. Besides, Microsoft's legal team argues, inflammatory E-mail and unguarded comments have no standing in an antitrust case, which should be based on facts and figures.
"The antitrust laws are not a code of civility in business," John L. Warden, Microsoft's lead trial lawyer, told the court in his opening statement.
In the weeks since, however, Microsoft has introduced its own evidence -- including E-mail from rivals planning to gang up to "kill the beast from Redmond" -- to try to show that Microsoft's swagger and style are not unusual among high-technology companies.
Still, antitrust experts say that the corporation's character could prove important because the Government is trying to show a pattern of illegal behavior by Microsoft over years. If the Government wins, it could argue for far stronger sanctions against Microsoft than were anticipated at the start of the trial.
"It could prove to be one of the strongest cards the Justice Department has to play," said Robert Litan, a former senior official in the Justice Department's antitrust division, now at the Brookings Institution. "Justice is arguing that Microsoft is a recidivist, which has consistently shown a disregard for the antitrust laws. They are trying to convince the judge that he should deliver a strong guilty verdict and then do something big and substantial so Microsoft won't do it again."
Microsoft scoffs at such reasoning, asserting that the Government has simply not mounted much of a case. "The Justice Department has presented no critical mass of evidence against Microsoft," said William H. Neukom, senior vice president for law and corporate affairs. "There is no monopoly. There is no predatory pricing. There is no illegal tying of one product to another. Microsoft's contracts have not foreclosed other companies from distributing their products."
The Government's case, most antitrust experts agree, is a mixed bag of stronger and weaker claims -- all of which Microsoft will try to refute when it begins its defense next week.
The Justice Department, these experts say, seems to have done best in establishing that Microsoft has a monopoly in personal computer operating systems and has imposed restrictive contracts on computer makers and Internet service suppliers.
"The monopoly argument pretty much makes itself, and it certainly looks as if Microsoft has crossed the line in terms of exclusionary contracts," said Carl Shapiro, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley and a former senior official at the Justice Department.
Microsoft's first defense witness, Richard Schmalensee, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will testify that despite its domination of the operating system market, Microsoft does not possess monopoly power. Mr. Schmalensee's rationale is that because of the rapid pace of innovation in the computer industry, Microsoft's dominance could be short-lived as it comes under attack from a variety of new technologies like Sun Microsystems' Java, an Internet programming language that could displace the pivotal role played by Windows.
Many technology experts regard that argument as only half true. "Microsoft is right when it says that its market position is under constant threat," said David Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard business school. But he added, "It would take a long time, a decade or so, to displace an entrenched technology standard like Windows."
The Government asserts that Microsoft's contracts with computer makers and Internet access suppliers unfairly excluded its main rival in the market for Internet browser software, the Netscape Communications Corporation, from key channels of distribution.
For example, America Online testified that it had agreed to make Microsoft's Internet Explorer the preferred browser for its subscribers instead of Netscape's Navigator after Microsoft agreed to give America Online a featured place on the Windows desktop -- an example, the Justice Department asserts, of Microsoft using its operating system monopoly to thwart competition.
Microsoft replies that its contracts are garden-variety business deals. Exclusive contracts with a handful of companies are not illegal, its lawyers say, as long as competitors have open access to many other channels of distribution. Netscape, Microsoft says, has distributed millions upon millions of copies of its browser -- proof that Netscape has not been hampered in any substantial way.
The Government's predatory pricing and product-tying charges, antitrust experts say, are the weaker elements of the case. The Justice Department contends that Microsoft's decision to give its browser away, despite having spent hundreds of millions of dollars developing it, is predatory. But the courts have generally rejected predatory pricing claims. In a landmark 1993 ruling in Brooke Group Ltd. v. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, the Supreme Court declared that "discouraging a price cut does not constitute sound antitrust policy."
Similarly, experts say, the Government's charge that Microsoft illegally tied its browser software to Windows to squelch competition in the browser market will be difficult to prove. Microsoft contends that its browser is an integrated feature of Windows.
Many industry experts have questioned Microsoft's motivation for integrating its browser and operating system, but the courts have been reluctant to meddle in product decisions. In a related case, a Federal appeals court ruled in June that Microsoft could bundle its browser with Windows, noting the "undesirability of having courts oversee product design."
As Microsoft finished its cross-examination of the Government's final witness today, the two sides argued over the issues of bundling and free distribution of Microsoft's browser.
The questioning turned unusually testy as Michael Lacovara, a Microsoft lawyer, asked Franklin M. Fisher, an M.I.T. economist, about the costs associated with giving away the Internet Explorer. Mr. Fisher said that while it might be easier for computer makers and consumers, "this case is not about being easy."
"If Henry Ford had a monopoly, we'd all be driving black cars," he said, his voice slowly rising. "That's not what competition is about. That's not what helping consumers is about. If Microsoft forced upon the world one browser, that would be really simple."
"Now you seem agitated," Mr. Lacovara said.
"I am agitated," Mr. Fisher shot back. "I feel strongly on this point. We're going to live in a Microsoft world. It may be a nice world. But it's not a competitive world."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Recovers From an Early Slide to Close Down 7.21, to 9,537.76

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks retreated from record levels but then rallied in the afternoon and finished little changed in a session marked by some warnings of profit shortfalls and a mildly negative reappraisal by one of Wall Street's most prominent strategists.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.21 points, to 9,537.76, after a slide from the start of trading that put the blue-chip barometer down as much as 118.95 points. The Nasdaq market, down early, even managed to climb back into positive territory to another record, its fifth in a row. It rose 5.23 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 2,326.09. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.61 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,269.73 
 "What we're seeing is backing and filling after a pretty amazing run," said Douglas R. Cligott, chief United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan. And while he called valuations "clearly stretched," he said stocks could keep advancing for at least several weeks as retail investors join portfolio managers in putting cash that builds up at this time of year to work.
J. C. Penney and Borders Group dampened early sentiment by warning of earnings shortfalls. The shares of J. C. Penney fell 3 5/16, to 43; Borders dropped 5 1/16, to 20.
The market also had to digest a reduction in stocks, to 70 percent from 72 percent, in the portfolio mix recommended by Abby Joseph Cohen, the widely followed chief strategist at Goldman, Sachs. This was the first change since Sept. 1, when Ms. Cohen raised her equity weighting from 65 percent.
"Equity valuation is less attractive today than in September," she said, "but we do not view valuation as excessive nor as an impediment to higher stock prices." She suggested moving money from stocks to higher-yielding corporate bonds, whose allocation she raised to 12 percent from 10 percent.
Also bringing down the market were comments made by Alice Rivlin, vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, who said that one must be "extremely optimistic about earnings to justify" current stock prices.
And while European markets were moderately lower, Brazilian stocks dropped 5.14 percent on fresh setbacks to efforts to bring the budget under control.
But when the combined weight of these developments failed to severely buckle the market, analysts said, buyers stepped in and prices mostly recovered.
"We continue to have a very favorable environment for equities," said Leif H. Olsen, a director of Absolute Return Advisors in Manchester, Vt., predicting a stronger economy this year than is generally forecast.
Several financial stocks stood out today, among them Citigroup, which surged 4 1/8, to 58 1/2, making the biggest positive contribution to the Dow. Chase Manhattan climbed 3 1/16, to 77 1/16; BankAmerica was up 3 3/16, to 67 9/16, and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter climbed 3 1/2, to 84 3/16.
The main drag on the Dow was Procter & Gamble, which fell 2, to 90 7/8, as it lost a top executive in its Asian operations to Kellogg.
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advancing ones by 1,954 to 1,142 as volume eased to 863 million shares, from 986.9 million on Wednesday.
In the bond market, the prices of Treasury issues fell as the dollar weakened. The price of the 30-year bond fell 30/32, to 100 14/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.22 percent, from 5.16 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Wall St. Firms Nimbly Handle A Hard Quarter

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Wall Street's major trading houses, buffeted by the financial upheaval that began when Russian markets collapsed in August, are starting to breathe a little easier.
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., two of the country's largest investment banking firms, soundly beat estimates for their fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, the latest sign of how resilient United States financial markets have proved to be in the wake of global economic turmoil. 
 "It's a measure of how quickly firms and markets have turned around since the early fall," said Derek J. Statkevicus, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. "The trading desks have done much better than people expected."
Shares of Citigroup soared $4.125, or almost 7.6 percent yesterday, to $58.50, as investors saw that company's trading operation benefiting from the same financial buoyancy enjoyed by rivals.
Still, Morgan Stanley and Lehman turned in sharply divergent performances, with Morgan producing stellar gains while Lehman's profits were far below those posted in the fourth quarter of 1997. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Morgan Stanley's shares jumped $3.50, or 4.3 percent, to $84.1875, while Lehman's shares rose 50 cents, to $54.125.
Moreover, even though international markets have settled down recently, the fragility of Brazil's economy -- and the financial damage that could be inflicted on the United States should Brazil's situation worsen -- looms over American financial services companies.
"There's a lot of money coming into the market right now and people might be unpleasantly surprised if things turn worse in Brazil," said Judah Kraushaar, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company.
Morgan Stanley, citing a strong results from its securities operation in a year marked by unnerving stock market volatility, said that net income for the fourth quarter ended Nov. 30 rose 51 percent, to $1.2 billion, or $2.07 a share, compared with $810 million, or $1.30 a share, in the period a year earlier.
The fourth quarter of 1998 included a large one-time gain on the sale of some business lines. Excluding that gain, Morgan Stanley's operating earnings still rose 9 percent, to a record $879 million, or $1.49 a share. Analysts had been expecting Morgan to report operating earnings of 96 cents a share in the quarter, according to the consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation. Morgan Stanley posted operating earnings of $626 million, or $1.05 a share, in the third quarter.
Typically, Morgan Stanley's securities business -- which includes securities underwriting, mergers and acquisitions advice, other investment-banking services and retail brokerage activities -- produces the lion's share of the company's profits. The fourth quarter was no exception. Morgan said about half its profit in the quarter came from its securities operation, powered by gains in mergers and acquisitions advice that more than offset an industrywide downturn in underwriting.
Robert Scott, Morgan Stanley's chief financial officer, said that the company's traders "tore the cover off the ball" by moving into Treasury securities and realizing big gains once other investors sought the same safe haven after stock and bond markets around the world went haywire in the late summer and early fall. The company also said that currency and commodities trading generated record results.
Profits from Morgan Stanley's asset-management business were up smartly in the quarter compared with 1997, though down compared with the third quarter, when the company registered losses on some troubled investment funds it was forced to bail out. The company's Discover credit card operation still lacks the scale to compete effectively with the larger credit card businesses controlled by competitors, but Morgan Stanley said it was planning to devote substantial resources to expanding the card business, particularly overseas.
Over all, Morgan Stanley is one of the few financial-services companies, with the exception of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, that appear to have navigated last year's unpredictable financial shoals successfully. "It's a very, very powerful company," said John Keefe, president of Keefe Worldwide, a financial-services consulting firm in New York.
Lehman, on the other hand, has had a far rougher time, largely because it does not dominate as many businesses as Morgan Stanley does and because it is still overly reliant on its large bond underwriting and trading operation -- a reliance that can hammer the company if it plays the bond markets incorrectly.
Lehman said it had net income of $74 million, or 51 cents a share, in the fourth quarter ended Nov. 30, down 60 percent from $185 million, or $1.30 a share, in the period a year earlier. Lehman earned $151 million, or $1.10 a share, in the third quarter.
Analysts had expected Lehman to earn 21 cents a share in the quarter and they attributed the surprise to better-than-expected results in its investment-banking business. Still, Lehman said its trading revenues were down sharply because of market volatility in September and October that hurt its bond business.
Lehman noted that even though it had a weak quarter the firm posted record results for the year as a whole. It also said it is optimistic about 1999 because of a recovery in the bond market and a backlog of debt and equity underwritings that should lift the bottom line.
"We're off to a gangbusters start in January, and the fundamentals of a good year are in place," John Cecil, Lehman's chief administrative officer, said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clinton Takes A Middle Path On Steel Curbs

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The White House told Congress tonight that President Clinton would not yet limit imports of foreign steel to the United States, despite the demands of steel unions and some producers, but would take a range of lesser actions intended to aid the industry.
In a report to Congress submitted days after a Congressional deadline while Mr. Clinton and his economic team debated the politically charged issue, the White House said it would seek to extend a $300 million tax break for steel producers. That may provide some modest relief to the companies, but would be only of indirect help to the United Steelworkers of America, the politically powerful union that had demanded sharp limits on Russian, Japanese, Korean and Brazilian steel that it said is being dumped in the American market. 
 The report also warns Japan, the largest exporter of some kinds of steel, that the Government would begin a broad investigation that could lead to tariffs on many types of Japanese steel if a surge of exports did not abate. Japanese shipments increased more than 400 percent in the first nine months of 1998.
In the end, the Administration stopped short of actually beginning that legal process, called a Section 201 proceeding, which many of the companies had urged in hopes of sending a stronger message to Japan and other nations.
The decision today came after a sharp split in the Administration. Trade officials, led by Commerce Secretary William M. Daley and the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, had urged tougher action. But Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had expressed what he delicately termed "reservations" about strong action, fearing it would send a signal that the United States was shutting off its markets to low-cost imports.
The steel glut was caused in large part by the Asian economic crisis, and encouraging exports by the Asian producers has been a key element of the strategy to get their nations back on track. The result, however, has been a surging trade deficit in the United States, as inexpensive foreign goods flood into the country.
"This has been a constant balancing act," a senior Administration official said tonight, "between trying to help the industry and the workers, without sending out a chilling message around the world."
The White House tax proposal would essentially permit American steel producers to write off losses against taxes paid in the previous five years, rather than against taxes the previous two years. The industry would save about $300 million, the Treasury estimates.
But that is a token amount compared with the losses caused by low-cost steel. And it is unlikely to end the debate over what kind of actions Washington should take, especially if layoffs continue in the steel industry.
The arguments over what to do about steel have been the source of several meetings at the White House involving Mr. Clinton, Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Rubin and in some cases Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
But the Administration found that its legal options were limited. It could not impose quotas, which are illegal under World Trade Organization rules. It was even reluctant to enter into "voluntary trade restraint" agreements, of the kind that used to govern auto and machine-tool trade with Japan. Those agreements, too, are now subject to challenge under international trading rules.
Nonetheless, members of the Congressional Steel Caucus have urged the Administration to negotiate voluntary restraint agreements with foreign producers, arguing that no countries are likely to challenge the accords in front of the World Trade Organization.
But the United Steelworkers and its president, George Becker, have gone further, urging outright quotas. They are powerful in Washington, and neither Mr. Clinton nor Mr. Gore, who needs their support in his bid for the Presidential nomination, wanted to alienate them. The report to Congress says that Mr. Clinton will appoint a White House official to speed "trade adjustment assistance" already legislated for steelworkers who have been laid off.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Carpet of Contempt

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
So here we are at the U.N. A half-century ago it was created to keep peace and expand freedom, not a feckless dream but a reachable goal dear to the United States, the key founding member.
Now the U.N. is carpeted in contempt for the U.S., for failure to use either its material power or what remains of its intellectual power to eliminate a minor dictator with major plans for mass slaughter. 
 The case of Secretary General Kofi Annan is part of the change at the U.N.
Power voids are filled, quickly. Mr. Annan moved into the emptiness created by the failure of American leadership against Saddam Hussein. He brought into his expanding role great charm and wit, and a clear concept of how to handle Saddam -- with diligent appeasement.
By himself, he has become Saddam's greatest single asset at the U.N. And with Russia, China, France and other countries "sympathetic to Iraqi sentiments," as it is put at the U.N., he is part of an active coalition, along with selected top members of the huge U.N. bureaucracy.
The coalition is determined to whittle U.N. arms inspection down to a useless splinter and lift U.N. economic sanctions on Iraq. That would open the road for Saddam to reach his goal of chemical, nuclear and biological weapons.
Don't worry, the coalition says, look at how many countries already have the weapons and don't use them. Concentrate on all the potential trade with Iraq.
This coalition does not exist because of its own strength. It exists because of the absence of American strategy for either eliminating Saddam's weapons potential or eliminating him.
With its three-day missile attacks, followed immediately by thinning out American strength in the region, Washington does not fool itself, Saddam or the U.N., and certainly not Mr. Annan.
Mr. Annan is sometimes a subtle man. I do not know what motivates him to try to appease Saddam. Possibly belief that unless somebody steps in, American policy will lead to disaster for all. Possibly the deep layer of third-world allegiances at the U.N.
But his techniques are not subtle. Each time Saddam ties up or throws out U.N. inspection, in violation of its peace agreement with the U.N., Mr. Annan waits awhile. Then after lots of secret hocus-pocus he pulls out the solution -- a new agreement in which Saddam again promises to cooperate with inspection, and again gets a good-boy reward, a weaker inspection system more acceptable to Iraq, for awhile.
A few months later, promise broken, same Annan show of compassion, the same hocus-pocus solution and promises; so on.
The Clinton Government does not criticize him. After all, it fought to get him named Secretary General, and usually gives its approval before and after his routines with Saddam.
Even when he praised Saddam's Government for its "wisdom, courage and flexibility" in February 1998 there was no criticism -- not even when he signed a "Memo of Understanding" with Iraq endorsing Saddam's indispensable lie. The memo says that "paramount" to the people and Government of Iraq is removal of sanctions against Iraq. Mr. Annan knows sanctions would quickly be eased and ended if Saddam carried out his 1991 promises to reveal his concealed weaponry and plans, within 15 days.
The reports from the inspectors headed by Richard Butler of Australia reveal Saddam's concealment. That is why Mr. Annan and Iraq are so intent about weakening the commission, why stories are floated that Mr. Butler's inspectors are U.S. spies -- to weaken the inspectorate so badly that Mr. Butler will resign.
As long as those Butler reports keep coming, Mr. Annan and other Iraq friendlies know the U.S. will veto lifting of sanctions. Probably -- is that creaking and cracking we hear in Washington's support for sanctions against the Iraqi tyranny?
The American public, as always, must share responsibility with its elected Government on what it does or does not do.
Despite the reports by U.N. inspectors about Saddam's concealment, despite his decision to force Iraqis to suffer sanctions rather than reveal his weapons of mass destruction, Americans seem entirely relaxed.
Yes, there was the World Trade Center bombing. But you don't really think terrorists would also use anthrax over here, actually use it?
