HEADLINE: In the End, Most Retailers Had a Happy Holiday

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
What was supposed to be a good season for retailers turned out to be a great one instead as last-minute and post-holiday shopping propelled December sales gains to their highest in half a decade, according to figures released yesterday by merchants.
Fears that the impeachment of President Clinton, the bombing of Iraq and unseasonably warm weather would dampen holiday buying turned out to be unfounded. The humming of the strong economy -- the best real-wage growth since 1985 and an impressive end-of-year rebound by the stock market -- was the only tune Americans seemed to hear. "Consumer confidence has remained outrageously high," said David Blitzer, the chief economist at Standard & Poor's. 
 In all, same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, a standard industry measure, rose 5.2 percent, according to the Goldman Sachs Retail Composite Index. Last year, December same-store sales rose a hardy 4.1 percent, but not since 1994, when retailers posted a 5.6 percent gain, has the growth been so robust. Richard Baum, a retail analyst with Goldman, Sachs, said, "You are not going to hear too many retailers complaining that Santa Claus was not kind to them."
But, in what is becoming a seasonal pattern, shoppers kept merchants waiting until the last minute to deliver the good news. Three weeks into the season, retailers were reporting solid but not stellar numbers. The week before Christmas, however, had the four busiest shopping days of the year, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers.
Jay Allen, a spokesman for Wal-Mart Stores Inc., said: "We had a good holiday period, but it was late in coming. The week before Christmas we saw a real spike in business." Mr. Allen said that although late buying had clearly become a characteristic of the Christmas season, it was also part of a larger trend. "People are generally buying closer to need; back-to-school is another good example," he said.
Mr. Allen's description of Wal-Mart's sales as "good" was modest to say the least. Discounters continued to reign supreme among merchants. And Wal-Mart, the largest retailer in the world, could have powered the holiday season increases practically by itself with a same-store sales increase of 9.4 percent. Right behind Wal-Mart were Target, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, and Family Dollar Stores Inc., with increases of about 7 percent each.
And after shoppers got their cut-price scented candles and Furbies, there was still plenty of money left to spread around other sectors. Jewelers, from the upscale Tiffany & Company to the mass-marketer Zale Corporation, had sparkling seasons as shoppers snapped up diamond-stud earrings and gold bracelets. Specialty stores, led by the Gap Inc., whose sales rose 19 percent, also had reason to celebrate.
Even many of the department store chains, which were pummeled in recent years, fared well this season. In particular, Federated Department Stores Inc., which owns Bloomingdale's and Macy's, announced a startling same-store sales rise of 5.7 percent, compared with a 1 percent rise last year. Carol Sanger, vice president for corporate affairs, could not help but brag a bit. "At the beginning of the year, after last year's disappointing holiday season, we really sat down and made a concerted effort to develop strategies for this Christmas selling period," she said. "And apparently it worked."
Ms. Sanger said that the company had been especially successful with gift-giving promotions that highlighted select items with careful packaging and heavy promotion. Packages of fruit preserves and jellies nestled in wooden crates and matched berry-colored sweater sets were big hits, for example.
Not everyone did well, however. J. C. Penney Company saw same-store sales slide a whopping 7.6 percent despite its own preseason forecast of a rise of 1 percent to 2 percent. Theda Page Whitehead, J. C. Penney's public relations manager, blamed warm weather and a spate of early retirements in 1997 that left the company with 500 to 600 new store managers.
Toys "R" Us Inc. ended a disastrous year with a drubbing as discounters cut further into its territory, particularly on electronic toys. "There was a lack of hot toys," said the company's chief financial officer, Louis Lipschitz. Nordstrom Inc. will not release its sales figures until the end of its fourth quarter, but analysts were predicting same-store numbers for December would be down by 5 percent to 7 percent. The company would not comment on its performance.
The next question is whether the sales announcements will translate into solid earnings. In recent years, merchants have been forced to cut prices to attract increasingly demanding customers. The result is that increased sales come at the sacrifice of profit. This year, the promotional environment was as fierce as ever, but retailers said they anticipated that and planned accordingly.
Many retail analysts are optimistic that profits will be solid when earnings are announced in several weeks. Jeff Feiner, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, said: "On balance, the companies that did very well -- the Wal-Marts, Costcos and the Targets -- did not give away the store. We believe profitability was very good."
Bruce Van Kleeck, president of the National Retail Federation, said he also expected overall profits would be good but added a note of caution. "Many retailers had planned high markdowns," he said. "But I am not sure quite so high" as they eventually took.
Sue Wollan Fan, a partner with Andersen Consulting's global retail practice, was even more skeptical. "It is a mixed bag of the desperates and the deliberates," she said of the stores that engaged in heavy price cutting. "Not everyone who got good sales figures is going to make it to the winner's circle when earnings are announced."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Lockout Left Many Cash Drawers Locked

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Through the 191-day National Basketball Association lockout, the economic losers were not only the players and the owners. There are the television networks that lost lucrative programming and the advertisers who lost a reliable way to reach young male viewers.
There are the arenas that lost revenues and were hamstrung from booking other events; broadcasters who were not paid, like Bob Papa, the Nets' radio voice, and hotels and restaurants that lost patronage from teams and fans. 
 "By the time a sold-out crowd here buys tickets, food and novelties, they've spent $1 million per game," said Richard Krezwick, president of the Fleet Center, the Boston Celtics' home.
There are the companies that make and sell T-shirts, jackets and replica uniforms licensed by the N.B.A., a $3 billion retail business in good times.
There are the concession workers, vendors, security guards and ushers -- some paid hourly wages, some paid on commission.
"I didn't rely on this income," said Ed Piseck, 30, who made about $100 a month as a bartender at McNichols Arena, home of the Denver Nuggets. "I just used it to pay off debt and for the new baby's college fund."
Millions of dollars have been rebated to season ticket-holders for unplayed November and December games. More will be refunded next month for January. Millions of dollars more were lost by retailers who cut back on N.B.A.-licensed merchandise the fans were avoiding. "All over, there were double-digit drops in sales," said Chris McEvoy, editor in chief of Sporting Goods Business.
The television networks that carry N.B.A. games refocused their programming. TNT and TBS, the Turner Sports cable networks, will have lost 50 telecasts through the end of January, and have filled the gaps since November with films.
NBC replaced its Christmas doubleheader in part with the movie "It's a Wonderful Life" and will fill its planned January telecasts with taped golf, skiing and other events. The Fox Sports Net has used classic N.B.A. games and other programs to replace 546 of about 1,000 games it would normally carry through local cable deals with 26 of the 29 N.B.A. teams.
"It will be a down year," predicted Neal Pilson, a sports consultant, "but better to have a down year that's a half-season than no season at all."
How much fan apathy will affect viewership and attendance is unknown. The uncertainty of post-lockout viewing is compounded by worries about Michael Jordan's status.
One of Jordan's newest enterprises, a $50 coffee-table book with high expectations called "For the Love of the Game," has underperformed, said Mary Ellen Keating, a spokeswoman for Barnes & Noble. "It's doing O.K., but people thought he'd be doing promotions," she said. Michael Jordan Cologne sold well in department stores and foreign markets during the lockout, but faltered in sporting-goods stores. "Fortunately, from the start, we created and positioned Michael Jordan Cologne as a celebrity-designer fragrance, instead of marketing it as a sports fragrance," said Sally Yeh, president of Bijan Fragrances, the scentmaker.
The league and players will have to woo disaffected fans, but they will move directly into a season, an edge it has over major league baseball, which endured an off-season and a spring training with replacement players before resuming normal operations after the 1994 strike.
"The wounds will heal by playing games," said Jon Spoelstra, a marketing consultant and former Nets president. "The league's greatest promotion would be for Michael to come back. A farewell tour would be a great marketing tool."
A lot of advertising and merchandising dollars are at stake. J. C. Penney, the largest retailer of N.B.A.-licensed merchandise, will wait until the season starts to advise its stores on restocking goods. Business fell by 70 percent in markets with N.B.A. teams.
"How the teams do may be the gauge," said Stephanie Brown, a Penney's spokeswoman. "I don't think they'll immediately call suppliers to order a ton of merchandise."
Michael Modell, co-president of the Modell's chain, said his N.B.A. business shrank substantially but the stores survived well with hot-selling Jets and Yankees merchandise.
"We'll have to wait a while to order more because so many players don't know where they'll be playing," he said.
Recently, Sporting Goods Business reported that N.B.A.-licensed business was down by nearly 50 percent for the fall and holiday season and orders would tumble by 80 percent for the spring. The magazine forecast a smaller drop for basketball sneakers, which were already in a sales retreat in the past few years.
"When there are no games, retailers don't reorder, they discount and get the merchandise the heck out," said Frank Vuono, a former N.F.L. Properties executive who is the president of Integrated Sports International, a New Jersey-based sports marketing firm.
Reebok's basketball shoe sales, led by Allen Iverson's $115 signature brand, are down by 8 to 10 percent.
"We produced 40 percent less of the Iverson product than last year," said Shawn Neville, senior vice president and general manager of Reebok North America.
As much as the lockout compelled fans, owners, players, television executives, capmakers, retailers and shoe retailers to contemplate a season without the N.B.A., it made part-time workers mull their low-profile plights.
Sam Gottlieb, 28, said his family's four parking lots near the Fleet Center in Boston have lost $200,000 without Celtics games. "Everyone loses," he said. "You just go on, you know? You hope it comes back."
Pam Morgan, 46, a part-time luxury suite attendant at America West Arena in Phoenix, earned extra money to give to her daughter, a college student. During a Coyotes hockey game Tuesday night, Morgan said: "If they don't care about the little peon, they sure should. If it wasn't for us, they wouldn't be employed."

HEADLINE: Foes of L.I. Mansion Lose a Zoning Battle

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. Jan. 7

 BODY:
The battle of the billionaire versus the millionaires came to a head at Town Hall here tonight, and the billionaire won. For now, at least.
Ira Rennert, a reclusive industrialist who enraged residents here with his plan to erect a five-building, $100 million complex on 63 acres, will be allowed to continue construction in an oceanside potato field in the back reaches of Sagaponack, the Zoning Board of Appeals ruled. The project, which would cover more than 100,000 square feet, is to include a 72,000-square-foot main residence that Mr. Rennert says is to be a single-family home. 
 About 50 people who attended the board's meeting at Town Hall tonight sighed as Edward Rush, the board's chairman, announced that the permits given to Mr. Rennert were valid. "Denial of a land use permit based solely on community opposition is impermissible," Mr. Rush said.
He added that the number of bathrooms (40), refrigerators (5, industrial) and bowling alleys (2) were not inconsistent with a large oceanfront mansion.
Linda Francke, a writer and not a millionaire who lives cater-corner to the site, was resigned. "In my mind it's welcome to the neighborhood," she said. "I always thought we were just whistling in the wind."
Opponents of the project said that the five-member zoning board, appointed by the Town Supervisor, Vincent Cannuscio, gave in to Mr. Rennert's deep pockets. Mr. Rennert's Renco Group was listed by Forbes magazine in 1997 as the 51st largest private company in America.
Mr. Cannuscio had sided with townspeople who wanted the project stopped, but reversed his position when a town lawyer warned Southampton that it would face a costly lawsuit it could not win if it tried to revoke permits that had already been issued.
The plan for the home -- which would be larger than San Simeon, or twice the size of the White House -- galvanized opponents who charged that Mr. Rennert's claim that the home would be occupied only by himself, his wife and his two adult daughters was a scheme to evade building and environmental regulations.
Albert Bialek, president of the Sagaponack Homeowners Association, which has raised $70,000 to prevent Mr. Rennert from blocking his and his neighbors' view of the ocean, asked how Mr. Rennert could call "a development with 6 outbuildings, a power plant, parking for 200 cars, 40 bathrooms, 29 bedrooms, 165 seat movie theater, a restaurant kitchen with five refrigerators and a grease trap of 1,500 gallons, two bowling alleys, a 3 million B.T.U. furnace, foot-thick walls and a network of underground tunnels a one-family home?"
"Yeah, sure," he said. "And I'm the King of Siam."
Mr. Bialek said he and 60 other residents would meet to plot their next move, most likely a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in Riverhead.
It is a move that Mr. Rennert's lawyers anticipate. "This is a single family home," said one of the lawyers, Anthony Tohill. "It is a big single-family home, but it is a single-family home nevertheless. I can see this thing is going to be in litigation for years, you can bet on that."
Last night, the speculation was thick at Town Hall as residents wondered whether Mr. Rennert, a New York businessman with a passion for Orthodox Jewish causes, was planning some sort of bunker or religious complex.
"What's it for?" asked Carolyn Hendrickson, a retired librarian who has lived in Southampton for more than 30 years. "Does he think in the year 2000 he and his associates will have to hole up in the ground? Is he expecting some cataclysm? Is it going to be a religious school or retreat of some kind? I don't trust him."
According to officials at Barney Skanska, the international construction firm handling the project, the concrete foundations of Mr. Rennert's home have been poured, and the setting of the steel girders will begin next month.
"It's a private residence for a man and his family and everything is up to code," said Edward P. Costello, senior vice president with the company. "Last time I checked, the flag still flies over this country, and the man has a right to build his home."
Not everyone in Southampton was upset by Mr. Rennert's plans. While the town is famous as an enclave of the rich and famous -- the author Kurt Vonnegut has a home here, as do Edwin and Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg, the writer Peter Matthiessen, the actor Roy Scheider and the director Andre Gregory -- residents who live here year round and scrape out a living doing odd jobs and construction, are in some ways glad to see the house going up. It means more work for them.
"It's putting money into the local economy," said Michael O'Shea, a carpenter from East Hampton who was working on a neo-colonial home not far from the Fair Field site, as Mr. Rennert calls it. "The fishermen are having a bad time. And most of the wealthy people pack it in for the winter and go elsewhere. The money's important to working men."
Mr. Costello said his company has hired union truck drivers, landscapers, sanitation workers and well diggers from the area.
A security guard who patrols the property is a local police officer.
Opponents of the mansion said they were disappointed at the low turnout on this cold January evening. They figured that many homeowners had gone away for the winter.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Orders Increase

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Orders placed with United States manufacturers rose six-tenths of a percent in November, the fifth increase in six months, as domestic demand offset weak exports, Commerce Department figures showed today.
The gain was led by metals, electronic instruments and chemicals. Orders dropped for textiles, electronic parts and lighting equipment. Orders fell 1.7 percent in October. 
 In another sign of economic strength, the number of workers applying for state unemployment benefits declined last week, the Labor Department said.
First-time claims fell by 22,000 in the week ended Saturday to a seasonally adjusted 350,000. The four-week average for jobless claims -- a less volatile gauge than the weekly figure, rose to 327,750, from 322,250 the previous week.
Jobless claims have fluctuated in recent weeks because of seasonal employment, reduced filing days, and other circumstances surrounding the holidays, analysts said.
For 1998, weekly claims averaged 317,208, compared with 321,135 in 1997 and 350,442 in 1996. The total number of people collecting unemployment benefits in 1998 averaged 2.215 million a week, down from 2.295 million in 1997 and 2.549 million in 1996.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Next Step Is Courting The Fans

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
After the National Basketball Association's 29 owners officially insured labor peace for the next six years, Commissioner David Stern was asked if he was bluffing when he said he would scrap the season. "You didn't pay to find out," he said, smiling.
In the same hotel conference room where the owners were scheduled to vote on canceling the season, they instead unanimously ratified a new collective bargaining agreement with the players as the league continued its kiss-and-make-up tour yesterday. 
 Flanked by his deputy commissioner, Russ Granik, and Billy Hunter, the union's executive director, Stern shed some light on an abbreviated season while also making a plea for renewed fan support.
"We are painfully aware of the beating that professional athletes and teams have taken at the hands of the public," he said. "We have talked about changing the paradigm. We have talked to teams about understanding the history and what is going on. This is the next step in that process. I ask you to judge us in a year."
Stern said the season would start on Feb. 5, and teams will play 50 games, most of which will be intraconference, though details are being worked out. If Michael Jordan returns, the chance for many Western Conference cities to see him are slim.
"In terms of the schedule, I am sure that what we will end up with is one that is much more conference-oriented than what we normally have, largely for travel reasons," Granik said. "Teams will play most of their games, the vast majority, within their own conference, although there will be some interconference play. A team from the East may play only five or six teams from the West. That is just the way the numbers are going to break out."
In a quest to win back fans, each team plays one exhibition game at home and another on the road, with no admission charged.
Stern added that beginning next season, at least 500 tickets for every regular-season game would be held until game time and priced at $10 each.
The expected outcome at the N.B.A. board of governors meeting came after players had approved the deal, by a vote of 179 to 5, on Wednesday. The lockout will remain until the agreement is in written form, which could take 10 days.
Concerned over the shape that players would be in, the union and the league agreed to open team facilities on Monday. Players will be allowed to work with trainers, but not directly with coaches. The hope was that the agreement could be reduced to writing by lawyers by next week and the free-agent signing period would begin by Jan. 18.
The regular season will last through April, with the playoff format unchanged. Granik said the N.B.A. finals should conclude by June 29 or 30.
"We're glad this is over,"' Hunter said. "Our players are anxious to play, and we're anxious to join hands with David, Russ and the owners of the 29 teams to really create a strong and familial relationship -- one that will take the N.B.A. to another level and to bring back the fans.
"The only regret I have is that it took us so long to get where we are. We're glad to be back, and we'll do whatever we have to do in order to demonstrate that."
The most debilitating labor war in league history cost the players nearly $500 million in salaries. It ended Wednesday morning after an all-night, 12-hour negotiating session at the league offices.
The owners emerged with the unprecedented concession of a maximum limit on individual salaries.
The days of one or two players gobbling up a team's salary cap and making it impossible for a franchise to sign a third star may be on the wane. Also, a player's need for a prominent agent to get him the most lucrative deal possible seemed to be reduced. But as to whether it would dramatically change N.B.A. economics, Stern was not prepared to say.
"There is no certainty for us with respect to payrolls," Stern said. "That said, it was very important for us to come up with a formula where teams could remain competitive. For us that was the essence of what a sports league is -- competition. We think that this is going to eliminate the movement because of economic disparity.
Asked about the impact of the deal on agents, Hunter said: "I don't think this agreement is going to in any way negate the need for agents. Obviously, when you're trying to keep 400, 500 ballplayers solidified, I still think there is going to be a great need for agents."
Beyond agents, general managers as well as league and team lawyers are going to be busy beginning Jan. 18. Three weeks of trades and free-agent signings are expected to significantly alter the playoff picture. More than 200 free agents will be bid upon, including Scottie Pippen, Dennis Rodman, Charles Barkley, Antonio McDyess and Jayson Williams.
Once the games start, players will be faced with an exhausting schedule until the playoffs begin. Teams will be asked on occasion to play three games in three nights, something that has not happened in the last 10 years.
"I'm sure it is going to be a mad scramble," Stern said.
To insure NBC and Turner are compensated for missed games -- the networks paid a combined $23 million to each team as part of their broadcasting agreement -- several interconference games will be retained.
As the league tried to put back the pieces yesterday, though, worrying about television seemed almost trite. "We're glad to be back in the basketball business again," Granik said.
 Hunter sat with his arms folded for most of the press conference, happy to let Stern explain why the two sides waged such a bitter fight for six months. After the last question was asked, the two adversaries shook hands. Lawyers who had traded angry words during the dispute joked and shook hands.
For a moment, the logistical nightmare of putting together a 50-game season in 12 weeks did not seem so daunting.
"We're doing this a bit on the run," Granik said. "We're happy to be planning the season. We were planning for a nonseason."

HEADLINE: Boeing Received Orders for 656 Planes in '98

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company, the world's leading commercial aircraft maker, announced last night that it had received orders for 656 planes in 1998, 15 percent more than the 568 ordered a year earlier.
But the value of the 1998 orders totaled $42.1 billion, compared with $42.8 billion in 1997, because the company sold more narrow-body jets last year, which are less expensive than its wide-body models. 
 It was also unclear whether Boeing's orders for 1998 surpassed those of Airbus Industrie, its only rival in the commercial aircraft business.
The European consortium, which is to release 1998 production and delivery figures on Monday, had more than 500 orders as of the end of November.
Hurt by the economic slump in Asia and a litany of production and delivery problems, Boeing sought to put the best face on its annual production and delivery data. In a news release hours after the stock market had closed, Boeing said the figures showed it "continued to increase its presence in the worldwide fleet in 1998, delivering more than two of every three commercial airlines of 100 seats or more."
Although Boeing releases airplane orders monthly, the figures released last night are the most comprehensive for the year and include some previously unannounced orders.
But the figures also illustrate that while the company's order backlog remains healthy, fewer customers are purchasing its most expensive and profitable airplanes.
The Seattle-based company said it expected to deliver a record 620 aircraft in 1999, surpassing the record of 563 last year.
Boeing also said it has delivered nearly 12,500 commercial jets, accounting for about three of every four jets in service.
Boeing was hampered by production problems throughout 1998. Late last year it said it expected to trim 48,000 of its 233,000 employees worldwide through 1999.
Its share price, which hit a 1998 high of $50 in July, has traded as low as $30.875. It closed yesterday at $35.8125 cents, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Take A Wild Rise To New Highs

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The stock market took a volatile ride to new highs yesterday, finishing a week marked by an Internet stock frenzy, a surge in other technology stocks and new economic data that showed the American economy is refusing, so far, to slow down.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which seesawed all day, rallied in the late afternoon to gain 105.56 points, or 1.1 percent, closing at a record 9,643.32. 
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.36 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,275.09. The technology-heavy Nasdaq index climbed 18.32 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 2,344.41. Both were also records.
While some of the highfliers of the technology sector, including Microsoft, Dell Computer, I.B.M. and Netscape Communications, slipped yesterday, the overall sector rose, lead by Cisco Systems and its promise of a new voice and data modem. The broader market was paced by Alcoa, which accounted for about one-third of the Dow's surge, after the company announced better-than-expected earnings, a stock split and a dividend increase. The S.& P. 500's performance was held back by declines in drug and consumer stocks, including Pfizer, Eli Lilly and Coca-Cola.
The Internet frenzy cost some investors a lot of money yesterday. Amazon.com surged 40 1/4, or 25.3 percent, to 199 1/8, and then gave up almost all its gains, finishing up 1 3/8 at 160 1/4. E*Trade, was up 10 13/16, or 16.9 percent, to 74 7/8, before giving back all but 3 9/16 of the day's gain. Still, for the first week of the year Amazon.com was up 49.7 percent and E*Trade 44.6 percent.
"Today was a good indication of why you have to be pretty careful," said Henry Blodget, senior analyst at CBIC Oppenheimer. "These stocks are incredibly volatile. They have spiked here massively and if your time horizon is longer than five minutes you are taking an inordinate amount of risk buying in at this level."
For some, the technology rally is creating a worrisome two-tier market. Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, is positive on technology stocks but concerned about the rest of the market. "We are getting real close to the levels of overvaluation we had in July of last year," he said. "While we are real enthusiastic about tech, we are recommending caution about the rest of the market."
He argued that the tech rally, not including the Internet mania, is powered by several credible forces. One is the improvement in expected demand for computer products since last August. Another is the billions of dollars of cash that portfolio managers and retail investors have on hand to invest. The third is that technology stocks seem to fit nicely into the two possible economic outlooks for this year. In one, the economy slows and interest rates fall but the key technology stocks still produce healthy earnings. In the other, the economy fools most forecasters and does not slow. Technology stocks are perfect here also, Mr. Cliggott said.
The increase of 378,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in December reported yesterday by the Labor Department supports the idea that the economy remains stubbornly strong, despite many forecasts of a slowdown. The job growth was far stronger than the 200,000 consensus forecast.
While the news was welcomed in the stock market, it contributed to weakness in the bond market, where evidence of economic strength often hurts prices. The Treasury's 30-year issue lost 21/32, to 99 24/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.27 percent from 5.22 percent -- its highest in nearly two months.
For the week the Dow was up 5 percent. However, for the last four weeks, the Dow was up 9.3 percent while the S.& P. 500 was up 9.3 percent. And the Nasdaq beat both, rising 15.5 percent.
But the real sign of the market's torrid pace -- and why a breather may be in store -- was the surge since the lows in 1998. The Nasdaq was up 65.2 percent since its Oct. 8 low, while the Dow gained 27.9 percent since Aug. 31 and the S.& P. 500 advanced 33.2 percent since the same date.
But the story of the week was Amazon.com, On Tuesday, it announced that it still had not made a penny in profit. In fact, losses are expected to rise to 18 cents a share in the fourth quarter report, three times the losses a year ago.
That makes no difference, apparently to investors. They are betting the on-line book and music seller is going to be a big winner in the future.
So all they cared about in Tuesday's announcement was the projection that fourth-quarter sales would jump to $250 million, well above forecasts of $175 million.
But those who got in last year have nothing but profits. From the bottom of the technology selloff on Oct. 8, the Nasdaq 100 index, which includes the biggest of the technology heavyweights, has soared 74.8 percent. But Amazon.com was up 457.8 percent.
"The frenetic buying of Internet stocks is going to make the tulip buyers of the 17th century look like value players," said Rick Berry, director of equity research at J. P. Turner & Company in Atlanta.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: CURRENCIES;
Sinking in Buoyant Waters

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Even while the stock market hits new highs, a crucial indicator of foreign confidence in the United States Government and its economy -- the dollar -- has been falling. No one can agree why.
By all the normal measures, it should not be happening. The American economy remains remarkably strong -- President Clinton today was hailing the longest peacetime economic expansion in the 20th century. The huge budget deficit that once was blamed for undercutting the dollar has turned into a surplus that is estimated to hit $76 billion this year. Inflation is practically nonexistent. 
 Yet investors are flocking to the Japanese yen. The dollar has fallen nearly 25 percent against the yen since August even as every indicator suggests Japan will remain the basket case of the world's major economies in 1999.
Last summer the dollar was trading around 145 yen, and many American officials feared it would rise to 160, to the enormous detriment of American exporters. Instead, it was trading around 120 yen by mid-December and bounced around 110 yen this week. What has changed in the fundamentals that are supposed to govern currencies over the long term? Very little.
The dollar did better against European currencies, but it is nonetheless down about 6 percent over the same period against the German mark.
So what is causing all this? It depends on whom you ask, and where they live. Here in the United States some say the cause is the swelling trade deficit. Others say it is the enthusiasm for the euro, the single currency that was introduced this week by 11 European nations. Even though the euro has fallen slightly against the dollar, it seems to be clearly on the way to establishing itself as the world's No. 2 currency. Still others say the dollar's decline is a byproduct of Japan's latest act of financial desperation, an unexpected increase in interest rates that appears to be drawing investors back to Japan, even if many fear the higher rates will further slow Japan's economy.
Ask foreigners, though, and many say the answer is being beamed around the globe 24 hours a day: the impeachment trial of President Clinton. "It's what I hear from friends and clients all over the world," said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist at the Norwest Corporation. "They see the chief executive of the world's greatest power going on trial and equate it to what would happen if that was occurring in their own country. And they conclude, rightly or wrongly, that the U.S. will not be able to provide leadership if things get dicey again."
Just this week, HSBC Securities, part of the HongKong and Shanghai Bank group, warned investors in a report to keep an eye on "political stability" in Washington. It notes that the market calculus is that Mr. Clinton will stay in office -- but of course the market calculus is based on the conventional wisdom blaring from television sets. And the conventional wisdom has been notably wrong at almost every major turn in the last year of handicapping the Washington scandal.
"The quick fix is not likely to be so quick," HSBC concluded, "and the odds could change as well."
To many Americans an impeachment explanation for the dollar's troubles seems outright ridiculous. But the fact of the matter, says Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, is that "there is no wholly rational explanation for this."
As always when currencies lurch in one direction or another, the effects are complex and unpredictable. Some of the decline may simply be a feeling that the sharp rise in the dollar over the previous couple of years had gone too far. American farmers, steelmakers and some big manufacturers have been complaining for over a year that a strong dollar, combined with the collapse of most Asian economies, was killing their business abroad and undermining their efforts to compete with cheap imports. For them a weakening of the dollar is welcome news -- and it perhaps partly explains the stock market's recent surge.
Today the dollar settled at 110.93 yen, down from 111.04 Thursday. It was up slightly against the euro, which fell to $1.15540 from $1.16700.
Still, no one seems to be celebrating at the United States Treasury. There, sharp fluctuations in currencies are viewed as one of the volatile fuels that have fired 18 months of global instability. The countries that linked their currencies to the dollar -- chiefly Thailand and South Korea -- could not sustain the connection as the dollar strengthened, making their products less and less competitive abroad.
Just because a rising dollar was bad news in 1997, though, it doesn't follow that a weakening dollar is necessarily good news in 1999. The world has changed a lot since then.
More than ever, the ground zero of the world's economic troubles is Japan. A bad year for Japan could mean a bad year for the rest of Asia, because there will be no engine of regional growth. And the strengthening of the yen is grim news for Japan's exports -- the best hope Japan has of limping back to growth by the end of this year.
So in a strange way, the Clinton Administration finds itself as worried about what a weak dollar means for Japan as what it means for America.
"We're in this odd position," one senior Administration official said this week. "What looks like good news for us could in fact turn out to be pretty troublesome for the world."
The unresolved question is whether the fall of the dollar and the rise of the yen says more about what investors around the world are thinking about America, or what they are thinking about Japan.
Mr. Sung noted that "America is saving less and less, and that is leading to some pessimism, and it doesn't look like the current account will be turning around soon." The current account is the broadest measure of financial flows.
Also, the talk of declining profits later this year clearly has many investors around the world spooked. These factors, combined with the political uncertainties of impeachment, create nervousness about the champion economy of the 1990's.
But perhaps the more mystifying change of perception concerns Japan.
The country's economic outlook is hardly improved; the best prognosis calls for 1999 to be a lot like 1998. But in one of those oddities that has peppered the Asian financial crisis, interest rates in Japan, which have been at rock bottom, are going up. And that may be luring money back into the country.
The rates are going up because the Japanese Government is issuing bonds with unaccustomed abandon, to finance a growing deficit as it tries to stimulate the economy. The higher rates -- combined with the cuts in American rates several months ago -- have narrowed the previously huge gap between Treasury bonds and Japan's offerings.
More surprising, Japanese officials seem to be encouraging the rising yen. Earlier this week Eisuke Sakakibara, the Finance Ministry official once known as Mr. Yen for his ability to move the markets (an ability that has waned), referred to the American stock market as "bubble like." Mr. Sakakibara has expressed that view many times before, making the argument that the United States today looks like Japan in 1989.
But perhaps Japan's top motivation for tolerating a high yen, no matter the damage it does, is political. The embrace of the euro confirmed a Japanese nightmare -- that years of weakness have undermined the yen's role as the world's second currency. So Japan's politicians, led by Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, are circling the globe this week talking about a currency triumvirate -- the dollar, the euro, the yen. To make that stick, there needs to be a strong yen, not a weak one.

HEADLINE: The Scale of Mr. Trump's Dreams

 BODY:
The normally loquacious Donald Trump has quietly amassed enough real estate and air rights to build an 861-foot-high skyscraper near the United Nations. What he touts as the world's tallest apartment project is too lanky, even for the architectural mishmash of Manhattan's East 40's. His bronze-glass monolith, the equivalent of 90 stories, would dwarf the 39-story U.N. Secretariat and its waterfront park. The project should be scaled back. But for the moment, Mr. Trump appears well positioned to put his signature on New York's skyline anew since his project is as-of-right, or not subject to extensive public review.
The project's legal pedigree does not mean the Giuliani administration should remain on the sidelines. As-of-right status shields a project from a full public review of its impact on air, light and traffic and from assessing wind shear and shadows. But City Hall may have grounds to scale it back, and the Planning Commission can forestall a recurrence. 
 City Hall should review the Buildings Department's approval of Mr. Trump's use of zoning rules that are as tough to decipher as Sanskrit. The agency found that the way he assembled air rights across zoning district boundaries fell within a mid-1980's exception to the ban on such mergers in the city's 1961 zoning code. At issue is whether Mr. Trump merely took maximum advantage of the rules, or flexed them. It should not require months for the city to review whether that judgment was reasonable and in line with how developers operate.
The far thornier task of safeguarding the city's skyline and its neighborhoods falls to the Planning Commission. It should revise the antediluvian zoning code to prohibit any developer from exploiting air rights, plaza bonuses and other zoning tools to create a structure that does not fit the scale of a neighborhood, while allowing reasonable use of air rights to save landmarks, help neighborhoods and promote economic development. Such zoning decisions must remain the province of city government, not neighborhoods or developers.
A Trump executive thinks his boss's project will someday be lauded as a landmark. But Mr. Trump's musings suggest an awareness of the mismatch between the building's scale and the U.N. environs. He said he believed that, had he boasted about his goal before buying the site and air rights, zoning would have been altered to stop him. His intuition should galvanize City Hall and the commission.

HEADLINE: Zalman C. Bernstein, 72, Iconoclastic Broker

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
When he started a securities firm under his own name in 1967, Sanford Charles Bernstein made sure that hurried investors would not fail to notice. To announce the firm, the 41-year-old upstart ran a series of full-page newspaper ads emphasizing in bold, black type a single word: "Bernstein."
The display of hubris drew a wave of titters. The titters turned to gasps when the Brooklyn-born Mr. Bernstein topped himself with a demonstration of chutzpah that is still reverberating on Wall Street. 
 At the time, so-called discretionary accounts, in which a broker makes all the investment decisions without consulting the client, were such an industry scandal that the New York Stock Exchange imposed strict controls and many old-line brokers banned them altogether. But Mr. Bernstein announced that he would seek nothing but discretionary accounts.
Given the potential for abuse by unscrupulous brokers tempted to churn accounts by buying and selling, collecting fees with each transaction, Wall Street laughed off Mr. Bernstein's chances for attracting serious investors.
By the time he died on Wednesday at 72 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Mr. Bernstein had long since had the last laugh.
His brokerage had grown into one of the world's largest independent investment companies, managing more than $80 billion in securities for 25,000 private and institutional clients, and Sanford C. Bernstein & Company had become one of the most respected names on Wall Street -- even as Mr. Bernstein, true to his contrarian ways, had changed his own name.
To honor a late-life surge of interest in his Jewish heritage and his conversion to Orthodox Judaism, he had moved to Jerusalem, established dual American-Israeli citizenship and replaced his "Sanford" and "Charles" with rough Hebrew equivalents, becoming Zalman Chaim Bernstein.
It took more than hubris and chutzpah to make Sanford C. Bernstein & Company a runaway success.
By the time he started the company, Mr. Bernstein had already made something of a name for himself. After enlisting in the Navy at 18 and becoming a Supply Corps officer in World War II, he studied economics and accounting at New York University, picked up a master's degree in business administration at Harvard and spent three years with the Marshall Plan in Europe. He returned to the United States with a French wife and such driving ambition that when the Value Line Investment Survey turned him down for a job, he won one anyway by offering to work without pay.
He later worked as a research analyst, money manager and institutional salesman at Oppenheimer & Company and then spent two years as a partner in a small securities firm, Ralph E. Samuel & Company, before striking off on his own. At first his younger brother, Paul, was his sole partner and he had a total of just seven employees, including his father, Jack, a retired jeweler.
His vision of a firm that would give comparatively small investors the benefits of professional money management was so novel, his brother recalled yesterday, that the Harvard Business School sent a team of student researchers to study the operation. They concluded that the approach was sound but wouldn't work for a Jewish firm.
They were half right. Within a decade, the firm was attracting huge investments from major insurance companies, banks and pension funds and had become known for the exhaustive research reports it sold as a sideline.
Ever the iconoclast, Mr. Bernstein shunned the prevailing system of star portfolio managers and adopted the so-called dividend discount investment model, which bases investment decisions on a formula for determining the value of a company's future earnings.
Since the formula depends on the accuracy of earnings projections, Mr. Bernstein concentrated on the quality of the company's research.
A big, gruff and sometimes unpolished man who wielded a mean cigar, Mr. Bernstein became famous for the pains he took in hiring, putting applicants through a battery of psychological and other tests and sometimes playing backgammon or chess with them to gauge their stomach for competition and cigar smoke.
The rewards of his efforts were considerable for Mr. Bernstein, who continued to be his company's largest shareholder after his retirement in 1993. But he lived modestly after he accepted the warm embrace of the close-knit Orthodox community, and he gave hundreds of millions of dollars to Israeli causes and other charities.
His family said that he died from complications of lymphoma. In addition to his brother, who lives in Manhattan, Mr. Bernstein, who was married three times, is survived by his mother, Martha, of Manhattan; his wife, Mem; a son, Claude, of New Canaan, Conn.; two daughters, Leslie Armstrong and Rochel Leah Bernstein, both of Manhattan, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Growth in Consumer Borrowing Less Than Expected in November

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Borrowing by American consumers increased more slowly than had been expected in November, rising by $3.9 billion, to a total of $1.301 trillion, according to figures released today by the Federal Reserve Board. Analysts had expected an increase of $5.5 billion.
The rate of new borrowing is down from October, when consumer borrowing rose $11.9 billion, according to revised figures. 
 An increase in auto loans in November more than offset a drop in credit card borrowing. Revolving loans, which include credit cards, decreased $700 million in November, after rising $4.6 billion in October. But auto loans rose $4.3 billion, after increasing $2 billion in October.
Other types of installment loans increased $200 million after rising $5.2 billion in October.
Consumer borrowing was rising at a 3.6 percent annual rate during November, down from 11 percent in October.
The unexpectedly low borrowing in November could point to a decline in the rate of consumer spending from last year, said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York. Or, analysts said, borrowing could be declining because the strong economy, with plentiful jobs and rising incomes, strengthened household finances.
But it is also possible that consumer borrowing may actually be rising, but in ways that are not measured by the Federal Reserve's report. With mortgage rates low, consumers have been refinancing homes and taking out home equity loans, which typically carry lower interest rates than credit card borrowing.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asian Stocks Take a Rest From a Dizzying Rally

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The bulls finally stopped stampeding across Asia today, after a week of powerful gains in stock markets from Seoul to Singapore. Analysts seemed almost relieved, since many were alarmed by the growing disparity between the rising markets and Asia's still-sinking economies.
Several experts here worry that the region could face a jolting retrenchment when investors eventually stop for a reality check. 
 "We certainly don't think this rally will extend beyond the second quarter," said Michael M. Sargent, the head of Asia-Pacific equity research at Salomon Smith Barney in Hong Kong. "Asia hasn't had its day of reckoning yet."
Today, stock markets here registered a mixture of modest gains and losses. The relative calm came after a dizzying week in which investors behaved as though the Asian crisis was a memory. Emboldened by record-setting gains in the United States and a stronger Japanese yen, they poured money into shares in Hong Kong, Seoul, Jakarta, Singapore, Taipei and Manila.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index declined by 1.1 percent today, the second consecutive day of losses. Some analysts said the retreat reflected a recognition that the region's markets were out of sync with the underlying economies.
In most of Asia, investors have barely paused to catch their breath since shares first began moving up in September. The region's markets have sustained the rally in the face of a relentless stream of dismal economic news, a situation that has left economists and portfolio managers here baffled.
"I'm really ready to throw in the towel and say, 'Nothing matters anymore but positive investor sentiment,' " said Mac Overton, a portfolio manager at MBF Unit Trust in Hong Kong. "The stock market has continued to increase despite three straight quarters of lower corporate earnings."
Mr. Overton noted that in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index rose even after China issued an unexpectedly bleak prognosis for its economy in 1999. The Chinese Government said that lackluster demand would weaken its domestic economy, while the regional crisis would cause its exports to falter.
"The negative implications of these problems for this year's economic performance should not be underestimated," the Government said.
How did Hong Kong, which depends so heavily on China, react to the warning? Investors drove the Hang Seng 4.5 percent higher on Thursday and a further three-tenths of a percent today. Analysts said shareholders disregarded the news from China and instead pinned their hopes on a cut in local interest rates.
After trading ended today, the Hong Kong Association of Banks announced that it would lower its benchmark short-term savings deposit rate to 4 percent from 4.25 percent. Some analysts said the announcement might disappoint investors, who had been expecting a deeper reduction.
In Jakarta, investors were distracted from Indonesia's continuing economic calamity by a new state budget proposed by President B. J. Habibie. Unlike previous budgets, Mr. Habibie's proposal, economists said, represented a realistic plan to deal with Indonesia's stagnant economy, spiraling inflation and weak currency.
Beyond these local factors, experts noted that Asia's stock markets were now largely propelled by such external forces as rate cuts by the Federal Reserve in the United States and the strengthening Japanese yen.
"The turnaround of the yen has been a big help for the rest of Asia," said Dong Tao, a regional strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston in Hong Kong. "It has reduced the risk of currency volatility in the rest of Asia, which has allowed markets like Hong Kong to cut their own interest rates."
Yet some analysts wonder how much more Asian countries can rely on rate cuts to jump-start their economies. In the last three months, Hong Kong has cut rates five times, Singapore three times and Thailand more than a dozen times. Even with low rates in Thailand, economists said the Government had not been able to reignite consumer demand or corporate investment.
Moreover, many experts doubt that the Japanese yen will maintain its strength. The yen has been bolstered in recent days by the introduction of the euro, which has diverted some investment capital from the United States to Europe. Late today, the yen traded at roughly 110 yen to the dollar. That makes the yen about 26 percent more valuable than in early August, when it traded at a nearly eight-year low of 147.66. But Mr. Sargent predicted that as the novelty of the euro wore off -- and the extent of Japan's economic ills re-emerged -- the yen would resume its downward spiral, reaching 140 to the dollar by late summer.
To some experts, the most damaging potential side effect of the rally is that it could breed complacency on the part of Asian governments, prompting them to delay or scrap needed economic changes.
"Legislators and decision makers may conclude that they don't have to act," said Jim Walker, chief economist of CLSA Global Emerging Markets in Edinburgh. "People could start to think the stock market is a precursor to a genuine recovery, and that's just wrong."
Mr. Walker noted that the Japanese stock market experienced a similar rebound after Japan's economic collapse in 1989 and 1990. Several months later, after Tokyo failed to deal with the country's growing financial crisis, the Nikkei reversed and plunged to new lows.
"We're into uncharted waters here because Japan was running huge budget surpluses before its crisis," Mr. Walker said. "I don't think the clock will keep ticking as long for the rest of Asia as it did for Japan."

HEADLINE: HIRING LAST MONTH KEPT A BRISK PACE

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Despite an unsettled global economy, lower corporate profits and a new round of layoffs, the American economy keeps creating jobs at an astonishing pace.
In December, the number of workers on payrolls grew by 378,000, the biggest gain in more than a year, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The unemployment rate edged down a tenth of a point from November, to 4.3 percent, matching the 28-year low set in April. 
 The last time unemployment was this low for any significant period was in 1969 during the height of the Vietnam War. The last time it was this low in peacetime was in 1957 when the first baby boomers were in the fifth grade and Dwight Eisenhower was in the White House.
The report contributed to another big rally on Wall Street, where major stock indexes finished at record highs. Page C1.
The December job results were helped by balmy weather in the North and East, which postponed the construction layoffs usual for that time of year. Further, a few statistical flukes probably inflated the figures a bit.
But signs of strength were impressive and widespread, reflecting robust spending by consumers and home buyers, who account for nearly three-fourths of economic activity. Among job seekers, the most disadvantaged groups -- blacks and teenagers -- had the biggest gains, and wage increases were strongest among the lowest-paid workers.
"If the economy is an eight-cylinder car, it's running on nine,' said David Blitzer, chief economist at the Standard & Poor's Corporation. "A little may be special factors like weather, but there's a lot of strength there."
The job market strength, which shows that the widely anticipated economic slowdown has yet to happen, caught forecasters off guard. After a wave of corporate layoff announcements and a surge in first-time claims for unemployment insurance in the last half of December, economists had expected job growth to weaken and unemployment to edge up.
Even President Clinton's chief economic adviser, Janet L. Yellen, acknowledged that she was amazed by the economy's momentum. "I'm surprised; it's great; it's just extraordinary," she said. "There's no obvious reason we can't continue down this path."
The President, speaking in Detroit, took credit for the economy's performance and for the 93-month-old expansion, now the longest in peacetime, though still more than a year shy of the record set by the 1960's expansion. Mr. Clinton called this a time "of American renaissance."
The December data capped a year in which -- contrary to predictions of fewer jobs, rising unemployment and stagnant incomes -- net job growth was nearly three million; unemployment hovered between 4.3 and 4.5 percent; wage gains, adjusted for inflation, were the best in a generation, and productivity growth picked up instead of slowing as it usually does as economic expansions age.
Moreover, some of the most disadvantaged workers have enjoyed substantial job and pay gains in the last two years. In December, for example, while the jobless rate for most major demographic groups was largely unchanged, the unemployment rates for black workers and teen-agers, typically multiples of the white and adult rates, dropped sharply. "We're finally back to the kind of tide that lifts all boats," Ms. Yellen said.
Most economists are still predicting a sharp slowdown in 1999 starting in the current quarter, although at least one acknowledged yesterday that there was scant evidence of that so far. Along with recent data showing that retail sales, home buying and car purchases remained strong through the end of the year, yesterday's jobs report suggested that the economy might have been expanding at a 4 percent annual rate in the final quarter of 1998, which is considered exceptionally strong.
Gail Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board, a private research organization, said, "We're going into 1999 with fundamentals better than in 1998."
There are good reasons for expecting some moderation of growth, though. Much of the rest of the world is either in recession or slowing down. Consumers have been spending much of their income at an unsustainable rate. Home buying is at a record pace.
Still, economists say job growth would have to fall below a rate of 100,000 or so a month for unemployment to start rising.
Factory employment, which fell during most of last year, declined by another 13,000 jobs in December. But that is a fraction of the losses in recent months. Factory employment has fallen by 272,000 jobs since March, as recessions in Asia and Latin America have hurt American exports. Despite record car sales, employment in Detroit is down 12,000 from a year earlier. On the other hand, manufacturers of anything related to the housing market -- from bricks and glass to furniture and hardware -- continue to thrive and did plenty of hiring last month, as they have done all year.
Weather was partly responsible for construction jobs surging by 104,000 last month, the biggest monthly gain since February 1984. Most of the gains were in outdoor work like highway construction and roofing as contractors were able to continue working longer than usual. But construction hiring has been strong all year. With state treasuries bulging and mortgage rates down to the lowest level in 30 years, public works and housing are both booming.
The main engine of job growth remained the service economy -- everything from fast-food chains to schools -- which added 290,000 jobs. Business services like public relations, consulting and computing did extensive hiring. Temporary-help suppliers had the biggest jump in head counts since August. With companies and government agencies scrambling to fix their Year 2000 computer problems, hiring by computer services companies was brisk; jobs in that industry swelled by more than 13 percent in 1998.
Jobs in the retail industry rose by 53,000 in December, bringing total gains for the year to nearly half a million. Restaurants added 33,000 workers. Department stores hired a lot of extra holiday help. A surge in renovation helped building-material and garden-supply stores add 9,000 jobs, the biggest increase of the year. Most services related to the building business expanded payrolls last year.
With workers in such demand, paychecks are fattening. Hourly earnings jumped 5 cents, to $12.98. That is a 3.8 percent gain for the year.

HEADLINE: THE TRIAL OF THE PRESIDENT: THE PRESIDENT;
Economy, Long a Friend, Brings Clinton More Help

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The stock market is in record territory. The economic expansion just hit its 93d month, making this the longest peacetime period of sustained growth in American history.
And if President Clinton needed any more reason to be upbeat when he stepped before the Economic Club of Detroit today, he got it this morning when the Labor Department announced that the economy generated a startling total of 378,000 new jobs in December, pushing the unemployment rate down to 4.3 percent. 
 As the Senate moved forward in its impeachment trial, the confluence of good economic news was just another reminder that this President remains either the most skillful overseer of the economy in decades, or the luckiest. If he escapes removal from office, it will be in no small part because of his high approval ratings, which are rooted in the nation's long run of prosperity.
How much of the credit Mr. Clinton deserves is of course a matter of debate. But he was not shy about claiming some today as he spoke to 1,500 members and guests of the Economic Club of Detroit, including hundreds of automobile industry executives and auto union leaders and most of Michigan's Democratic Congressional delegation.
"We meet today at a time of an American economic renaissance," Mr. Clinton declared.
He said the current expansion was more impressive than past ones for several reasons, among them that it had brought not only higher real incomes for most Americans but also minority unemployment rates that are at the lowest levels since the Government began keeping those statistics in 1972.
"This is a rising tide that is lifting all boats," Mr. Clinton said.
The President spoke at Cobo Arena, site of the North American International Auto Show, the world's largest new-car exhibit, which he toured beforehand. The automobile industry is celebrating its second-best sales year ever, and the region's economy is booming.
The White House, clearly recognizing how important the national economy's performance is to Mr. Clinton's survival in office, is making certain he is seen presiding over announcements of the good news.
On Wednesday, he announced that the Administration expected a Federal budget surplus of at least $76 billion in the current fiscal year, the highest such figure ever in terms of absolute dollars (as opposed to percentage of the budget). And today he braved snowy runways in both Washington and Detroit to spotlight the latest favorable trends.
White House aides insist that these are not events stage-managed solely to divert attention from the impeachment trial.
"The President obviously understands what's going on in the Senate," said Joe Lockhart, the White House press secretary. "It's in the hands of the Senate. He's focusing on his agenda."
In his 35-minute address this afternoon, Mr. Clinton said that despite the steady flow of favorable developments, the Government still faced challenges in dealing with economic matters. He said the Administration must still grapple with caring for the elderly and providing an education to equip the nation's young to compete in the global high-technology economy. He said many inner cities and rural areas had yet to share in the benefits of the economic boom.
He also said the huge volume and high speed of international capital flows posed a threat to the stability of nations around the world, whose problems could spread to the United States. And he noted that rapid growth posed environmental problems that, he said, must be met with new investment in energy-efficient technology and a reduced dependence on fossil fuels, which contribute to global warming.
Many of the Economic Club's members are Republicans, but they too appeared focused mostly on the economy and said they wanted the President's impeachment difficulties over as soon as possible. One big donor to Michigan Republicans, Heinz Prechter, chairman and founder of ASC Inc., a manufacturer of car sunroofs, said that while he was uncertain whether Mr. Clinton should be removed from office, he was sure that the current political furor should be brought to a quick conclusion.
"I don't think that most of us in leadership positions can condone what President Clinton has done," Mr. Prechter said, "but we can't have this public show go on forever."
Having finished his formal remarks, the President took several questions from the audience, screened by his host, Dennis Archer, Mayor of Detroit and Mr. Clinton's choice to be co-chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
If anyone in the audience wanted Mr. Clinton's views on the impeachment trial playing out in Washington, they were disappointed. The questions he took concerned alleged dumping of steel by Japan, Russia and Brazil (he is against it), the new Europe-wide currency, the euro (he is for it), and increased spending on the military (he is for it, to a point).
The final question came from a 12-year-old, who wanted to know the person Mr. Clinton had met as President whom he most admired. Mr. Clinton named Yitzhak Rabin, the assassinated Israeli Prime Minister, and Nelson Mandela, human rights hero and President of South Africa.
Outside the hall where Mr. Clinton spoke was a small congress of demonstrators.
One held a sign reading, "It's the perjury, stupid," a play on the slogan that gained currency within Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign team, "It's the economy, stupid." Another sign proclaimed, "Impeach, Indict, Incarcerate."
But there were pro-Clinton demonstrators as well, one of whom held a placard reading, "G.O.P.: Get Our President."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economy Rewards Workers With a Boom in U.S. Jobs
Despite an unsettled global economy, lower corporate profits and a new round of layoffs, the American economy kept creating jobs at an astonishing pace in December, adding about 378,000 new positions. Unemployment fell to 4.3 percent, matching the 28-year low set last April. Signs of strength in the economy were impressive and widespread, showing healthy gains in employment and wages among disadvantaged demographic groups.
For 1998 as a whole, net job growth was nearly 3 million and unemployment hovered between 4.3 and 4.5 percent. Except for a period at the height of the Vietnam War, the last time unemployment was this low for any significant length of time was in 1957. Page A1. 

American consumers scaled back their rate of borrowing in November, adding $3.9 billion in new debt, the Federal Reserve reported, compared with $11.9 billion in October. Revolving loans, which include credit card borrowing, decreased, but auto loans rose sharply. C3.
 
Hyundai Plans to Sell Divisions
Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, said it would sell 11 of its affiliates in an effort to raise more than $5 billion. Hyundai, the largest of the giant family-dominated conglomerates, called chaebol, that dominate the nation's economy is under pressure from the Government to lower its debt, now estimated at $36 billion. C2.
 
Disney Recalls a Video Release
Disney recalled 3.4 million copies of the animated video "The Rescuers," apparently because a nude image was inserted. The image cannot be seen when the video is run at normal speed. A Disney spokeswoman would say only that the image was objectionable, but there were reports that the unauthorized insertion was a photo of a woman's nude torso. C3.
 
F.A.A. Orders Tests on Planes
The Federal Aviation Administration issued an emergency order for special tests on Embraer 145's, Brazilian-built regional jets heavily used by some U.S. airlines, and Cessna 750's, which are business jets. The order followed three instances of engine shutdowns because of suspected oil leaks. A8.

Wild Day for Broadcast.com Shares
Trading of shares in Broadcast.com, a Dallas Internet company, was stopped temporarily yesterday on the Nasdaq stock market after the stock had jumped more than 70 percent in value by 11:51 A.M. Trading resumed at 1:20 P.M. even though the company declined to comment on what might have caused the surge. The stock opened at $132, rose to a high of $230.50, and closed at $197.50, up $65.50 for the day. C2.
 
MCI Worldcom Won't Buy Airtouch
MCI Worldcom said that it had decided not to pursue a bid for Airtouch, the nation's leading wireless telephone company. Airtouch has been in merger talks with Bell Atlantic, the nation's largest local phone concern, which wants to buy the company in a stock deal valued at about $45 billion. Vodafone Group PLC, a British wireless carrier, has also proposed buying Airtouch, suggesting a deal worth $54 billion in cash and securities. C14.
 
Lucent Predicts a One-Time Gain Lucent Technologies, a maker of telecommunications equipment, predicted a one-time gain of 97 cents a share in the its first quarter, which ended Dec. 31. The gain reflects an accounting change that better represents benefit expenses. C3
 
Cuba Scoffs at Easing of Sanctions
In the first official Cuban reaction to President Clinton's decision on Monday to ease a few elements of the United States' economic embargo against Cuba, Jose Luis Rodriguez, Cuba's Economy Minister, dismissed Mr. Clinton's changes as "crumbs." The President had said American companies would be permitted to sell food and farm supplies to nongovernmental organizations in Cuba. Most elements of the sanctions would remain unchanged. A5.
 
Sale of Bottler to Fetch $1 Billion
Pepsico will gain $1 billion from the planned sale of a majority stake in its bottling operations to the public. Pepsico disclosed the amount of the initial public offering for Pepsi Bottling Group Inc. in a regulatory filing. C3.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
In Bow to Reality, N.B.A. Allows Talks With Agents

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE

 BODY:
Fearing a mad scramble for free agents three weeks before the season is scheduled to begin, the National Basketball Association agreed yesterday to permit teams to negotiate with player agents immediately.
From Michael Jordan to Zan Tabak, the decision opens the floodgates for nearly 200 players to negotiate new contracts through their agents. No deals can be signed until the new collective bargaining agreement is set in writing sometime next week. And the moratorium for players having contact with teams remains in effect until training camps are scheduled to begin Jan. 18. 
But the cloak-and-dagger methods of many agents and team executives will end this weekend.
After consulting with the union, and aware that talks were already secretly going on after Wednesday's settlement that saved the season, the league sent memorandums to the 29 teams about 5 P.M. yesterday advising them that negotiations could proceed.
"There was obviously such pent-up demand that it wasn't worth fighting about," one league official said on condition of anonymity.
Jordan has yet to decide whether he will retire, but a free-agent class that includes Antonio McDyess, Scottie Pippen, Dennis Rodman, Damon Stoudamire and Jayson Williams is about to experience the N.B.A.'s version of Job Fair '99, replete with the usual inducements and recruiting tactics from prospective employers.
One agent, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Nets were keenly interested in acquiring McDyess, the skywalking forward whose youth and athleticism make him perhaps the No. 1 commodity. But it will be almost impossible for the Nets to acquire a player of that caliber under the new $30 million salary cap.
Phoenix and Denver, teams McDyess has played for, were also in the bidding, as was Houston. The Nets are planning to keep Williams.
Jimmy Sexton, Pippen's agent, said there was a possibility his client would return to the Chicago Bulls when the 50-game, lockout-delayed season is scheduled to open Feb. 5.
"Scottie loves Chicago, loves the team and so, if we can work a deal out that works for Scottie, I think he would like to stay there," Sexton said.
Each team will play two preseason games, with the Knicks and the Nets playing a home-and-home series. But many teams still need players. The Bulls, Orlando Magic and Rockets have only four players apiece under contract, while the Suns have five.
Stan Kasten, the Atlanta Hawks president, told The Associated Press that he was suspicious that other teams were getting a jump on negotiations in violation of the rules. He said he had spoken with Commissioner David Stern about the situation and vowed to turn in any team that breaks the rules.
Knowing that teams and players were secretly negotiating for the past 48 hours, the league deemed the moratorium as unrealistic.
"I've got lesser guys that I need to get into camps," said Eric Rudolph, an agent who represents the free agents Johnny Newman, Kebu Stewart and Shawnelle Scott. "It just makes sense to lift the moratorium. I'd like to be able to negotiate. So now, when the 18th comes, it's like a formality of cutting their deals. A lot of g.m.'s were pushing hard for it for no other reason than they wanted to find out if a certain player was interested in their teams."
Said another agent, on condition of anonymity: "Whether they lifted it or not, I'm just telling you we've been going about business. So have a lot of other people."
Golden State is said to be trying hard to trade Latrell Sprewell, with Miami and San Antonio the most interested. The controversial All-Star guard has not played since November 1997 after choking and punching his coach, P. J. Carlesimo, and subsequently being suspended for the remainder of last season. His contract was originally terminated as well, but an arbitrator sharply reduced the penalty and allowed Sprewell to return to Golden State contractually. The Warriors have been trying to deal him since.
The season is expected to start in four weeks, and the playoffs could end in late June or early July. Charlotte is in the most trouble regarding free agents, with both centers Vlade Divac and Matt Geiger fielding offers from several teams.
But the Bulls remain the most intriguing subplot, with nine players on the open market. The feeling among most team officials is that if Jordan and Pippen somehow are retained, the club will try to sign Rodman, Steve Kerr, Bill Wennington and Luc Longley to attempt a run for a fourth consecutive title.
 With the decision yesterday, teams were, in theory, allowed to put together deals last night.
"It eliminates any need for investigation," the agent Keith Glass said. "Obviously, people have been sitting around for six months doing nothing. So it's eliminated any hypocrisy. It puts everybody on equal footing.
"I mean, I've been calling and wishing people a Happy New Year just to get a conversation going, and I think they're questioning my sincerity."
The collective bargaining agreement included salary maximums for the game's highest-paid players, eliminating the glut of $100 million deals that the owners claimed had crippled N.B.A. economics.
A player with 10 years of experience can make no more than $14 million in the first year of his deal -- with the possibility for annual 12 percent raises. With restrictions like those, some league officials said they believed that the need for agents would be reduced. Glass, for one, was not buying that theory.
"We're like city rats, we're very adaptable," he said. "We can live anywhere in any deal. We will survive. They can't exterminate us."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
U.S. Ignored Threats Before Embassy Bombings
An examination of events in the year before the assaults on the American Embassies in Tanzania and Kenya shows that the security concerns of the United States Ambassador to Kenya were more intense, more well founded, more specific and more forcefully expressed than has previously been known. The Ambassador, Prudence Bushnell, had been fighting for months for a more secure embassy in the face of mounting terrorist threats and a warning that she was the target of an assassination plot. Her appeals were dismissed by the State Department. A1 

Special panels set up by the State Department to investigate the bombings of the embassies in Africa called on the department to consider closing a number of embassies around the world that are vulnerable to terrorist attack and replacing them with regional "super-embassies." A7
 
Agencies Firm on Pollard
Law enforcement and intelligence officials said they remained adamantly opposed to shortening the life sentence of Jonathan Jay Pollard, a former Navy intelligence analyst convicted of spying for Israel. But the agencies' opposition to granting Mr. Pollard leniency may not end the debate over the case, the officials said. President Clinton has the exclusive power to grant clemency, and the officials said Mr. Clinton's aides could seek to reduce Mr. Pollard's sentence or give him a release date. A3
 
Iraqi Damage Underestimated
The Pentagon's senior commanders claimed that the American and British raids on Iraq had caused more damage than initially reported. Almost three weeks after the bombing stopped, officials said they based their latest assessments on intelligence information that went beyond aerial or satellite photographs of the damage done in four nights of air and missile strikes. A3
 
Rebel Leader Commits to Peace
The commander of the largest rebel force in Colombia sought out government officials and foreign dignitaries, saying he was committed to seeking progress in talks to end the civil war and blaming death threats for his absence at a ceremony to start the process. A4
 
Italian Premier Meets Pope
Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema, a former Communist leader, had a private audience with Pope John Paul II. For many years the Communist Party and the Roman Catholic Church were at bitter odds, and although Mr. D'Alema's selection as Prime Minister was met with apprehension by the church, he is trying to better relations. A3
 
Birth Control Pill Found Safe
