HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
In New Orleans, Madame John's Legacy

BYLINE: By FRANCIS FRANK MARCUS 

 BODY:
For more than 200 years, the house at 632 Dumaine Street in New Orleans has survived fire, floods and hurricanes to become a French Quarter landmark and rare example of the classic Creole cottages built by families that settled the city in the 18th century.
After being closed for more than a decade, the small museum known in the neighborhood as Madame John's -- its official name is Madame John's Legacy -- is freshly restored and open to the public, still a model of adaptation to life in the subtropics. 
 Its design resembles the 18th-century architecture found in the French West Indies. High ceilings mitigate the stifling summer heat. The living quarters were raised from the ground to escape dampness and flooding. Tall, carefully placed windows capture breezes from the Mississippi River, which flows nearby.
The house dates to 1789, when it replaced a similar structure built in 1730 that had been ruined by a fire that destroyed most of New Orleans in 1788. In 1794 a fire that leveled much of the rebuilt city spared Madame John's Legacy. The name was taken from a book of short stories, "Old Creole Days," by George Washington Cable, who used the cottage as the setting for a melodramatic tale about a woman of mixed racial ancestry.
Madame John's Legacy was closed more than 10 years ago by the Louisiana State Museum system, which owns it, largely because of a money shortage. It reopened in November with a permanent exhibition of folk art, 70 paintings, drawings, sculptures and mixed-media pieces by self-taught Louisiana artists, donated by two New Orleans collectors, Dr. Kurt Gitter and Alice Rae Yelen, his wife. The ground floor, enclosed by thick brick walls and once used as a wine cellar, contains a series of exhibits explaining the history of the house, using reproductions of old paintings, documents and pottery found in excavations of the site. The museum, (800) 568-6968, is open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday; admission is $3. FRANCES FRANK MARCUS
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: Madame John's. "Sweet Emma," by Lorraine Gendron, from an exhibition of works by self-taught artists. (Photographs by Louisiana State Museum)

HEADLINE: Where Architecture Is Multilingual

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS; CLIFFORD KRAUSS is chief of the Buenos Aires bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
IF the walls of Buenos Aires could speak to me, I know they would speak in French, Italian, German, Hungarian and English.
A clock tower that is a knockoff of Big Ben tells commuters how late they are for work as they pick up their taxis at the Retiro train station, the largest Edwardian terminal in the world. Galerias Pacifico, the fashionable mall on the Calle Florida, is modeled after the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele in Milan. Entire neighborhoods, like La Boca or San Telmo, feel like blue-collar Italy; while Palermo Chico and swathes of Recoleta feel like upscale France. 
 As a new resident of Buenos Aires, I sometimes feel as though I am in the Disney World of European architecture. Only three blocks from my apartment, the Circulo Militar military club on Plaza San Martin mixes the trademarks of the chateau at Chantilly, the Luxembourg Palace in Paris, and a pavilion of the Louvre. The immense Inmaculada Concepcion church in the northern barrio of Belgrano is a copy of the Pantheon in Rome. The Teatro Colon, the epicenter of opera and ballet for all of Latin America since its inauguration in 1908, mixes the architectural styles and acoustical devices of La Scala with those of the grand opera houses of Vienna and Paris.
Unlike the ancient Indian ruins and colonial baroque churches of Mexico City or Lima, Buenos Aires architecture may seem hopelessly derivative. (Argentina was a cultural and economic backwater until the 19th century.) But you would have to travel to London, Paris, Milan, Rome, Vienna and Budapest to see all the rich derivations of European architecture that you can see in Buenos Aires alone.
Argentina's mix of styles reflects the broad impact of waves of European immigration in the 19th century (which included many distinguished architects and artisans) and the cattle and foreign-investment bonanza of the early 20th century. It financed the building of scores of lavish mansions and palaces as well as giant Government offices, shopping arcades, railroad stations and banks in the European taste. The mixing of diverse European styles in the same block, even in the same building, is as Argentine as the tango. The city's signature dance form mixes African and Latin rhythms with the tangy lyrics of lunfardo, a local slang mixing Spanish and Italian.
There are no neighborhood architectural tours in English, and all the architectural guides to the city are in Spanish. A mere inconvenience; here are three walks you can take at an easy pace over two days.
One place to begin seeing the great buildings of Buenos Aires is along the Avenida de Mayo, still the political heart of Argentina, if no longer its cultural heart. The great thoroughfare is frequently compared to the Champs-Elysees for its lasting vitality and to Budapest's Andrassy Avenue for its architectural eclecticism.
On one end of the avenue is the grand Congress building, inspired by the Reichstag in Berlin, with an imposing green dome shooting into the sky like the cupolas of Turin. On the other end of the avenue, crossing Avenida 9 de Julio, is the Casa Rosada, the presidential palace where Eva Peron stole many Argentine hearts from a balcony. The palace is graced by French mansard roofs, a grand Italian baroque central arch, and galleries of columns and arches straight out of the Italian Renaissance. And, in between, there is the Cafe Tortoni, where the poets and literati sip coffee in demitasse cups under a stained-glass skylight inspired by the one in Maxim's in Paris.
There are English-language tours of the Congress, as well as the building that once housed La Prensa, a major newspaper, and now is used as a government office building. This latter building is a derivation of the Palais Garnier, Paris's ornate opera, with a roof crowned by a gilded statue celebrating press freedom and an interior graced by an assortment of French and Italian murals of the Fragonard variety.
But the best idea is a long walk along the avenue, stopping at the antique bookshops, cafes and ice cream parlors, and late at night, the lively Avila flamenco club. Just above the Avila, it is worth taking a look inside the bizarre Barolo office building. The soaring skyscraper was designed in the early 1920's by an Italian architect, Mario Palanti, whose imagination inspired undulating balconies and sculptures, multiple domes within domes, and wall inscriptions from Dante's "Divine Comedy."
Fabio Grementieri, an architectural historian who works for the City of Buenos Aires, showed a friend and me around Avenida de Mayo recently. We toured one building that is a smaller version of Vienna's central postal building, as well as buildings with European architectural motifs ranging from German Jugendstil to Italian Liberty Style. At 747 Avenida de Mayo, an office building worth seeing for its ornate grillwork, is a typical hodgepodge of splendor: The classical-looking pediments on the second floor are Flemish, while the tower, spire and mansard roof are obviously French.
"Walking up Avenida de Mayo feels like Paris, but it's really like Budapest," Mr. Grementieri said. "That is why when Alan Parker wanted to finish filming 'Evita' after he left Buenos Aires, he went to Budapest."
Francophiles who like to shop at Nina Ricci and Louis Vuitton will like this second tour: a stroll along the Avenida Alvear from the Plaza Francia to Plazoleta Carlos Pellegrini. It is Buenos Aires's most elegant avenue, well worth taking the short walk after the obligatory visit to the Recoleta cemetery. It's a way to combine a visit to the grave of Argentina's greatest populist, Evita Peron, with a view of the mansions once owned by the very oligarchy she loathed. Snacks are recommended in between: coffee and pastry (Viennese or French) at the Cafe La Biela or a drink in the lobby bar at the handsome Alvear Palace Hotel, Buenos Aires's answer to the Ritz.
There are nearly a dozen blocks of French architectural gems on the Alvear. Architectural historians bemoan the fact that that so many of the turn-of-the-century mansions built by the great cattle families of Argentina -- grand examples of late Victorian, Beaux-Arts and Italian Renaissance -- were destroyed during the city's several urban renewals since the 1930's. Most of the lost mansions were replaced by neo-classical apartment houses that are French in feeling. Among the mansions left standing, the most impressive are the Vatican Embassy on the corner of Montevideo Street, and the eerie, ivy-draped Residencia Duhau at 1671 Avenida Alvear. The Vatican Embassy has a marvelous mansard roof, as does the Brazilian ambassador's residence in the Plazoleta Carlos Pellegrini.
The latter is a nice copy of the Jacquemart-Andre Museum on Boulevard Haussmann in Paris, with a sprinkling of accents added from the chateau at Fontainebleau. It was built in the 1920's by the Peredas, one of several Argentine cattle families who visited Europe and made copies of the buildings they liked most when they returned. "Rich as an Argentine" was a popular phrase in Europe in the 1920's.
Regrettably, the Brazilian ambassador's residence is only open to the public for tours on rare occasions, as is the neighboring French Embassy, one of the more complex Beaux-Arts buildings in the city. The latter was set to be bulldozed in the 1970's under the military junta, to expand the Avenida 9 de Julio. Residents complained bitterly. President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France agreed, stood up to the generals, and said his diplomats would not move.
It just goes to show that interesting buildings usually have interesting stories. And the Plaza San Martin, the heart of a third walking tour, has many of both. It is Buenos Aires's most beautiful plaza, especially in early November when the brilliant purple jacaranda trees are in bloom. The jacarandas were transplanted from the tropical north and are an integral part of the landscaping by Charles Thays, a French architect who also worked on Parisian parks at the turn of the century.
A slow walk around the Circulo Militar, the Louvre spinoff, is a good place to start a tour of the Plaza San Martin. This wonder of opulence was once owned by Jose C. Paz, the publisher of La Prensa, who built the grandest palace he could in order to entertain there once he became president. Mr. Paz never won the presidency, but he did give one very special party in his mansion during which he introduced the tango to Argentine high society in the 1920's -- shortly after it won acceptance in Paris.
The only part of the old Paz mansion open to the public is a small military museum.
On the other side of Plaza San Martin is the mansion built by the Anchorenas (a branch of the same family that built what is today the Vatican embassy), now the ceremonial center of the Argentine Foreign Ministry. Designed by Alejandro Christophersen -- the Argentine architect who was born in Spain to Norwegian parents in 1866 and trained in Brussels and Paris -- the mansion takes up a block and is a galloping mix of French classicism and Art Nouveau. It is closed to the public, but a peek through the gate reveals the cobblestoned cour d'honneur with its understated grillwork and columns designed to reflect the Louis XIV and XV periods. Around the block, on Calle Basavilbaso, an enchanting little black iron and glass pavilion juts out of the Anchorena mansion with a terrace on top.
Mercedes Castellanos de Anchorena wanted her palace to have a view of the Rio de la Plata and the austere neo-Romanesque Santisimo Sacramento church across the plaza that she had simultaneously built with an imposing marble altar lavishly decorated with bronze, mosaic and onyx. The glorious view lasted about 20 years.
In the early 1930's, an aspiring oligarch named Corina Kavanagh fell in love with New York's Art Deco skyscrapers. When she bankrolled construction of an Art Deco behemoth at 1065 Calle Florida, it spoiled the Anchorenas' view, starting a feud that has been called "the war of the socialites."
The Kavanagh Building, in any case, is a nice reminder of home for any New Yorker.
No trip is complete without a visit to the Teatro Colon. Like seeing a tango show, attending the opera at the Colon is a rich window on Argentine glamour and style. The opera season that just ended was plagued by bad labor relations, financial problems and sometimes awful reviews.
But no matter the quality of the music, a big part of the experience of attending a performance at the Colon is partaking in the luxury and history of the building. It is a monumental mix of Italian, Viennese and French styles that is massive even by the dimensions of the Avenida 9 de Julio, one of the widest avenues in the world at almost 600 feet across, on which it stands. The exterior displays layers of arches, mouldings, sculptures, balconies and columns that some critics have characterized as more severe than beautiful. But it is the interior that really shines -- even if most of the marbled walls are really only painted stucco.
FOR those who cannot attend an opera, there is a one-hour tour of the theater given in English and several other languages. I have taken the tour twice, and my only complaint is that there was not a mention of the sordid crime that changed the architectural destiny of the Colon. But the guides are courteous and knowledgeable, pointing out details from the Venetian mosaics on the floors and the beautiful mix of white Italian marble and pink Portuguese marble on the stairways to the boxes and orchestra seats still covered in their original burgundy velvet and gold brocade.
Designed by Francisco Tamburini, an Italian architect, just before his death, the auditorium has virtually perfect acoustics. The crystal chandelier has 700 bulbs, and there is a thin circular corridor at the top of the muraled domed ceiling that allows 15 musicians and singers to perform above the heads of the audience.
The guides like to quote Pavarotti, who once said after performing there that the theater had only one defect: "It is so perfect you can easily hear every mistake."
But for me the best part of the tour is the several floors below ground, where you get a rare chance to see world-class ballet dancers practice and several historic opera costumes on display. The heaviest of them is a gown from Mussorgsky's "Boris Godounov"; inlaid with faux jewels, it weighs 50 pounds. And there is a dress worn by the soprano Claudia Muzio in a 1933 performance of "Tosca."
And the theater's tragedy and scandal are operatic in scale. Sadly, Tamburini did not live long enough to hear a formal concert in his masterpiece. And before his protege, a fellow Italian named Victor Meano, could complete Tamburini's work, he was murdered -- shot by a man he found uninvited in his house one night in 1904. It was the former butler who did it, one fired a few months before, who was having an affair with Meano's wife.
The third architect to lead the project, a Belgian named Julio Dormal, was no fan of Meano's and scotched most of the remaining designs for the interior, including Tamburini's and Meano's desire for a corridor of stores in the lobby. Dormal junked that in favor of a grand entrance, and he looked to Versailles for the fabulously ornate, mirrored hall on the second floor.
Perfect for strolls at intermission and for Friday afternoon recitals, it is considered one of the great rooms in Argentina. It never would have existed had Meano's butler been more discreet.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Euro Airport as Regional Hub

BYLINE: By ROGER COLLIS; ROGER COLLIS writes the Frequent Traveler column for The International Herald Tribune.

 BODY:
SWISSAIR has introduced nonstop service from Newark to Basel, Switzerland, welcome news to travelers who can now make fast connections through a small, user-friendly airport to provincial cities like Bilbao, Nuremberg, Dresden, Toulouse, Nice, Marseilles, Valencia, Friedrichshafen and Rostock.
There are also flights to major cities such as London and Berlin, but often to business airports like London City and Tempelhof, a short cab ride to the city center. In addition, there are connections to megahubs like Heathrow, Charles de Gaulle in Paris, Amsterdam and Frankfurt -- if that's where you need to go. 
 The six-times-weekly service, which began Dec. 17, is by Swissair Airbus 310 (42 business-class and 143 economy seats) as a code-share with Delta Airlines and Crossair -- Swissair's regional subsidiary -- which is developing an extensive hub-and-spoke network through Basel.
Newark-Basel is the first of a dozen similar "long, thin" services (that is, with sparse traffic) that will be operated in Crossair colors on routes such as Basel-Buenos Aires/Atlanta/ Mexico City/Charlotte, N.C. -- what I call regional long-haul routes. Cross air ultimately plans to acquire a long-haul fleet of upgraded Boeing 767's to serve these routes.
Book a flight to Basel or Mulhouse, France, and you'll arrive at the same airport -- Euro Airport Basel-Mulhouse-Freiburg -- right at the border separating Switzerland, France and Germany in the Upper Rhine Valley.
Four million people live within 60 minutes of the airport, which is 6.3 miles (10 kilometers) from Basel; 16 miles (26 kilometers) from Mulhouse and 46 miles (75 kilometers) from Freiburg in the southwestern corner of Germany. Zurich will be 45 minutes away when a new highway is completed.
Euro Airport, 50 years old but in the process of expansion, will have served nearly three million passengers in 1998 (around 40 percent each from France and Switzerland and 20 percent from Germany) with 12 airlines currently offering more than 45 scheduled flights to 92 destinations in 25 countries. Such carriers as Air France, British Airways, Sabena, KLM and Lufthansa serve 36 cities in 20 countries from Euro Airport.
 
Bypassing the Megahubs
Crossair plans to develop Euro Airport as a regional hub for people who wish to travel between, say, Nuremberg and Bilbao, or Dresden and Toulouse, thus saving time and avoiding the misery of changing planes at a megahub like Amsterdam, Brussels, Frankfurt, London, Paris or Zurich, which give priority to long-haul connections.
Crossair's "Euro Cross" is a new strategy that provides more than 520 connections a day between 40 cities through Euro Airport with an expected connecting time of 20 minutes. The carrier aims to have 1,000 daily connections linking 48 European destinations by next year, including regional services from Euro Airport to such destinations as Warsaw, Budapest, Athens, Ankara, Bologna, Stockholm, Copenhagen, Glasgow, Oporto, Trieste and Moscow, as well as long-haul routes to North America and Asia.
Euro Cross flights arrive and depart in four coordinated waves: early in the morning, midday, afternoon and evening, enabling people traveling to and from most destinations in Europe to get there and back the same day. For example, Toulouse-Vienna via Euro Cross is 2 hours 15 minutes faster than via Zurich; Amsterdam-Bilbao is 2 hours faster than via Paris; and Friedrichshafen-Birmingham is 1 hour 30 minutes faster than connecting in Frankfurt.
"If someone could fly point-to-point from Frankfurt to Palma at a suitable time, he would never go via Euro Cross, or if someone in Nuremberg could save time by flying to Bordeaux via Frankfurt, he would not use Euro Cross," says Moritz Suter, president and chief executive of Crossair. "But people will take Euro Cross because it is faster and easier in many cases."
 
Convenience at a Price
Crossair flies to 82 European destinations (plus around 25 routes on behalf of Swissair) with a fleet of 80 aircraft consisting of 33-seat Saab 340 turboprops, 50-seat Saab 2000 turboprops and 97-seat Avro RJ jets. The company carried 4.7 million passengers in 1997 -- 19 percent more than the previous year -- and made a net profit of about $28 million.
Small planes operating frequent flights on lightly traveled routes and relatively high fares are the key ingredients to Crossair's success. Round-trip fares from Euro Airport to London City, a 15-minute cab ride from the City, or Heathrow are $1,085 in business class, $845 in economy and $185 discounted fare.
Crossair is what you might call a "high frills" carrier. Riding the 33-seat Saab 340 Cityliner, for example, is the next best thing to a private plane. On short flights you're served regional specialties with wines to match, or open sandwiches of smoked salmon and cheese with Champagne from a real bottle.
The triangle where the frontiers of Switzerland, France and Germany intersect on the Rhine is the crossroads of ancient north-south and east-west trading routes, in use long before the nations were created. Alsace changed hands many times between France and Germany over the years -- belonging to Germany from 1871 to 1918 and again from 1940 to 1944.
From the balcony of Mr. Suter's office at the airport, you can see the city of Basel to the south, St. Louis in France to the north, and beyond that the German city of Weil-am-Rhein on the other side of the Rhine and to the northeast Lorrach, in Germany. Mulhouse is to the northeast; to the north is Mulheim in Germany and Strasbourg in France.
 
A Historical Crossroads
The region had its genesis as a trading hub in 1226 when Bishop von Thun of Basel mortgaged his entire fortune to build the first bridge on the Rhine -- the tollhouse still stands in the center of the old bridge. Merchant caravans from Scandinavia and northern Germany would come down through the Rhine Valley, crossing the river at Basel on their way south via the Alps to Italy; the silk caravans from China came up from the Balkans, crossing the Rhine here, and continuing on to Paris and London.
In the mid-19th century, railway engineers followed the old caravan routes: the night express from Stockholm to Palermo still crosses the Rhine at Basel -- one of the most important railway hubs in central Europe.
Germany and France have train stations on Swiss ground in the center of Basel. Modern highways follow the old routes from north to south and west to east, still crossing the Rhine at Basel.
The Euro Airport is an intercultural experience. It is built on French soil and run by a kind of public joint venture between France and Switzerland with board members from each country along with representatives from Germany -- a fast-growing sector of the airport's business.
There is a French-Swiss frontier within the airport, which apparently can be shifted depending on how many departure gates are needed on either side.
The Eurobar straddles the frontier; the same bartender serves on both sides. The Airport Grill offers entirely different menus on the French and Swiss sides, with the food coming from the same kitchen. A three-course dinner with wine could cost $55 a person on the Swiss side, a third less on the French side.
Whether you use the French or Swiss side depends, of course, on where you're heading. (Each country has its own immigration and customs channels.) But it may be a good idea to compare taxi and car rental prices in French and Swiss francs. There are separate parking lots on each side.
If you're going to Germany, you can come out either side. But the airport bus to Freiburg goes from the French exit. And a French taxi is likely to cost a lot less than a Swiss taxi. You may like the idea of taking a French taxi to Germany or Switzerland.

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
Euro Neurosis

BYLINE: By JEFFREY E. GARTEN; Jeffrey E. Garten is dean of the Yale School of Management.

 BODY:
For more than 50 years washington longed for a strong Europe as a political and economic partner. With the limited introduction of the euro last week, will the gods be punishing us by granting our wish?
 The birth of the euro is the most important change in the international financial arena since 1971, when President Nixon announced that the dollar would no longer be exchangeable into gold. The "euro zone" will have a larger population than America's and the second largest economy in the world. For the first time since pre-World War I days, when the British pound was the world's key currency, a potential rival to the U.S. dollar is on the horizon. 
 What difference could all this make to Americans? Three scenarios, all set approximately five years from now, when the euro is fully established in world markets, give a glimpse of what may lie ahead.
 1. TRADE WAR Suppose a series of global trade negotiations is reaching its conclusion in 2004. Let's assume that the entire negotiation becomes stalemated, with recriminations and threats flying across the Atlantic. To pressure Washington, the European Central Bank -- the equivalent of our Federal Reserve -- begins to lower interest rates, thereby weakening the euro. As a depreciating euro makes European products cheaper, imports begin to flood American markets.
 Washington, fearing a rapidly rising trade deficit and slower economic growth, faces an agonizing choice: either push down the dollar in retaliation, thereby starting a global trade war, or give in on a few trade issues. Uncle Sam caves.
 2. DOLLAR COLLAPSE Suppose American intelligence discovers that North Korea is mobilizing troops for an invasion. Washington visibly strengthens military ties with Tokyo to demonstrate to North Korea that both American and Japanese soldiers are prepared to defend South Korea.
 China is offended by the American initiative because it has historically felt threatened by the United States-Japan military alliance, and because it wants to reduce the tensions in its own backyard by less confrontational diplomacy. Unable to pressure Washington any other way, Beijing begins to exchange a portion of its huge holdings of Treasury bonds for euro securities, which are seen as a good substitute for the greenback.
 As dollars are sold, the greenback falls sharply in value. Aside from being livid that someone is manipulating its currency, Washington also has to be concerned about the threat of inflation that will arise because cheaper dollars will raise prices on imports. President Gore or President Bush offers to meet his Chinese counterpart to discuss less provocative ways to handle the confrontation.
 3. LEADERSHIP CRISIS Asia has recovered from economic collapse, but a new financial debacle occurs in Latin America. Because America's trade and banking links to the region have become so strong, Washington quickly orders the International Monetary Fund to provide bailout funds. But wait. A new voice is heard from Frankfurt, headquarters of the European Central Bank.
 "Not so fast," it says. "Latin America is your problem, not ours." The European Fed uses its voting power, which now aggregates at least 11 European nations, to veto Washington's plans. It is the first veto of such American action, and the President is forced to plead with Congress for taxpayer funds to rescue our friends to the south.
These aren't paranoid stories from the twilight zone. In the past, Washington hasn't hesitated to use dollar diplomacy to press Japan to open its markets, to force England and France to change their foreign policies and to muscle the I.M.F. to intervene abroad in economic crises. Now that there will be two powerful global currencies, why shouldn't the new big guy on the block exercise his clout from time to time?
 The euro won't necessarily lead to confrontation between Europe and America. But if it succeeds, it will mark the passing of the old order for Europe, for Washington's dominance of trans-Atlantic relationships and for the conduct of international finance.
 America had it easy when it was king of the hill, printing money to finance its chronic trade deficits and service its growing foreign debts. And in times of great crisis or uncertainty, the world parked its money in Treasury securities, contributing to a stronger dollar and lower interest rates. Now that there will be two economic giants, investors will have a choice, and America will have to play by someone else's rules.
 The big question is whether Washington and Europe will cooperate closely to manage global monetary affairs, or whether they will try to practice traditional hardball financial diplomacy. For the sake of economic growth everywhere, let's hope they take the friendly path. Otherwise, the global economy is in for turmoil that will vastly overshadow anything that has happened in Asia recently. When the relationship between the dollar and the euro goes haywire, countries accounting for nearly half of world trade and production will be affected, and the ripples will insure that all global trade and investment will become unsettled.
Money is increasingly the currency of power these days, and the old patterns and relationships are about to change. How Washington and Wall Street handle this new challenge will say a lot about how the new century begins -- in America and around the world.

HEADLINE: What Welfare-to-Work Really Means

 BODY:
Thanks to Jason DeParle for his thoughtful and revealing article (Dec. 20). He captured the contradictions of nationwide welfare- reform efforts. It is unfortunate that welfare policy continues to be gripped by the same conflicting impulses to protect and to punish the needy that have characterized American public-assistance policy for more than 200 years. The coexistence of social-services workers and fraud investigators within agencies whose stated purpose is to serve the needy epitomizes this tension. The overworked and undertrained workers on the front lines of welfare reform across the nation deserve some clarification as to whether their duty is to alleviate poverty (an economic condition, let us not forget) or to cut welfare caseloads. Without such clarification, they are being set up for failure by the powers that be.
 
Jennifer A. Moon
Seattle

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Outreach, the Wandering Museum's Specialty

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG; Vicki Goldberg is the author of "Power of Photography: How Photography Changed Our Lives."

 BODY:
ART gets around. Museums are pretty well stuck in one spot, but their treasures keep on truckin'. At a time when museums build buildings that tend to be more significant than the collections they shelter, some centers have gone the less expensive route of converting existing industrial centers into galleries. A few others are experimenting with putting art, at least temporarily, into essentially unconverted places that respectable museums would once have thought dreadfully infra dig: marginal retail areas, department stores, dance halls.
If a museum can install art in abandoned banks and garages, if the New Museum in SoHo can call itself a museum though it has no permanent collection, if the Contemporary Museum in Baltimore can operate with neither collection nor home, has the museum been redefined as merely a state of mind? 
 A museum is still a museum if it's closed for a year or two, but its exhibition potential drops alarmingly. At the Pompidou Center in Paris, the permanent collection has been closed since September 1997 while the galleries are being restored, though the contemporary galleries remain open for temporary exhibitions until mid-1999. (The entire museum will then close until the year 2000.) But France's modern treasures have not been stashed in mothballs. Bernard Blistene, vice director for contemporary art of the Pompidou, says with a tinge of horror in his voice that putting such a great collection into storage for two years would amount to confiscation.
Besides, the Pompidou, a national museum and well aware that not everyone can travel to the capital, considers decentralization part of its mission. Already the biggest lender in the world, according to Mr. Blistene -- approximately 6,000 items every year -- the Pompidou is sending out more than 100 loan exhibitions while its doors are shut. Among them are major shows of Kandinsky and Giacometti for regional museums in France, 120 "masterpieces of the collection" for Tokyo, and the exhibitions of 20th-century art currently at both branches of the Guggenheim in New York.
Mr. Blistene is also organizing an enormous exhibition in a Paris department store for March. This will occupy an entire floor -- more than 16,000 square feet -- of Le Samaritain, a store where you can buy a lipstick, a bike and a hamster in one outing. Le Samaritain has never before regarded itself as a branch of the national museums of France.
This store, an early example of an emporium where people discovered they could buy floor mops and frou-frou in one place, will house a festival of art by young contemporary artists, many of whom are marrying conventional arts to unconventional media. The exhibition will include fashion, performance, music, dance, lectures and happenings, all free. Mr. Blistene says he would "like to reconsider the generosity and diversity of art of this century, the intensity and efficiency of contemporary art, not art as just a dead object."
Why a department store? Michael Kimmelman pointed out in The New York Times that in America, from the late 19th century to the 1950's, certain department stores maintained the populist ideal by giving lowly shoppers a taste of high art. Some of these exhibitions in the land of commerce were mounted with the aid of museums. In the 1930's, the Museum of Modern Art's "Machine Art" show traveled to department stores in the Middle West. The French have only occasionally shown art in a department store; depending more heavily on Louis XVI than Thomas Paine, they have been more inclined to use national fairs than commercial outlets to educate the public taste in art.
Mr. Blistene, however, is delighted with the opportunity to put art where once only shoppers dared to tread. He notes that people go where things are happening -- the Armory, for instance, or the Gramercy Park Hotel in New York when they open up to art. And he was looking for an empty place and a site for stimulation and activity, "a way to react against the temptation of being melancholy," as he puts it.
He believes that nostalgia is currently being used as a barrier against contemporary reality but insists that art must remain involved as well as critical. "People think it was better yesterday," he says. "I think it's always better tomorrow." One might think shopping was the way to cure melancholy in today's society; perhaps Le Samaritain will provide an avant-garde alternative to the capitalist anodyne it ordinarily prescribes.
It seems only fitting that at a moment when museums are creating virtual department stores within their precincts, the jazziest art of the day should take up residence in the realm of the ladies who lunch. And it is delicious to think that someday at Bloomingdale's or Saks the mechanical voice that now and then pretends to be an elevator operator might call out, "Lingerie and intimates on four; fifth floor, Pollock, Rothko and de Kooning."
FOR those who will not go to the mount of Parnassus, Parnassus will obligingly come to them. Art long ago joined the rounds of daily life via public sculpture in parks and airline terminals and on occasional billboards and advertising pages. Museums, too, want to creep into quotidian consciousness, to play a role in the texture of ordinary, 9-to-5 life.
They also need more space for display and are conscious that they need to address different audiences. The Los Angeles Contemporary Museum opened not one but two temporary spaces and, like the man who came to dinner, they stayed on. In the late 1970's, the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts had a wandering exhibition on an "art truck" until insurance and conservation permanently put on the brakes.
Two and a half years ago, the W.P.A./ Corcoran, part of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington but independent of it, began putting on shows of emerging regional artists, many of them recent graduates of art schools in the Baltimore, Washington and Richmond area. The shows now appear in Project Space, temporary quarters in a former nightclub called the Insect Club in a slightly rundown business district. Metal grasshoppers as large as hallucinations still stand guard by the door while the bar looms darkly along one wall.
This decor is appropriately rakish for the kind of installation art that sends aluminum-foil leaves wafting across the gallery to the sound of grinding gears, or displays suits that look like torture instruments, with artists strapped into them on weekends. MCI, the communications company, opened a sports arena nearby late in 1977, and Nadine Gabai-Botero, the program director for the W.P.A./Corcoran, says the area's economic good fortune will probably drive out unprofitable contemporary art. Then art will be on to the next marginal area, perhaps to spaces that are available only for a month or two, prime for a lightning strike by the art corps.
This is a guerrilla art tactic, to invade a location where art never lived and billet the art troops there for a while, a maneuver not usually employed by established museums. In the late 1960's and 70's, when artists were vigorously questioning and frequently repudiating the role of museums, alternative spaces sprang up to shelter art that did not want entry to museums, or could not gain it. After a while a few museums saw the usefulness of such places and began to set up their own alternatives.
Baltimore's Contemporary Museum has made guerrilla artfare a modus vivendi. A museum without a museum, the Contemporary is a full-time nomad, a homeless institution that not only has no collection but has no location either.
Founded in 1989 and headed since 1996 by Gary Sangster, the Contemporary puts on two shows a year, one in, and in conjunction with, a local institution and the other in some highly improbable place, like a former Polish convent, a former Buick car dealership, an abandoned bus garage without electricity and the former Famous Ballroom, without either fame or heat.
"Catfish Dreamin'," a project by Alison Saar, was installed on a 1959 Chevy pick-up and driven into 80 neighborhoods in four states over a period of five months, giving the term "traveling show" a down-home dimension. "Too Jewish?," a show organized by and first shown at the Jewish Museum in New York, was exhibited in Baltimore in a vacant shopping mall, a notable instance of art taking up where commerce leaves off.
This doggedly temporary Contemporary Museum first made a national name for itself in 1992 when it worked with the Maryland Historical Society to install Fred Wilson's "Mining the Museum," an ironic look at the neglect of African-Americans and Native Americans in historical displays. A show last spring, "Mysterious Voyages/New Photography," a bold exploration of the current search for meaning in photography and art by artists like Sophie Calle, Adam Fuss, Andreas Gursky and Thomas Struth, was in the vacant ground floor of a downtown office building three blocks from Baltimore's red-light district and two from a police station. Visitor records revealed an audience drawn from both the surrounding area and the art world; the attempt to reach a local community must be working.
Mr. Sangster says: "We operate in the discourse of ideas about the visual. We're not here just to expose artists or artworks but ideas that influence the community through visual means." The Contemporary asked visitors, including some local critics, to write their own labels for "Mysterious Voyages"; eventually three were put up for each piece.
Mr. Sangster would now like a more permanent space -- ideally an aircraft hangar in the middle of Baltimore, if only he could find one -- to give the museum a stronger identity. In the meantime he is eyeing the Web, having already done one show on it, as the most likely means to preserve the explorations of a museum that cannot afford to publish. The Web, in fact, may be the outreach museum of the future, bringing art straight to your desk at any hour. Numerous museums and galleries beam it into your home right now, unfortunately at a resolution not much more convincing than the one you made on New Year's Eve.
So what is a museum, and where? It may be whatever a director or curator says it is, a rather new twist on Marcel Duchamp. Back in the 1920's, Hannes Meyer, an instructor at the Bauhaus, thought that museums should all be rededicated as soccer fields. The history of art takes many curious turns; we may yet live to see soccer fields rededicated as museums.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 2; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1337 words

HEADLINE: Asheville Public Market Hoping to Bloom

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE 

DATELINE: ASHEVILLE, N.C.

 BODY:
The Grove Arcade began life in 1929 as a public market, but housed Federal offices for nearly half a century. By year's end, the mammoth building in the heart of this city's downtown will recapture its birthright.
This month workers moved into the 269,000-square-foot building, one of the nation's first indoor malls, to begin the $10 million transformation. Asheville officials hope a public market will do for their city what similar enterprises have done for others. 
 In the last decade, public markets, with locally owned small businesses that focus on selling local products, have breathed life back into downtowns or renewed long-neglected sections across the nation. Dozens of cities are building or planning new markets, including the Portland Public Market in Portland, Me., which opened in November. In other cities like Atlanta and Buffalo, millions of dollars have been invested in long-standing markets.
"As institutions, they're so ancient, one of the things that we all share cross-culturally," said David K. O'Neil, the former manager of the Reading Market in Philadelphia, who is now a market consultant. "It's nice to have a center of your community where everything connects."
Markets, he said, touch people at an emotional level.
"People are attracted to people," he said. "They love to buy from people who know the product." Markets, he added, create an environment of conviviality.
Mr. O'Neil estimates 100 markets exist today. Best known perhaps is Pike Place Market in Seattle, founded in 1907, which noticeably declined in the 1970's.
After $55 million was invested in the market, it turned around. Today, the market spills across 22 acres on Puget Sound and attracts 11 million people each year. It also generated a total investment of $650 million from private developers of stores, hotels and 1,800 apartment units.
Aaron H. Zaretsky, the executive director of the Asheville effort, was a director at Pike Place for 15 years before moving here three years ago. Mr. Zaretsky heads the Grove Arcade Public Market Foundation, a nonprofit organization that has leased the building from the city.
The Grove Arcade was built by E. W. Grove, who made a fortune selling tonics that were said to cure all manner of ills. His slogan was "makes children and adults as fat as pigs." Mr. Grove also built the Grove Park Inn, a luxury resort still operating about five miles away from the arcade.
Mr. Grove had planned for a high-rise tower on top of the marketplace, but he died before the building was finished. The work stopped at just two stories. In 1942, the Federal Government, looking for space outside Washington to house agencies not essential to the war effort, bought the Grove Arcade. Until three years ago when a new Federal Building was built a block away, all the nation's weather data were stored at the National Climatic Data Center in the Grove Arcade.
At one time, the largest computer in the region -- an eight-foot-tall UNIVAC used to store weather data that filled an 80- by 150-foot room -- was housed in the building. It was such a novelty that a small platform was built outside the office so residents could watch it work. The platform still exists in the arcade walkway.
When the weather center and other smaller Federal agencies moved into the new Federal Building, the Government deeded the property to the city. The foundation that has leased the building from the city is responsible for the renovation of the basement and first floor of the building, while a private developer will refurbish the upper two floors and a mezzanine for offices and residences.
On the first floor, foundation planners hope to lease space to an eclectic mix of businesses, everything from a Thai restaurant to a bicycle shop, a fish market to a craft store. To keep the flavor of a public market, all the stores will be locally owned and will cater to a local clientele. Generally, public markets provide opportunity to small businesses, giving them an edge on larger, nationally known chains.
And some nationally known businesses have started out at public markets. Starbucks Coffee began as a small coffeehouse in Pike Place.
Public markets are not to be confused with festival markets, which H. Christopher Slusher, Mr. Zaretsky's assistant, describes as shopping districts filled with upscale national chains catering to tourists. Fanueil Hall in Boston and Inner Harbor in Baltimore would be considered festival markets, he said.
Public markets are more down-home, as in a fish store in Pike Place where a worker is apt to throw a salmon across the shop to have it wrapped for a customer. "The stores showcase the best products of a region," said Mr. Slusher, an architect who worked for the National Trust for Historic Preservation before coming here in 1998.
Here, Appalachian crafts and handmade furniture will be spotlighted, as will smoked salmon and ramp, a garlicky onion that grows wild in the southern Appalachians and is considered a delicacy. Mr. Slusher hopes stores will feature baskets, weaving and quilting as well as the basic needs: groceries, banks, photo developing, garden supply, ice cream shop, a mailing service.
So far, 450 people have expressed a desire to open a shop in the public market area, which ultimately will have 60 spaces plus about 15 stalls for fresh food vendors. Financing comes from a $1 million grant from the United States Economic Development Administration, $1 million in contributions and $2.5 million in financing. A parking lot -- for cars and bicycles -- will be constructed in the basement.
The foundation has leased the top three floors of the building to Rick Skelton, an Atlanta developer who intends to renovate the space for an undetermined number of offices and 52 apartments that will be converted to condominiums in a few years. In addition, a band shell in the tower overlooking the rooftop will be renovated and the roof will be used for public gatherings, meetings, receptions and dancing.
The residences and the rooftop overlook downtown Asheville and the Blue Ridge Mountains, which ring this city of 60,000 in western North Carolina. The marketplace will serve to foster an already reviving downtown, said City Manager James L. Westbrook Jr. He hopes the city will be able to attract a medium-priced hotel chain to the block between the marketplace and Asheville Civic Center to enable the city to play host to bigger conventions.
Unlike some larger and more famous Southern cities like Atlanta and Charlotte, Asheville has not leveled its historic buildings in favor of new development. City leaders say it has the nation's second largest number of Art Deco buildings after Miami. City Hall itself is an Art Deco tower whose renovation has just been completed with a $1 million yearlong replacement of its distinctive red tile roof.
A few blocks away is the First Baptist Church, whose Art Deco design sets it apart from its Baptist cousins of staid brick, high white steeples and white columns.
"It was a conscious decision to retain these buildings," Mr. Westbrook said.
The city has worked, too, to develop and enhance its artistic side. Shops that were long empty now house art galleries, jewelry stores, crafts, even a shop that features items from expeditions. Pack Square features a number of museums, including one that features minerals and gemstones, for which North Carolina is famous. Sculpture dresses up many street corners and yards outside buildings. One notable piece -- by Albert Paley, the metal sculptor -- stands outside the new Federal Building. Some locals consider it brilliant; others say it looks like a plane crash.
Mr. Slusher says planners hope the Arcade Marketplace will further revitalize life in the inner city.
"This building was beautifully designed and is in remarkable condition," he said. "This city has a heart and soul as an urban center and can reclaim itself as the center for commerce in the region. We're well on our way to doing that."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Pride, as Fragile as Glass, Is Shattered

BYLINE: By NEIL GENZLINGER 

 BODY:
THERE are thousands of things to break in the southern New Jersey glass-making city of Millville. Go there with a toddler, as I did recently, and you can expect a day full of lessons in fragility and frustration.
Which is appropriate, in a glum way, because at the moment the people of Millville know quite a lot about both. They know that fragility isn't limited to ornate glasswork; it extends to jobs, factories, ties to the past. And they know that in the economy of the late 20th century, the definition of frustration is this: You make a basic, utilitarian product, you make it well, your plant turns a profit, and you still get thrown out of a job. 
 Last month Millville learned that the Ball-Foster Glass Container plant, whose six giant smokestacks are a sort of local signature, will close at the end of March. About 300 jobs will go with it, as will a bit of history. Ball-Foster and its predecessors have been making glass at Millville since 1806, longer than anyone else in America.
For Millville, this is gloomy news indeed. "It raises our unemployment rate three points, just this one closing," said Kim Warker, the city's economic development director -- raises it to 10.5 percent.
The toddler and I didn't go to Millville to see the Ball-Foster plant, of course. We went to see the romantic side of glass -- Wheaton Village, where you find gorgeous displays at the Museum of American Glass and $1,000 paperweights at shops next door.
Abby, the toddler, learned about frustration at that museum. There was smashable stuff everywhere, but it was safely in glass cases. She kept reaching for the 200-year-old bottles, the delicate lamps, but crunching her hand against the cases. It's a good thing; our guide said she'd heard that the only unbreakable glass object is a marble.
Across town, Lawrence Levy has been awash in his own frustration. He's a union leader at Ball-Foster. He knows his members do a hard, hot job ("I've caught on fire more than once") and do it well. They make hundreds of thousands of bottles a day, mostly beer bottles, but incredibly, that's not enough -- the factory is old, and Ball-Foster can do the job faster and cheaper at some of its 19 other plants.
Mr. Levy is frustrated that the factory is closing even though it runs harmoniously -- he goes out of his way to praise the plant manager, Al Camp. He and many others call the plant a Nafta casualty, and they wonder if any of this would have happened had Ball-Foster not been owned by the French conglomerate St.-Gobain.
"You might as well run the foreign flag up and down at City Hall," Mr. Levy says, noting that Millville's two other glass makers are also foreign-owned. "We've given away our industrial base in this country."
The thing is, at Ball-Foster headquarters in Muncie, Ind., you hear a similar note of despair. "The glass business has been consolidating left and right, and what is terribly frustrating is, it's plants with good people, good attitudes," says Joel Patrick, the director of marketing and communications.
"In a sense," Mr. Patrick says, "you wish you had something to point to" -- union strife, sagging quality, whatever -- "but we have nothing to point to." Just not enough business to go around, thanks to plastic.
Back in Millville the $1,000-paperweight world is just as disappointed as the factory world. There's a rare mutual respect there. It's because the one came from the other -- back in the 1800's, it was workers tinkering on their lunch breaks who really expanded the notion of glass as art.
Gay Taylor, the museum's curator, says the first truly American paperweights came from Millville -- the famous Millville Rose was one. Ms. Taylor knows all about glass, how the sand and other natural resources of southern New Jersey gave rise to the industry; how that industry has been dying for decades. "This large plant is just a beautiful sight to see," Ms. Taylor says. "To think of it being idle is just devastating."
So we left Millville knowing a lot about fragility and frustration, and their connection. And when we got home, it seemed important to test the marble hypothesis.
Abby's older sister leaned out a second-story window and pitched a marble onto our concrete patio -- just a medium-strength throw. It survived easily. So we ran the test again, throwing the marble full force.
We're still looking for the marble. The impact sent it ricocheting off the patio and into last fall's unraked leaves. I like to think that a few years from now, Abby and I will be doing yardwork and will stumble upon the round nugget. Still in one piece; a survivor.

HEADLINE: JERSEY DIARY

 BODY:

DEAR DIARY:
I was coming out of the Lincoln Tunnel and heading home to Weehawken when I looked up to see the large Panasonic sign saying, "Honk if you love digital." 
 Under the Panasonic sign is an official road sign that says, "Blowing horn is $350 fine."
 
THOM CURLEY
 
During the recent holiday shopping frenzy, a cab pulled over at Cornelia and West 4th Streets in the West Village in Manhattan. A young woman with flowing hair and doe-like eyes hopped out, struggling with an enormous package the size of a hamper.
She placed the box on the sidewalk and tried to get a better grip on it. Many people glanced over, but only one offered assistance.
"Can I help you with that, miss?" said a gentleman who was carrying gifts of his own. He reached out to help the woman steady the huge box.
"Thank you," she said, "but I'm not going very far."
"No problem," the man replied. "I'm just waiting here for a few minutes until my wife is finished shopping."
The damsel-in-not-much-distress said: "I'll be O.K. But that's very nice. It's unusual for someone to offer help like that around here."
The good samaritan replied: "Well, I live in New Jersey. We do things like that."
"I'm sure that's it," she said with a smile. Then the woman, the actress Elizabeth Berkley, hustled away, balancing the huge box and eventually entering a nearby building.
 
JOE BRESCIA
 
My sixth-grade daughter recently started home economics at Thompson Junior High School in Middleton. The first day of class she came home all excited and told us that she would be cooking things as soon as the next week.
I asked her the first thing they would be cooking.
"Kool-Aid," she exclaimed.
 
BETSEY REGAN
 
 My son Zachary, who attended a birthday party at the Strawberry Hill Preschool in Livingston, was entertained by a Barney character.
When Zachary got home he told me about the party, but said that it wasn't the real Barney.
"How do you know," I asked.
"He had a zipper," was the reply.
 
SCOTT WHITE
 
Not long ago only the famous
had to hide their conversations
from nosy paparazzi,
but thanks to this diary
we're all up for print speculation.
You're not nosy, or so you say.
But this diary's changed your ways.
You've been told to snoop,
give The Times the scoop.
Now we are both hunters and prey.
 
TRACEY L. PARADISO
 
I came home from work recently to find a chipmunk in the upstairs hallway of my home in Mahwah.
I cornered him in the bedroom and rounded up a basket and a bowl to capture him and toss him outside. He ran from the closet to the bathroom, and I quickly closed the door.
When my husband came home -- using pillows and household objects -- he prepared a pathway from the bathroom door to the front door. With all other means of escape blocked, he opened the bathroom door.
The next thing I heard was: "Oh, honey, you don't have to worry about Alvin. He's gone."
Alvin had jumped into the toilet.
 
MARY WEYANT

LENGTH: 1241 words

HEADLINE: To Get From Here to There, More Long Islanders Choosing a Limo

BYLINE: By STEWART KAMPEL 

 BODY:
WHEN Herbert Gross of East Northport needed to get to Islip MacArthur Airport the other day for a flight to his vacation home in Tamarac, Fla., he called Charlie. Charlie is Charles Lo Bianco Jr. of Class Limousine Inc., of Bellmore, who chauffeurs Mr. Gross, his family and his dog to and from the airport several times a year.
"We just find him very reliable. He helps us with our dog, Looie, and we avoid the hassle of the crazy traffic and deciding what to do with our car," said Mr. Gross, who is president of Vision Inc., an advertising agency in Manhattan. "And when we come back, either he's there or one of his drivers is." 
 Mr. Gross is one of a growing number of Long Islanders who have become fans of limousines -- once the transportation toy and ploy of only the well-to-do and celebrities.
One big reason is convenience.
"People are realizing, that's private and corporations, that the limo is highly efficient," said Rick Cohen, chief executive officer of Limousine Digest. "It fills a niche that no other type of transportation can."
If you have several people with luggage, he went on, you don't want to squeeze into a taxi. "The limo is moving more and more people."
Besides being efficient, limousines are safe -- a way to avoid the dangerous combination of drinking and driving.
Bob Kubika, president of the Nassau-Suffolk Limousine Association, a trade group representing more than 120 companies, said: "Nobody wants to be behind the wheel of a car where the driver has been drinking and nobody wants to get caught. It's dangerous and expensive. Being in a limo is a lot cheaper than getting caught."
The Christmas and New Year's Eve trade was extremely busy for the hundreds of limousine company owners on the Island. According to the State Department of Motor Vehicles, there were 1,999 limousines registered in Nassau County in 1997, and 2,011 in Suffolk. Rental prices range from $65 to $125 an hour.
When it comes to weddings, another staple of the limo business, there's no season. "There are 20,000 weddings in Nassau and Suffolk each year," said Kirk Ronnemann, the general manager of Boomer Esiason's Class One Limousine in Ronkonkoma, which already has more than 400 weddings booked for 1999. "And don't forget the bachelor and bachelorette parties."
(Mr. Esiason, the former football player turned announcer, is not a principal in the company but is a friend of an owner, Paul Lobel.)
Limousines rented for weddings often come with specially trained drivers who have become familiar with church procedures, help lay down a special carpet and send people down the aisle on time.
More than 90 percent of the long stretch vehicles on the Long Island roads are white. "Brides seem to like white," said Mr. Kubika, who has his own company in Ronkonkoma. "They make a big impression. They look bigger and snazzier."
In the past, limo businesses appeared and disappeared as fast as new telephone directories came out. But the steady wedding market, plus a strong economy, have helped the industry stabilize, according to John H. Gore of United States Coachworks.
Not every client is going to a wedding or an airport. In fact, Mr. Ronnemann recalled a client last spring who didn't want anything to do with airports; he asked to be driven to New Hampshire because he was afraid to fly. At the going-and-coming rate of $1.62 a mile, Mr. Ronnemann said, a plane ticket would have been cheaper.
Recently a sheik from Saudi Arabia rented a car for 15 days from Class One. "And a sedan to go behind for security," said Mr. Lobel. "The same driver traveled with the party the entire time. The sheik's people gave him a Rolex as a tip."
Mr. Ronnemann recalled another unusual trip, about three months ago, when a "rather destitute man, a real loser," suddenly came in to a lot of money as a result of a financial settlement. He hired a stretch limousine and asked to be driven to his old neighborhood in Central Islip to show off his new fortune. Once there, he and his friends consumed a case of beer and he got drunk.
"We took him back to the Holiday Inn so he could sleep it off," Mr. Ronnemann said. "But he called us back and wanted to do it again. We refused and he got rather indignant. We told him we wouldn't allow drinking in the car and our driver was not going to carry him to his room. By the way, he was carrying a bag with about $40,000 in cash."
Just about everyone in the industry seems to agree that, aside from convenience, a major factor in the increasing popularity of limousines is the fear of drunken drivers, in their own vehicle or on the other side of the road.
In general, Mr. Cohen of Limousine Digest said, the limousine "makes good sense" for those who want to drink. If friends get together, he said, they can split the cost and "for a few extra dollars they can drink and have a good time."
Around prom time, one of the busiest seasons, the limousine association sends a representative to speak to school officials and parents, outlining its no-drinking, no-drugs policy.
"We have a strict policy against young people drinking or doing drugs," said Mr. Kubika. "We work hand-in-hand with MADD Mothers Against Drunk Driving . We have the kids sign an agreement with their parents about drinking and drugs. The parents like it because they know we're going to take good care of their prize possessions."
Brian Gold, a candy distributor who lives in Garden City, hired a limo to take his son Nicholas and seven other 10th graders to the "Winter Wonderland" show at Garden City High School and to see the Christmas tree at E.A.B. Plaza in Uniondale, and then on to several parties.
"There's no question that the limo is a safe way of going," Mr. Gold said.
It can also be a splashy way, literally, for someone who rents the newest vehicle in the small fleet of Bob Marc Limousines of Deer Park. Marc Henig, the owner, has equipped a long white stretch with a Jacuzzi. It is obviously not for everyone.
"My late father thought I should counter the competition by doing something like this," said Mr. Henig, who arranged for a company in Texas to stretch a truck, a Ford F350 with four tires on the rear axle to handle additional weight. The hot tub carries 100 gallons of water, less than backyard tubs, but it can seat two to four people. The normal rate for renting this limo is $125 an hour, with a five-hour minimum.
In the two months he has offered the limo, Mr. Henig said, a few people have taken the plunge, at tailgate parties in the Meadowlands before football games, for example. "A girl in a bikini in a hot tub," Mr. Henig said, "is a perfect way to draw attention. And don't forget those couples that want a romantic interlude."
On one recent Saturday the limo with the hot tub saw service in Far Rockaway, Queens, rented as a gift for the wedding of Kishore Sumarzer and Amreeta Goolcharran of Far Rockaway. A friend, Rick Brocia, a cook at the Cornbread and Caviar restaurant in Baldwin, arranged for the five-hour rental after Mr. Sumarzer had seen the vehicle and admired it.
"The reaction from the bride's side was ecstatic," Mr. Brocia said. "Everybody wanted to get inside the limo -- it was too cold to use the tub -- and one time we had 20 people in it, looking inside, jiving around."
Mr. Brocia said that a lot of the fun at a wedding of this type was about competition. "We outdid ourselves," he said. "We just showed them up."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In / Lincoln Park in Yonkers;
A Convenient Slice of Middle America

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
KEVIN GORMAN and his wife, Marie, have just passed the kind of landmark that most people can only dream about: They have lived in their Lincoln Park home long enough to have just made their last mortgage payment.
"It's been 25 years," Mr. Gorman said, "And I'm going to burn that mortgage."
Now that they have reached that occasion, the couple, who raised two daughters in their three-bedroom Cape Cod in the Yonkers neighborhood, have no intention of moving, at least for now. 
 "Not while I'm still working," said Mr. Gorman, who is an import specialist with the United States Customs Service. He commutes every day in a car pool to the World Trade Center.
"I've always liked Lincoln Park for its proximity to Manhattan," he said. "When we were shopping for homes, we looked at Orange County and other places, but this was much more convenient."
In many ways, Lincoln Park is a typical Yonkers neighborhood. "It's not the most affluent," said Lee Ellman, the city's Director of Planning. "It's right in the middle, sort of a 'Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House' kind of place."
Sandwiched between major thoroughfares such as Central Park Avenue and McLean Avenue, Lincoln Park exists as a distinct residential oasis of tree-lined streets. Even though the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway is just east of the neighborhood, there is surprisingly little noise or traffic on the streets, which resemble those of a small middle-American town far removed from normal bustle of southern Westchester County.
Mr. Gorman said that one of Lincoln Park's main attractions for him and his family is the ability to walk to local shopping.
The major shopping district is McLean Avenue, where there are a variety of bakeries, delicatessens and restaurants, like the popular Mannion's Restaurant, an Irish pub that caters to the recent influx of Irish immigrants.
Some establishments have reputations that extend far beyond the immediate neighborhood, such as the Lincoln Park Pastry Shop, which makes the "best rugelach in Yonkers," Mr. Ellman said.
Margo Bennett, who has her own real estate business in Dobbs Ferry, just opened another office in Yonkers last month. "I'm a Yonkers resident and my husband has been in the city forever," she said. "I wanted to also sell in the city." She considers Lincoln Park an urban type of suburban neighborhood -- "Riverdale-like," she said, referring to the upscale section of the northwest Bronx.
The average price of a house is in the low $200,000's and the high end hits the upper $300,000's, Ms. Bennett said. Most houses were built on small lots in the 20's, 30's and 40's. They are primarily Tudors and brick colonials, with a smaller number of ranches that came in after World War II.
One current listing is for a three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath brick colonial built in 1940 and selling for $225,000. "The average price at Lincoln Park is perfect for young families," Ms. Bennett said. "And we're getting a lot moving in from the Bronx. They prefer the neighborhood to many others since it's so convenient."
A lot of buyers these days are of Irish or Italian extraction, she said. "They're attracted to the two parochial grammar schools," St. John the Baptist and St. Paul the Apostle, both Roman Catholic grammar schools, serving grades pre-k through 8.
Both schools offer a core academic curriculum, as well as music, art and computer classes. St. John has an enrollment of 360 students, with an annual tuition of $1,900; at the 350-student St. Paul the tuition is $2,400.
THE Stein Yeshiva of Lincoln Park, which was established in 1984, recently moved to a new ranch-style building at Wendover Road and Central Park Avenue. The yeshiva has eight classrooms, office space, a library, a lunchroom and a playground. There are plans to add a gym and additional classroom space to handle larger-than-expected enrollment.
The school, which goes from kindergarten through eighth grade and accepts both boys and girls, started with 30 students and now has more than 140. Until the new space is added, some classes are being held at the Lincoln Park Jewish Center. The yeshiva declined to disclose its tuition.
At one time, Lincoln Park was a predominantly Jewish neighborhood, according to Elliot Palais, who, with his wife, Lorraine, has lived there since 1961.
"In many ways the neighborhood hasn't changed all that much," Mr. Palais said, "but now it's much more mixed, and there are very few Jewish families anymore." Mr. Palais is president of the Lincoln Park Jewish Center, which is also a synagogue and has been a neighborhood fixture for over 60 years.
"We've lost a lot of Jewish families over the years," Mr. Palais said. "They retired and moved away and we're not getting the young families." Thirty years ago, the center had a membership of about 500 families, Mr. Palais said. "Now there are between 90 to 100 and they're aging," he added.
At one time, the local public elementary school, called School 21, was a prime attraction for young families to Lincoln Park. "It was the cream of the crop," Mrs. Palais said. "It gave out the most Regents scholarships."
In 1986, in response to a Federal Court order requiring Yonkers to desegregate its schools, the city revamped the entire system, replacing neighborhood schools with a magnet program in which parents can send their children to any school in the district, if space is available.
All the schools specialize in particular subjects and students are bused in from other areas. The two public schools in Lincoln Park are School 21, for grades pre-K to 5, and the Lincoln High School of Economics and Finance.
School 21 focuses on the teaching of foreign languages and multicultural education. "We teach Spanish and Italian, and the foreign language teachers participate not only in the language classes, but in the regular academic classes too," said Ana Celia Delgado, the school's principal.
School 21 also emphasizes reading, Ms. Delgado added, and has a 40-minute silent reading period first thing every morning. Last year, the school also had a sixth-grade class, which has now moved to the middle-school level.
"Ninety percent of our sixth-grade students last year tested above average in the state's standardized reading and math exams," Ms. Delgado said.
The Lincoln High School of Economics and Finance requires a core curriculum of mathematics, applied mathematics, science, humanities and foreign languages; all subjects are taught in relation to the business world.
The school offers advanced-placement courses in Spanish, English, calculus, biology, United States history and government.
For some of Lincoln Park's longtime residents, small changes can loom large. "It doesn't have the same quality of life it once did," Mr. Palais said. "For instance people never used to park in front of other people's homes. But that's a little thing. Otherwise it's pretty much the same."
The stateliest homes in Lincoln Park are near the Jewish Center, according to Anthony D'Apice, of D'Apice Realty. There, Georgian brick colonials and Tudors stand on green knolls overlooking streets seemingly with as little traffic as there might have been when the houses were first built 50 or more years ago.
"I think people bought them or had them built there so they could walk to the temple," Mr. D'Apice said. Moving out from the Lincon park Jewish Center, the homes get a little smaller and closer together, he added.
SOME streets have almost all Tudor homes. Then just around the corner and there are streets of colonials. In the 1990 census, there were 1,726 households in the neighborhood, 65 percent built in 1949 or earlier, 82 percent in 1959 or earlier. "Those numbers haven't changed that much," said Mr. Ellman, the Director of Planning. "There hasn't been a whole lot of new construction since then."
Although not exactly in the neighborhood, Lincoln Park residents can easily walk to Tibbetts Brook Park, a 161-acre recreation center run by the county. It has six tennis courts, picnic tables, lake skating and fishing, ballfields, hiking and biking trails, miniature golf and a swimming pool.
There's also the much more modest, but popular, one-and-a half-acre Conor Jr. Park, on McLean Avenue, which is run by the city. It also has tennis courts, as well as a children's playground and basketball courts.
The park, which dominates a major entry point into Lincoln Park from Central Park Avenue, recently underwent a $200,000 renovation, including new landscaping, playground equipment and basketball courts.
"It was time," said Mitchell Tutoni, one of the city's park commissioners. "The park gets a lot of use from people of all ages. It's very popular with seniors, who like to sit on the benches in the passive green space on McLean Avenue. You can see them all day long in the nice weather. And the young people use the ballfields and basketball courts. It's really a neighborhood park in the truest sense of that word."

WHAT'S IN A NAME?: The City of Yonkers is not sure how or when Lincoln Park got its name. "But there was a Lincoln station nearby on the old Putnam division of the New York Central Railroad," said Jeffrey Williams, principal planner for Yonkers, adding that trains started operating on the Putnam line in 1881. "Before being called Lincoln Park, the neighborhood was known as Hillview." There might be a Civil War connection, since several roadways -- Sedgwick, Sherman and Lee Avenues -- are named for Civil War-era generals. A short entry in "Place Names of Westchester County, N.Y.," however, says that Lincoln Park is an 1893 developer's name for the area between Sedgwick and Central Park Avenues, south of McLean Avenue. "The Lincoln station on the Putnam division was opened shortly thereafter," the entry says. There is also a .55-acre park, formerly called Memorial Park, acquired by the city in 1921, southeast of South Broadway and McLean, the site of a monument to Abraham Lincoln. The park is now called Lincoln Park.

HEADLINE: As Gas Prices Fall, East End Feels Left Out

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KIGGEN MILLER 

 BODY:
IF East Enders have the impression that they are in their own little world out there, this time they may be right. While the rest of the country is enjoying gasoline prices that, adjusted for inflation, are the lowest since the 1950's, on the East End prices are among the highest in the nation.
State Assemblyman Fred W. Thiele Jr., Republican of Sag Harbor, said so many people on the East End have complained to him about the prices that he has asked the State Consumer Protection Board to investigate. 
 The national average retail price for regular unleaded gasoline is about 93.5 cents a gallon and has been steadily declining for three months, according to the Department of Energy. On the Island, the average price in Nassau County is $1.06, while Suffolk County's average is $1.09.
But Mr. Thiele has found that prices are from 15 to 20 cents per gallon higher in the five East End towns of Riverhead, Southampton, Easthampton, Shelter Island, and Southold. Those lofty prices can be found consistently in only one other place in the continental United States: California, mainly around San Francisco, where the Lundberg Survey, a California company that tracks gasoline prices, says the average price is $1.20 a gallon.
"The cost of living here is high, but it's not enough in my mind to justify differences of what may be as much as 35 cents a gallon," Mr. Thiele said. "People have a right to know why their gas is so expensive."
Good luck finding out. A Mobil station in Southampton is selling regular gasoline for $1.19 a gallon. In Bridgehampton, a BP station is selling it for $1.29, and it's $1.25 at a Sag Harbor Getty station. None of the East End gasoline stations contacted for this article would comment about their prices. Mobil Oil, which has several stations on the East End, wouldn't explain the higher prices except to say that they are affected by real estate costs, taxes, salaries, transportation of gas from terminals, and competitive conditions in the area.
Duncan MacKenzie, a spokesman for the New York State Petroleum Council, a trade association representing the major oil companies and a division of the American Petroleum Institute in Washington, said local gas prices were indicative of the cost of living for each area.
"It's unfair to single out gasoline," Mr. MacKenzie said. "All consumer goods in that area are going to be higher."
Consumers have a much simplier explanation.
"They're really milking the public," said Robert Callendar of Southampton, who has complained to Mr. Thiele about the prices. "It's always been this way and there's no business logic for it."
Mr. Thiele said that major oil companies may be operating under the impression that East End residents are affluent and can pay more.
"We know that the median income on the East End of Long Island is lower than the rest of Long Island," he said.
Tim Ryan, a spokesman for Suffolk County Executive Robert Gaffney, said East End prices were in some cases lower than western Suffolk, pointing to a survey completed last month by the Suffolk County Executive's Office of Consumer Affairs of 52 retail gasoline stations in Suffolk.
"If we're talking about the five East End towns being higher than the rest of the county, that's simply not true," Mr. Ryan said, referring to a Consumer Affairs survey of gasoline prices.
The New York and Long Island region are subject to Federal E.P.A. regulations requiring an additional process called reformulation, by which gas is made to burn cleaner, according to Steve LaFever, a spokesman for the State Consumer Protection Board. The reformulation process is required because of poor air quality in the region, adding to cost of retail gasoline prices, he said.
However, Mr. Ryan said the reformulation regulations apply to the entire region, not just to the East End, so they affect prices equally. "There is absolutely no correlation between any environmental rules and prices on the East End" he said. "Everything just costs more on the East End."
Although the consumer board can investigate the pricing, it has no enforcement powers. But the State Attorney General does, who Mr. Thiele also plans to notify. Scott Brown, a spokesman for the Attorney General's office, said it could only act if there was evidence that stations were colluding on prices, and no one is accusing gas dealers of that. Otherwise, there is little the Attorney General can do.
"I think there's a lack of competition here, but to me, there's an element of gouging in that," Mr. Thiele said. "If you're charging higher prices just simply because you think you can get away with it, that's unfair."
Federal and state taxes account for about 50 cents per gallon of retail gas prices, but there is no standard markup for gas dealers, Mr. MacKenzie said. "If they want to charge $5 a gallon and they can get it, that's their prerogative," he said.
Ed Lincoln, assistant manager at the Southampton Mobile station on Route 27, agrees that gasoline prices on the East End average 20 cents higher, but said he could not explain why.
"Once you pass the Shinnecock Canal, there are higher prices," he said. "I don't know why. People are commenting, but not complaining. We're selling a lot of gas, so we must be doing something right."
