HEADLINE: Q&A/Nancy Wyman;
One Woman's Passion for the Budget

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
WHEN State Comptroller Nancy Wyman was asked what book she had read most recently, she answered, "The state budget," what she describes as an "exciting and interesting" operation.
In her years in the legislature representing the Tolland area, Ms. Wyman has fought hard for generally accepted accounting practices, what she calls "truth in budgeting," to replace what she scornfully calls "this thing called a modified cash basis." (She explained that it is a system that permits the delay of major payments in order to show an artificial surplus.) 
 She will again propose to the Governor and the legislature that generally accepted accounting practices, mandated by the state but not followed by municipalities, be adopted. "I am very tight with the taxpayer's money," she said. But she has also been an outspoken advocate for better funding in education and health care. She was first, she says, to propose a children's health plan, now known as the Husky Plan, but she said, "the media credited the Governor." Would she like credit? "Sure!"
She is the first woman in the comptroller's job, having entered politics via the Tolland Parent Teachers Organization, then the school board. Next she ran successfully for the State House where she served for eight years.
"When asked what I wanted to do next I said 'Comptroller'," she recalled. "The response was 'You mean Secretary of State, don't you?' " She laughs. No, her passion is the number crunch. She is pleased to see more woman entering state government in Connecticut. "What you see are young men and older women," she explained, the women having taken time first to raise children.
Recently Comptroller Wyman met to discuss the state's economy. Following are excerpts from that conversation:
 
Q. What does the State Comptroller do?
 
A. I am considered the fiscal guardian for the state. I basically take care of the health care and benefits for all the state's employees. I purchase health care for 166,000 people -- 50,000 state employees, their families, retirees and their families. We're the people who really keep an eye on how the money is being spent in the state. We put out a monthly report that talks about where we are and what it looks like for the rest of the year and a year's report in January that covers the entire year and looks to the future.
 
Q. How is the financial health of Connecticut?
 
A. Of course we concentrate a lot on the debt. After all, we are the highest debt per capita in the country. As far as our economy, we look pretty good right now. We will have a surplus at the end of the year again. What we are seeing is a slowdown of the revenues coming in.
Last year at this time we had already brought in about 13 percent more in revenues from income taxes. Now we're at about 5 1/2 percent more. That's because we are now very low on unemployment. Before we were putting people on new jobs all the time. Right now it is bottoming out for us.
Before when we had the major layoffs, income tax revenues were way down. Now they are coming up. The interesting part is corporation taxes are doing pretty well even with the cutbacks we've been doing.
 
Q. Is there something we should be doing to take advantage of the good times to protect us from another cycle of economic uncertainty?
 
A. My biggest fear is that during good times we have not done the revamping that we should have been doing. We have let things go instead of looking for cost savings and efficiencies in government because the revenues have been so high. We're sitting pretty.
So when the times are good we cut taxes. We don't put our hand in your pocket. But when the state is in trouble, that usually means you the taxpayer are in trouble. We come back and increase your taxes. We'd like to see a much steadier flat pattern so we don't have these games.
 
Q. What are some cost savings you can see?
 
A. About a year and a half ago the Federal Government gave us leeway to deal with Medicaid and Medicare. We started to study it. I guess it got too confusing for the Governor's people and they let it drop. Health care is one of the biggest costs in our state budget not only for our state employees but for the Medicaid population. That's one thing we could have done and should have done for the people of the state.
 
Q. Is the Medicaid population that financially significant for the state?
 
A. It's about a $2 billion portion of our budget. Over $1 billion of that is going to our senior citizens' nursing homes. Most people think that it's the poor person in Hartford or New Haven that's on Medicaid. It's not. The majority of Medicaid goes to the senior citizens in nursing homes.
My big push is for people to buy long-term health care insurance now. Talk about efficiency in government, this is a long-term efficiency. You might not see savings today but in the long run, if you can keep people at home with an insurance policy, they won't change over to Medicaid so quickly. And it will improve the quality of life for seniors.
 
Q. Are Connecticut's computers ready for the year 2000?
 
A. The Governor had a force of people come into each agency to determine how much it would cost to ready the state's computer systems for the year 2000. One of the estimates was $6 million for my agency. My people said, "Please Nancy give us a chance. Let us try. We think we can purchase systems and it won't cost you nearly that much."
In fact two out of our three systems are up and running and have been for the last five or six months. The third system will be running by the end of this month or beginning of February. It will cost us no more than $700,000. That's over $5 million in savings for the people of the state.
My question is: "What's happening in those other agencies?" We sent out a note offering to help out with the year 2000. I don't know if it's politics but they all stayed away.
 
Q. Why are you suing Blue Cross/ Blue Shield?
 
A. Blue Cross/Blue Shield has changed. When they started in this state well over 50 years ago, they were a not-for-profit. So the state gave them a lot of breaks -- tax breaks, hospital breaks, many different areas, because they were a charitable type of organization.
They went to a mutual company in 1985-86. Now they are for-profit since Anthem came in and bought them. They had a major surplus of about $270 million. What they want to do is shift the money that they have from tax breaks and the surplus to Indiana. We are saying "No." That money should at least stay in the state of Connecticut and be used for our policyholders.
About 78 percent of people in state government have Blue Cross/Blue Shield. My husband and I also have a small policy which makes me a policy holder. So I thought in my position I could fight for the policyholders in the State.
There are two lawsuits going one. The other is from the Attorney General's office. We should be getting money one way or the other.
 
Q. Did you support the tax rebate?
 
A. We came up with this because I believe in keeping the financial status firm and straightforward. If you look at business profit at the end of the year, the stockholders usually get a refund. Our original proposal said No. 1, you fill the Rainy Day Fund which is like a savings account, then second you take 80 percent of that money and give it back as a rebate and the rest put toward retiring the debt.
We came out with it months before the Governor, but because he does get much more press than the Comptroller does, the Governor picked it up and ran with it. There were many Democrats who were not happy with it and many Republicans who were not happy with it but I believe rebates should be permanent.
 
Q. What happened to the lottery money earmarked for education?
 
A. Ella Grasso wanted to bring in lottery tickets to the State. The only way she could do it was to say that the money would be dedicated to education. That's how she sold it. Of course that's the one statement that Ella Grasso made that anyone who lived in the state at that time has never forgotten.
We only get about $700,000 from the scratch tickets. The Mashantucket and Mohegan gambling money is dedicated to the municipalities to keep their budgets balanced.
We spend over $2 billion in this state on education. The lottery money is basically in the general fund and we pay for education out of the general fund.
 
Q. Will Connecticut ever abolish the state income tax?
 
A. There is no way that anybody can come in and abolish the state income tax. If it wasn't for the state income tax the Governor wouldn't be getting his Patriots right now. We overspent our budget the last two years exceeding the cap on spending. The only way we could do that is because revenue is coming in. Most of our revenue comes in from the state income tax.

LENGTH: 1676 words

HEADLINE: Making Films, Making Waves

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

 BODY:
LIGHTS! Camera! Complaints! When the thrill of film production gives way to the reality of traffic jams, generators and klieg lights, some residents, particularly those in small towns and villages, find themselves less than star struck. Reflecting what many Manhattan neighborhoods have been complaining about for years, some municipalities are seeking to limit the disruption that can come with movie, television and commercial production in their neighborhoods.
The reaction comes at a time when the county has been aggressively courting the film industry and partly reflects its success. Cities, towns and villages have been host to a variety of feature productions. The county's Film Bureau estimates that the movie business will bring more than $10 million into Westchester this year. County Executive Andrew J. Spano views the industry as an important component in the county's economic development and earlier this year reinstituted the Film Bureau, which had been disbanded in 1995 by Andrew P. O'Rourke, the County Executive then. 
 To be sure, many municipalities are delighted to be the site of commercial productions. Yonkers has been nicknamed Westchester's Tinseltown and was recently described in a cover story in Daily Variety in Hollywood as a hot spot for filmmaking. New Rochelle has been the host to 18 commercial shoots this year, ranging from commercials to feature films. And movie making has not lost its glamour. Even the most jaded resident can get excited about a Harrison Ford or Woody Allen sighting.
Further, make-believe can be unexpectedly charming. Last month travelers at the County Airport saw fall foliage on the trees in front of the terminal -- even though it was a nude December day. A production company had attached fake leaves to the bare branches to film a scene for the movie "Random Hearts," which stars Harrison Ford and Kristin Scott Thomas. The filming, which had been delayed, was meant to re-create Manchester Airport in New Hampshire in the fall.
As the movie industry becomes a bigger presence in the county, municipalities have been challenged to balance the interests of movie producers with the needs of residents. Towns often stand to make substantial fees by allowing filming on their streets; at the same time they face aggravated residents who do not appreciate being told they cannot walk down those streets during filming.
"People move into these towns for the quality of life," said Mayor Sean Treacy of Sleepy Hollow, which has been host to several film projects. "The question we have to ask is, Is it right to disrupt that for additional monies to the municipality?"
Each of Westchester's 44 municipalities has its own regulations concerning commercial filming. Most charge fees and regulate traffic, parking and the hours filming is permitted. Some also require advance notification of residents concerning a production. To expedite business for production companies, Iris Stevens, the County Film Bureau's liaison, has published a guide, which includes each town's requirements. She said films always bring money into a municipality.
"It has a wonderful ripple effect throughout the community that these films are in," Ms. Stevens said. "Money goes into pet community projects. Money goes into the police DARE fund, building funds. When they run out of paint, they go to the hardware store. They use local delis. They rent V.F.W. halls. It's a nice chunk of money."
Sleepy Hollow was expecting just such a windfall when the village was negotiating with Universal Studios over the filming of "One True Thing," which starred Meryl Streep. Village officials and studio personnel worked out a contract with 42 clauses, which, among other things, had the film company paying $1,000 a day to the village, $500 to the local garden club and $20,000 to a neighborhood project.
The filming, however, never happened in Sleepy Hollow. Residents balked at night filming in a residential neighborhood, objecting to the expected noise, traffic and lighting. The homeowner across the street from the location refused to allow the production crew access to his property, and in frustration, the studio withdrew its application. The movie was later shot in New Jersey.
"We were living diagonally across from the location, and they were going to be shooting overnight," Klaus Schmidt of Sleepy Hollow said. "I'm certainly not against shooting movies, but this created some sticky problems. There were going to be numerous trucks, generators and lights. The movie company was pretty arrogant about it. They told us they would give us dark curtains, and if it really bothered us, they would put us up in a hotel. They were so darn sure that everyone would say, 'Oh, wonderful!' "
Hastings-on-Hudson commands one of the highest fees for filming: $1,500 a day and other requirements, including paying for off-duty police officers, posting a bond and signing contracts with merchants, who also receive a fee when filming takes place downtown. "We require any production company to jump through a lot of hoops to be able to film here," Neil Hess, the Village Manager, said.
When H.B.O. went to Hastings last month to film "Earthly Possessions," starring Susan Sarandon, which was also filmed in New Rochelle and Yonkers, they paid the village $20,000 altogether. Susan Maggiotto, Deputy Manager for Hastings, said the feature that makes Hastings attractive to movie producers -- the quaint, old-time look of the village -- also makes production difficult to manage.
"Our little downtown is very concentrated and bordered on one side by the river," Ms. Maggiotto said. "There are very few choices of egress. In New York City, if you're blocked, fine, you go another way. In Hastings, there's just one way to get where you're going, and if you can't go that way, you're stuck."
Ms. Maggiotto said that some merchants did not see the benefit of film production. "They say that the crews come in with their own food trucks, so they're not in the local delis," she said. "All they see is that their own customers can't get to their stores."
The manager of Hastings Video disagreed, saying she greatly enjoyed seeing her small town transformed for the filming of "Earthly Possessions." Stores were dressed up with new fronts, and a rain machine produced drizzle in front of her store.
"It was fun," Dorothy Honovich-Kavanah, the video store manager, said. "Our store became Get Away Travel. The architect firm next door became a bank. The bank was made into a funeral home. And Susan Sarandon was lovely and gracious. It was really a nice thing to happen here."
A Hastings resident, Linda Atkinson, was trying to run errands on the day "Earthly Possessions" was being filmed. "You're trying to go about your daily business and some young kid comes up and says, 'Excuse me, you're not allowed on this side of the street,' " she said. "And you want to say, 'Excuse me, but I live here and I need to go to the video store and the bank.' "
Ms. Atkinson, an actress and a documentary film producer, said she knew the industry all too well. One recent morning she found a young woman in her front yard. The woman said she represented a film producer who was interested in using the house next door for a location.
"Being in the industry, I know my neighbor is excited because she's going to make a couple of thousand bucks, but I know we're talking about 20 trucks maybe, miles of cables, and you're talking about people that don't mind walking in your yard or stepping on your lilac bush," Ms. Atkinson said.
Ms. Stevens, of the county film office, said that film crews are now taking a much more respectful attitude toward private property. "I've monitored most of the productions that have gone on here," she said. "Part of my job is to protect Westchester County. I have seen a real change. There's a softer, gentler production community, which is much more mannerly."
Ms. Stevens said that some municipalities greatly desire filming and some abhor it, and there was little in between. One community that has seen little production is Armonk in the town of North Castle. Supervisor John A. Lombardi of North Castle said, "This is not a neighborhood where people feel they need the income for the community." He said even the possibility of opening a four-screen movie theater in the town raised residents' hackles.
Coincidentally, many of the communities that are home to movie stars have the strictest filming ordinances. Supervisor John R. Dinin of the town of Bedford -- where Glenn Close, Chevy Chase and Richard Gere live, among others -- said: "Basically, we don't look at this municipality as a great revenue source. While we don't mind filming, this is first and foremost someone's residence." Mr. Dinin said he has had requests ranging from taking over the entire hamlet of Katonah and blocking it from traffic to having buses explode.
Pound Ridge, which is home to Christopher Reeve, Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins, recently updated its filming ordinance, adding fines for noncompliance. Supervisor Joy G. Simpkins said that Pound Ridge was happy to work with film companies but added that production must be controlled.
The new regulations prompted the local weekly newspaper, The Patent Trader, to run an editorial titled, "That's Telling Them," which said, "Maybe they can get away with high-handed behavior in Hollywood, but in northern Westchester, we all know who owns the world, and it isn't some outfit with a camera."
This kind of talk is discouraging for Ms. Stevens, whose job it is to encourage film making in the county, but she takes it in stride. Ms. Stevens said: "This is a business of extremes, and that's how the towns are. They either love it or they hate it. Some communities really don't care if it's the Pope -- no filming allowed, period. But if I can't get access to one community, there's always another that looks like it or that can stand in for it. And there are plenty of places that welcome movies and the economic development they bring."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%); NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
In the Last 2 Years, Rental Construction Spurts

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FOR most of the last decade rental apartments were the wallflowers of the residential market in northern and central New Jersey, where production of such housing had slowed to a trickle.
But in the last two years developers have renewed their interest in building apartments, seizing what they say is an opportunity to build upscale rentals in urban areas that until now were unable to accept such units and in suburban markets that until recently resisted them. 
 While the focus is on the Hudson River shoreline, rentals are sprouting in urban areas like Morristown and New Brunswick, as well as in suburban towns like Westwood.
"There has been a dramatic increase in rentals," said Paul J. Kaliades, president of the New Jersey Apartment Association, a trade group in East Brunswick. "But the new starts just begin to bring balance back to the rental equation, which has been imbalanced since the condo conversion craze of the last decade took lots of units off the market."
State figures show the number of housing permits issued for rental units last year was 3,994, or about 13 percent of the total of 29,795 permits issued. In 1997, 3,201 permits were issued for rentals, or about 11 percent of the total number of 30,357 housing permits.
Much of the recent activity is the work of three companies: Avalon Bay Communities, a real estate investment trust based in Alexandria, Va., whose only business is developing rentals; the 30-year-old Applied Companies of Hoboken, which started out building affordable rentals in Hudson County and switched in the mid-80's to market-rate rentals, and the Roseland Property Company, a five-year-old firm based in Roseland that builds mostly rentals as well as housing for the elderly and detached houses.
The companies are building or will build over the next 18 months a total of 6,500 rental units.
Several factors are motivating these and other builders to put up rentals, including the state's strong economy and housing market.
The ripple effect from Manhattan's rental market also cannot be overlooked, Mr. Kaliades said, noting that the rental vacancy rate in northern and central New Jersey was 5 percent.
Another factor is the availability of financing. "Apartments remain an investment vehicle of choice," said Steven D. Heller, senior vice president at Arcs Commercial Mortgage Company of Princeton. "Central and northern New Jersey, where there are wall-to-wall people building apartments, are as safe bets as you can get."
But, Mr. Heller said, challenges persist that will keep the field of players limited and demand ahead of supply. They include the scarcity of properly zoned sites and high construction and land costs. Many municipalities also continue to resist rentals because they are perceived as taxing local resources, especially schools.
SOME of the new projects are rising on once commercially zoned land. Others are being developed as a result of towns' wanting -- or being forced through builder lawsuits -- to meet their obligations under the state's Mount Laurel doctrines, which require municipalities to provide opportunities for developing housing for people making 50 to 80 percent of the median income in the area.
Analysts expect 1999 to be another good year for the state's rental market. Officials at Avalon, Applied and Roseland, like other developers, said they will stay the course because of the unmet demand from people who choose not to or cannot buy.
Roseland started out acquiring reclaimed properties from lenders. But in the last two years it has made the transition to a private development company that concentrates on rentals "because even though they are harder to do and require a lot of capital, there is little vacancy and turnover in the northern and central New Jersey market," said Marshall B. Tycher, Roseland's president.
Roseland, which secures its financing from pension funds and insurance companies, is building 2,000 apartments in northern New Jersey and will be developing 1,000 more over the next year. With the land it now owns, Roseland has the potential to build more than 6,000 units.
Two projects under way are on the Hudson River shoreline in West New York: the Landings at Port Imperial with 276 units and Riverbend at Port Imperial with 1,032 apartments. They are rising on the 100 acres the company owns and plans to develop into a community with 4,200 residences.
"We cut our teeth on the waterfront in Hudson County," Mr. Tycher said, "Now the issue is to build in the suburbs outside of Hudson so we are picking markets where the rents are at a premium to offset the high construction costs."
To that end Roseland is building a 216-unit complex in Westwood in Bergen County, where no new rentals have been built in 20 years. It also has a development under way in South Plainfield with 252 apartments, 15 percent of them Mount Laurel units.
Most of the apartments Roseland builds have one and two bedrooms and 775 to 1,175 square feet of space to appeal to young professionals and empty-nesters rather than families, Mr. Tycher said. Monthly rents for the riverfront units are $1,600 to $2,400 or $2 a square foot. Rents for suburban apartments -- typically 750 square feet for a one-bedroom and 1,050 square feet for a two-bedroom -- are $1,050 and $1,400, respectively, or $1.10 to $1.60 a square foot, he said.
The Applied Companies owns and manages 5,000 rentals, and has some 1,500 units under way or expected to begin in the next 15 months. It also has the potential to build a total of 3,500 units on land it now owns.
Applied, which also is active on the riverfront, has built or is building 350 apartments on the southern waterfront in Hoboken in a project called the Shipyard that will eventually contain 1,160 units. The company, with separate partners, also plans to build 550 more units on Hoboken's southern waterfront and an equal number of units in Fort Lee.
In addition, it also has built or is building projects, each with 100 rentals, in the downtowns of Morristown and New Brunswick. Applied secures its financing from banks, pension funds and institutional partners.
EXPLAINING his company's strategy, David B. Barry, senior vice president at Applied, said: "Our roots are in the urban areas, which allowed us to see the demand for market-rate rentals. That demand is ongoing in cities that offer cultural amenities and infrastructure to support them."
Demographics also favor rentals, Mr. Barry added. He said forecasts were that the number of people in their 20's would increase in the next decade as would the number of empty-nesters -- markets that he said his company courts. Applied builds mainly studio to two-bedroom units with 600 to 1,200 square feet of space. Mr. Barry said riverfront units rent for $2 a square foot or $1,200 to $2,400 a month. Those in Morristown and New Brunswick, which range from 600 to 975 square feet, rent for about $1.50 a square foot, or $900 to $1,460.
"Except for the potential of a short-term slowdown in the absorption of riverfront units," Mr. Barry said, "we think the rental market is a good place to be for the next few years."
Avalon Bay Communities, which has built 2,000 rentals in the state, is now developing 620 additional units in two projects -- one with 351 units in Fort Lee, the other with 269 units on the Jersey City waterfront. In the next 18 months it also plans to build three other projects totaling 1,380 units in Florham Park, Freehold and Edgewater.
"Our strategy is to create a dominance," said Gwyneth J. Cote, a regional vice president at the company. With the new projects, she said, Avalon will have four projects each in and around the Route 1 corridor in central New Jersey and along the shoreline in Hudson and Bergen Counties.
The company also is known for pushing the envelope on rents. At Avalon Cove, its 504-unit community along the Jersey City waterfront, the one- to four-bedroom units, rent for $1,700 to $4,650 a month, or $2 to $2.20 a square foot -- the highest rents achieved so far.
"In good times and bad our philosophy does not change," Ms. Cote said. "We're in the luxury market and there will always be people willing to pay for a quality apartment, especially in northern and central New Jersey where, like the rest of the metropolitan New York region, the demand is high and the supply is thin."

HEADLINE: In the Region / Connecticut;
Casino Traffic Pointing Way to Revival in Norwich

BYLINE: By By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
JOHN M. SMITH, the third generation of his family to run the Cranston Company in downtown Norwich, decided 16 years ago to move his art gallery and framing business out of the downtown and into a strip mall in the Norwichtown section.
"Downtown had a lot of the same problems that every other downtown had -- parking was not convenient, a lot of buildings were not being kept up and it just wasn't a good place to do business," Mr. Smith recalls. "So we left." But late last year, he moved back, into a 2,800-square-foot building at 100 Water Street newly renovated by the Norwich Museum Trust, a group that is working with the city and other groups to breathe life back into the downtown. 
 "I don't think I've ever seen a community so focused on revitalizing its downtown," Mr. Smith said.
City Manager William Tallman is anxious for the start of four projects that will invest almost $50 million in the downtown, including two new hotels, a transportation center and an artists' complex with apartments and galleries. Construction on the projects is to start in the next several months.
"The town has never really thought well of itself, the feeling was it was second class, and it always would be, and second class was good enough," Mr. Tallman said. "That's changed. I think there's a renewed sense of pride, the City Council is very aggressive about revitalization, and everyone is working together."
Meg Malmborg, the city's tourism director and head of its Main Street Project, said the city had not only placed more emphasis on attracting new businesses but also cracked down on blighted buildings, forcing owners to make improvements or give them up. Norwich has also invested in new sidewalks, street lamps and other amenities and is working with private organizations, regional groups and state agencies. Formerly, initiatives might have focused in one area or been undertaken by one group.
"In the past, I don't think anyone realized how hydra-headed this problem was," Mrs. Malmborg said. "You can't just attack one of the problems, you have to do it holistically, and that's what we're doing now."
To be sure, the projects envisioned would represent the revitalization of only the core of the downtown, with the hope of other projects to follow.
Ted S. Montgomery, executive vice president of the Norwich Community Development Corporation, said the city hoped that the interest in the downtown would spread to other parts of Norwich. His organization has obtained a $100,000 state grant to study expansion of the city's 450-acre industrial park by up to 200 acres.
"The downtown is like the ego of the community -- people judge you a lot on the looks of your downtown," Mr. Montgomery said. "People have to realize that the downtown affects the entire community."
In the 18th and 19th centuries, Norwich was affluent, with a deep-water port on the Thames River giving it access to Long Island Sound and with a number of rivers powering textile and other mills that are still there, though largely vacant.
For much of the last half of this century, however, it declined as the mills closed and trading moved away. Today the city of 36,000 in eastern Connecticut is experiencing a rebirth -- once again partly resulting from its location. Norwich is only a few miles west of the Foxwoods Resort Casino operated by the Mashantucket Pequot tribe and a few miles north of the Mohegan Sun Casino of the Mohegan Pequots. Much of the renewed interest in downtown Norwich stems from the traffic through the region generated by the two casinos.
The Mashantuckets have also demolished five decrepit buildings in the downtown in what was once known as the Mercantile Exchange to make way for an $18 million, 100,000-square-foot development that will include a 120-room hotel, retail space and a restaurant. "The tribe has a number of members who have personally invested in downtown Norwich, and have committed to helping revitalize the city," said Susann Viafora, a tribal spokeswoman. "The feeling is, what's good for the community is good for the tribe, and vice versa."
ARTSPACE L.L.C., which opened an apartment building in Hartford in 1997 that drew 400 applications for 48 units, is finishing up plans for a $7.5 million renovation of the city-owned former Goldberg building at Chestnut and Franklin Streets, and the Konover Investment Corporation is planning a $12 million to $15 million renovation of the former Wauregan Hotel at Broadway and Main Street.
"Time and the weather have not been kind to the building," David H. Kagan, executive vice president of Konover Investment, said of the Wauregan, which was a luxury hotel in the 19th century. "The roof has been open to the elements for some time, so the majority of the interior is going to be a complete rebuild. But we hope to save the original facade and some of the architectural treatments."
The company has uncovered photographs of the hotel in its glory days, and will seek to do a faithful restoration, with about 60 rooms and a ballroom. Although two new hotels have opened in Norwich in the last few years, a Comfort Suites and a Marriott Courtyard, Mr. Kagan does not expect to compete with them.
"This is not going to be a Ramada or a Motel 6," he said. "It's going to be upscale, one of a kind, with period antiques in the rooms and lobby and the feel of a grand European boutique hotel."
The state has put up most of the money for a $7 million transportation center near the viaduct at the southeast edge of downtown, a complex that will bring together rail, taxi, bus and ferry service.
Besides the four projects going through the final approval process, a number of others are on the drawing board. The largest involves the other casino operator, the Mohegans, who are discussing with the city a proposal for a $9 million technology center in the former Masonic building on Broadway.
Ronald Aliano, a local businessman who founded a successful ambulance company 27 years ago, then built an upscale marina on the harbor in 1987, a new restaurant on the waterfront two years later and a miniature golf course three years ago, is now renovating an Art Deco building on Main Street. "If the marina hadn't been done, I think it would have been a lot more difficult to get people interested in the downtown," Mr. Aliano said. "That whole area was an eyesore. Now, it's time for other projects to move forward.
"If you look at the architectural detail, Norwich clearly was very vibrant at one point. It's just a matter of putting it all back together. We've always talked about the great potential of Norwich. Hopefully, with the Mashantuckets' development, and Konover doing a hotel, and all the other work that's happening, it will be a catalyst for even more."
The question now is whether the development proposals will spark even more interest in the downtown, Mrs. Malmborg said. She is preparing a request for proposals for a restaurant in a former city firehouse in the downtown. Already, six restaurant operators have asked to be notified when it is ready, she said.
"That will be a good indicator whether there's any interest from outside the area, whether all that's happening is really attracting new business," Mrs. Malmborg said. "I think a lot of people are still waiting to see the actual buildings going up, though, before they are ready to jump in."

HEADLINE: There's Money to Spend But Priorities Differ

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
FLUSH from their joint success in landing the New England Patriots, Gov. John G. Rowland and the Democrats who control both houses of the General Assembly were tripping over themselves last week with promises to work together during this year's legislative session. At the same time, however, they have announced conflicting priorities that could mean tense months ahead.
Governor Rowland and his fellow Republicans in the legislature have stressed their desire to put a brake on, or even pare, state spending, while Democrats said they hoped to take advantage of the booming economy to make progress on education and other issues that took a back seat as the state struggled out of the recent recession. 
 Mr. Rowland does not plan to ask for any new big-ticket projects, but he told legislators he would not retreat on any of the major programs passed during his first term, including health coverage for uninsured children, open-space preservation and pollution reduction in Long Island Sound.
The new session, which began Wednesday and runs through June 9, kicked off with good will toward all. Shortly after he was sworn in for a second term, Mr. Rowland told legislators he was eager "to continue that same bipartisan approach that has worked so well for us over the last four years." The Senate President pro tem, Kevin B. Sullivan, Democrat of West Hartford, used his opening address to call for "a spirit of mutual respect that values what each has to offer."
But that was Day 1, and Mr. Sullivan acknowledged in a pre-session briefing that opening day at the State Capitol amounts to dessert. When the Governor delivers his budget on Feb. 10, Mr. Sullivan said, "There's the opportunity for vegetable and other sorts of unsavory things." When the food fight begins, here are some things that will be on the menu:
Senate Democrats announced an agenda, "Common Sense for a New Century," that includes a continuation of the tuition freeze at state colleges and universities, new protections for the privacy of medical records, and aid to school districts for Internet equipment. Some of the potentially more expensive items are a pilot program to cover adults who do not have health insurance (similar to the program for uninsured children), increasing direct student aid for colleges and universities, and improving the availability of mass transit.
"This is one of those years where there is a real opportunity to be responsibly proactive," said the Senate Majority Leader, George C. Jepsen, a Democrat from Stamford. "Sometimes you just have to plug the dike. But this year, because of the strong economy, we're not under pressure."
The new Speaker of the House, Representative Moira K. Lyons, a Democrat also from Stamford, staked out similar ground in her speech accepting her election during the legislature's opening session. "The last General Assembly made strides by improving reading and early-childhood education," she said. "These initiatives should be maintained and strengthened so that all children have the opportunity to succeed."
But a Republican leader of the Senate, Louis C. DeLuca of Woodbury, indicated that his party is headed in a very different direction. Although he, too, said he favors increased spending on education, he said he hoped for an agency-by-agency review, in order to spot areas for cutbacks.
"The danger is that when the times are good we say, 'Well, everything's fine,' " said Mr. DeLuca, the minority leader pro tem. "This is when good businesses cut back and get a little thinner. And then when the bad times come, they can survive. Morning comes! The hangover comes."
House Republicans also issued a formal agenda, topped by tax cuts. "We're not saying they have to be massive," said the House Minority Leader, Representative Robert M. Ward of Northford. "We just think that we need to set the tone that to control the spending, you gradually ratchet taxes down."
The House Republicans also said they want to expand state support for charter and magnet schools, to allow parents more choice, and to increase accountability for teachers and administrators, eliminate automatic promotion and attack habitual truancy by making parents responsible.
The two parties have several areas of overlap in their plans. (Even the packaging blurs the traditional distinctions between the parties. The Senate Democrats' platform is headlined, "Spending restraint, property tax cuts, education, health care top list," while the House Republicans go with, "Republicans Target Income Tax Cuts, Schools, Tuition Freeze, Open Space.")
Both parties want to strengthen the state's Megan's Law, which is supposed to make it possible for citizens to learn if any neighbors are convicted sex offenders. Although regulation of health maintenance organizations was a Democratic campaign issue, Republicans seemed to be jumping on board. House Republicans made it one of their agenda items. And the Senate Minority Leader, M. Adela Eads, a Republican of Kent, said, "The H.M.O.'s need monitoring. I've been getting a lot of mail about this."
This is a year when the legislature will adopt a two-year budget, and one of the most pleasant -- although potentially contentious tasks -- will be deciding how to spend the budget surplus from last year -- which is expected to wind up between $350 million and $500 million. In his State of the State address, Mr. Rowland said he wanted to "cut additional taxes, whenever and wherever possible," and raised the possibility of another tax rebate like the one last year, which his critics had derided as an election-year gimmick.
Democrats seem willing to go along. "Rebates could be part of the final puzzle," Mr. Jepsen said. "It is doesn't mean that some Democratic leaders are going to be out there pushing for them. But if the Governor insists," he said they could be part of a solution.
In Connecticut, Democrats traditionally push for property-tax relief and Republicans prefer income-tax cuts. So while a tax cut is likely, the formula will be hotly debated, and some hybrid is likely to result.
As another use for the surplus, Mr. Jepsen said legislators might try to reduce the long-term cost of the $375-million stadium in Hartford for the New England Patriots by increasing the amount of the surplus that is to be used for a down payment on construction, beyond the $100 million currently planned. That would save the state money in the long run, by reducing the amount that must be borrowed.
This may be the last year when legislators have such a big cushion. In a recent report, the State Comptroller, Nancy Wyman, a Democrat who was inaugurated on Wednesday for a second term, warned, "There are now clear signs that the exceptional revenue growth that we have been experiencing is slowing." (Ms. Wyman talks about state finances in an interview on Page 3.)
Whatever happens, Fairfield County can expect to be looked after as never before now that Representative Lyons of Stamford is the House Speaker, the first woman to hold that office. She promised to continue looking out for the region in the areas of mass transit, highway safety and economic development. Mr. Jepsen, the Senate majority leader, is also from Stamford.
As the session progresses and tempers flare, Senator Sullivan says he has thought of a way to retain the civility that seemed like such a good idea during opening week: "If either the Governor or us stray too much from that," he said, "we're prepared to bring Jesse Ventura in to mediate."

HEADLINE: After a Roller-Coaster Year, Optimism

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
REAL estate executives used words like "frothy" and "giddy" and "frenzy" to describe the investment market in the New York area during the first half of last year. Fueled by a seemingly unlimited amount of capital from Wall Street, real estate investment trusts and private operators bid against each other for available properties, driving up prices.
Today, the froth has flattened and nobody is feeling very giddy. At the same time there is little gloom. 
 Although the capital markets took the industry on a roller-coaster ride last year, the fundamentals of the commercial real estate business remain strong and most executives are optimistic about the coming year.
"We are at the top end of a real estate cycle, so 1999 should be a good year, but not a spectacularly good one," said Dennis Yeskey, managing director of the real estate services group at Deloitte & Touche, the accounting and consulting company.
Michael T. Cohen, president of Williams Real Estate, said that "what we saw last year was a historic disconnect between the rental and sales markets." Mr. Cohen said that commercial rents remained strong even as the prices of properties fluctuated in response to activity in financial markets.
"The good news," said Raymond G. Torto, a principal in Torto Wheaton Research, an econometric analysis firm specializing in real estate, "is that real estate has made it in capital markets," allowing financing to be raised by public stock and bond offerings.
"That is also the bad news," he added, noting that events in foreign countries can affect projects and prices in the United States, regardless of local market conditions.
Real estate investment trusts, known as REIT's, were the first to feel the market's sting, as disenchanted investors drove the prices of their shares down, preventing the REIT's from selling more shares to finance a continuation of their buying binge. The overall stock market also took a sharp lurch downward in August, raising fears of layoffs in financial services companies.
Those worries have not entirely evaporated despite the market's strong showing in recent months.
"We saw that public markets for real estate are quick to go down and slow to recover," said John I. Bralower, the president of Sonnenblick-Goldman, a real estate finance company. "The underlying market for the properties did not go down as much as the stocks."
Meanwhile, recessions in Asia, currency problems in Russia and the near-collapse of a huge American hedge fund shook up the bond market in this country, leaving Wall Street firms unable to convert the mortgage loans they had already purchased into securities.
With widespread uncertainty about the future pricing of mortgage-backed securities, liquidity dried up and sales ground to a halt.
Properties that had been for sale were withdrawn from the market because of uncertainty and declining bids. According to Insignia/ESG, a real estate brokerage and services company, properties that were pulled off the market included the 1.5 million-square-foot building at 450 West 33d Street, the 1.1 million-square-foot structure at 237 Park Avenue, at 45th Street, and the million-square-foot building at 450 Lexington Avenue, at 45th Street.
One transaction that did close reflected the abrupt drop in pricing. The Witkoff Group acquired the Woolworth Building, at 233 Broadway, for $133 million after having successfully reduced its original -- and accepted -- bid of $157 million. The seller was the Venator Group, the successor to the old Woolworth Corporation..
All the time the capital markets were churning, most of the real estate fundamentals were strong, with office vacancies low and rents stable or climbing. According to a year-end report prepared by CB Richard Ellis, a brokerage company, the overall office vacancy rate for Manhattan was 5 percent, with the Midtown North subdistrict, generally defined as 32d to 59th Street, river to river, down to 3.2 percent availability.
Asking annual rents for all classes of multitenanted commercial buildings in Manhattan reached $36.60 a square foot in the fourth quarter, according to the report, compared to $29.96 at the end of 1997. Brokers reported that some prime buildings in key locations, such as 9 West 57th Street and the General Motors building at 767 Fifth Avenue, were fetching as much as $70 to $75 a square foot.
Because of these strong fundamentals, most real estate leaders say they are cautiously optimistic as they head into 1999. The relative lack of new construction in Manhattan will keep office rents high, they say, although builders in New Jersey are betting those rates will drive some companies to their developments along the Hudson River waterfront.
The big layoffs that were feared in the financial services industry have not materialized, reducing the chances that a lot of office space will be dumped back on the market.
Meanwhile, new industries, most of them computer-related, are growing in Manhattan and injecting new life into what had been declining postindustrial neighborhoods, such as the garment manufacturing buildings in the teens between Fifth and Sixth Avenues and the old printing buildings near Hudson Square on the west side.
The companies in these new industries are contributing to the numbers and pace at which new leases are being signed. "Leasing velocity over the last two years has been 25 to 30 percent better that the best years in the past," said Stephen B. Siegel, the president of Insignia/ESG.
Mr. Siegel said he expected the pace to decline somewhat in 1999, but added that some large space users, including the NASDAQ stock trading operation and the German-based publishing company Bertelsmann, are actively looking for new quarters.
Liquidity will return to the market, real estate executives say, as Wall Street firms sell their portfolios of existing loans and start looking for new business. "People talked about a capital crisis, but it was really a pricing crisis," said John D. Lyons, chief executive of Granite Partners, a real estate financing firm. "People were not lending because they did not know what price to lend at."
He said that one result of the crunch is that money is more expensive for acquirers and developers than it was. He said that interest rates are 2 to 2.5 percent above Treasury securities with a similar maturity, compared to 0.8 to 1.0 percent above during the summer. But he said that was still more favorable than the 3 to 3.5 percent premiums that prevailed three years ago as the market was developing.
At the height of the crunch in October, he said, lenders were demanding rates of up to 7.50 percent, regardless of how low the rates on Treasury securities fell.
Higher interest rates and the need for buyers to put up more equity capital means that the prices paid for property are expected to be somewhat lower than in the first half of 1998.
"The return on equity is higher than debt," said Barry Gosin, the chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate, explaining that stockholders want more income for their greater risk than the relatively more secure bondholders.
Mr. Gosin said if a purchaser has to put up 30 to 40 percent equity -- rather than the 5 or 10 percent that was sufficient when money was flowing out of Wall Street -- it limits the ability to bid. "You have to pay less for properties," he said. "It's that simple."
Mr. Gosin said that prices appeared to be down 10 to 20 percent, although not many transactions have closed since the bond market crunch began in the fall.
Some real estate executives say the markets have functioned as they are supposed to, cutting off funding before too many people joined the party. "The capital markets exerted discipline and prevented overbuilding," said Mitchell Hersh, the president of Mack-Cali Realty, a New Jersey-based REIT. "It is usually supply that puts markets out of balance."
The furious pace of the first half of 1998 many have contributed to the slowdown in the later months, said Thomas L. Benneville, managing director of LaSalle Partners' investment banking group.
"A lot of guys in my business had the year in the bag by July," he said. "So when the markets got hit, they had no reason to move quickly."
But he predicted that sales activity would pick up quickly this year. "The real estate fundamentals are still good," he said, "and you have to eat in '99, too."
Others agreed. Darcy Stacom, an investment sales specialist at the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage company, said that the Wall Street firms started getting back in the market late last year and that she expected sales to be brisk early in the year. "We are going to see a lot of product for sale in the first quarter," she said.
One sale that closed late in the year was that of Exchange Place Center, a 700,000-square-foot waterfront office tower in Jersey City, for $175 million. The building was purchased by BBV U.S. Real Estate Fund III, a German investment group, from Prudential Real Estate Investors.
In the leasing market, brokers say they expect the landlords in New York to continue to have the upper hand, but few are predicting sharp increases in rent.
"There have been better times to be a tenant," said James Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners, a tenant's representative. "Rents will go up marginally, but you will see less free rent, less work and tougher lease terms," he said, referring to provisions that give tenants a period of no rent and require landlords to contribute to renovation costs.
But some brokers say the summer's dips in the stock market have cooled the demand for space. "During the summer there was an intense frenzy for every piece of space," said Mitchell Steir, an executive vice president of the Julien J. Studley brokerage company. "That has leveled off. Now the landlords do not have two backup deals for every bit of space."
Although the decline in the price of REIT shares sharply slowed their pace of acquisition, it did not prevent Reckson Associates Realty Corporation from becoming the second of the suburban-based REIT's to enter the Manhattan office market. The first was Vornado Realty Trust, which acquired the Mendik Company's midtown portfolio in early 1997.
Reckson reached agreement to acquire Tower Realty, a Manhattan-based REIT with seven buildings totaling 2.3 million square feet, including Tower 45 at 120 West 45th Street.
The original plan was for Reckson to be an equal partner with Crescent Real Estate in an acquisition vehicle called Metropolitan Partners. But when Crescent pulled back, Reckson went ahead with the acquisition for a total of $680 million in cash, stock and assumption of debt, with Crescent remaining as a passive investor.
Scott Rechler, the president of Reckson, described the acquisition as a strategic one for the company, which already has properties on Long Island, in New Jersey and in the area north of New York City.
A report by CIBC Oppenheimer, a securities brokerage and research firm, on the deal said that "With Reckson having established a dominant position as an owner/operator of office and industrial real estate in the suburban New York market, the Tower acquisition appears to be a natural extension to fill a geographic void in its portfolio." But it warned that Reckson needed to find managers for the Tower properties who are both savvy about the Manhattan market and able to participate smoothly in a suburban-oriented company.
The following is a look at markets in the metropolitan area:
 
Midtown
Prime Office Space
Is Scarce
Space in modern buildings in good locations is all but unavailable, real estate executives report. "In the top 65 buildings north of 42d Street, the vacancy rate is about 2 percent, which is something that we have not seen since 1980," said Steven A. Swerdlow, senior managing director of CB Richard Ellis's metropolitan area office.
With prime space scarce, some tenants are even leasing space they do not currently need in anticipation of even higher rents and stiffer terms in the future. "We are seeing a mentality of taking an extra 10,000 square feet of space and warehousing it," said Robert Emden, an executive managing director of Grubb & Ellis, a brokerage company. "Tenants are concerned about protecting themselves down the road."
Unlike the last office market peak in the 1980's, there is very little building going on in Manhattan, and the few projects under way or announced are largely preleased. The Reuters news and financial information company will occupy most of the 856,000-square-foot building, designated 3 Times Square, being constructed at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street.
The largely complete 1.6 million-square-foot building at Broadway and 42d Street, designated 4 Times Square by its developer, the Durst Organization, will be divided between the Conde Nast publishing company and the Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom law firm.
The financial services company Bear Stearns will be the principal tenant of a 1.1 million-square-foot building under way on Madison Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets.
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter will be the principal tenant and co-developer of a million-square-foot building to be built on what is now a parking lot on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets. The co-developer is the Rockefeller Group, the former proprietor of the landmarked Rockefeller Center and still the part owner and manager of four buildings along the west side of the Avenue of the Americas facing the center.
 
Downtown
High-Tech Firms
Keep on Arriving
Because the midtown market has reached saturation, "the overflow tenants will have to flow downtown," said Mr. Cohen of Williams Real Estate. "Because that is where the double-digit vacancies remain."
During the year, Guardian Life Insurance Company of America said it would move from the Union Square area to 7 Hanover Square near the lower tip of Manhattan, while Empire Blue Cross & Blue Shield decided to leave midtown for 461,000 square feet at One World Trade Center.
"The most important thing for downtown was that there was no disaster in financial services," said Mr. Siegel of Insignia/ESG. He said that the developing infrastructure of what was once canyons of office buildings -- new stores, hotels and other amenities -- was making the area attractive for people who like to live near where they work.
In addition, the city-subsidized Plug 'n' Go program and other incentives have attracted computer-based companies to downtown buildings that have been rewired and outfitted for tenants who need robust telecommunications, power and cooling services.
"All this activity has accelerated the relocation of numerous small high-technology companies from places like Vancouver, Cambridge, Mass., and New Hampshire to downtown," said a report by CB Richard Ellis.
 
The Suburbs
The Action Is
In New Jersey
New Jersey is where the commercial development action is, both along the west bank of the Hudson and in the middle of the state in Morris and Somerset Counties. Private developers are leading the way, with REIT's -- even those with development sites -- holding back because of uncertainty about how financial analysts will value projects that have no current income.
"Wall Street does not know how to handle development projects, so the REIT's will not build on speculation," said Donald P. Eisen, executive managing director for the suburban market at Cushman & Wakefield. Mr. Eisen said that between 2 million and 3 million square feet of office space was under construction in the state, which he said was not a major addition to a 140 million-square-foot market.
SJP Properties is building three speculative office projects in Morris, Somerset and Mercer Counties totaling 900,000 square feet and has an agreement with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to build a 1.2 million-square-foot office building on the waterfront in Hoboken.
Although he will not start the Hoboken project without an anchor tenant, Steven J. Pozycki, the company's president, said his relationship with pension funds insulated him from the ups and downs of capital markets.
"The funds followed us in the early 1990's when we were doing acquisitions and since 1994 when we resumed development," he said. "Our investors know we will take reasonable risks."
Mr. Pozycki said that with Class A office buildings replacing abandoned industrial plants on the Hudson, the west bank of the river should be regarded as part of the Manhattan market. But it is a place that is cheaper and where it is possible to erect buildings with large floors suitable for trading floors.
Emanuel Stern of Hartz Mountain Industries is developing projects as varied as an office building at 90 Hudson Street in Jersey City, the TriBeCa Grand Hotel at Sixth Avenue and White Streets in Manhattan and an 1,100-car parking deck in Newark.
He said the problems in the credit markets actually helped established developers like himself, who can finance their own projects if necessary. "It's the new guys who get hurt," he said.
Speculative building is also under way on Long Island, where Greenway Plaza Office Park, a Melville developer, started a 100,000-square-foot office building on Pinelawn Road in Melville in July. Fortunato Development of Bohemia followed in October with a 60,000-square-foot building at Airport Corporate Center in Bohemia. And in December, the Tilles Companies began a 100,000-square-foot building at Gateway Office Park in Woodbury.
In Westchester, a rising vacancy rate, caused by the relocation of large companies such as I.B.M. and Nynex, is squelching any plans to build. The country's overall vacancy rate stood at 18 percent in 1998, compared to 16.5 percent the year earlier. In the business hub of the county, White Plains, vacancies were 30 percent, up from 28.3 percent in the previous year.
The little building that is under way in Connecticut is not taking place in the traditional office center of Stamford, but in places like Shelton, Norwalk and suburban New Haven. One of the most ambitious projects is under way in Bridgeport, where the city is embarked on a $1 billion, 3-million-square-foot waterfront commercial and retail development.
 
Retail
Low Vacancy Rates
And Higher Prices
A low vacancy rate -- under 5 percent, according to some reports -- and strong demand for prime locations has driven up rental rates for retail space in Manhattan, with parts of Madison Avenue among the most expensive in the world.
"A store with 4,000 square feet on the ground on Madison Avenue commands in excess of $500 a square foot," said Faith H. Consolo, a senior managing director of Garrick-Aug Associates, retail real estate specialists. "A year ago those deals were $250 to $250 a square foot."
Ms. Consolo said that the strong economy and the appeal of New York were behind the demand. "New York is where retailers want to be," she said. And the appeal is not just glamour. Sales at a Manhattan store can be as much as those of five or six suburban mall stores combined.
"There is competition for every location that comes on the market," said Alan Victor, an executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation, a retail brokerage company. He said the demand came from stores already in Manhattan, such as the Gap, Old Navy and Coach, which added locations, and from newcomers such as Restoration Hardware, which are opening their first stores.
In addition to high-fashion stores that cluster on Madison and Fifth Avenues and are slipping into areas like SoHo and the Flatiron District, chains that deal in more mundane items and have been successful across the country are looking to New York for expansion, brokers report. They say that Wal-Mart and Target are particularly interested in breaking into this market.
 
Hotels
Room Rates and
Occupancy Rise
The city's hotels continue to be essentially full, with profits rising as operators raise room rates and developers scour the city for sites to build new hotels or convert existing buildings for use as hotels.
According to a report by E&Y Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group, occupancy last year was 83.0 percent compared to 81.5 percent in 1987. The average room rate in the city reached an all-time high of $192 a night, which was a 9.5 percent increase over the previous year.
Revenue per available rooms, a key indicator of financial performance, also reached an all-time high of $159, according to the report, which was a 11.5 percent increase over 1997.
The financial performance of hotels in New York far outstrips the rest of the nation, said Sean Hennessey, head of the new York hospitality practice of PricewaterhouseCoopers, an accounting and consulting company.
Mr. Hennessey said that in 1991 annual income per room after expenses in New York was $9,179, compared to $4,977 for the rest of the country. In 1997, the figure for New York was $32,008 compared to $10,100 elsewhere. "New York is three times more profitable than the average for the United States," Mr. Hennessey said.
As a result, there are 16 hotels with a total of 3,256 rooms under construction, renovation or considered likely to go forward, according to a PricewaterhouseCoopers survey. Nine more hotels, with 3,540 rooms, are in the planning process, and 17 more, with as many as 6,480 rooms, are in the proposal stage.
But rapidly rising room rates may be too much of a good thing, Mr. Leventhal said. "With the average daily rate for Manhattan approaching $200 a night," he said, "Manhattan could be pricing itself out of some market segments such as wholesale and leisure travel as well as lower-rated corporate travel."

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Fewer Firefighters But Lots of Chiefs

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: WEST NEW YORK

 BODY:
At an appearance here last month to talk about the regional fire department formed by five communities in Hudson County, Governor Whitman praised the effort to overcome the state's history of home rule. The merger, the Governor told the crowd, would result in a property tax savings by stripping away overlapping layers of bureaucracy strewn across municipal borders.
But relinquishing turf as closely guarded as firefighting zones is difficult. When the newly formed North Hudson Regional Fire and Rescue -- made up of departments from Union City, North Bergen, West New York, Weehawken and Guttenberg -- swore in its leaders last Monday, it had an unusual and somewhat unexpected command structure: two chiefs and two executive directors. 
 "So much for economy," said David I. Fox, a lawyer who represented Union City firefighters in an unsuccessful suit to put the merger to a vote.
Although proponents of the merger defended the layers of leadership, critics said it flew in the face of the effort to reduce the bureaucracy. "It's going back to square one: more chiefs, fewer Indians," said Mayor Peter LaVilla of Guttenberg.
At the department's swearing-in on Jan. 4, Anthony J. Presutti was appointed chief of administration; he will be paid the same $125,000 a year that he had received as chief of the West New York Fire Department. His co-chief of operations, Robert A. Jones, who had been the chief in Union City, will continue to receive $130,000 a year. Jeffrey C. Welz of Weehawken, sworn in as executive director of operations, and Michael J. DeOrio of North Bergen, the executive director of administration, will both earn $42,500 a year.
Robert Aiello of West New York, chairman of the department's governing board, said that having two chiefs and two executive directors was a temporary measure to insure a smooth transition. "My gut reaction is, that will narrow down in the next couple years," Mr. Aiello said, adding that the chiefs are in their 60's and nearing retirement.
Just how much money the regional department will save is uncertain, Mr. Aiello said. For one thing, no budget has been agreed on, though officials expect savings by cutting some of the 350 positions through attrition. In addition, the departments had different pay scales; officials acknowledged that salaries were likely to go up for lower-paid firefighters rather than have higher-paid people take cuts.
There are also startup costs, which Governor Whitman said last month would approach $2 million, including the buyout plan, legal and consulting fees and new equipment. But, she added, the state could pay those costs under pending legislation.
A spokeswoman for Ms. Whitman, Wendi Patella, said the department's multiple management team does not represent a bureaucratic backslide, and the Governor still expects "significant" savings from the merger.

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
One Track, Two Loads

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
Like the goose that suddenly started laying golden eggs, New Jersey's rail system has turned from an unwelcome burden to an invaluable treasure, a vital artery for commuters as well as goods. While that may be welcome news for the region's economy, it may not be for the commuters whose trains will face growing competition for track space on crowded freight lines.
As demand for passenger service has surged statewide, with little new track being laid, a reorganization of the region's freight rail system is scheduled to take effect March 1, splitting the old Conrail monopoly between two national shippers, CSX and Norfolk Southern. The shift will return competition to the area for the first time in more than two decades. 
 The effect over the next few years, most industry experts believe, will be dramatic increases in freight business as the new competition forces prices down and service quality up. A tug-of-war between passengers and freight is an almost certain outcome, the experts say.
"It's very difficult to operate freight and passenger service on the same tracks," said Craig Lewis, a vice president at Norfolk Southern. "With the speed of passenger trains, it's almost like a Pac-Man scenario." Passenger trains are so much faster that the space between trains needs to be much greater.
The struggles are likely to be intense. Irritated commuters can always complain to their elected officials; after all, the New Jersey Department of Transportation and New Jersey Transit are state agencies. But as in most of the country, the majority of existing tracks are owned by private freight lines and passenger trains pay for the right to run on them.
On March 1, 445 of the 1,000 route miles (multiple tracks can be laid along a single route) Conrail owns in New Jersey will fall under the jurisdiction of what is called "new Conrail," a jointly owned subsidiary of Norfolk Southern and CSX, and the remainder will become the property of one or the other parent company, as part of a deal worth more than $10 billion. Each parent will get one major northern and southern route into New Jersey: Norfolk Southern will take over the route from Bound Brook to Allentown and from North Bergen to Suffern, while CSX will take the route from North Bergen toward Albany (the West Shore Line) and from Bound Brook to Trenton.
New Jersey Transit currently operates on a total of about 850 miles of track, of which it owns 500 miles. CSX and Norfolk Southern will own about 100 miles and Amtrak owns about 240.
All the players have anticipated friction, and have tried to foresee ways of minimizing it. Since New Jersey Transit owns at least some of the track the freights will run on, it will have leverage in disputes. And there are already carefully negotiated guidelines that aim to protect passenger service without unduly hobbling the freights. For instance, the D.O.T. and New Jersey Transit say there will be no curtailment of current passenger service, so conflict will be reserved for the expansion of commuter services New Jersey Transit has planned, particularly in northern New Jersey.
For instance, CSX expects its freight business to need all the capacity on the West Shore line. But New Jersey Transit has plans to expand service in that area, and the agency bought some right of way along the route in 1978.
The conflict has its roots in the early 70's, when half a dozen freight companies went bankrupt. The Federal Government stepped in, creating Conrail in 1976. For 11 years it operated the company, selling off any "extra" land and rights, a downsizing that railroad watchers now groan over, since it would be prohibitively expensive, if not physically impossible, to reclaim those resources.
"Once you have people building pools in the old right-of-way, it becomes pretty hard to get it back," said Douglas Bowen, president of an advocacy group called the New Jersey Association of Railroad Passengers.
In 1987 the Government sold Conrail to the private sector, so when CSX and Norfolk Southern signed an agreement last year to pay more than $10 billion for it, they were making an ordinary business deal, in which the first priority is turning a profit.
Norfolk Southern has a reputation for accommodating passenger service, according to Mr. Bowen. On the other hand, he said, CSX "has a reputation for being notoriously anti-passenger rail."
"I don't want to say it doesn't play fair, because it's their railroad, they can do what they want," Mr. Bowen added. But some would call their approach downright hostile."
CSX presents itself as an asset to an area that needs to make some difficult choices for its own economic vitality. For the moment, the state D.O.T. agrees. Increasing the amount of freight that moves by rail gets truck traffic off roadways and allows the region's economic strength to grow. Local imports and exports should increase, as should traffic to and from Ports Newark and Elizabeth, both say.
"The region has grown its industrial base," said Mike Brimmer, a regional vice president for CSX. "And you still have major facilities that depend on rail, like the chemical companies, the Ford plant in Metuchen, the G.M. assembly plant in Linden. And the same population that increases the demand for passenger service also increases the demands for orange juice and televisions."
Not all the passenger rail companies expect trouble. Amtrak, for instance, is positively sanguine. Rick Remington, a spokesman, said that freight on Amtrak's Northeast Corridor generally operates only between 10 P.M. and 6 A.M. and that Norfolk and CSX were already running about six more trains during those hours without creating problems.
And if a train loaded with freight could make its delivery schedule only by running during prime passenger hours?
"It's our call," Mr. Remington said. "It's our railroad."

HEADLINE: N.J. LAW;
Smoke Signals

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Smokers in New Jersey took such a shellacking at the cash register last year that they stopped buying cigarettes in numbers never seen before. How many stopped smoking is a separate question.
Since the state cigarette tax doubled last Jan. 1, sales have declined about 12 percent, Treasury Department data show. While some sales have been chased across state borders, public health experts estimate that at least two-thirds of the decline reflects a decrease in smoking. 
 "Wow, that's a whole lot more than we predicted," said Larry Downs, director of New Jersey Breathes, a coalition of anti-smoking organizations. Before the increase, Mr. Downs said, consumption had been dropping by 2 to 4 percent a year. "Something's going on," he continued. "I'll give you 4 percent for people buying cigarettes elsewhere and I'll take the 8 percent drop."
Mr. Downs said the tax increase had set up "a real-life public health experiment": While New Jersey's tax rose to 80 cents a pack from 40 cents, neighboring states maintained their rates -- Pennsylvania at 31 cents a pack, New York at 56 cents and Delaware at 24 cents. Len Fishman, the state Commissioner of Health and Senior Services, said the initial wallop was meant to drive down sales, even though most of the new revenue finances health care.
"We were hoping a dramatic increase would decrease consumption," Mr. Fishman said. "We did predict that there would be a reduction in the number of people who smoke." He said that in his travels around the state, "a lot of people have told me that they quit, and a lot told me that this was the straw that broke the camel's back."
The tax increase placed New Jersey behind only Alaska and Hawaii, at $1 a pack, and Washington State, at 82.5 cents. (On Jan. 1, California's tax rose to 87 cents a pack.) The sticker shock was compounded last month by a price increase, 45 cents a pack at wholesale and about 60 cents at the counter, from tobacco manufacturers.
The two hits raised prices by about 50 percent. At Wawa convenience stores, for example, premium brands cost $3.32 a pack, up from $2.22 before the tax increase.
Revenue from tax stamps from Jan. 1 through June 30, the end of the 1998 fiscal year, were about 13 percent below what they would have been had sales remained at their 1997 levels; when the effect of volume discounts was taken into account, the decline in cigarette sales was about 12 percent, Treasury Department officials said.
Preliminary figures for the current fiscal year show similar decreases. When the tax took effect, cigarette revenue was already falling; in the fiscal year 1997, revenue dropped 2 percent. Had that dropoff continued, 1998 revenue through November would have been about $433.3 million, or 54.2 million cartons. Instead, revenue was about $379.4 million, or 47.4 million cartons. The gap, then, represents about 6.8 million cartons, and there is no way to know how many were bought in other states.
In New York, cigarette tax revenue from January to November 1998 was 0.3 percent below collections fore the same period in 1997 Pennsylvania reported a 1.4 percent increase in 1998. In Delaware, where revenue was already increasing at a rate of 3 percent a year, the first half of 1998 saw a 10 percent increase over the first half of 1997. Pennsylvania's additional revenue through November represents about 1.2 million more cartons than were sold from January to November 1997, but sales were declining -- by 1.8 percent in the 1997 fiscal year -- and if that decline had continued, the extra tax collections would represent about 2.9 million more cartons.
Delaware's extra sales through November, assuming a continued 3 percent increase, exceeded 500,000 cartons. While researchers have consistently found dropoffs in smoking after price increases, they cannot know exactly what role prices have played. There have been few large, one-time price increases, and no precedent for a tax increase as large as New Jersey's.
Mr. Fishman cites the example of Massachusetts, which raised its tax 25 cents a pack in 1992 and registered a 12.5 percent decline in sales the next year.
"Talking about price increases can be tricky," Mr. Fishman said. "If you have gradual increases, you lose some of the impact. A state with a high tax may have had less of an increase over the years."
It is especially hard to measure the effects of cigarette prices on underage buyers. Many studies have concluded that price has a greater effect on children and teen-agers than on adults. But a recent analysis by economists at Cornell University, using data on students who were eighth graders in 1988, found that price increases had very little effect on whether they took up smoking.
And while the smoking rate among adults has been inching down -- to 23.2 percent of adults nationwide and 21.5 percent in New Jersey, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention -- it has sharply risen among teen-agers and children. In its most recent published survey of high school seniors, taken in 1997, the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research found that 24.6 percent were daily smokers, a figure that has steadily climbed from a low point of 18.1 percent in 1988.
In New Jersey, the centers' 1997 survey of 9th to 12th graders found that 38 percent had smoked a cigarette in the previous month and 19 percent were daily smokers.
Mr. Fishman said his department had predicted a decline of 10 to 12 percent in smoking among children and teen-agers as a result of the tax increase and that its effects would become clearer this spring, when the state surveys middle-school students.
It will be longer yet before the manufacturers' price increase, which took effect only in late November, shows measurable results. But Rich Herbeck, co-owner of Irwin Tobacco and Candy, a distributor in Trenton, said that even though the increase was nationwide, it was sending New Jerseyans across the bridges just as the tax hit had done last January.
"People were so shocked by it that they're looking for any method to save money," Mr. Herbeck said.
