SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 9; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1081 words

HEADLINE: ON THE TOWNS: THE ARTS;
Healing the Wounds of Racism Through Expression

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
A CONNECTION between Newark and next month's PBS broadcast of "I'll Make Me a World," an examination of black contributions to American culture, may have been a marriage made in heaven.
The scheduled broadcast of the six-hour series comes at a time when the city is still awash in the enthusiasm generated by the success of the year-old New Jersey Performing Arts Center and the hopes it has fueled for a broader revitalization of the city. It also coincides with a movement within the city to get in closer touch with Newark's rich artistic roots, and to view the city anew despite its image as a troubled urban area. 
 "It is a depressed area, but we all know that as far as the culture and art is concerned, it is not depressed, but very rich," said Faith Ringgold, a visual artist in nearby Englewood. "It is important that Newark know that they may not have much money, but they have great art and artists."
Getting that message out is the goal of the Newark Coalition for "I'll Make Me a World," consisting of local arts groups, colleges, foundations and artists who have arranged nearly two months of events promoting the show and Newark's artistic heritage. The coalition includes the Newark Museum, the New Jersey Historical Society, Seton Hall University, the New Community Corporation, Aljira: A Center for Contemporary Art and WBGO-FM.
The events, which begin today and run through February, range from art exhibitions and jazz concerts to lectures, films and radio programs. The events will highlight not only the contributions of artists like Ms. Ringgold, Amiri Baraka, Sarah Vaughan and Paul Robeson, who are prominently featured in the series, but also the work of local artists who are not, like the Montclair jazz musician and composer Steve Colson, and the photographers Bill May and Mansa Mussa and the painter Bisa Washington, all of Newark.
Newark is one of 11 communities nationwide that have received grants from national and local foundations to develop programs highlighting and promoting the series, produced by the award-winning documentarian Henry Hampton and his production company, Blackside Inc., in association with WNET, Channel 13. Mr. Hampton, who died in November, was the executive producer of the "Eyes on the Prize," documenting the civil rights movement; "America's War on Poverty"; "The Great Depression" and "Malcolm X: Make it Plain."
Robert Lovell, director of publishing, education and new media for Boston-based Blackside, said such local efforts were part of the the company's attempt to draw attention to its work amid the cacophony of offerings available on 65 cable television outlets, the Internet and other competing media. It was also a way of promoting partnerships between large cultural institutions with smaller, local African-American arts groups, as well as extending the educational uses to which the programming can be put -- both of which, he said, nicely dovetailed with the educational and cultural missions of foundations around the country.
In addition to foundation money assembled by Blackside, the Newark coalition received support for its programs from the New Jersey Council for the Humanities and the Morristown-based Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation.
Two visits to Newark by Mr. Hampton over the last two years suggested the possibility of some synergy between the broadcasts and local concerns, coalition members said. Alexandra Christie, a program officer with the Dodge Foundation, recalled a program at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in October 1997 at which the foundation, which gave financial support to the documentary, was honoring Mr. Hampton.
"His being here inspired people to think about things locally," Ms. Christie recalled. "The first thing he said to us from the stage was that he wanted to talk about memory and how you can't understand where you are going unless you understand where you have been. He saw things that no one else saw, and suddenly what he was doing and what so many of us wanted for Newark seemed a perfect match."
Last year, Mr. Hampton returned to Newark to be honored by Aljira, a small art gallery and performance space, said Jane Stein, program coordinator at the Newark Museum. He met more people among the city's arts community and made more converts to the idea of promoting the documentary along with Newark's arts community and artists.
Sam Pollard, a co-executive producer of "I'll Make Me a World," who with Ms. Ringgold will be part of today's start of the local coalition's promotional programs, said he hoped the series would draw attention to the arts' importance to any society. He recalled that the actor Ossie Davis, one of several artists featured and interviewed in the series, said art -- whether it was music, painting, literature, dance or other performances -- was a way for black people to find out who they were as they struggled to overcome racism and the other consequences of their history as slaves.
"He saw the arts as being like a breath of fresh air," said Mr. Pollard, interpreting Mr. Davis. "So we are not only trying to highlight heroes of the past but encourage people to take a look at the people in their community who are contributing artistically today."

HEADLINE: Looking for the Right Words at the Detroit Show

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
ONE problem with auto makers' headlong rush to cross-breed sedans, wagons, trucks, vans and four-by-fours is coming up with ways to categorize the new, hybrid forms they are creating.
More than a dozen such crossover vehicles made their debuts here last week at the North American International Auto Show, either as products soon to be sold, as prototypes of future offerings or as design studies that may -- or may not -- find their way into showrooms in some modified form. But even those scrambling to meet what they perceive as new, unfilled needs in private transportation seem daunted by the semantics of their creations. 
 Robert J. Eaton, chairman of DaimlerChrysler, called the Chrysler PT Cruiser -- a high-roofed small sedan with minivan-style cargo flexibility and a profile out of the 1930's -- a "segment-breaker too cool to categorize." The car will go on sale in about a year, starting below $20,000.
Nissan called the design of its S.U.T. "a collision of a truck and a sport utility vehicle" and its new Xterra sport utility "a tough, mobile place for stuff."
Toyota described its latest small car, the Echo, as having "low floor height with a high seating position."
J. Mays, Ford's vice president for design, called the (My) Mercury a concept vehicle "that blurs the boundaries between a car, a truck and a sport-utility vehicle." And when unveiling the Explorer Sport Trac, a twist on Ford's popular sport utility with a pickup bed replacing the covered cargo compartment, spokesmen were reduced to calling it "not a car-truck, but a truck-truck."
While these combinations got much of the attention here, the auto companies have not altogether abandoned the market for car-cars. Chevrolet showed its 2000 Impala, dusting off one of America's best-known automotive names for its new flagship, which will replace the Lumina when it goes on sale next summer. Likewise, Buick showed its redesigned 2000 LeSabre, which is to reach the market even sooner, and Lexus announced that it would import in mid-2000 its IS sport sedan, a competitor to the BMW 3-Series and Audi A4.
Mercedes-Benz showed its all-new S-Class, a trimmed version of the biggest sedan it makes, while a smaller new Jaguar, the S-Type, made its American debut.
New small cars included Toyota's Echo, aimed at the 20-somethings Toyota calls the "Net generation," with upgraded stereos and special CD compartments; DaimlerChrysler's all-new 2000 models of its Dodge and Plymouth Neon, and Ford's Focus, which replaces the Escort.
Among the few announcements of environmental interest, Honda said it plans to sell its V V gasoline-electric hybrid, which has very low emissions and is said to go 70 miles on a gallon of gas, in the United States. And Ford displayed a working version of a car that runs on advanced fuel cells that convert hydrogen to energy with no emissions, though executives acknowledged that a production version would not come until 2004 at the earliest.
Although nothing on display at Cobo Center generated the buzz accorded last year to the Volkswagen New Beetle, the car that came closest to being the show-stopper was a Ford Thunderbird that captures the flavor of the original T-Birds of 1955-57. The two-seat roadster has a removable roof, prominent round taillights, porthole side windows, hooded gauges and a pastel palette. It is likely to be sold as a 2001 model.
Another name from the mid-50's, the Chevrolet Nomad, was revived as a sporty retro-style wagon, also resembling a sport utility.
Two European sports cars were also crowd pleasers. The Audi TT, a post-industrial design with a striking Bauhaus-style interior, made its American debut; it goes on sale in late spring. And Mercedes showed its Vision SLR, a design study for a high-style, super-high-performance sports car that draws on the Formula One look.
Another design study, from Nissan, capitalized on the nostalgia for that company's Datsun 240Z sports car of the early 70's. The updated Z has a similar long-hooded look and was planned to sell for less than $25,000 -- an amount that Nissan said was equivalent, after adjusting for inflation, to the price of the original.
Two of the few companies without sport utilities joined the fray. Hyundai showed a prototype, the Santa Fe, that would compete with vehicles like the Honda CR-V and Toyota RAV4. And BMW rolled out its first all-wheel-drive vehicle, the X5, which it insists is a "sport activity vehicle" not intended for off-road use -- a strategy intended to prevent the cannibalization of sales from its Land Rover unit. It will be built in South Carolina and reach market late this year.

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2; Page 40; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1005 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
These Pilots See a Bumpy Flight

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH most mutual fund investors closed out 1998 with gains, the road was rocky, with their climb hampered by sharp dips and the summer selloff.
The five professional money managers who have built hypothetical retirement portfolios over the last five years for The New York Times expect volatility to increase in 1999. 
 "I'm expecting a very rugged year," said Jack A. Brill, a San Diego adviser who hews a "socially responsible" course. "My guess is that the market will break 10,000, with a 15 percent meltdown during the year," he said. "I'd expect 10 to 15 percent growth at best."
Mr. Brill tied for first place among the five advisers in the fourth quarter. His portfolio rose 20.34 percent, lifted by its bias toward large- and mid-capitalization stocks. It was handicapped only by an investment in Vanguard GNMA, which rose less than 1 percent.
He is whittling some holdings to make room for the Citizens Index fund, but is otherwise sitting tight. He figures -- as do the other four advisers -- that a diverse portfolio is the best weapon against market volatility. That, and a stiff upper lip. "I think individual investors should play the market for the long term, looking past the daily hype and focusing on solid growth," he said.
WHAT, of course, is not always easy to do. Susan Dziubinski, editor of Morningstar Fund Investor, a newsletter, noted wryly that while diversification remained her touchstone, it did not pay off in 1998. "This certainly wasn't a good year for a contrarian portfolio like mine," she said. "Small value continued to lag, and so did emerging markets. And nearly nonexistent inflation hammered Oppenheimer Real Asset, my portfolio hedge."
Ms. Dziubinski came in right behind the two leaders for the quarter, with a gain of 17.01 percent, and has tinkered only a bit with her portfolio.
Among the minor adjustments, she is condensing her large-cap international funds by scuttling Ivy International in favor of EuroPacific Growth, which has lower expenses. Similarly, she is jettisoning Small Cap World, a global fund with a large chunk of small domestic stocks, and buying Founders Passport, a small-cap fund with less than 3 percent of assets invested in the United States.
She is also selling the Fidelity Fund, which she concedes is a top performer, and buying TIAA-CREF Growth and Income. About 80 percent of the TIAA-CREF fund tracks the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. "Over the long term," she added, "I question the ability of active managers to really add value when it comes to large-cap investing."
Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y., was tied with Mr. Brill for first place in the quarter and retains the lead among the five managers over all, with a cumulative gain of 129.69 percent since July 7, 1993, when the contest began. In that time, the five portfolios have risen an average of 107.09 percent, compared with a 212.16 percent return for the Vanguard 500 Index fund, which mimics the S.& P. 500.
THE performance of the hypothetical portfolios is tracked each quarter by Lipper Inc. of Summit, N.J. It excludes sales charges, transaction costs and taxes because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts. The five managers can choose any fund open to new investors and can shift money quarterly. They were asked to pick portfolios intended to grow for 20 years.
All the portfolios earned double-digit returns in the quarter -- a period in which Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher, calculates that diversified domestic equity funds rose an average of 18.78 percent.
Mr. Jacobs is adding to his holdings in Vanguard 500 Index, formerly called Vanguard Index Trust 500, bringing it to 15 percent of assets from 12.5 percent. This change, plus the 35 percent weighting in Vanguard Total Stock Market, enables him to reach his goal of being 50 percent invested in index funds. The extra money for the Index 500 fund comes from selling a small chunk of Baron Growth and Income, lowering it to 10 percent of the portfolio.
He is also replacing American Century/20th Century International Discovery, a small-cap fund, with Montgomery International Growth, a large-cap blend fund, because he thinks big stocks will outperform smaller ones overseas.
Eric M. Kobren, president of Kobren Insight Group and editor of Fidelity Insight in Wellesley, Mass., finished next to last in the quarter, with a gain of 15.68 percent. His portfolio, made up entirely of Fidelity funds, was held back by a 20 percent investment in Fidelity Spartan Government Income, which slipped 0.23 percent. Even so, he is increasing his position in the fund to 25 percent from 20 percent. He is adding to the bond holdings, he said, "because strong corporate earnings growth will remain hard to achieve in 1999."
Mr. Kobren is doubling his position, to 20 percent, in Fidelity Contrafund II, which he calls "a fund with the flexibility to go anywhere in the market in search of good stocks." He is reducing his position in Fidelity Small-Cap Stock to 15 percent from 20 percent. And he sold his entire 10 percent holding in Fidelity Real Estate, because, he said, the bond fund provides sufficient diversification.
Harold R. Evensky, a financial adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., finished last in the quarter, with a portfolio gain of 14.44 percent.
In a departure from his usual practice of making few changes, Mr. Evensky is giving his portfolio a new look this quarter. He is selling his position in Cohen & Steers Realty Shares and using that money to start an 8 percent position in Vanguard Extended Market Index, to give added exposure to smaller stocks. He is replacing Warburg Pincus International Equity, which gained 12.88 percent in the last quarter, with Montgomery International Growth. He is also exchanging Blackrock Small Cap Growth for Undiscovered Managers Behavioral Growth.
"It remains tough," he said, "to preach intelligent diversification in long-term investing in an environment like this."

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2; Page 39; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
4 Who Found a 4th-Quarter Feast

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
REBOUNDING from the nasty summer selloff, managers of United States diversified stock funds breathed a sigh of relief in the fourth quarter. On average, their funds returned a gratifying 18.8 percent. The strong close pulled their average returns up to 15.1 percent for 1998, though that was still far behind the 24 percent of 1997.
But the top-performing equity managers whistled an even happier tune, with quarterly returns of up to 70 percent. 
 Here, four winners for the quarter look back at what made them such standouts -- and offer a glance ahead.
 
Earnings Up, Rates Down
"We got a double whammy this year," said Douglas S. Foreman, who manages the $256.6 million Morgan Stanley Dean Witter TCW Mid-Cap Equity Trust from Los Angeles. The fund returned 49.2 percent in the fourth quarter, landing in third place among United States diversified stock funds.
"We had companies that met or beat earnings expectations when many companies were falling short, so the value of our predictable growth went up measurably during the year," Mr. Foreman said. "Also, falling interest rates boost stock prices for companies which are exceeding earnings expectations, because the earnings are worth more as investment alternatives become less attractive."
Yahoo, at 6.1 percent of assets, was his biggest hit for the quarter and for the year, up 584.3 percent in 1998. "We think the company is unbelievably well positioned to capitalize on the Internet, which is a paradigm shift in technology and in the way people communicate," he said. He sees annual earnings gains topping 50 percent for the next three years.
Another good performer was Best Buy, a consumer electronics chain, at 3.2 percent of the fund. It rose 231.8 percent. "New management has engineered a terrific turnaround," Mr. Foreman said. He expects the company to exceed consensus earnings forecasts of $2.25 a share for its fiscal year ending in February 2000, up from $1.98 this year.
Mr. Foreman does not expect the economic troubles of Southeast Asia to end until late 1999. But he does not see further interest-rate cuts in the United States.
 
A New Industrial Revolution
For Jim D. Oelschlager, who manages the $57 million Pin Oak Aggressive Stock fund, technology is the bellwether sector for his fund -- and for the nation. Pin Oak returned 44 percent in the quarter, capturing eighth place among United States diversified funds.
"We believe that what's occurring in technology today is equivalent to the Industrial Revolution in the late 1800's," he said.
So it is not surprising that the 24 stocks in Pin Oak are mostly technology companies. One of his biggest fourth-quarter winners, up 69.1 percent, was Applied Materials, which makes semiconductor manufacturing equipment. "When the Asian contagion started in late 1997, no one thought anybody would build another plant," Mr. Oelschlager said. That pessimism has faded. He expects earnings growth of 20 to 30 percent a year for the next three to five years.
He also made money in Cisco Systems, the networking hardware giant, which rose 50.2 percent in the quarter. "There's a lot of questions as to who will be the big Internet winners, but we know Cisco will, because they're building the infrastructure used by the Amazon.coms and other Internet companies," he said. He expects earnings to grow more than 30 percent annually over three to five years.
As for 1999? "I'm a raging bull," he said.
 
Opportunity in the Storm
The third-quarter turmoil spelled fourth-quarter opportunity for Frederick R. Kobrick, who runs the $41.4 million Kobrick Capital fund, formerly Kobrick-Cendant Capital. He found much value in 1998, the fund's first year of operation, as stocks were periodically beaten down.
The fund, which owns 65 stocks, returned 40.3 percent for the quarter, placing 13th among United States diversified stock funds.
"When financials were chewed up in late summer, we bought a lot of banks and brokerages," which accounted for about 20 percent of the fund at the peak, he said.
Mr. Kobrick made money with Chase Manhattan, which he bought in early October at $40 a share. It finished the year at $71. He likes the company for its diversified income sources. "Chase does banking around the world and is expanding rapidly in Europe as it embraces the euro," Mr. Kobrick said. He expects per-share earnings growth of 30 percent in 1999.
Among his other fourth-quarter winners was the EMC Corporation, which he called the leader in mass data storage.
"Management is brilliant, and the company is run conservatively, so they usually beat earnings estimates," Mr. Kobrick said. He called EMC "a great long-term growth company" and expects EMC's stock price and sales to double in the next two and a half years. He sees a 40 percent increase in per-share earnings in 1999.
Mr. Kobrick said he was optimistic about 1999. "Profits will be better than the consensus thinks," he said.
 
A Convertible Hot Rod
Sandra K. Durn, who runs the $265.5 million Nicholas-Applegate Convertible Income Shares from San Diego, returned 19.9 percent in the fourth quarter, finishing in first place among taxable bond funds. She attributes the strong finish to the equity-type analysis she uses to buy convertible bonds. "We own convertibles where the underlying company has strong fundamentals and a positive outlook, which makes us different from other convertible managers, who focus more on yield than company prospects," she said.
In general, she expects convertible bonds in her portfolio to give her 80 percent of any upward movement of the common stock, but 50 percent or less of any downward movements. That is what kept her out of trouble in 1998, she said: "By focusing on these criteria, we've missed the big blow-ups in convertibles this year."
Among her top money makers were convertible preferred shares in Cox Communications, a cable company. "They have a growing subscriber base and are adding new services," Ms. Durn said. She projects a 15 percent annual earnings growth rate over five years.
She also made money with the convertibles of Costco, the warehouse retailer. The chain has posted what she described as "very impressive" sales growth of about 12 percent. "And they recently launched a new regional store in Chicago which is doing very well," she added.
In general, Ms. Durn is optimistic. "We feel that the market will continue to be strong, at least for the first part of 1999," she said. "Interest rates should stay low, which should prevent a slump in corporate profits."

HEADLINE: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Donald J. Trump;
Previewing The States Of Beauty

BYLINE: By BOB MORRIS 

 BODY:
ON Thursday, the temperature had dropped to a sub-freezing chill, but at Life, the nightclub on Bleecker Street, things were heating up. Donald J. Trump was expected at any moment for a promotional party for the Miss U.S.A. Pageant, which will be broadcast live next month on CBS.
In anticipation of his arrival, the contestants were all aflutter. Or maybe they were just cold. Near the door, Miss New York and Miss Connecticut stood around in skimpy skirts and tops absolutely unsuitable for winter. But since they had been instructed not to wear stockings with their BCBG designer outfits, they stoically exposed their toes and legs (midriffs and shoulders, too) to blasts of frigid air. The only thing that kept them warm was the idea of a moment with Mr. Trump. 
 "It's cold, but at least it's not Buffalo," said Miss New York, Kimberly Ann Pressler, a data entry specialist with glitter in her hair, who will attend college in Buffalo this fall.
So what did they know about Mr. Trump anyway?
"He makes lots of money," Miss Pressler said. "And his upstate casino helps our economy."
"He owns a lot of things," said Miss Connecticut, Christina D'Amico, a sales representative, who plans to pursue an M.B.A. degree after college, "including some property in Bridgeport."
Would they consider dating him?
With beauty queen diplomacy, they both said that he was wonderful, but perhaps not their type.
"I want to marry for love, not money," Miss D'Amico said.
When Mr. Trump finally arrived, he dispensed two kisses to Shawnae Jebbia, Miss U.S.A. 1998, who, with the eager tone of a child reporting good news to Father, told him about a new job she had just nailed as a television host. "I'm going to become a TV personality," she said.
After congratulating her, he moved on to peddle his pageant to reporters. "What I do is successful because of the esthetics," said Mr. Trump, who owns part of the Miss Universe Organization (producer of Miss U.S.A.) and is planning to start a modeling agency. "People love my buildings and my pageants."
Downstairs, the self-appointed arbiter of all things beautiful arrived to whoops and cheers. He was swamped by young women. "Looking good," he said. One woman, who called him "Donald," asked for a kiss. He obliged, then asked, "Do I know you?" It turned out he did.
As he posed and mingled, Mr. Trump conjured a connection, however tenuous, to his contestants. Miss New Jersey, for example, has parents who go to his Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City. "That's what I love to hear," Mr. Trump said. He told Miss North Carolina that he plays golf in Pinehurst, and Miss Colorado that he recently got back from Aspen. "I own property there," he said.
One place where he has not staked a claim yet is Rhode Island. He regretted that. "Look how beautiful Miss Rhode Island is," he said before pressing more flesh -- hands, arms and an occasional bare shoulder.
"You're all so beautiful," he said. Then, he was out the door, leaving his fans to their own resources. To that end, Joy Hall, Miss North Carolina, was seen giving her phone number to Mitch Marrow, a defensive end for the Carolina Panthers, who had promised her seats to a game.
"They better be good seats," Miss Hall said to a friend, after he had moved on. "If you give your phone number to someone, you should at least end up on the 50-yard line."
Mr. Trump is not the only one to understand the art of the deal.

HEADLINE: To Russia With Gifts For a Partner on Ice

BYLINE: By MARCIA BIEDERMAN 

 BODY:
WHAT do you get the teen-age girl who has everything? A horse? A Miata? How about a real live Russian ice-dance partner?
Two years ago, when Ariel Williams, then a 10th grader at the Dalton School in Manhattan, began to show promise in ice dancing, her mother, Marian Williams, scouted for a full-time partner for her. The search led to Dmitri Boundoukin, a Russian-born skater who was soap-opera handsome. 
 But the economic imbalances between Russia and America being what they are, Mrs. Williams found herself offering to cover all of Mr. Boundoukin's personal and training costs, which can run to tens of thousands of dollars a year. In the spring of 1997, she and her daughter moved from New York to Marlboro, Mass., so Ariel could train year round with Mr. Boundoukin, who was 19 and lived near a favorite Russian coach in Shrewsbury, Mass.
The bills, Mrs. Williams said, including living expenses for both partners, coaching fees, dance lessons and costumes (which can cost $1,000 for women and $500 for men), were paid by her former husband, Gary W. Williams, a partner at the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs. "I'm lucky," Mrs. Williams said. "My ex-husband pays for it."
Such arrangements are increasingly common in ice dancing, a sport that attracts many American girls but few American boys, according to skaters, their parents and senior figures in the sport. They say that girls' parents often dangle the keys to a car or a house, along with a promise of all expenses paid, to get foreign-born skaters to lead their daughters in waltzes and tangos around a rink.
"It's buying a partner," said Judy Blumberg, a former national champion ice dancer whose family did not support the American-born Michael Seibert when they won three medals at world championships and finished fourth at the Olympics in 1984. (That was the year Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean, ice dancing's most famous pairing, won the gold medal.)
American boys, who prefer hockey, are seldom interested in ballroom dances on ice. (The sport differs from freestyle pairs in that there are no jumps and no lifts above the waist.) The dominant figure in the sport now is the diva Pasha Grishuk of Russia. So male partners in this country are often recruited from abroad. The laws of supply and demand have led young men from Russia, where ice dancing is just another sport, to increase what they demand for their services. But the largesse of the girls' parents means that "they'll never be independent," Ms. Blumberg said.
"I think most Russian boys expect to be taken care of," she continued. "They want an expensive costume, or this car and not the other car."
NOT all the foreign-born partners are Russian. Susan Chalom of West Bloomfield, Mich., said she scoured the nation for a year for a partner for her daughter, Eve, then 12. The search ended in Boston, where Eve tried out with Mathew Gates of Hitchum, England. Mrs. Chalom, recalling that tryout, said, "I remember I was filming, and I was filming with my mouth open."
In the seven years since then, Mrs. Chalom said, she has paid virtually all expenses for Mr. Gates. For him to come from England and live in her home, she had to become his legal guardian, since he was then 16. When her son left for Yale, Mr. Gates got his room and his car. Her largest expenses, though, were training and travel. Costs for the two skaters now top $90,000 a year, she said.
"I kind of go with what my kids want," Mrs. Chalom said. "Eve is the one who dragged me to the rink." Eve lost much of her hearing when she was hit by a car at age 4. "I probably went along with it more agreeably because of that," her mother said. Where has the money come from? "There was a man," Mrs. Chalom said: her former husband, Eve's father, Edward Chalom.
These days the two train in Plano, Texas, and Mrs. Chalom pays for them to live with two Dallas families. And Mr. Gates, now 23, earns some money by teaching skating so he can pay for incidentals. "Like shaving cream," Mrs. Chalom said.
Mr. Gates said he is thankful for the Chaloms' support. "But I am giving Eve as much opportunity as she gives me to go where she wants to go," he said.
The partnership has worked well. The couple have won medals at the national championships and were on the United States World Team in 1997. But even with that success, Mrs. Chalom agrees with critics in the sport who say that such partnerships often do not result in medals, because skaters are not matched by leg length and proficiency, but rather by financial factors. She said she knew of an American novice competitor whose parents went to Russia to find her a partner. Although the man was an elite skater in Russia, he agreed to compete as a novice here.
"But he pulled her around the ice," Mrs. Chalom said. "She didn't win."
Oleg Fediukov said Mrs. Chalom must have been describing him. Mr. Fediukov, who is with his third American partner (all three families have supported him), said that six years ago his initial patrons, Julieanna Sacchetti, then 14, and her parents traveled to Russia in search of a partner and found him.
Soon he was installed in their home in Wellesley, Mass. "They were pretty upscale people," he said. But he described skating with the inexperienced girl as "six months in hell."
Julieanna "didn't really trust me and my knowledge," he said. He added, "We couldn't get along -- I would say something innocent, and she would get upset and tell her mother."
Christine Sacchetti, Julieanna's mother, tells it differently. She said that Mr. Fediukov was too advanced to partner a novice, but that he did not explain that. "He played dumb," she said. (Mr. Fediukov responded that he had made his proficiency clear to the family before coming to the United States, and that they had seen him skate with Julieanna.)
Of the conflicts with her daughter, Mrs. Sacchetti said, "He was rude and unkind and unfeeling toward her."
"We were naive," said Julieanna Sacchetti, who is now 20. She said she knows other American families who were taken advantage of by what she called manipulative Russian skaters "because these parents love their daughters so much."
In any event, Mr. Fediukov left the Sacchettis. Since 1996 he has skated with Debbie Koegel, whose family has no complaints. Her mother, Susan Clayman, said she and her husband, Martin Clayman, pay most of the $60,000 in training and living expenses for the couple, who finished second last month at the Eastern sectional championships for senior-level ice dancers in Oldsmar, Fla.
Ms. Koegel's mother bristled at the suggestion that supporting Mr. Fediukov is tantamount to buying a partner. "Oleg is not paid to skate with my daughter," she said. "Oleg wants to skate with my daughter."
No doubt that is true, especially since Mr. Fediukov, now 26, and Ms. Koegel, 21, are a couple off the ice as well, sharing a town house in Brookhaven, Pa. Mrs. Clayman said Mr. Fediukov "is not dressing in Calvin Kleins and Polos and driving a Corvette -- he has a broken-down Honda that needs a radiator."
But then there is the case of the physician and his wife who brought a partner from Russia for their daughter and presented him with the room and car formerly belonging to her brother, only to see him leave after a single month with the complaint, "American girls can't skate."
"It was a nightmare," said the girl's mother, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But she rejected the suggestion that she and her husband had been victimized. "We just got so caught up in it," she said.
Leslie Gamez, the team director for the United States Figure Skating Association, said such situations are "a private matter between those two individuals." The association, the sport's governing body, does not enter such disputes.
Many parents reject any criticism about their part in the ice-dance "bachelor auction." Typically, they maintain that it is other families who are taken advantage of, that their daughter's partner is a hard worker with modest needs. Even when the partnerships win no medals, some parents say they would do it again.
BEFORE teaming up with Ariel Williams, Mr. Boundoukin was the partner of Tara Modlin, whose parents, Sherry and Bobby Modlin of Garden City, N.Y., provided housing for him for two years in Lake Placid, N.Y., shopped for his groceries and covered all his training costs.
"Everybody I know thought I was nuts," said Mr. Modlin, who owns a textile exporting business in Manhattan. He said he used to drive 600 miles round trip to see his wife and daughter in Lake Placid on weekends. But he said he has no regrets. "It cost me a fortune, but I wouldn't give back one minute of it," he said, because Tara "earned it" by winning medal after medal as a novice.
The Modlins didn't just open their wallets. "We got into an adoption situation," Mrs. Modlin said. Until Mr. Boundoukin turned 18, the Modlins became his legal guardians so that he and Tara could compete in the United States National Figure Skating Championships. (He needed an alien-registration card to do so, and their guardianship assured that he could get one. Noncitizens, however, are ineligible for Olympic teams.)
After finishing last among the junior-level skaters in a field of 13 at the 1997 nationals, the Modlin-Boundoukin team broke up. Tara Modlin said there were tensions after an unsuccessful season capped by a last-minute change of coach and program. The family said there were also romantic problems. "It was uncomfortable that his attraction was bigger to me than mine to him," Tara Modlin said. (Mr. Boundoukin refused repeated requests for interviews on the events surrounding his skating career in the United States.)
Her father was relieved. Although he considers Mr. Boundoukin "a great kid," he did not view him as marriage material for his daughter, who is now 20 and is majoring in sociology at the University of Pennsylvania. Tara, who no longer skates competitively, said she misses Dima, as her former partner is known, but she said he and other Russian skaters in America didn't "get" her interest in academics.
"After a while," Mr. Modlin said, "I wanted him to stay away from my daughter. I wanted her to pay attention to books."
The Modlins continued to pay Mr. Boundoukin's rent for a few months until he got on his feet, around the time he teamed up with Ariel Williams.
In interviews last year, Mrs. Williams, Ariel's mother, said the family at first provided sole support for Mr. Boundoukin, but eventually a group that helps "promising skaters" began giving him support. She later confirmed that the group was the New England Amateur Skating Foundation.
Herbert E. Kaplan, the president of the foundation, a charitable trust based in Providence, R.I., said Mr. Boundoukin is one of 100 skaters for whom the foundation raised $600,000 last year.
Ariel's father, Gary Williams, declined to be interviewed, but a family friend, who called this reporter at what he said was Mr. Williams's behest, said Mr. Williams was contributing to the Amateur Skating Foundation. The friend, who refused to be quoted by name, would not say how much.
Some people in the sport say that the foundation provides a funnel for families to give money to skaters while receiving a tax deduction. For example, Ms. Clayman, the mother of Debbie Koegel, said she and other family members pay the nearly $60,000 annual expenses of Ms. Koegel and Mr. Fediukov through the foundation because of the "tax advantage."
Mr. Kaplan said: "We support a lot of Russian skaters. I call it my rent-a-Russian program." He said donors cannot earmark checks for a specific skater (which would threaten the tax deductibility of their contributions). But he said they can "suggest" recipients, subject to the approval of a three-member foundation committee.
Ninety percent of donations are under $100, he said. He would not say if larger donations had come in with the suggestion that they go to Mr. Boundoukin. There is "nothing unusual or untoward" about the grants to the young man, he said.
Don Roberts, a spokesman in Washington for the Internal Revenue Service, said the foundation's arrangements appeared to violate no tax regulations, so long as it remained in control of the funds.
So far, Mr. Boundoukin and his partners have not reached the sport's senior ranks. The Boundoukin-Williams team, scheduled to make its first important appearance at a regional competition in Florida last month, withdrew after a "medical emergency," a competition organizer said. It has not registered for the national championships Feb. 7 to 14 in Salt Lake City.
Within skating, people like to gossip about the Russian partners, but few raise serious objections. Skating, they say, is expensive, and the demands of training do not allow for a full-time job. Dick Button, the two-time Olympic gold medalist and television skating announcer, said it's "perfectly fine" for American families to support foreign-born skaters.
"I am only interested in good skating," he said. "I don't care if the person comes from Boise or Vladivostok."
Until more American boys discover the joys of a twizzle, a step maneuver during a waltz, the imbalance is not likely to change. "I keep saying to these little hockey boys, 'You know, you could have a great future in figure skating, and all these girls in your arms,' " Mrs. Williams said.

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2; Page 35; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Saying No to Summer Panic Brings a Winter of Content

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
IN a dramatic comeback that cheered the holders of more than 100 million mutual fund accounts, the fund industry turned in a rollicking performance in the final quarter of 1998. The average United States diversified stock fund returned 18.8 percent, the fattest gain for any quarter since 1982, when the business was less than one-eighth its present size.
Buoyed by a Federal Reserve whose interest-rate cuts clearly reflected more concern about heading off world recession than about fueling stock prices, the market rewarded the overwhelming majority of fund investors who, rather than running for cover, either sat tight during the midyear turbulence or used it to pick up bargains. 
 Their persistence allowed their fund managers to avoid the necessity of selling shares or husbanding cash. And the rewards in many cases were fourth-quarter returns that exceeded the gain in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a leading benchmark that has traditionally been hard for stock fund managers to beat.
But while a half-dozen categories of actively managed stock funds surpassed the 20.9 percent gain in the S.& P., it was growth funds that really excelled -- a trend that embraced companies of all sizes.
Growth funds that invest in stocks with large capitalizations -- capitalization is the total market value of all of a company's shares -- jumped an average of 26.3 percent in the October-through-December period and 36.5 percent for all of 1998. Mid-cap funds also rallied and came in a close second, up 26.1 percent for the quarter and 18.3 percent for the year.
In an even sharper recovery, beaten-down small-cap growth funds racked up a 24 percent fourth-quarter advance that hoisted their full-year return from negative territory to a 4.3 percent gain.
For the growth funds, the chief advantage was economic turmoil abroad, which caused fears of a recession at home. Companies that are not closely tied to the business cycle were at a premium, and many investors sought quality within the stock market.
In particular, many growth funds had a high representation of telecommunications and technology stocks, which rebounded with a vengeance. Some fund managers have even ventured into Internet rockets like Amazon.com, the bookseller, and Ebay, an auctioneer, which rose 187.8 percent and 435.4 percent, respectively, in the quarter.
Specialty funds that hold the stocks of technology companies did best of all, surging 41.7 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher.
But bond funds, to the surprise of some people, were flat by comparison. Indeed, 15 of 21 classifications eked out gains of less than 1 percent. Long-Term Government funds lost 1.2 percent, on average. Emerging-markets bond funds returned 12.3 percent, in contrast to disastrous quarters earlier in the year. This disappointing fate for the bond funds, analysts said, showed that investors had anticipated the Fed's rate cuts, the first of which came during September.
Many investors seeking refuge from foreign turmoil moved to Treasuries, largely ignoring corporate and tax-exempt municipal issues. Funds investing in convertible bonds, sometimes a substitute for stocks, were high performers for the quarter.
Although much of Asia remains in recession, markets there rebounded smartly on anticipations of recovery. Stock funds investing in Pacific Rim countries and Asia, but excluding Japan, rose an average of 27.6 percent in the fourth quarter. But these funds still suffered a loss of 10.4 percent for all of 1998.
Matthews Korea and Matthews Pacific Tiger were the biggest international winners in the quarter, soaring 102 percent and 40.5 percent, respectively. Fidelity's Japan Small Company fund surged 34.8 percent.
THE remarkable stock-market comeback in the United States and elsewhere followed one of the worst selloffs in years, producing a sharp whipsaw for some investors who played the game of trying to time the market's ups and downs.
But the revelation of 1998 may well be the steadfastness of the nation's 67 million fund investors, about half of whom also own stocks directly, when confronted with a mid-July to early-October plunge that many argue was a genuine, if compressed, bear market.
Despite industry assurances that an overwhelming majority of shareholders would stand fast, there were skeptics. When the sun is shining, they argued, it is easy for investors to say they'll hang in there -- especially if they have never suffered through such a slump before. But when the storm comes, they added, many people change their tune.
Yet investors were resilient. "The selloff was fairly steep, and the reaction was very mild," said John Rea, chief economist at the Investment Company Institute. For the first time since 1990, equity fund investors in August sold more than they bought, but the outflow was a mere four-tenths of 1 percent of assets, he said.
And while the effects of the plunge lingered into the fourth quarter, when inflows lagged behind, Mr. Rea contended that one thing had become clear: "Long-term investors are willing to accept some short-term volatility."
Still, a few months' decline -- and even the considerably longer slump for small-company stocks -- is not as brutal or disheartening as a more traditional bear market, like the one that lasted for most of 1973 and 1974 and slashed the value of blue-chip stocks by 40 percent.
Almost as big as the market's emphasis on growth during the latest quarter was its preference for larger companies.
"If you were in big growth companies, you were in fat city," said Robert C. Doll, chief investment officer at Oppenheimer Funds in New York, which has 50 funds with a total of $100 billion in assets. "But if you were small and value-oriented, you got taken to the cleaners."
Sheer size is increasingly important, agreed Beth Terrana, portfolio manager of the Fidelity Fund, a $9.7 billion member of the giant Fidelity Investment group, which has been generally shedding a reluctance to pay premium prices for the most popular large-cap stocks.
"I've been very strongly in favor of big-cap stocks," she said. "The world has become excruciatingly competitive," she added, and in a slow-growth environment "he who spends the most normally wins." Large-cap companies have the financial heft to spend with abandon.
The biggest stocks tend to be bought by the biggest funds, since managers can take meaningful positions in them without unduly affecting prices.
Indeed, the biggest fund of all, Fidelity Magellan, with $83.6 billion in assets, not only outperformed the S.& P. 500 last year for the first time since 1993, but recorded a fourth-quarter gain of 27.2 percent, second-highest among the nation's largest 25 funds. First was the Janus Fund, at 28.4 percent.
Robert Stansky, Magellan's manager repositioned the fund, which is closed to most new investors, late in the summer; he piled into growth stocks and beaten down high-technology issues.
For the full year, Magellan's 33.6 percent advance was surpassed among giant funds only by the Janus Fund, at 38.9 percent; Fidelity Blue Chip Growth, up 34.8 percent, and American Century Twentieth Century Ultra, up 34.6 percent.
Despite recent successes by portfolio managers, passive investment continues to grow. Money is pouring into Vanguard 500 Index, now the second-biggest fund, at $74 billion.
A rising proportion of fund buyers, newly sensitive to advisory fees, trading costs and tax issues, are willing to settle for returns that come close to matching market averages rather than chasing the hot-shot manager of the day, said Kurt Cerulli, principal of Cerulli Associates, a research and investment counseling firm in Boston.
"The argument for indexing is pretty compelling," Mr. Cerulli said, noting that management fees for index funds run as little as one-fifth of a percentage point a year, compared with three or four times as much for the typical fund. Fees can exceed 1.5 percent when other expenses, like marketing charges, are included.
While the market was showering large and growth-oriented funds with outsized gains, managers bent on sniffing out value in undiscovered or beaten-down or cyclically depressed shares remain frustrated.
"It's painful" being out of fashion, said Ronald Spaulding, the value-oriented chief investment officer for eight stock funds and five bond funds advised by the Safeco Corporation of Seattle. "The market always returns to value, to fundamentals, at some point. The question is timing."
The underperformance of value managers persisted throughout the year; particularly striking was the chasm that developed between investment extremes, noted John Rekenthaler, research director at Morningstar. Investors in the average small-cap value fund suffered a 7 percent loss during 1998, while large-cap growth funds climbed 36.5 percent, on average, a difference of 43.5 percent. "I haven't seen the like of it," Mr. Rekenthaler said. "I'd be surprised if we've ever had a number that large."
ONE lesson may be that fund performance, at least in the short term, often depends more on investment fashion than on the skills of portfolio managers. In practice, this means that because fashion is as fickle in markets as in clothes, it makes no sense to chase after last year's winners.
Yet choice in mutual funds -- by some counts there are now more funds than stocks -- continues to expand. The proliferation is prompting many investors who once regarded funds as simplifying their investment life to seek professional help with complexity.
One new fund is a closed-end offering called Value Line No. 1 Strategy Trust. It will invest in the 100 stocks given a top ranking for timeliness -- defined as a likelihood to rise more quickly than other stocks -- by the Value Line Investment Survey.
Some new products border on the eccentric. Trying a different take on the indexing phenomenon, the new Guinness Flight Wired Index fund will invest in 40 so-called new blue chips, as designated by Wired Magazine. The Wired list is intended to track the information economy of the next century, much as the Dow Jones industrial average, started in 1896, was intended to track the industrial economy of the 20th century.
The companies it chose, Wired said, display "not just intelligent use of technology, but also more abstract notions, including globalism, innovation and strategic vision."

PUB-DATE: January 10, 1999

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2801 words

HEADLINE: Funny, They Don't Look Like Fat Cats

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

 BODY:
THREE decades ago, Congress, embarrassed by the disclosure that 155 wealthy Americans had paid no Federal income taxes, enacted legislation aimed at preventing the very rich from shielding their wealth in tax shelters.
Today, that legislation, creating the alternative minimum tax, is instead snaring a rapidly growing number of middle-class taxpayers, forcing them to pay additional tax or to lose some of their tax breaks. 
 Of the more than two million taxpayers who will be subject this year to the alternative minimum tax, or A.M.T., about half have incomes of $30,000 to $100,000. Some are single parents with jobs; some are people making as little as $527 a week. Over all, the number of people affected by the tax is expected to grow 26 percent a year for the next decade.
But many of the wealthy will not be among them. Even with the A.M.T., the number of taxpayers making more than $200,000 who pay no taxes has risen to more than 2,000 each year.
How a 1969 law aimed at the tax-shy rich became a growing burden on moderate earners illustrates how tax policy in Washington can be a hall of mirrors.
While some Republican Congressmen favor eliminating the tax, other lawmakers say such a move would be an expensive tax break for the wealthy -- or at least would be perceived that way, and thus would be politically unpalatable. And any overhaul of the system would need to compensate for the $6.6 billion that individuals now pay under the A.M.T. This year, such payments will account for almost 1 percent of all individual income tax revenue.
"This is a classic case of both Congress and the Administration agreeing that the tax doesn't make much sense, but not being able to agree on doing anything about it," said C. Eugene Steuerle, an economist with the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Washington.
Mr. Steuerle was a Treasury Department tax official in 1986, when an overhaul of the tax code set the stage for drawing the middle class into the A.M.T.
In eliminating most tax shelters for the wealthy, Congress decided to treat exemptions for children and deductions for medical expenses just like special credits for investors in oil wells, if they cut too deeply into a household's taxable income.
Congress decided that once these "tax preferences" exceeded certain amounts -- $40,000 for a married couple, for example -- people would be moved out of the regular income tax and into the alternative minimum tax. At the time, the threshold was high enough to affect virtually no one but the rich. But it has since been raised only once -- by 12.5 percent, to $45,000 for a married couple -- while the cost of living has risen 43 percent. And so the limits have sneaked up on growing numbers of taxpayers of more modest means.
"Everyone knew back then that it had problems that had to be fixed," Mr. Steuerle recalled. "They just said, 'next year.' "
But "next year" has never come -- and it is unlikely to arrive in 1999, either. While tax policy experts have known for years that the middle class would be drawn into the A.M.T., few taxpayers have been clamoring for change.
Among those few, however, are David and Margaret Klaassen of Marquette, Kan. Mr. Klaassen, a lawyer who lives in and works out of a farmhouse, made $89,751.07 in 1997 and paid $5,989 in Federal income taxes. Four weeks ago, the Internal Revenue Service sent the Klaassens a notice demanding $3,761 more under the alternative minimum tax, including a penalty because the I.R.S. said the Klaassens knew they owed the A.M.T.
Mr. Klaassen acknowledges that he knew the I.R.S. would assert that he was subject to the A.M.T., but he says the law was not meant to apply to his family. "I've never invested in a tax shelter," he said. "I don't even have municipal bonds."
The Klaassens do, however, have 13 children and their attendant medical expenses -- including the costs of caring for their second son, Aaron, 17, who has battled leukemia for years. It was those exemptions and deductions that subjected them to the A.M.T.
"What kind of policy taxes you for spending money to save your child's life?" Mr. Klaassen asked.
The tax affects taxpayers in three ways. Some, like the Klaassens, pay the tax at either a 26 percent or a 28 percent rate because they have more than $45,000 in exemptions and deductions. Others do not pay the A.M.T. itself, but they cannot take the full tax breaks they would have received under the regular income tax system without running up against limits set by the A.M.T. The A.M.T. can also convert tax-exempt income from certain bonds and from exercising incentive stock options into taxable income.
It may be useful to think of the alternative minimum tax as a parallel universe to the regular income tax system, similar in some ways but more complex and with its own classifications of deductions, its own rates and its own paperwork. The idea was that taxpayers who had escaped the regular tax universe by piling on credits and deductions would enter this new universe to pay their fair share. (Likewise, there is a corporate A.M.T. that parallels the corporate income tax.)
At first, the burden of the A.M.T. fell mainly on the shoulders of business owners and investors, said Robert S. McIntyre, executive director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a nonprofit group in Washington that says the tax system favors the rich. Based on I.R.S. data, Mr. McIntyre said he found that 37 percent of A.M.T. revenue in 1990 was a result of business owners using losses from previous years to reduce their regular income taxes; an additional 18 percent was because of big deductions for state and local taxes.
But that has begun to shift, largely as a result of the 1986 changes, which eliminated most tax shelters and lowered tax rates.
 WHEN President Reagan and Congress were overhauling the tax code, they could not make the projected revenues under the new rules equal those under the old system. Huge, and growing, budget deficits made it politically essential for the official estimates to show that after tax reform, the same amount of money would flow to Washington.
One solution, said Mr. Steuerle, the former Treasury official, was to count personal and dependent exemptions and some medical expenses as preferences to be reduced or ignored under the A.M.T, just as special credits for petroleum investments and other tax shelters are.
Mortgage interest and charitable gifts were not counted as preferences, according to tax policy experts who worked on the legislation, because they generated more money than was needed.
But the A.M.T. has not stayed "revenue neutral," in Washington parlance.
The regular income tax was indexed for inflation in 1984, so that taxpayers would not get pushed into higher tax brackets simply because their income kept pace with the cost of living.
The A.M.T. limits, however, have not been indexed. The total allowable exemptions before the tax kicks in have been fixed since 1993 at $45,000 for a married couple filing jointly. For unmarried people, the total amount is now $33,750, and for married people filing separately, it is $22,500.
If the limit had been indexed since 1986, when the A.M.T. was overhauled, it would be about $57,000 for married couples filing jointly -- and most middle-income households would still be exempt.
Mr. Steuerle said he warned at the time that including "normal, routine deductions and exemptions that everyone takes" in the list of preferences would eventually turn the A.M.T. into a tax on the middle class.
That appears to be exactly what has happened.
For example, a married person who makes just $527 a week and files her tax return separately can be subject to the tax, said David S. Hulse, an assistant professor of accounting at the University of Kentucky.
And the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997, which allows a $500-a-child tax credit as well as education credits, may make even more middle-class families subject to the A.M.T. by reducing the value of those credits.
Two Treasury Department economists recently calculated that largely because of the new credits, the number of households making $30,000 to $50,000 who must pay the alternative minimum tax will more than triple in the coming decade. The economists, Robert Rebelein and Jerry Tempalski, also calculated that for households making $15,000 to $30,000 annually, A.M.T. payments will grow 25-fold, to $1.2 billion, by 2008.
Last year, many more people would have been subject to the A.M.T. if Congress had not made a last-minute fix pushed by Representative Richard E. Neal, Democrat of Massachusetts, that -- for 1998 only -- exempted the new child and education credits. The move came after I.R.S. officials told Congress that the credits added enormous complexity to calculating tax liability. Figuring out how much the A.M.T. would reduce the credits was beyond the capacity of most taxpayers and even many paid tax preparers, the I.R.S. officials said.
 EVEN if Congress makes a permanent fix to the problems created by the child and education credits, it will put only a minor drag on the spread of the A.M.T. as long as the tax is not indexed for inflation. The two Treasury economists calculated that revenues from the tax would climb to $25 billion in 2008 without a fix, or to $21.9 billion with one.
In 1999, if there is no exemption for the credits, a single parent who does not itemize deductions but who makes $50,000 and takes a credit for the costs of caring for two children while he works, will be subject to the A.M.T, estimated Jeffrey Pretsfelder, an editor at RIA Group, a publisher of tax information for professionals.
If the tax laws are not changed, 8.8 million taxpayers will have to pay the A.M.T. a decade from now, the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation estimated last month. Add in the taxpayers who will not receive the full value of their deductions because they run up against the limits set by the A.M.T., and the total grows to 11.6 million taxpayers -- 92 percent of whom have incomes of less than $200,000, the two Treasury economists estimated.
While many lawmakers and Treasury officials have criticized the impact of the tax on middle-class taxpayers, there are few signs of change, as Republicans and the Administration talk past each other.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who as the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee is the chief tax writer, said the A.M.T. should be eliminated in the next budget.
"Unfortunately, the A.M.T. tax can penalize large families, which is part of the reason why Republicans for years have tried to eliminate it or at least reduce it," Mr. Archer said. "Unfortunately, President Clinton blocked our efforts each time."
Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said the Administration was "very concerned that the A.M.T. has a growing impact on middle-class families, including by diluting the child credit, education credits and other crucial tax benefits, and we hope to address this issue in the President's budget.
"Subject to budget constraints, we look forward to working with Congress on this important issue," he continued.
That revenue concerns have thwarted exempting the middle class runs counter to the reason Congress initially imposed the tax.
"You need an A.M.T. because people who make a lot of money should pay some income taxes," said Mr. McIntyre, of Citizens for Tax Justice. "If you believe, like Mr. Archer and a lot of Republicans do, that the more you make the less in taxes you should pay, then of course you are against the A.M.T. But somehow I don't think most people see it that way."
THE Klaassens, meanwhile, are challenging the A.M.T. in Federal Court. The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit is scheduled to hear arguments in March on their claim that the tax infringes their religious freedom. The Klaassens, who are Presbyterians, say they believe children "are a blessing from God, and so we do not practice birth control," Mr. Klaassen said.
When Mr. Klaassen wrote to an I.R.S. official complaining that a $1,085 bill for the A.M.T. for 1994 resulted from the size of his family, he got back a curt letter saying that his "analysis of the alternative minimum tax's effect on large families was interesting but inappropriate" and advising him that it was medical deductions, not family size, that subjected him to the A.M.T.
Under the regular tax system, medical expenses above 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income -- the last line on the front page of Form 1040 -- are deductible. Under the A.M.T., the threshold is raised to 10 percent.
Still doubting the I.R.S.'s math, Mr. Klaassen decided to test what would have happened had he filed the same tax return, changing only the number of children he claimed as dependents. He found that if he had seven or fewer children, the A.M.T. would not have applied in 1994.
But the eighth child set off the A.M.T., at a cost of $223. Having nine children raised the bill to $717. And 10 children, the number he had in 1994, increased that sum to $1,085 -- the amount the I.R.S. said was due.
"We love this country and we believe in paying taxes," Mr. Klaassen said. "But we cannot believe that Congress ever intended to apply this tax to our family solely because of how many children we choose to have. And I have shown that we are subject to the A.M.T. solely because we have chosen not to limit the size of our family."
The I.R.S., in papers opposing the Klaassens, noted that tax deductions are not a right but a matter of "legislative grace."
Mr. Klaassen turned to the Federal courts after losing in Tax Court. The opinion by Tax Court Judge Robert N. Armen Jr. was summed up this way by Tax Notes, a magazine that critiques tax policy: "Congress intended the alternative minimum tax to affect large families when it made personal exemptions a preference item."
Several tax experts said that Mr. Klaassen had little chance of success in the courts because the statute treating children as tax preferences was clear. They also said that nothing in the A.M.T. laws was specifically aimed at his religious beliefs.
Meanwhile, for people who make $200,000 or more, the A.M.T. will be less of a burden this year because of the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997, which included a provision lowering the maximum tax rate on capital gains for both the regular tax and the A.M.T. to 20 percent.
Mr. Rebelein and Mr. Tempalski, the Treasury Department economists, calculated recently that people making more than $200,000 would pay a total of 4 percent less in A.M.T. for 1998 because of the 1997 law. By 2008, their savings will be 9 percent, largely as a result of lower capital gains rates and changed accounting rules for business owners.
"This law was passed to catch people who use tax shelters to avoid their obligations," Mr. Klaassen said. "But instead of catching them it hits people like me. This is just nuts."
 
Three Ways to Deal With a Taxing Problem
 
PRESIDENT CLINTON, his tax policy advisers and the Republicans who control the tax writing committees in Congress all agree that the alternative minimum tax is a growing problem for the middle class. But there is no agreement on what to do. Here are some options that have been discussed:
 
RAISE THE EXEMPTION -- Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, two years ago proposed raising the $45,000 A.M.T. exemption for a married couple by $1,000. But that would leave many middle-class families subject to the tax, because it would not fully account for inflation. To do that would require an exemption of about $57,000, followed by automatic inflation adjustments. That is the most widely favored approach, drawing support from people like J. D. Foster, executive director of the Tax Foundation, a group supported by corporations, and Robert S. McIntyre, executive director of Citizens for Tax Justice, which is financed in part by unions and contends that the tax system favors the rich.
 
EXEMPT CHILD AND EDUCATION CREDITS -- For 1998 only, Congress exempted the child tax credit and the education tax credits from the A.M.T. But millions of taxpayers will lose these credits, or get only part of them, unless Congress makes a fix each year or permanently exempts them.
 
ELIMINATE IT -- Mr. Archer and other Republicans want to get rid of the A.M.T. but have not proposed how to make up for the lost revenue, which in a decade is expected to grow to $25 billion annually. Recently, however, Mr. Archer has said that in a period of Federal budget surpluses, it may be time to scrap the budget rules that require paying for tax cuts with reduced spending or tax increases elsewhere. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

SECTION: Section 8; Page 13; Column 6; Sports Desk

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
The N.B.A. Is All About Spinning

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
It's going to be tougher now. Rooting for local teams or resenting individual players is no longer smart enough. Now that political-style spin has engaged the arena, the National Basketball Association spectator has to bring to the court an attitude worthy of the disinfomercials that have emerged since the lockout ended. "Love that game" is a peeling bumper sticker.
How will you greet the new season? As a rebirth after a racial Armageddon, a labor-management fiasco, a triumph of small over tall, a mockery of working-class values, a brilliant plan to bring us more quickly to the playoffs? It really doesn't matter what you choose, so long as you don't just sit there and moan when they dunk. Find an angle. You'll win with a spin. 
 Real fans can read the players' collapse in the signs in other sports. The Jets' surge was credited to Bill Parcells's friendly fascism; obviously, players need to be manipulated and ordered. Then there is the widening scandal of the International Olympic Committee; obviously, the real sport in sport is business, and you can't beat the bosses at that.
Most significantly, Yogi Berra finally rolled over for George Steinbrenner. It was the sensible thing to do. First of all, Yogi needed publicity for his new museum. More important, as men age, there are few tighter bonds than those between old enemies. Who knows you so well, has thought about you as often and as deeply? Yogi and George, after all, are cartoon figures in the minds of almost everyone but themselves. Yogi's refusal to set foot in the Stadium while George was the owner was noble, and still is, although it became stupid. Nobody cares anymore that Yogi was crudely fired as Yankee manager. Since then, almost everyone in America has been crudely fired, in one way or another. Yogi is not stupid. George came to New Jersey last week. Yogi will go to the Bronx next season. All will be right with that world.
As one who admired Walt Frazier, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Isiah Thomas above all others, the sight of Patrick Ewing, clogging the Knicks' heart and fronting the players' association, was disheartening. It was too easy for me to believe that he was a puppet of David Falk, as he was once a puppet of the recently resigned Georgetown coach, John Thompson. Actually, I do not necessarily believe this, but I am not privy to accurate basketball rumors, much less the truth, so I will enjoy the self-interested takes on this past nonplaying season, including the following:
1. It was just a battle between soft little white guys, David Stern and David Falk, who couldn't make the varsity cut in high school. The commissioner who created the modern sport and the super agent who represented an aging corps of super players went man-to-man for control of the game. This is an alluring spin for most fans, who are soft little white guys. No matter which David won, we won, too.
2. The league won big. By dragging the players back on court without ceding to their major demands, the N.B.A. stuffed the greed genie back in the bottle and capped it, giving inspiration to all the beleaguered conglomerates struggling with ungrateful workers. Most media outlets, owned by conglomerates and staffed by ingrates, support this spin.
3. The players really won. By delaying the season, making reasonable demands (the Smith College economist and players union consultant, Andrew Zimbalist, was best on this) and showing themselves as a diverse group, in class, intelligence and financial need, they transcended the living animated figures marketed by the N.B.A. and became people. Also, they were the ones who saved the season.
4. TV won. The length of the regular N.B.A. season and the need to carry it has always bothered television and advertising (same thing) executives who have always preferred to cut to the chase, where the audience and the rates are. Now, a truncated season will feel as if it has the urgency of playoff time.
5. The fans won. The idea of a backlash, that Joe Sixpack, whoever the suits think that is, will not come back because he is hurt, disgusted or discovered the Monet exhibit while the Celtics were dark, is not only silly. It is also enormously pleasing to Joe, his investment banker and his antique book dealer, because they think there will be concessions. The game will find new ways to entertain him, give him free trinkets for showing up, make his seat warm.
6. The gasbags won. Everyone with access to ink, air time or cyberspace will have a chance to pontificate at length about the meaning of all this until it is time to watch games, at which time we will pontificate on the effect of all this on dunking, before we go back to our real jobs, which is uncovering the love-that-game billionaire owner who was raised in a log cabin without cable and the power forward who manages to keep focus despite five criminal indictments.
Love that spin.

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2; Page 35; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk
