SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1969 words

HEADLINE: Rebellion in White: Doctors Pulling Out Of H.M.O. Systems

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
For Dr. Clement Barone, a radiologist on the Upper East Side, the final straw came when Blue Cross Blue Shield told him it was cutting reimbursements for mammograms to $42 each. (He charges $200.) He dropped the plan, and said he might stop accepting all managed care soon.
Dr. Barney Softness, a pediatrician on West End Avenue, said he decided that he could take no more when Oxford Health Plans suggested that he cut costs by getting rid of the registered nurses in his office. Instead, he told Oxford goodbye. 
 Dr. Byron Thomashow, a pulmonary specialist in Washington Heights, recalled how he had fought with one company for three hours to get permission to do a procedure on a woman who was coughing up life-threatening amounts of blood. He said the dispute underscored why he was no longer in a managed care plan.
While 92 percent of doctors in New York State accepted managed care last year, it seems that a small rebellion is on. Fed up with years of acrimonious relationships with managed care companies, doctors, particularly those serving upper-middle-class patients, are quietly starting to fight back.
Many are dropping plans that have the lowest reimbursement rates or biggest administrative headaches, or represent the fewest of their patients. Others are washing their hands of the carriers, forcing patients to pay up front and file claims the old-fashioned way, or pay the fees themselves.
Still others are looking for alternative ways to negotiate with the companies, like forming group practices or other professional associations that have more leverage to seek better reimbursement rates.
And hospitals are trying to fight back by asking the New York State Attorney General's office to look into managed-care company practices.
"There is no question that a growing number of doctors are disassociating themselves from managed care," said Dr. Charles Aswad, the executive vice president of the Medical Society of the State of New York. Still more, he said, "are being much more judicious about looking at managed care contracts."
While it is too early to quantify much of the activity, some numbers are startling: 10 percent of the doctors affiliated with New York Presbyterian Hospital have dropped out of managed care in the last three months, and 50 percent have whittled the plans they accept, said Dr. Myron Weisfeldt, the chairman of the hospital's department of medicine.
"There are a tremendous number of physicians that to one degree or another are beginning to separate themselves from managed care at some financial risk to themselves," he said.
And there are signs that the movement extends past New York City's borders: the Summit Medical Group, for instance, a practice with 100 doctors in Summit, N.J., recently dropped Blue Cross, and others are expected to follow suit, said Dr. Greg Sachs, president of the Medical Society of New Jersey.
 
Opposition Grows In California and Texas
 Doctors' opposition to managed care is on the increase elsewhere, as well. In California, doctors have formed a group to push their opposition, and in Texas, some are also forswearing managed care. But experts say New York is particularly interesting because doctors here are rejecting a system that is still quite new and that has rolled into the region at a breakneck speed in the last few years.
Chief among their complaints have been reduced fees and more restrictions from the insurance companies on referrals and procedures.
"California had an evolution toward managed care, and we have had a revolution," Dr. Aswad said. "And that is why you hear about these disruptions and large groups' suddenly getting out."
This movement raises difficult questions about whether doctors can and should expect to make the same good living they did before the managed care movement, and whether a decision among some of the brightest and best to drop managed care plans simply recreates the caste system of care that health maintenance organizations were meant to eliminate by providing preventive care and a variety of services.
Clearly, New York is not leaving the managed care business.
The H.M.O. Trade Conference, a trade group, said that it had not yet heard of managed care companies' worrying about a mass exodus.
But it is just as clear that in the last few months many doctors, who have been unhappy about managed care almost since its introduction to the New York area, seem to be dropping out entirely, for several reasons.
Most important, consolidation among the managed care companies has increased, underscored by the announcement that Aetna U.S. Healthcare -- whose tough bargaining on rates makes it one of the least popular insurance carriers among doctors -- will acquire Prudential Health Care.
As the companies grow larger, their ability to dictate rates and policies is likely to increase.
Further, many companies have cut reimbursement rates significantly in recent months, causing many doctors to conclude that they cannot make any money by accepting them. Doctors may also be reacting to rising complaints from their patients, and taking advantage of a strong economy that has forced many employers to be more sensitive to their workers' health care demands.
"I just couldn't stand it," said Dr. Thomashow, the pulmonary specialist in Washington Heights. "The thought of being put on hold lines by people who don't know a quarter of what you are doing to get permission for patients to go to the bathroom was distasteful to me."
He knows he may lose patients, but he said he hoped he could persuade some to stay, even if that means lowering their bills. "If patients can't pay, then they don't pay," he said. "There are patients I will make less money off of than if I took managed care, but I don't care, because it is my choice."
The revolt tends to be led by doctors who have affluent patients who are both demanding and willing to pay for the services if they must. But some doctors, whose patient population is more diverse, are trying to form groups to challenge the companies en masse.
For example, the Mount Kisco Medical Group in Mount Kisco, N.Y., has started to take advantage of its size -- 64 doctors under one roof -- to negotiate with managed care companies.
It has dropped some plans that were demanding too much paperwork, said Dr. Scott D. Hayworth, the group's chief executive officer. But it negotiated a more favorable contract with others, including Oxford and Aetna.
"We are 64 doctors," Dr. Hayworth said, "so we are lucky because we have better negotiating power. Does that mean if you could wave a magic wand and make managed care go away, would we? We would want that for sure. But we make the best of it."
 
Forming a Group Not Always a Solution
 Experts predict that more large groups will come together -- perhaps in the form of unions. But forming groups does not always assure power.
For example, in 1994 Dr. Jonas Goldstone and Dr. Saul Kaplan formed Mid-Manhattan Medical Associates, an association of 26 doctors from various specialties who organized to arrange better ancillary services, like laboratories, and to deal with managed care through a central business office.
While many of their goals as a group have been met, they have not won better reimbursement rates from insurance carriers, they said.
"We are finding out that the projected income we expected in dealing with managed care has not materialized," Dr. Goldstone said, explaining that companies have not been receptive, either because the group is too small or the companies just don't care if they lose their business.
At this point, he added, "A number of us are seriously considering exiting managed care."
If someone's doctor informs her he will no longer accept her insurance plan, the options are clear: she finds another doctor or she pays up. And if she is in a plan that partly reimburses for visits to doctors out of the network, she files a claim.
Hospitals, too, are bridling at managed care. The biggest complaint is that companies are refusing to reimburse for the full number of days that patients spend in a hospital, contending that certain illnesses can be treated in shorter stays.
"I cannot overstate enough the sense of frustration within the hospitals," said Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, a trade group. "I have seen a whole turnabout in the last four or five months. We have gone from tolerance to feverish pitch, and we are seeking help from the authorities as well as lawmakers so H.M.O.'s stop abusing hospitals."
The association has asked the State Attorney General's office to pursue the matter of trimming days, and the association is contemplating lawsuits against individual companies, Mr. Raske said.
Some hospitals are also considering forming their own managed care companies -- common among providers of services to Medicaid recipients.
Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx is forming one such program to insure children, and hopes to extend it throughout its system.
Most doctors say that quality of care, not their own earnings, is driving their decisions.
They contend, for instance, that when managed care companies push for high-volume practices, the increased workload reduces the time they can devote to each patient, as well as to teaching, reading medical journals and working in clinics.
They also recognize the painful reality that only middle class and wealthier patients are likely to have insurance plans that allow them to choose their own doctor in exchange for a lower reimbursement rate, typically 80 percent or less.
"I don't want a practice just for rich people," said Dr. Softness, the pediatrician. "That was never my plan. But I also want to be able to give the kind of care that I think people deserve."
But some health care experts predict that a tiered health care system is in the offing with a movement like this one.
"I think we are moving toward a two-tiered or three-tiered structure of health care," said Michael Lichman, senior vice president of Willis Corroon of New York, one of the country's largest insurance brokers.
 
Despite Market Glut, Doctors' Income Rose
 Others, too, say that despite a glut of doctors in the 1980's, doctors' incomes rose higher than those of other professionals. They contend that in a supply and demand economy, lower salaries would have been expected.
"If doctors say that quality will fall as reimbursements fall, they are insulting themselves," said Uwe S. Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University. "The truth of the matter is that when a group of laborers are in surplus, wages fall. They are the only group that is unwilling to accept that."
Doctors who serve the poor, doctors fresh out of school who have no established patient base and doctors working in towns where one employer dominates the market are among those who simply cannot refuse managed care.
"You can't drop H.M.O.'s if you have a family to feed and a dog who depends on you," Mr. Lichman said. "Patients have become used to walking into a doctor's office and paying $10, and you can't say, 'O.K., I'm back in the fee-for-service business.' "
But as long as employers continue to offer plans that give employees a chance to go to doctors outside their networks -- which is likely in a strong economy -- and H.M.O.'s continue to push doctors to cut costs, more are likely to leave the H.M.O.'s.
"I hear every day about other groups of doctors who are dropping managed care," said Dr. Barry G. Chaiken, who founded the Association of Independent Physicians in New York, a new and growing group of doctors free of managed care.
"As managed care comes in and insists on fee discounts of 30 percent or more, physicians have to change their practices to survive," he said.

HEADLINE: Banks Put Their Faith In Building Churches;
Lending to Improve Neighborhoods

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The storefront was plain, the street unprepossessing, and the skies sent down torrents of rain. But inside last Sunday, more than 100 members of the New Jerusalem Church were rejoicing -- singing and dancing, swaying and shouting -- as their minister thanked God, "who makes us sit together in heavenly places."
Literally. For, Bishop Altamont G. Blackwood said, "there is no more heavenly place than the church." And the congregation's new church, complete with a bell tower and steeple, is rising on Springfield Boulevard in eastern Queens, just a few blocks from the commercial strip that has been New Jerusalem's home for more than 20 years. 
 Though the congregation gives God most of the credit for the new building, He does have a most worldly partner: the Chase Manhattan Bank, which has lent the congregation more than $1 million for the project.
The bank is doing so not merely out of the goodness of its corporate heart. Under the Federal Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, banks are required to lend money to help struggling neighborhoods in which they do business. And while governments seem to have neither the will nor the power to help with community redevelopment projects, Chase and other banks are turning to God -- or at least, to some of His servants here on earth -- to do such work.
"We decided that these institutions are critical to the communities we care about," said Carol J. Parry, the bank's executive vice president for community development. "Our ultimate objective is to make those communities better places to live."
The theory behind the Chase program is fairly simple: if churches are bigger and have more seats, they can attract more parishioners, who will finance and work on more community projects. It is mostly black churches that have received loans, though the program is open to all types of congregations and faiths. The bank also provides grants and technical assistance to religious organizations. The churches pay regular commercial interest rates on the loans.
Banks have a long history of lending money for church-sponsored programs, like low-income housing. But financing church buildings as a way to help communities is something new. (Chase made its first such loan, for just $150,000, in 1994.) Other large banks, like First Union in Charlotte, N.C., are also trying to increase their involvement with churches, and the approach was featured at a conference on community redevelopment in October organized by the American Bankers Association.
Churches across the country have occasionally borrowed from banks before, though often only with the help of wealthy members willing to cosign the loans or to put up a lot of cash as security.
Black churches have had particular trouble getting loans, said Albert C. Tew, a former commercial banker who as a consultant to churches has helped arrange some loans, including New Jerusalem's. "There aren't too many lenders who are aware of how African-American churches actually operate," he said.
Gradually, however, banks are becoming aware of the critical role churches play in poor neighborhoods.
"The church is the foundation of everything we do, in housing, health care, and for senior citizens," said Edwin C. Reed, chief financial officer of the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens. "Seats mean revenue to me."
Allen's history serves as a sort of parable for those who support lending to religious institutions. Membership in the church, which was founded in 1834, has soared since the Rev. Floyd H. Flake became pastor in 1976, when the church had 1,400 members and a building that could seat 200. Today, the church has a congregation of about 10,000 and offers three Sunday services at a new building that seats 2,500. The congregation raised $10 million of the $25 million cost; the rest was financed by a group of banks put together by Chase last year.
The church has become a major employer in Queens, running a dizzying array of social programs, including low-income housing, a transportation service, a center for the elderly, a shelter for battered women, a school and a project to improve local commercial strips. The neighborhood, once one of the poorest in Queens, is thriving.
Even for such a powerhouse of a church, getting a loan was not easy, for reasons Mr. Reed said he understood. Not only can it be hard to figure out where a church will get the money to repay a loan, he noted, but there is also the question of collateral. No bank would want to repossess a church, and if it did, what would it do, get corporate executives to come in to preach?
"Walter Shipley is a wonderful person," Mr. Reed said, referring to the chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, "but he cannot pack my church every Sunday."
But if lending $15 million to Allen took an act of faith, lending $1 million to New Jerusalem took a real leap. After all, the church has just 250 members, almost all immigrants from the West Indies, and they are by no means rich.
And unlike Allen, whose pastor was also a Congressman for many years, New Jerusalem is not a force in local politics. Not only is Mr. Blackwood not a politician, but he does not even know any politicians, he said. "I haven't even shaken any one of their hands," he said. "This is a straight loan. I had no strings to pull."
But what their leader does have is a financial track record. Now 52, Mr. Blackwood has been preaching since he was a teen-ager in Jamaica, and he came to this country in 1970. Within seven years, he had scraped together enough money to make a down payment on a little building on Francis Lewis Boulevard, where he started his church, whose full name is the New Jerusalem Church of God in Christ Jesus (Apostolic) Inc. The $57,000 building was paid for in three years.
When it was started, his congregation had only five members -- all related to him and living in the small apartment over the church, Mr. Blackwood recalled. He remodeled the building himself, moving the bathrooms, finishing the basement, painting the tiny office.
Today, the sanctuary has wood-paneled walls, a drop ceiling and wall-to-wall carpeting; the wooden pews are supplemented with folding chairs when the crowd gets too big, which it often does.
In 1990, Mr. Blackwood found a vacant lot for sale; he raised and borrowed money for the down payment and got a five-year mortgage from the owner. Within three years, he and the congregation had paid off the $127,500 cost of the land.
The congregation has also raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for the new church, and this accomplishment is one of the reasons Chase was comfortable making such a large loan to such a small group, said Earlene Hampton, vice president of the Chase Community Development Corporation, the unit of the bank that made the loan last spring.
How has the congregation come up with so much cash? And how will it cover the roughly $150,000 annual mortgage payment?
The church does some fund-raising. It sells oranges from Florida and sponsors bus trips to family-oriented spots like the theme park Sesame Place in Langhorne, Pa., said Maria Angus, the church's secretary. Elfreda Moore, a 78-year-old matriarch of the church, sells hats outside the doors on Saturdays.
But most of the money comes out of church members' pockets. Many of them tithe, giving a tenth of their incomes to the church, and they also contribute to special fund-raising campaigns, Mr. Blackwood said. "Some folks that give it, give their last mite," he said. "but they find such favor and love in what we are doing that they give what they have to give."
Certainly, they seem to be giving with joy. At last week's noon service, the plate was not passed; rather, members filed to the front of the church to contribute money and checks. Once the offering was completed, Clara Pettigrew led the choir dancing down the aisle and then back up to the front, as everyone sang that they would "Walk and Talk in the New Jerusalem Way."
It does not hurt the fund-raising effort that neither Mr. Blackwood nor the assistant ministers receive a salary from the church. Mr. Blackwood owns a small hardware store, and his wife works at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where, as part of his ministry, he leads services in the psychiatric ward twice a month. Although he supervises almost a dozen Apostolic churches in and around New York, he continues to live simply and to spend the church's money very carefully, said Mr. Tew, the consultant.
The people who give the most will get the best seats in the new church -- and those seats will be grand. Pews for 650 people will fill the floor and balcony under a soaring wooden ceiling. Glass blocks in the stone walls will form stylized crosses in the front and back of the huge room. There will be enough space on the dais up front for all the ministers and elders, the senior and junior choirs, and even a baptismal pool.
In the basement, there will be room to serve hot lunches to 270 needy people, and to expand the church's free food distribution program. These programs are now run out of the old church's cramped basement, which does not have a kitchen or enough exits to accommodate much of a crowd. That old building will be turned into a church-sponsored day care center.
These plans were crucial in Chase's decision to give the church a loan, Ms. Parry said. And so was confidence that the congregation would grow to fill the new church.
The median household income in the mostly black neighborhood is about $58,700 a year, according to projections by the Queens College sociology department. The mostly single-family homes in the neighborhood are small but neat; many of the commercial areas, however, are far less prosperous-looking.
The new church is replacing decrepit buildings on land that was being used as an illegal dump, church members say; it sits between two open lots, their fences festooned with signs advertising everything from used cars to goat meat.
Mr. Blackwood hopes to acquire these lots someday, to add more parking, perhaps even to build a school. But for now, he is just trying to restrain his impatience to see the church completed, and to plan a ceremony for the grand opening, which he hopes will be in March.
And, along with his congregation, he is literally counting his blessings. The list last Sunday was long -- the service lasted almost three hours -- and included all kinds of things, spiritual and physical, including the new church.
"I didn't dream He would lend us more than $1 million to build a church, just a small group of people as we are," Mr. Blackwood said, as exclamations of "Jesus!" and "Hallelujah!" rose from the congregation. "He made a way where there was no way."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
GOLDSTEIN, LEON M.

 BODY:
GOLDSTEIN-Leon M. The administration, faculty, staff and students of Kingsborough Community College, City University of New York, deeply mourn the passing of Leon M. Goldstein, its beloved President for the past 28 years. His visionary leadership made Kingsborough one of the finest institutions of higher education in the country. His innovative, pioneering educational, cultural and community service programs for the residents of the borough of Brooklyn and the City of New York have demonstrated all the positive aspects of collaboration, cooperation and commitment to excellence. President Goldstein's creative programs including College Now, Family College, My Turn, Diploma Now, New Start and the Kingsborough High School for the Sciences have responded to the needs of people of all ages and have served as models for other colleges across the nation. Through his forceful leadership and dedicated professionalism Leon Goldstein has been an inspiration to all those he has touched. As a student of the City University of New York, a member of its faculty, an administrator and as a president, Leon Goldstein exemplified the very mission, heart and soul of public higher education. He was a strong voice for the educationally and economically disadvantaged, women returning to the workforce and education for new immigrants. He championed the cause of access to higher education for all New Yorkers. President Goldstein will long be remembered for his extraordinary ability to bring out the best in people. He was loved and will be missed by the entire Kingsborough Family. Our hearts go out to his wife, Mary, his son, Michael, his daughter, Lisa and her husband, Glenn. Funeral services will be held Sunday, January 10 at 1:15 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York City. GOLDSTEIN-Leon M. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Kingsborough Community College President Leon M. Goldstein. Dynamic leader of the College for 27 years, distinguished educator and administrator, extraordinary champion of the New York State community college movement, and outstanding alumnus of City College and Brooklyn College, he served CUNY in numerous capacities with great distinction as Acting Chancellor, Acting Deputy Chancellor, Chair of the Fiscal Affairs Committee of the Council of Presidents, Chair of the Chancellor's Advisory Committee on Academic Program Planning, University Dean for Community Colleges and Dean and Professor of History at New York City Community College. Recognized nationally for his leadership and commitment to higher education, he served as Vice President of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, and Chair of its Commission on Higher Education. Committed to access and excellence in education throughout his career, he was in the forefront of pioneering programs established at Kingsborough Community College including College Now, Family College, Teacher's Academy, the Kingsborough High School for the Sciences, My Turn and New Start. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Anne A. Paolucci, Chairwoman Board of Trustees Christoph M. Kimmich Interim Chancellor GOLDSTEIN-Leon. On behalf of the instructional staff at CUNY, the Professional Staff Congress notes with profound sadness the passing of President Leon Goldstein of Kingsborough Community College. President Goldstein's contribution to the building of Kingsborough and its widely admired place in American higher education is his great legacy. The university community is also in his debt for his admirable service as CUNY Dean for Commmunity Colleges, Acting Deputy Chancellor and Acting Chancellor of CUNY. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his widow, Dr. Mary Goldstein, and the entire Goldstein family. Dr. Irwin H. Polishook, President Dr. Richard J. Boris Vice-President Dr. Rina Yarmish, Chapter Chair Professional Staff Congress/ CUNY

HEADLINE: Off the Urban Rust Heap, a Factory Goes to Work

BYLINE: By ALEX PRUD'HOMME

 BODY:
THE dark brick factory complex on the Brooklyn waterfront would not look out of place in a moody industrial landscape by Edward Hopper. A few years ago, most of the windows were broken, roofs were collapsing, interiors were contaminated with asbestos and the basement was cluttered with leaking drums of toxic substances. The city, which owned the site in the Greenpoint neighborhood, was on the verge of demolishing this cluster of buildings.
Walk inside today, though, and you find a warren of vibrant spaces filled with hundreds of woodworkers, artists and craftsmen. You hear hammering and grinding noises, smell oil paint and sawdust and see teams of cabinet makers banging together kitchen cabinets -- or a single artist laboring over multicolored spiral glass sculptures. 
 Built in the 19th century as a rope factory, the complex at 1155 Manhattan Avenue -- actually eight connected buildings -- is now home to the Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center, a nonprofit corporation that provides woodworkers and artists with affordable work space in a communal environment.
"If I hadn't moved here, I'd be out of business," said Ricky Eisenberg, the owner of Creative Cabinets and Carpentry Ltd., one of the center's 68 tenants. "In Manhattan, I was paying double the rent for a quarter of the space I have here. So now I have an eightfold advantage. This building is run by half-communism, half-capitalism, and it works out pretty good."
However muddled the ideology, urban experts count the Greenpoint project in the vanguard of a campaign to revive inner-city industrial zones one building at a time.
"We didn't really have any models for how to do this," said David Sweeny, 34, the center's chief executive. "We aren't visionaries with 10-year plans for incubator projects. We're problem-solvers, opportunists."
In New York, as in cities across the country, opportunities abound for creative reuse of the derelict hubs of once-thriving manufacturing economies. Over the last three decades, thousands of New York's manufacturers have been driven out of business or out of the city, the victims of escalating rents, taxes and crime rates; onerous zoning regulations, and tight-fisted banks.
But the Greenpoint center offers a model for bringing some of the abandoned industrial space back to life. In the early 1990's, Mr. Sweeny and his board of directors cobbled together a patchwork of financial support from public and private sources, and -- with political pluck, the good will of suppliers and the sweat equity of tenants -- took control of the complex.
In 1994, the first year of operation, the buildings were in such bad shape that the center could rent only 40,000 square feet of space to 12 businesses. Today, virtually the entire 360,000-square-foot complex is rented, and its tenants employ 460 people.
The project has generated jobs and job training for Greenpoint, a blue-collar neighborhood with a population that is largely Polish, Irish and Hispanic. It is contributing $135,000 a year to the city in property taxes and about $800,000 in city and state payroll taxes. There is a long waiting list of prospective tenants. Mr. Sweeny's organization is consulting for a number of like-minded nonprofit groups, has just opened a for-profit furniture business and is evaluating other old industrial sites where it hopes to reproduce its brand of what Mr. Sweeny calls "commie venture capitalism."
"I'm not at all surprised by their success," said Anne Habiby, director of research at the Institute for a Competitive Inner City, a group in Cambridge, Mass., that was founded by Michael S. Porter, a Harvard Business School professor, to promote business expansion in distressed urban areas. What the Greenpoint center has done, she said, "is to reproduce in microcosm the elements of a successful economy."
And while the Greenpoint group isn't the only one in the country doing this kind of work, she said, "they are way out ahead of the curve."
 
Pioneers in the Wreckage
The buildings at 1155 Manhattan Avenue became the city's problem in 1972, when their last owner, the Grossen Dye Works, failed to pay its taxes. Left largely empty and decaying, the complex fell into further disrepair.
In the 1980's, a few artists and woodworkers were allowed to take 30-day leases on odd spaces scattered around the buildings, as long as they agreed to plug leaks, build walls and wire the work spaces themselves. The rent was minimal and the space was vast, but only a few pioneers were willing to take the risk.
"The building was a wasteland," recalled Dennis Niswander, an abstract painter who found his way to Greenpoint in 1982, after the rent tripled on his Times Square studio. "I'd have to walk through 10,000 square feet of empty, decrepit space to get to my studio," said Mr. Niswander, now the center's physical-plant manager.
"It was emergency conditions all over," he said.
The city closed down some parts of the buildings for code violations, estimating the cost of necessary renovations at $14 million. The complex was shopped to residential developers, but with the drop in real estate prices in the mid-80's, there was little interest.
In the meantime, tenants who were fed up with conditions in the complex banded together as the Woodworking Center Equity Corporation, to manage the building and negotiate leases. They hired Mr. Niswander to do major repairs, like fixing a burst water main. He and a crew of three removed some 250 tons of scrap metal and learned to move abandoned machines weighing up to two tons with nothing but crowbars.
In the process, they developed a sense of ownership for a crumbling structure that, it seemed, no one else wanted.
"This building has retained a kind of aesthetic and human history not documented anywhere," Mr. Niswander said. "I crawled around every square inch of it, until it became like the exterior of my skin."
Mr. Sweeny entered the picture in 1990. A slight, bearded economics graduate of the University of Vermont, he had a mild manner that concealed a strong will. At the time, he was the director of economic development for the North Brooklyn Development Corporation, a nonprofit community group. Forgoing the Harvard Business School, where he had been admitted, Mr. Sweeny became swept up in Mr. Niswander's enthusiasm.
"I'd been studying how to bring employment to low-income neighborhoods, and this project seemed like a great lab experiment in which to test my theories," Mr. Sweeny said.
Along with the angry tenants and a number of volunteer real estate and legal specialists, the two men incorporated the Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center in May 1992 and applied to buy the entire complex.
"It seemed so elegantly simple," Mr. Sweeny said. "The city was getting no taxes from this building and they had no buyer, yet it was filling up with tenants who were willing to fix it themselves. I thought it would be easy."
But it wasn't. On Thanksgiving weekend in 1992, inspectors from the city's Department of Buildings shut down the elevators, calling them unsafe, and fined a sister agency, the Department of Real Property, which owned the buildings. Unable to make deliveries to the upper floors, 60 outraged woodworkers protested by smashing wooden chairs into splinters on the steps of City Hall.
"It was a highly balkanized situation," recalled Leslie Winter, a former assistant commissioner in the Division of Real Property who now is chairman of the center's board. "The city was fining itself, and everybody had different ideas on what should be done with the building."
A few months later, the city's Economic Development Corporation allowed Mr. Sweeny's group to take over management of the building, though not the leasing of space.
The galvanizing moment came in 1993, when city officials refused to allow a French furniture maker to finance $500,000 in improvements and lease 30,000 square feet in the complex. Mr. Sweeny and Mr. Niswander had had enough. They created a 200-page development schedule and invited city politicians to Greenpoint, "to smell the sawdust and see the furniture," Mr. Sweeny said.
Carl Weisbrod, then the president of the Economic Development Corporation, visited the site on his own and agreed to intervene on the center's behalf. On Feb. 28, 1994, the city sold the building to Mr. Sweeny's group for $1. The city had already spent $750,000 on an environmental cleanup of the site and now promised to set aside an additional $1 million for safety improvements, like fixing the sprinkler system and elevators.
"From the city's perspective, we assumed a $14 million liability for a dollar," Mr. Niswander said.
 
Building a Balance Sheet
In 1994, the center lost $180,000. "The first year was the worst time for us -- and the best," Mr. Sweeny recalled, stroking his seeing-eye dog, named Mr. Rogers, as he sat in his modest, doorless office at the center. Born with retinoblastoma, a rare form of cancer that causes a tumor on the eye, Mr. Sweeny has gradually lost all of his sight over the last few years -- though, as long as he could, he continued to bicycle fearlessly across the Brooklyn Bridge.
In that difficult first year, Mr. Sweeny said, enthusiasm did much to keep the project going. The managers granted rent credits to tenants for renovation work they had done on their own spaces; some contractors and materials suppliers deferred their compensation, and Mr. Sweeny, who was working full-time at the center by this time, didn't take a salary for the first 10 months.
"That's the part of the model that I'm not sure others can replicate -- everyone's dedication," Mr. Sweeny said. "It was completely crazy. I didn't know how we were going to finance our operations. I didn't even know who our tenants were going to be. A sophisticated real-estate person would have told us, 'There's no light at the end of this tunnel -- no light.' "
That was certainly what Mr. Sweeny was told by most of the financiers he approached.
"Our first year we were shopping for a line of credit and were continually rejected," he said. "The banks gave us good chat on the phone, but they were skeptical."
Fortunately, there were other sources of help. When the founders established the Greenpoint Center organization, a grant of $7,500 from the J. P. Morgan Charitable Trust accounted for nearly a third of its budget.
"In a situation like that, a little bit of money goes a long way," said Hildy J. Simmons, managing director of community relations and philanthropic services at J. P. Morgan. "In grant-making, you try to support the right people, and we really responded to David Sweeny. He was determined to make things happen. What he's done is the best of modest-scale economic development in the city."
Since taking possession of the building, the group has received additional small grants from the Morgan trust and from Brooklyn Union Gas and Chase Manhattan Bank; aid from foundations like the New York Foundation, which helps support grass-roots neighborhood projects, and loans from agencies like the Federal Office of Community Services and the Nonprofit Facilities Fund, a private group that has some city financing.
The center has used the money to improve the services it offers to tenants -- from computer training programs and apprenticeships for underprivileged teen-agers to help for cabinetmakers in learning to market their skills.
Today, the center, with an operating budget of about $1 million a year, is self-sufficient. Rents pay for the upkeep and improvement of the buildings' windows, roofs and elevators and underwrite a full-time construction crew.
"If all of our grants were to dry up tomorrow, the building would be fine," Mr. Sweeny said. "We just wouldn't be able to offer our training programs. What we do isn't social welfare for small businesses; it's strict economic development."
The center is finishing the last phase of its renovation, bringing the cost to $6.8 million -- $3 million from the center's earnings and the remainder from a combination of grants and loans from Government and private sources. The total is half what the city had projected for restoration, but the project has been spread over four years, instead of the one-year plan that the city favored.
One of the center's strengths has been staying true to its mission of keeping rents affordable and building a community of woodworkers and artists. The directors -- "four hippie woodworkers; four gray suits from the worlds of finance, architecture and law, and me," is how Mr. Sweeny characterized them -- made it a priority.
"We had fishmongers looking to rent space, and it was tempting to take their money," he said. "But we learned that real estate becomes more valuable when you restrict the kinds of tenants you allow in."
By being part of a critical mass of businesses that draw on similar skills, trade their resources and do not compete directly with one another -- all at a strategic location near Manhattan -- the center's tenants "gain a clear competitive advantage," said Ms. Habiby of the Initiative for a Competitive Inner City.
"The power of business development is around clusters," she said. She pointed to Grand Rapids, Mich., the location of another emerging woodworking cluster, and to a telecommunications cluster that has flourished in downtown Oakland, Calif.
The concept is as old as the Middle Eastern bazaar or the European farmers' market and as fundamental to urban life as the flower, fish and food markets that still thrive, to varying degrees, in even the creakiest American cities. But it is being rediscovered after several decades in which the growth of American light industry was largely in the suburbs or the cities of the Sun Belt.
The Brooklyn center, Ms. Habiby said, "is certainly a model for others to watch." And, she added, "their mix of funding seems ideal."

Many Languages, Few Borders
Inside 1155 Manhattan Avenue, the work spaces range from an artist's 600-square-foot studio to a 30,000-square-foot woodworking operation that employs 70 people on three floors. Average rents in the building are $4 to $5 a square foot, compared with $10 to $12 for comparable space in Manhattan and $7 to $9 in Queens.
"Every time you open a door, it's a new story," said Mariusz Cwalina, the building superintendent, a native of Poland whose father is a woodworker at the center. "You could wander in here for a week, and every person you meet is speaking a different language and doing something different."
Tenants often give one another advice or work together on projects. "There's a lot of cross-pollination here," said Paul Seide, a glass artist who has been at the center since 1990. Mr. Seide makes colorful glass spirals filled with neon gas, and another tenant makes wooden pedestals for the spirals to sit on.
In 1994, the complex invested $200,000 in a wood production center, filling an L-shaped room with new woodworking machinery for communal use. Last October, the center established Spacecraft, its first for-profit business, a joint venture with the furniture designer Jonas Milder, who is based in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to build and distribute a line of tables, desks and bookcases.
Critics have questioned the harnessing of for-profit subsidiaries to nonprofit organizations, saying such connections can create misunderstanding of a nonprofit's finances and pollute its philanthropic mission. But Mr. Sweeny, ever the pragmatist, dismisses naysayers. If Spacecraft succeeds, he said, "we'll put the profits back into the building, which is good for everyone."
Mr. Sweeny, who draws a $50,000 salary from the Greenpoint center, says that he is actively seeking to replicate the project in another industrial site of similar vintage. But he allows that it won't be any easier the next time around.
"In retrospect, I'm astonished we survived," he said. "It would be a disservice to tell people they can put together a deal the way we did. I think we managed it because of the unique amalgam of people we have here. You can't franchise that. But if we can find the right opportunity, we might try it again."

HEADLINE: Mortgage Tax Break: Who Gets What

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSON

 BODY:
The income-tax deduction for home mortgage interest is one of the most popular politically, but its economic effects are perverse: Experts call it an "upside down" subsidy because the more a taxpayer earns, the greater the tax cut it yields.
 
 But the degree to which that is true is obscured by the way Washington policy makers usually present the figures. Congress recently released its annual chart on the subject, showing that, in aggregate, 20 percent of the tax savings from deducting home mortgage interest go to taxpayers making more than $200,000 a year.
 But when savings are compared taxpayer by taxpayer instead of in big lump sums, the skew toward the top income groups is much starker.
 By this measure, for each dollar in tax savings going to the average taxpayer making $200,000 or more, the average taxpayer in all lower income groups combined saves just 6 cents. Taxpayers making $30,000 to $40,000, putting them on the lower rungs of the middle class, save 2 cents on the dollar, and those making less than $10,000 save an average of 3 one-thousandths of a cent.
 Looked at another way, for each dollar in tax saved by the average taxpayer making less than $10,000, an average taxpayer in the top income group saves $29,200.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Jazz's Best-Known Label at 60

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS 

 BODY:
WHEN Alfred Lion, a refugee from Nazi Germany, founded Blue Note Records in New York in 1939, he had no idea that the small label would become an item of worship. This month, celebrating its 60th anniversary, Blue Note is filling clubs in Manhattan with past and present members of its roster.
The widespread adoration of the label has its roots in the Lion's extraordinarily high level of artistic production. Over the years, the label recorded Bud Powell, Miles Davis, Thelonious Monk, Art Blakey, Freddie Hubbard and Wayne Shorter. No other record label in jazz has been as consistent in quality. And the art that has adorned its album covers has become iconic, copied, used ironically on pop albums or as part of pop design. It has become a brand name. In 1994, an English book of the label's record covers confirmed that its imprimatur had extended beyond the jazz world; a year later Rizzoli published a coffee-table book of photographs by the label's co-founder, Francis Wolff, called "The Blue Note Years." There had been earlier hints that the jazz world wasn't going to be big enough for the label: a discography and several waves of reissues, including previously unissued material, not all of it worthy of Lion's stamp of approval. 
 Jazz fans could talk about their favorite Blue Note record, the sumptuousness of the label's sound. They could even discuss who the engineer was (usually Rudy Van Gelder) and where the sessions mostly took place (at Mr. Van Gelder's studio in Englewood, N.J.). But nobody would have predicted the sort of adulation that has transpired.
In 1968, the label, which had always been a small independent company, was bought by the conglomerate United Artists, and the quality plummeted; it was no longer run by the legendarily fastidious Lion, who died in 1987. By 1976, the label had closed down. Eight years later it started up again. At the time jazz, which had undergone the worst period in its history, was beginning to show a quickening pulse. Blue Note had also become the jazz wing of a major label, Capital, giving it the financial wherewithal to work with. It was to be run by Bruce Lundvall, a jazz fan who had been the president of Columbia Records and later president at Elektra and Capital. As an inducement to run Capital, he was asked to restart Blue Note; it was his favorite label.
Some of the intense interest in the label is a testament to its own marketing plan: Mr. Lundvall has always presented the company as special, distinct from the rest of the jazz world. To take advantage of the hunger on the part of rap artists, the label packaged a series of compilations intended for sampling. It licensed material to the mail-order reissue company Mosaic, which put out anthologies of Blue Note material in boxed sets that appealed to the fetish collector in all of us. And the company has routinely figured out ways of packaging and repackaging the same catalogue, creating limited edition series along with boxed sets of some of the labels bigger stars like Dexter Gordon and Herbie Hancock.
During Mr. Lundvall's tenure Blue Note has come close to reproducing the impulse of the original label. He has had failures, but in the last few years he has taken the company to its best position since Lion left. It's now the only major label dedicated to the adventurous mainstream, just as it was under Lion's leadership.
This month's celebration might be seen as cynical on the part of the record company, as simple self-aggrandizement. But for anyone who knows Mr. Lundvall, it's clear that marketing and love of the music aren't mutually exclusive. And Mr. Lundvall is anything but cynical.
At 63, he's one of the few jazz record company executives who goes out to hear music regularly; if somebody tips him off to promising young musicians, he'll actually stay out late to hear them. He'll set up auditions for those who come highly recommended. And he has done his best to balance the needs of a major label accustomed to thinking in the economic terms of pop music and the unpleasant reality of jazz sales.
So Mr. Lundvall has signed pop jazz artists like Everett Harp and Richard Elliot, whose sales offset the losses incurred by the serious young jazz musicians he has brought in. The reissue program produces a windfall. The CD version of John Coltrane's "Blue Trane," for example, has sold some 300,000 copies in the United States alone; Herbie Hancock's "Maiden Voyage" has sold 150,000 copies here. And he has tried to keep the scale of the original label. In the 1950's, it released slews of albums because the economy was right; while the albums didn't cost much to make, they didn't sell particularly well either, usually between 2,000 and 3,000 copies. Jazz record companies today, caught in the pop world, now release fewer albums and expect them to sell more.
MR. LUNDVALL, like Lion, has let the other major labels take most of the expensive jazz stars and has instead worked on signing lesser-known musicians and turning them into important figures. The result is a string of powerful albums by the saxophonist Greg Osby and a promising first album by the vibraphonist Stephon Harris. Mr. Lundvall signed the singer Cassandra Wilson when she was a virtual unknown; she's now selling well, even in pop terms, and is one of the best-known singers in jazz. Joe Lovano, the veteran saxophonist, has flourished on the label. Mr. Lundvall has also signed two of Cuba's most brilliant pianists, Chucho Valdez and Gonzalo Rubalcaba. He has nurtured the career of the young, gifted pianist Jackie Terrasson, releasing four albums by him. And the trumpeter Tim Hagens, virtually unknown, has released four albums, including a recent mixture of jazz and the dance style drum-and-bass.
Like the original Blue Note, Mr. Lundvall's version doesn't define any single vision of the avant-garde, but it does tread between the old and new styles. He likes swingers in the jazz tradition, but swingers that think, that are looking for the new without forgetting the old. And there are exceptions to even his traditionalism: the clarinetist Don Byron now records for Blue Note, as do Medeski, Martin and Wood, a jazz funk group.
There's a farm system at the company, somewhat like the one at the original Blue Note. Mr. Lundvall listens to musicians' advice; Mr. Osby brought the pianist Jason Moran to his attention, and Mr. Lundvall signed him. The young saxophonist Mark Shim came to his attention through the singer Betty Carter. The pianist James Hurt, who has recorded with one of the more thoughtful of the current crop of Blue Note musicians, the saxophonist Sherman Irby, has a development deal with the label.
The farm team guarantees the label a future, as long as Mr. Lundvall can keep the company solvent by juggling the money makers and the money losers. So far, it has worked, and he has made Blue Note the best of the major labels in jazz. He, and the label, deserve their month of recognition, if not more.

HEADLINE: St. John The Unfinished;
Dean of Cathedral on Morningside Heights Vows to Fix What He's Got, Not Build More

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
THE Cathedral of St. John the Divine, more than a century in the making, may never be really finished. Construction of the world's largest cathedral has always been on-again, off-again. Now it's off again, for the forseeable future, as guardians of the Episcopal cathedral turn to preserving what has been built instead of pushing further skyward. While the unbuilt towers, spires and transepts designed years ago wait, church leaders face a new challenge: how to raise millions of dollars to maintain the beloved stone church at Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street on Morningside Heights.
Since the cornerstone was laid in 1892, construction has been halted by engineering problems, economic shortfalls and changing architectural tastes -- which helps explain the jumble of Gothic, Romanesque and Byzantine styles -- as well as two world wars, the social upheaval of the 1960's and the real estate bust of the late 1980's. 
 This time the decision not to resume building is based more on internal than external influences. As recently as 1996, cathedral officials were talking of starting a $100 million building fund to resume construction, which had stopped in 1992. But then the cathedral got a new Dean, the Very Rev. Harry H. Pritchett Jr., who decided it was time to shelve the dream of his predecessor, the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, to at least complete the south tower. Dean Pritchett persuaded church leaders that they had little choice: Either act now to preserve what has been built over the past century or there will be no structure left to build on in the next.
But financing the repairs, cathedral officials say, will not be easy. Passing the plate, even in a church that can seat 2,500 worshipers at a time, will not raise the estimated $20 million to $40 million needed to fix up the cathedral. The problem, officials concede, is that from a fund-raising viewpoint, maintenance is not exciting. It would be easier, they figure, to raise that level of money for an imaginative array of social programs or to finish the south tower, now partly covered in blue sheeting, with the 20-year-old scaffolding rusting onto the cream-colored granite. The idea now is to remove the scaffolding and cap the tower with a temporary, modernist plastic crown that could remain for years, an apt reminder of the cathedral's nickname: St. John the Unfinished.
Dean Morton wanted to keep building. Dean Pritchett does not. "Dean Morton had some wonderful ideas about completing the cathedral, or at least the south tower," Dean Pritchett said. "He and his leadership had a great vision of the cathedral as a community building effort. I share much of that, but I think my role is to position for that to happen in the future.
"Rather than simply focusing on completing the cathedral, we've got to preserve what's there in order to one day finish it," Dean Pritchett continued. "Sure, we could argue back and forth about whether it's really advantageous to have the biggest Gothic cathedral in the world, but the truth is, we've already got it. So the question becomes, what to do with it? How can you be a good steward of this incredible gift?"
Crumbling buildings and an unfinished cathedral were not all that Dean Pritchett faced when he took the helm. He has also had to deal with a chronic budget deficit, which was $750,000 in the year ended June 1998, a desire for more social programs, and traditional tensions between the cathedral's trustees and the trustees of the Diocese of New York over the cathedral's mission, programs and administration.
The cathedral, by definition, is the seat of the Bishop, the Right Rev. Richard F. Grein, who heads the diocese and is chairman of both boards. But the property is in the hands of the cathedral's trustees and the Dean, who oversees 122 people, including priests and a full-time staff. "The Diocese is here and the Dean is here and the way the polity is set up, the Bishop is in charge," Dean Pritchett said. "He is in authority, and yet the trustees and the Dean own the property."
"This is a very complex organization," he said. "It needed new development, new reconciliation, new building up of leadership.
"The tension and the ambiguity between the cathedral corporation and the diocese corporation is now more creative," Dean Pritchett continued, "rather than the divisive and destructive tension there had been in the more recent past."
Did that tension include a debate over construction versus repairs. "I don't want to get into that," the Dean said. "I inherited the tension, and my goal is to not cover over it but to help reconciliation to take place so we can go forward. People are caring about the cathedral as an incredibly important part of the life of the city. It must be preserved."
The Dean seems to have gathered support for his proposed maintenance regimen. "This was not a difficult decision to make," said Bishop Grein, who took over from the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr. in 1989. "Cathedrals have long lives and go through all kinds of phases. This isn't a dramatic move in terms of a cathedral."
Bishop Grein, who in 1992 claimed that the cathedral could be completed in 20 years for $100 million, said spending on maintenance could save millions later. "If you don't do this," he said, "the dollar costs keep growing. Last time the dome leaked, it wiped out all the reconstruction we had done on the organ and we had to start all over again."
But Dean Morton, now Dean Emeritus of the cathedral, said he was saddened to see his dream deferred. "Construction of the cathedral is part of its mission," he said, noting that Bishop Grein was expected to retire in a few years, perhaps shifting diocesan politics again. "My hope and my prayer," he said, "is that once the transition is over and the new bishop is there and there's a new dynamic in operation, that construction will again be part of the ongoing agenda of the cathedral."
Dean Morton was skeptical about how successful a fund-raising drive for building maintenance might be. "Repairing sidewalks and removing scaffolding is hardly earth shattering," he said. "It's hard to raise money for that kind of thinking. In fact, I think it's a downer. Forgive me for saying so, but putting a cap on the tower, that's not an upper. That's a downer. Obviously, they're putting a lid on construction. I suppose you can turn that around into a positive thing, but it's not a very sexy thing."
Still, he acknowledged, repairs are needed. "You have to do that," he said. "Cathedrals are monsters. They are big, heavy and very expensive. They've got to be maintained. If not, you're in deep trouble."
Dean Pritchett and the executive vice president of St. John the Divine, Stephen Facey, have hired a real estate consultant to look into ways of generating income from the property. They have also retained the firm of Polshek Partnership Architects to survey conditions and develop a plan to address structural problems and to improve the cathedral and its 13.5-acre grounds. A preliminary five-year plan envisions spending some $20 million on a range of projects, from repairing the south tower masonry to replacing the nave roof to fixing stained-glass windows to restoring other features of the property.
Among the many unfinished construction projects, the south tower remains the most obvious. Work on it began in 1978 under Dean Morton. Updating a medieval tradition, he created a program that trained neighborhood youths in the art of stone cutting. He secured outside money and support from a real estate developer, David Teitelbaum, who helped establish a company for the project.
That was "during the whole 'Bonfire of the Vanities' period, when everybody was having marble kitchens and bathrooms and foyers built," Dean Morton said. "David spent millions on high-tech laser stone cutters and we began training young people. He was able to expand the number of workers from 5 to 20 to almost 70 at one point."
The idea was to raise money for the tower while training people to cut stone for it. But in 1992, after 50 feet was built with some $10 million in donations, the project stopped. "It got very complicated," Dean Morton said. "The financial panic hit and the real estate situation really sort of went to hell. Suddenly the market collapsed and the company was in a situation with all this expensive machinery, and for all practical purposes the company went bankrupt."
Today, the stoneyard is silent, some pieces carved into Gothic spires, others still in raw form. "Everything that was built, it's paid for," Dean Morton said. "And just sitting there are the stones, waiting to go up, also paid for."
Another project that started and stopped, though much longer ago, is the north transept, also known as the Women's Transept because money to build it was raised solely by women. (Transepts are the massive wings that complete the cross pattern of typical cathedrals.)
Construction on the north transept began during the Depression and ended on Dec. 7, 1941, Pearl Harbor day. Today, with a temporary roof and the original interior construction scaffolding, the space is used for a gift shop. If the south transept were to be built, an 1843 Greek Revival building would have to be moved or demolished. "I really don't think that will be an issue any time in our lifetime," said Andrew S. Dolkart, a historian who teaches at Columbia University's School of Architecture and is the author of "Morningside Heights: A History of Its Architecture and Development" (Columbia University Press, 1998).
Mr. Dolkart, who supports the building hiatus, said he did not think much more would be constructed in this generation, except perhaps the south tower. No one knows when, or if, the north tower, the transepts and massive central tower and spire meant to soar above the crossing will ever be completed.
The original design, by the architectural firm of Heins & La Farge, featured a largely Byzantine interior, with rounded arches and windows. But in 1907, as architectural fashions were shifting, George Heins died. Four years later, Christopher Grant La Farge was ousted from the project amid tremendous controversy. This paved the way for a Gothic Revival architect, Ralph Adams Cram, to take over. Cram set out to "eradicate any hint of the original Byzantine design," Mr. Dolkart said. But construction stopped before he could finish.
"The dramatic history of the building is very evident from its appearance," Mr. Dolkart said. "You have this unfinished part, this beautiful Byzantine section that is still visible. So even if they were to decide they wanted to continue with construction, how would they deal with these points where the Byzantine and the Gothic meet? Do you keep the Byzantine features? How do you keep them? And how do you finish without losing this character that so many people appreciate?"
Some interior column capitals are still uncarved, as are many blocks intended to be interior and exterior statues. The back, or ambulatory, wall has exposed concrete. And the rough-hewn granite of some support walls in the crossing remains exposed, lending a cavelike feeling to the immense space. "Many people feel the incomplete, raw space is their favorite part," Mr. Dolkart said. "They really love it."
Dean Pritchett sees it this way: "Even if someone came in here tomorrow with a check to finish the cathedral, sure, it would be wonderful. But on the other hand, you would think, 'Gosh, is this what the church ought to be putting $100 million or $150 million into?' "
Dean Pritchett said cathedral officials were considering a special fund-raising campaign for the preservation effort , but added, "There's a lot to do to put that in place." He said his time and cathedral resources were stretched among various needs, among them vital programs, like those aiding the poor, the homeless and people with AIDS, reform of the cathedral bureaucracy and maintenance of the church buildings.
Connie Hildesly, one of the cathedral's 16 trustees, said she expected support for the idea of repairing and maintaining the property instead of pressing ahead with plans to build. "Harry Pritchett's style is to be very consensus building, so we expect a healthy discussion," she said.
Bishop Moore, who said he was no longer involved in cathedral politics, observed that what went on inside a cathedral was more important than the physical structure. "The medieval cathedral in Europe was the center of political activity," he said. "Plus there were women nursing and children playing and goats wandering around. It was very different from English cathedrals, which are on grassy hills, removed from the town, clean and quiet. But this is beat-up, eclectic, dirty New York."
"Everyone wants to see the tower finished," Bishop Moore said. "But if you want it bad enough, where's the $10 million?" In any case, he said, there is nothing wrong with an uncompleted cathedral. "St. John the Unfinished is O.K. with me," he said. "New York is an unfinished city."
 
Even the Five-Year Plan Will Cost $20 Million
It takes time, money and devotion to care for a 106-year-old monument, especially one with 120,000 square feet of floor space on 13.5 acres of property with a collection of aging buildings, gardens and statuary.
With the help of the firm of Polshek Partnership Architects, the Dean, the Very Rev. Harry H. Pritchett Jr., and his staff have come up with a five-year plan for fixing up the property.
The most notable change would take place on Amsterdam Avenue between 110th and 113th Streets. That is where the cathedral's main entrance and western facade are situated, as well as the entrance to the close, which holds cathedral and diocesan offices living quarters, a school, majestic trees, landscaped gardens and a spectacular outdoor pulpit.
Preliminary first-stage plans call for spending $4.32 million on various projects, including repair of the masonry of the south tower, which was raised 50 feet above the nave roof before construction was halted in 1992. Rusting scaffolding put up in 1978 would have to remain until the pointing was done. The tower would be waterproofed, and glass would replace the blue plastic that flaps in the windows. A $600,000 funnel-shaped crown might be placed atop the tower until construction resumes someday.
"It's a screen to protect the top of the stones and the steel that is up there for an eventual carillon," said Stephen Facey, executive vice president of St. John. "It's also a way to signal that we are not finished, that we're not trying to pretend this a finished tower."
Other first-stage projects would include wrapping the main stairway around the southwest corner, clearing out piles of cut and uncut stones in the nave garden, new fencing, signage and outdoor illumination and opening up the close. "We really want to beautify the entrance," said the Right. Rev. Richard F. Grein, who heads the diocese. "We have 500,000 visitors a year."
There is talk of moving the Peace Fountain, a massive bronze sculpture by Greg Wyatt installed in 1985, to another part of the property. Dean Pritchett refused to comment on the fountain, which some find fascinating and others repugnant.
The second stage would be a $4.8 million restoration of the 1843 Town Building, a crumbling Greek Revival structure south of the cathedral that houses many social programs. The work would include masonry repair, roofing, new windows and doors, pedestrian links to the nave, wheelchair access and new lighting.
Next would come renovations to the cathedral apse and school, which would cost an estimated $2.94 million, including repair of the roof and stained glass windows and restoration of the St. James Chapel. The upper school playground would be moved, and a new entry to the cathedral would be created, on Morningside Drive. New fencing, signs and lighting would be installed.
Plans also call for $3.17 million worth of work to replace the nave roof, repair stained glass windows, restore the nave garden, the north pedestrian way, the Diocesan House window and resurface the south drive.
The final stage envisions a new entry, with access for the disabled, for the south tower elevator, widening of the front walkway, restoration of the north field and new gates and lighting. The estimated cost? $4.1 million.
And that five-year plan could be just a beginning. Cathedral officials said $40 million could be spent rehabilitating all structures on the property. DAVID KIRBY

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption last Sunday about the Cathedral of St. John the Divine reversed the identities of the present and former Deans of the cathedral. The current Dean, the Very Rev. Harry H. Pritchett Jr., was at the left; the former one the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, was at the right.
A time line chart on Jan. 10 tracing the continuing construction of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine misstated the surname of the Episcopal Bishop of New York who announced in 1887 that the cathedral would be built. He was Henry Codman Potter, not Porter. The error was pointed out on Jan. 19 in a telephone call from the Bishop's great-great-nephew, which was misdirected to an editor who was traveling.

Charts: "TIME LINE -- Rome Took a While, Too"
Some memorable dates in the history of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Morningside Heights:
 
1887 -- Bishop Henry Codman Porter of the Episcopal Disocese of New calls for a great cathedral to rival St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Catholic edifice being built on Fifth Avenue. Wealthy Episcopalian families, including the Vanderbilts and Astors, donate generously.
1889 -- Sixty-eight designs are submitted to trustees but are not revealed to the public because some architects object.
1891 -- Trustees choose design, by Heins & La Farge, that combines Gothic exterior details with Byzantine and Romanesque interior.
1892 -- Trustees demand larger church with more Gothic elements, and order it to be built on an east-west, rather than a north-south axis citing Episcopalian doctrine that requires apse, or rear of the cathedral, to face east into the rising sun. Thus, front of cathdral will not face south onto 110th Street, and will not be visible from downtown. It will face west onto Amsterdam Avenue, and be visible to far fewer people. Cornerstone laid on Dec. 27, St. John's Day.
1893 -- Construction starts, and stops when soft stone is discovered where bedrock had been expected. Talk of moving the cathedral a block south is dismissed because trustees believe that moving a cornerstone is a bad omen. Three years and at least a half-million dollars are spent excavating soft stone and pouring concrete.
1907 -- The architect George Heins, dies. His partner, Christopher Grant La Farge, stays on as work is finished on choir and crossing.
1909 -- "Temporary" dome built over crossing with special tiles created by Rafael Guastavino, a Spanish immigrant. His company finishes in just 15 weeks, without using support structures.
1911 -- Apse, choir, crossing and first two chapels consecrated, April 19. A month later, trustees remove La Farge and hire Ralph Adams Cram, who sets out to totally "Gothicize" the cathedral and eradicate any sign of original Byzantine design. Building fund is depleted.
1914 -- With a donation from J.P. Morgan, huge Cathedral House is completed, consisting of the Bishop's House and Deanery.
1916 -- Cathedral construction resumes in May but stops in November when money again runs out. World War I and continuing financial problems postpone construction until 1924.
1925 -- A wealthy lawyer, Franklin D. Roosevelt, begins major fund-raising campaign. Work begins on baptistry, nave, Women's Transept and west facade.
1941 -- Expanded cathedral dedicated, Nov. 30. One week later, Japanese bomb Pearl Harbor, and work on cathedral stops again and does not resume for 40 years.
1978 -- Dean James Parks Morton begins stone-cutting apprentice program for south tower and later announces design competition for south transept. Winning design is not built.
1982 -- Construction resumes on south tower.
1992 -- Stone-cutting program is ended. Construction on south tower is stopped after only 50 feet, a small portion, is built.
1996 -- Dean Harry H. Pritchett Jr. replaces Dean Morton, who retires. Dean Pritchett begins focusing on preservation of existing cathedral, rather than additional construction.
(Source: "Morningside Heights: A History of Its Architecture and Development," by Andrew S. Dolkart (Columbia University Press, 1998)

HEADLINE: Down in the Valley, a Heated Economy Cools Just a Bit

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Silicon Valley's surging economy slowed during 1998, stung in part by the Asian economic crisis, according to an annual report that tracks the health of the nation's leading high-technology center.
Silicon Valley added 19,400 jobs last year, compared with 62,000 in 1997, and exports from the region declined for the first time in eight years, according to the 1999 Index of Silicon Valley, which was released today. 
 The report, which is compiled by Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network Inc., a coalition of corporate and civic organizations, shows that the region has continued to grow but that some of the remarkable start-up fever, a trademark of the area, has ratcheted back. Initial public offerings, which peaked at 73 in 1996, fell to 32 in 1998, and commercial vacancies, which have been at historic lows, inched up slightly, by more than a percentage point, from the previous year.
Despite some signs of slowdown and a long recession that has gripped the semiconductor equipment industry, which is centered in the Valley, there were still signs indicating that the area remains a remarkably robust economic region.
For example, the real average wage in the area rose 2 percent last year, to $49,060, and real per-capita income continued to rise at a rate faster than that of the nation as a whole. Quick-growing companies, or "gazelles," increased to 92 from 64, largely on the strength of the explosion in Internet commerce. And the amount of venture capital invested in Silicon Valley grew 14 percent, to $3.3 billion.
The slowing of the growth rate in the area was not viewed as entirely bad by the researchers who track the region's economic and quality-of-life trends.
"You can say we've gone back to a more normal growth rate," said Douglas Henton, president of Collaborative Economics in Palo Alto, Calif., which prepared the report for Joint Venture. "The Valley's long boom has put incredible pressure on the environment and on housing and transportation."
For the first time, the report included data that compare the region's productivity in specific industries with the rest of the country. Measured in terms of value added per employee, Silicon Valley workers in the computer and communications industries generated $250,000 for each employee, compared with slightly less than $100,000 for the average United States worker. Valley workers also sharply outpaced average rates in the semiconductor industry and in software.
"We're getting a tremendous amount of productivity," Mr. Henton said.
Despite the continued strong growth of the Valley economy, Joint Venture officials noted some signs of inequality and a failure to meet future educational needs.
For example, from 1991 to 1997, the report shows that real income fell 8 percent for households in the bottom fifth of income distribution. At the same time, real income rose 19 percent for households in the top fifth of the income pyramid.
Moreover, the high school graduation rate, which is now at 70 percent, has been slipping in the last five years; the graduation rate for Hispanic students stands at 56 percent.
"The new economy, which is more and more diverse, and the new demographics are not intersecting," said Ruben Barrales, president and chief executive of Joint Venture. "You have Hispanic and black kids who are not participating, and we're looking at an unsustainable scenario right now."
Transportation and housing also continue to be issues that plague the area. Last year, 31 percent of the freeway miles in Santa Clara County received the worst possible congestion rate, up from 26 percent in 1997.
Despite the fact that Silicon Valley is considered to be the most wired region of the country, only 52 percent of its residents have access to E-mail. That falls to less than 30 percent for those households with incomes of less than $40,000.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Silicon Graphics Bets On New Work Stations
After three years of declining fortunes, Silicon Graphics is placing a big bet today as it introduces a line of work stations built around Intel chips and Microsoft software.
While analysts like the new machines, nearly all remain neutral on Silicon Graphics' stock, saying that the company has yet to show that it can return to sustainable growth and profitability. Given Silicon Graphics' history of introducing brilliant new technology only to fumble on product delivery, it is perhaps not surprising that analysts are taking a wait-and-see attitude. Market Place. Page C2. 

The Katharine Graham of Japan
Sawako Noma, 55, the president and chief executive of Kodansha, Japan's largest publishing company, is often compared to Katharine Graham, the former publisher of The Washington Post. Like Mrs. Graham, Mrs. Noma took control of a family company, in the face of some resistance, after her husband died. Unlike Mrs. Graham, Mrs. Noma took charge of an empire of 1,173 employees, 54 magazines, a newspaper, and book companies in Japan, the United States and Europe. C15.
 
Growth Slowing in Silicon Valley
Silicon Valley's surging economy slowed during 1998, stung in part by the Asian economic crisis, according to an annual report that tracks the health of the nation's leading high-technology center. The region added 19,400 jobs last year, compared with 62,000 in 1997, and exports declined. C13.
 
Industry Could Pay a Price for HDTV
As several companies announce plans to sell high-definition television sets at much lower prices, in some cases for less than half of what the cheapest sets cost only last fall, some executives are worried that the prices may be too low and will threaten the industry's profitability in the short term. C14.
 
Ascend to Sell Computer Division
Ascend Communications, a maker of advanced data communications equipment, will announce today that it is selling its Stratus Enterprise Computer division for more than $100 million to a group led by Investcorp, the Middle East investment group. C14.
 
Preview of 2000 Goes Well
Because many computer programs look a full 52 weeks ahead, many users had feared that the advent of this year might cause problems as computers encountered the Year 2000 problem for the first time. Although there were a few mishaps last week -- some older equipment in New York could not produce 00 on auto inspection stickers so chose 91 instead, for example -- the disruptions seemed to be isolated. C3.
 
Gitic Debt Repayment Delayed
Chinese officials told dozens of creditors of the Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corporation, or Gitic, not to expect repayment of $4 billion anytime soon. C2.
 
Auditors to Disclose Conflicts
Beginning in July, auditors must disclose any relationship they have with the public companies they audit that could compromise their independence, according to new rules approved by the Independence Standards Board. C2.
 
Toyota President to Lead Group
In a surprising move, the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations made clear its intention to elect Hiroshi Okuda, the president of Toyota, as its new chairman. C18.
