HEADLINE: MEDIA;
The Kay Graham of Japan's Media Industry

BYLINE: By SUZANNE CHARLE 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
In a wood-paneled room rich with Persian carpets in the sedate Bunkyo-ku district, Sawako Noma, 55, sat forward as she offered a visitor coffee. Wearing a neat gray suit with knee-length skirt, her short hair neatly coiffured, her crossed ankles leading to sensible low heels, Mrs. Noma looked to be the prototypical Japanese housewife: demure, gracious, unprepossessing.
Which is exactly what Mrs. Noma was until 1987, when her husband died and she took over the reins of Kodansha Ltd., Japan's largest publishing company. 
 "I had no editorial experience, no schooling in business," she said. Her resume bears out her words. The first entry, after higher education (Seisen Women's University) reads: June 1987 -- President and C.E.O., Kodansha Ltd.
She is, some say, the Katharine Graham of Japan's media industry. The busts guarding the fireplace in a room of the corporate headquarters are those of her grandfather, Seiji Noma, who started the company in 1909, and her grandmother who ran the company for a time. But to make the analogy complete, one might have to throw in Random House for good measure. As head of Kodansha, Mrs. Noma reigns over an empire of 1,173 employees, 54 magazines, a newspaper, and book companies in Japan, the United States and Europe that published 2,576 new titles in 1997.
Like her counterpart at The Washington Post, Mrs. Noma met with some resistance when she assumed power. "Kodansha tends to attract some very smart, very arrogant, very hidebound people -- extremely well-paid men who see themselves as creme de la creme," said a publishing executive who insisted on not being identified. "There was a tremendous war -- rather like the Heike-Genji war," he said, referring to Japan's 12th-century civil war. "The Nomas had become weak, because there was no male heir ready to assume power."
Mrs. Noma graciously but firmly skirted any suggestion of rebellion, saying only, "I think everybody thought the president had to be a man." But she said her son, Yoshinibu, was only 18 years old at the time, a university freshman. "I didn't want to sacrifice his youth," she said, adding that she wanted him and her three daughters to be able to experience life and make their own mistakes. At the same time, she felt a sense of duty to the family "It was my obligation to become president," she said.
Listening to her speak, it is clear that she also relished the chance to break out of her sheltered existence. "My curiosity was stronger than any fear," she said.
"I didn't say anything," Mrs. Noma recalled of her first year on the job. "I just watched and found out how things were run. Then I started making suggestions."
Her suggestions have won her respect inside and outside her company, and business analysts credit her with Kodansha's success. (In 1996, World Business, an Asian business magazine, selected her as one of the world's 50 most prominent businesswomen). In the decade since she has taken over, Kodansha has solidified its position as the No. 1 publishing company in Japan. Corporate sales in 1997 topped 200 billion yen ($1.8 billion) -- a 32 percent increase over 1987, and a quite respectable figure considering that Japan has been in recession for the last seven years.
One of her first acts as president was to dump Penthouse Japan from the company's magazine roster. She approved the addition of a number of women's magazines to an already successful group. The new ones are Voce (which concentrates on beauty with a clever ad campaign featuring some of Japans most unattractive personalities, all made up), Vivi (aimed at women in their teens and 20's) and Mine (for independent young women, single or just married).
"The Japanese magazine business has been horrible since the bubble burst," said Robert Kirschenbaum, president of Pacific Press Service, a Tokyo photographers' agency. "But the women's magazines continue to do well."
The magazine stable -- which accounts for 64 percent of Kodansha's sales -- is broad, ranging from the respected literary magazine Gunzo, with a circulation of 20,000, to the comic magazine Shonen, 400 pages of tales of wild-eyed sushi chefs and crazed ninjas. Shonen is bought by 4.2 million preteen and teen-age boys and girls each week.
The book list is similarly varied, ranging from works by literary luminaries like the Nobel laureates Yasunari Kawabata and Kenzaburo Oe to children's books, including "Totto-chan: The Little Girl at the Window," which has sold 6.8 million copies.
Mrs. Noma has also continued to expand Kodansha's global reach by financing several literary awards -- including one for translations of Japanese literature -- and by publishing works of Japanese literature through Kodansha International and its subsidiary, Kodansha America.
Mrs. Noma's eldest daughter, Chikako Noma, who works as a senior editor for Kodansha America in New York, noted that the international division was more of a mission than a profit center. The mission has met with considerable success. The division has introduced English translations of the works of the Nobel laureates as well as those by younger writers, including "Norwegian Wood," by Haruki Murakami.
Perhaps most surprising, under Sawako Noma, the editors at Kodansha America have published original titles on American life, several of which have made it to best-seller lists. "Having Our Say," the stories of Sarah and A. Elizabeth Delany, two black sisters, sold 1.5 million copies and was on the New York Times best-seller list for 35 weeks (hardcopy) and 63 weeks (paperback, published by Dell).
No Western publishers have achieved such bicultural success, although the Japanese public has a voracious appetite for foreign books.
Sawako Noma and others point out that publishing is very different in Japan from what it is in the rest of the world, and the language barrier has proved to be a mighty fortress against foreign incursion, as would-be interlopers like Rupert Murdoch have learned.
Japanese publishers are also blessed with a public that is almost 100 percent literate.
"In America, there are a limited number of people who can be called readers," said Tetsu Shirai, deputy executive director of Kodansha International who headed Kodansha America in the 1980's. "In Japan, the ordinary citizen likes to read -- reading is seen as entertainment and has been since the 16th and 17th centuries. In America, there seems to be a psychological barrier for people to go to a bookstore. Here, it isn't uncommon, even in the smallest of towns, for people to set a date to meet at a bookstore."
Nonetheless, Japanese publishers are worried. Sales show that instead of buying books and magazines, young people are spending their money on cellular phones and computer games. Kodansha and other publishers are starting a campaign this spring to combat this trend.
And Sawako Noma signed off on the company's expansion into animated movie and video productions, based on its cartoon characters. "Akira," which stars a big-eyed character by the same name, became an instant classic, and "Ghost in the Shell" hit No. 1 in sales in its seventh week on the United States video charts in 1996.

HEADLINE: WB Succeeds By Serving Youth Alone

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 10

 BODY:
Along with much of the audience and most of the profit, the confidence bordering on arrogance that once characterized the network television business has faded away this season.
But it is alive and well in at least one place, TV's youngest, hippest and increasingly only upwardly mobile address: the upstart would-be network known as WB. 
 Pointing to figures that make WB the only broadcast network to demonstrate ratings growth this season, company executives consider themselves already securely established as a legitimate fifth network, on track to turning a profit within two years, and in position to assume complete leadership among the youngest segment of adult TV viewers within five years.
And maybe, the two top WB executives said, the network might just even start scheduling more shows from Warner Brothers, the studio owned by its parent company, Time Warner -- if only the studio starts making shows good enough and hip enough to squeeze their way onto the roster that now includes such youth-oriented hits as "Buffy, the Vampire Slayer," "Dawson's Creek" and "Seventh Heaven."
"Warner Brothers just has to do a better job" developing shows with the youthful skew that WB requires, said Jamie Kellner, the chief executive of WB. Mr. Kellner and Susanne Daniels, the new president of WB's entertainment division, spoke at a session of the Television Critics' Association meeting here last week and in separate interviews later.
For WB, "broadcasting" is increasingly a misnomer because the network is unflinchingly dedicated to never becoming too broad for its own good. The model, as Mr. Kellner put it, is not what NBC has been for the last five years, the dominant network with a wide range of viewers, nor even what Fox would like to become, the leader with the large adult group of viewers up to the age of 49.
Radio is attractive as the new model, Mr. Kellner said, because radio companies have done increasingly well on Wall Street despite being highly fragmented and controlling extremely small slices of audience.
That looks to be the future of television networks as well, he said, adding, "If it's going to be a fragmented marketplace, make sure the one you're hanging onto is the most valuable one in terms of advertisers."
As WB sees it, what advertisers want is youth, more youth and nothing but the youth, and the network is searingly focused on giving them exactly that. Far from looking to expand its reach, to compete for wider segments of viewers, Mr. Kellner said, WB would stick to its youth orientation. "Our goal is to remain with a median age under 30 years of age," he said. "That is the long-term, set-in-stone goal for this network."
But at least one other goal when the network was established four years ago by the Warner television studio was that it would serve as the fallback distribution outlet for the programs the studio makes. Warner Brothers was concerned about the increasing effort by the networks that carried its programs, mostly NBC, owned by the General Electric Company, and ABC, a unit of the Walt Disney Company, to fill their schedules with shows they themselves owned. Subsequent schedules from those networks have begun to validate those concerns.
Mr. Kellner conceded that "vertical integration is going to happen in television," with networks relying more on shows delivered by the studios with which they are aligned.
Does that mean Warner Brothers will soon be restricted to producing shows exclusively filled with characters in their teens and early 20's?
Barry M. Meyer, the executive vice president of Warner Brothers, said he did not think so, because he could not envision a time when a network would be totally vertically integrated, locking out shows from any other studio. He conceded that the "landscape has changed a bit," with networks like NBC trying to compel studios to cede ownership to them on every show scheduled.
"But we are still producing older shows for CBS and a lot of shows for NBC," Mr. Meyer said. "If there is a major shift in the policies at these networks, then the whole industry is going to have to be re-evaluated."
In the meantime, Warner Brothers is more than happy with the success being built by WB, Mr. Meyer said. "How could we not be pleased?" he asked. "I don't think it's too strong a statement that the WB is redefining the business in a way, both in its economic model and the way they have niched themselves."
Still, for the moment at least, WB is hardly a conduit for Warner Brothers programs; only a few of its shows, and none of its high-profile hits, are provided by the Warner studio. Instead, WB's schedule is dotted with shows supplied by the Warner Brothers studio's main rivals, like Fox ("Buffy"), Disney ("Felicity"), Sony's Columbia unit ("Dawson's Creek") and Aaron Spelling's Spelling Entertainment Group("Seventh Heaven").
The WB connection has proved to be a windfall for these studios because in recent years shows on WB have sold re-run rights in syndication for very high prices. Ms. Daniels noted that after its first year, "Buffy" sold to the FX network for more than $1 million an episode.
Mr. Kellner said WB was under no obligation to favor Warner Brothers shows. The network is a partnership of Time Warner, the Tribune Company television stations group and his own company, Acme Broadcasting. "We're in this together," Mr. Kellner said, adding that if Time Warner and Tribune are unhappy with WB's executives, "they can fire us if they want to," but that while they're in place "we operate the business."
He said that "in our first two years we got no cooperation from the studio." Very few of the studio's producers generated programs for WB. Since then, he said, "more effort has been made." But he said, "Maybe there's a hex on us or something like that, but we've not been able to break through yet with Warner Brothers."
Mr. Kellner added: "We always said we were going to put on the best shows. It's their job to get some of their shows to be the best shows."
Ms. Daniels said she expected more Warner shows to start filtering to WB soon, after existing deals tying some of the best Warner Brothers producers to NBC and ABC run their course. She mentioned the team of Marta Kaufman, Kevin Bright and David Crane, the creators of "Friends"; Bruce Helford of "The Drew Carey Show," and John Wells of "E.R."
"The object of the business is to make money," Mr. Kellner said, describing the approach he believed Warner Brothers executives should apply to WB. "The younger you are in terms of the appeal of your programs, the higher the value in syndication."
Mr. Kellner contrasted WB's strategy for building a new network with that of Fox, where Mr. Kellner worked during its ascension in the late 1980's and early 1990's. The mistake Fox eventually made, both he and Ms. Daniels said, was to abandon its one-time identity as "the bad-boy network," as Ms. Daniels put it, in a quest to overtake NBC for command of the broader age group favored by many advertisers, viewers between the ages of 18 and 49.
Mr. Kellner said the push by Fox, a unit of the News Corporation, to acquire rights to the National Football League was a mistake because it signaled the end of a programming approach characterized by the philosophy "If you can see it somewhere else, it doesn't belong here."
Instead, football became hugely costly. "The Fox network is not profitable now," Mr. Kellner said,
For Fox, of course, this analysis flies in the face of the growth that acquiring football helped fuel, both in adding stronger affiliated stations and in gaining wider credibility for Fox as a full-fledged network.
Still, Mr. Kellner has a growing body of ratings results to back up his arguments. Of the six networks now competing in prime time, only WB has shown increases in viewing this year, about 10 percent for the season. More important for WB, whose early success came largely as a result of enormous viewing by teen-age girls, some of the most significant increases have been among viewers who qualify as young adults, those between the ages of 18 and 34.
Mr. Kellner said WB took in about $300 million in advance commitments from advertisers last spring, and he predicted the comparable figure will reach $450 million this year. Movie advertisers, particularly, have flocked to WB shows, looking for the young viewers that form the base audience for so many contemporary films.
So confidence -- yes, even arrogance -- is brimming over at WB.
"When we are the No. 1 network 18 to 34, we'll probably be the most profitable network in America," Mr. Kellner said. "That's our goal."

HEADLINE: One Nation, Unplugged;
The Titans of Wireless Are Tearing Down Regional Fences

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
George F. Schmitt, president of Omnipoint Communications, a small wireless phone carrier, recalls sitting in his kitchen in Montville, N.J., one morning last May with Omni, his pet blue and gold parrot, and hardly believing what he was hearing.
In a public conference call, top executives from the AT&T Corporation, the nation's biggest communications company, were explaining how they meant to rewrite the de facto rules for pricing wireless calls. Not only would AT&T do away with long-distance charges for wireless, but it said it would also end the additional "roaming" fees for using a phone when traveling to an area covered by a different company's network -- a charge that consumers had been resenting since the first mobile phones made their debut in the 1980's. 
 It certainly sounded like a great new cost-saving convenience for wireless customers. But the move also seemed such a drastic economic departure from the industry's conventional practices that Mr. Schmitt wondered how anyone -- even mighty AT&T -- could afford it.
"I stayed home so I could listen to the call that morning, and I was sitting there thinking, 'How can they do this?' " Mr. Schmitt said in an interview last week. "After the call was over I sat there for a long time with Omni, but until I saw their ads I think I really underestimated it. They did an outstanding job of changing who would use AT&T and pulling customers in."
Mr. Schmitt may have had only his parrot to keep him company that morning, but he was hardly alone. It took many communications experts time to realize that by introducing the plan that day that it called Digital One Rate, AT&T had changed the ground rules of the wireless business in the United States.
For some, the depth of that shift may not have become clear until Dec 31, when reports emerged that the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's No. 1 local phone company, was trying to acquire the leader in wireless, the Airtouch Corporation, based in San Francisco, for around $45 billion. Bell Atlantic had apparently decided that being merely the third-biggest wireless carrier in the United States was not enough and that it was prepared to dilute its future earnings to acquire Airtouch's network.
And last week it became clear that Bell Atlantic was not alone in coveting Airtouch. Vodafone Group P.L.C., Britain's largest mobile phone carrier, also jumped into the bidding. And yesterday reports emerged that British Telecom P.L.C. was also considering making an offer. MCI Worldcom Inc. weighed a bid last week, but decided to pass.
"Given the way the market is moving, there is certainly virtue in having a national footprint, whether you achieve that through ownership or through partnership," said Jonathan Marshall, an Airtouch spokesman.
Bell Atlantic declined to comment.
Whatever the outcome of the Airtouch bidding war, analysts do not expect that takeover to be the industry's last.
In other parts of the communications industry, it is an old story: You need scale to thrive, and perhaps even to survive. But in the wireless sector it is being told these days for the first time. As AT&T and other major players, like Nextel and Sprint, use their national footprints to create leverage in the marketplace, smaller, regional carriers like Omnipoint and even the Baby Bells are feeling the pinch.
For consumers, the carriers' move to a national battlefield means lower rates, better service and broader coverage. For the carriers, however, the changes can mean slimmer profit margins, tougher competition and a drive to find partners with deep pockets.
"The little guy is getting squeezed," said John Bensche, a wireless analyst at Lehman Brothers, who acknowledges that he also initially underestimated the impact of AT&T's new plan. "AT&T sort of exploded the market with One Rate. For the regional guys it's going to be hard; it's going to be very hard. You can make money. You're not going to go bankrupt. But you may be doomed to sort of subpar returns. So I think some of these guys are going to merge."
Besides reflecting the impact of national competition, the looming shake-out may be an inevitable consequence of the sheer proliferation of wireless carriers.
Until a few years ago, almost every American metropolitan market had only two cellular carriers. But in 1996 the Federal Communications Commission auctioned rights to a big swath of frequencies, and that led to the creation in 1997 of as many as four new wireless carriers per market in some places. What was good for competition, however, has not always been good for the carriers' books.
The problem is that a new wireless carrier must spend millions, sometimes billions, of dollars to build an extensive network before signing up a single customer. The competition, meanwhile, may be able to charge lower rates because its network is already in place. Or the new entrant often finds itself building alongside a giant like AT&T or Sprint that can either pay for the construction out of the cash flow generated from its existing long-distance business or can afford to borrow billions at low interest rates.
"We're clearly seeing a move to where more market share is being captured by national services," said Andrew Sukawaty, chief executive of the Sprint PCS venture. Sprint PCS is not yet among the top 10 wireless carriers, but in the 1996 auctions, it bought licenses covering almost the entire country.
"This has become a national financing game," Mr. Sukawaty said, "and it's hard to see how the local and small-business players will be able to make it."
In some ways, Mr. Schmitt's Omnipoint -- which offers service in New York City, elsewhere in the Northeast and in Miami -- provides a good example of the challenges facing small wireless carriers. Pressed for cash, Omnipoint was able to secure $375 million in new financing late last year, mostly from companies with which it already does business, Siemens of Germany and Northern Telecom of Canada. Nonetheless, the company is canvassing foreign communications companies in search of someone to buy a big equity stake or perhaps even to acquire the whole company.
Still, Omnipoint is unusual among small carriers in being able to secure additional financing at a crucial stage. Other carriers, like Pocket Communications, which owned a license for the Chicago area, have filed for bankruptcy protection.
No wonder some small regional carriers are forming partnerships in hopes of expanding their service areas and pooling marketing costs. One such group is the GSM Alliance. The alliance takes its name from G.S.M., or global system for mobile communications, a digital wireless technology that is used widely in Europe and Asia but has not become as popular in the United States. Among the GSM Alliance members, which have banded together to form roaming agreements, are Omnipoint, Aerial Communications, Powertel, Western Wireless and Microcell of Canada.
But the GSM Alliance, while far from a failure, has not yet made much of a dent in the marketplace. Some small-company executives involved in the group say that it is being held back by the caution of two Baby Bell members, Bell South and SBC Communications. Those executives said the Bell companies, attuned to regulatory concerns, have been reluctant to back initiatives, like collaborative pricing plans, that were proposed by other members of the group.
But people close to the Bells note that one company's foot-dragging may be another's compliance with antitrust laws. SBC, for example, is still trying to gain regulatory approval of its planned acquisition of the regional phone company Ameritech, which recently put its Chicago wireless system up for sale to help address regulators' concerns. That system should fetch more than $2 billion.
Although many people on Wall Street and in the communications industry expect some of the GSM members eventually to merge as they try to expand their coverage areas, a role may remain for regional carriers in the wireless business. Earle Mauldin, who oversees the BellSouth wireless operations, said that only about a quarter of his company's wireless customers roam outside their home markets. And Stanley T. Sigman, who runs SBC's wireless business, said only 4 percent of his customers roam outside SBC's territory.
But for AT&T, with its national presence, those regional arguments do not hold up.
"If you were paying 80 cents a minute when you're on the road making a long-distance call, would you roam?" said Dan Hesse, president of AT&T's wireless operation. "It's a chicken-and-egg thing."
And even some of the regional carriers acknowledge the growing allure of a national reach. "Most people are calling a few towns over to their mom and dad or their place of work or where their kids go to school," said John W. Stanton, chairman of Western Wireless, one of the larger regional carriers, and chairman of the Cellular Telephone Industry Association.
"There will clearly be some regional players playing roles in the market," Mr. Stanton said. "There will also be a few national players that will have the vast majority of subscribers."

HEADLINE: Reno's Tenure Sets a Record This Century

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Attorney General Janet Reno is set on Monday to become the longest-serving Attorney General of this century, surpassing the record set 60 years ago by Homer S. Cummings, an Attorney General in the Administration of Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
Ms. Reno's longevity at the Justice Department is notable because she got the job in March 1993 almost by accident when President Clinton hurriedly plucked her from her job as the elected prosecutor for Dade County, in Florida, after his first two nominations for Attorney General collapsed in embarrassing controversies over household workers. 
 Ms. Reno, 60, is unlikely to break the record for longest time in the post. That is held by William Wirt, who served for 11 years over the Administrations of James Monroe and John Quincy Adams, from Nov. 13, 1817, to March 3, 1829.
Mr. Cummings held the post from March 4, 1933, to Jan. 2, 1939, serving as one of Mr. Roosevelt's chief legal advisers during the Depression banking crisis, and helping to create the New Deal recovery program.
Mr. Cummings's insider role at the White House serves as a sharp contrast to the chilly gulf that has often separated Ms. Reno and Mr. Clinton, whose aides have complained about Ms. Reno's crusty independence each time (five so far) that she has referred cases involving Cabinet officials to independent counsels.
But the independent counsel statute has also indirectly helped Ms. Reno keep her job. Largely because removing her would seem blatantly motivated by political pique, Mr. Clinton has never dared to try.
Ms. Reno's tenure got off to a potentially disastrous start when she approved a tear gas assault in April 1993 by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on an armed religious cult barricaded at a compound near Waco, Tex. More than 80 people died in a resulting fire. Ms. Reno accepted responsibility for the tear gas assault, but said the deaths were caused solely by David Koresh, the Branch Davidian leader, who died in the fire.
In legal circles, Ms. Reno has never been regarded among the giants of the Attorney General's office. Nor has she compiled a record of aggressive initiatives like Robert F. Kennedy's efforts on civil rights or organized crime.
Still, in a period when crime rates have been falling, Ms. Reno has been an advocate for law enforcement and measures against youth violence and violence against women.
In the Justice Department her stewardship has elicited criticism and praise. Her wooden manner, lack of command of some issues and inability to set priorities have infuriated subordinates and threatened to erode her authority over a burgeoning department of more than 100,000 employees.
But Ms. Reno remains a solitary figure of propriety in the frequently troubled Clinton Administration. She has many admirers within the Justice Department, particularly among lower-level employees. They regard her as a relentlessly honest and rigorously fair public official who has softened the aloof image of the office.
Still, a joke going around the department suggested how some aides are ambivalent about Ms. Reno's tenure. As the joke goes, one employee says to another, "Did you know that Janet Reno has just broken the record for the longest serving Attorney General in the last 150 years?"
His colleague replies, "I thought she'd been here longer."

HEADLINE: In the Nation's Capital, Historians Leave Impeachment for the Future

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
With a contemporary constitutional drama going on just a few miles away, historians flocked to the nation's capital last week to discuss topics like the dilemma of the South Asian intellectual and acoustics in early America.
So why did the 113th annual meeting of the American Historical Association include nary a word (officially, anyhow) on impeachment even as it explored long-ago violence in the politics of North Carolina and Kentucky and the French influence on Cairo in the 19th century? 
 "These programs are prepared months in advance," Prof. Eric Foner of Columbia University, the association's president-elect, said on Friday without a trace of defensiveness. "What is esoteric to one person may be essential to another."
Professor Foner is an expert on the Civil War and the Reconstruction era that occasioned the last Presidential impeachment, that of Andrew Johnson in 1868, and he emphasized that the several thousand historians gathered here Thursday through today were very much interested in the events unfolding at the Capitol.
"This is being discussed a great deal in the corridors," the professor said. "And I can tell you that very few historians here feel that the charges against President Clinton rise to the level of impeachable offenses."
The practicalities of scheduling aside, some historians offered higher-minded reasons for not jumping into scholarly explorations of the current impeachment. When the extent of Mr. Clinton's troubles began to emerge, there was a lot of discussion among historians, face-to-face and via electronic mail, Prof. Richard Jensen of the University of Illinois at Chicago recalled.
"It was totally politicized," Professor Jensen said, "so we stopped talking about it." At least for a while.
To politicize a subject, he said, is to risk contaminating it, at least when one hopes to approach the subject as a scholar in quest of the elusive truth. Far better for historians, he said, to let the subject cool a bit first, much as the Senate is supposed to be the saucer that cools the tea, legislatively speaking.
Prof. Carole Shammas of the University of Southern California, whose speciality is economic history, tried to foreclose any discussion of impeachment by jokingly throwing up her hands. "I don't know anything about Monica Lewinsky," she said.
More seriously, she wondered whether the Clinton impeachment would help set off another sea change in American politics: a reaction against the growing power of conservatives, much as there was a backlash against liberal causes three decades ago. (A historian, not a fortune-teller, she did not try to answer her own question.)
Michael Brose, a graduate student at the University of Pennsylvania, specializes in Asian history but said he and those who share his field have been caught up of late in the impeachment: "It's a big topic, especially coming here to Washington." Soon, he said, the impeachment will be grist for scholars.
And Ronald J. Granieri, an assistant professor at Furman University in Greenville, S.C., said he and some of his colleagues have concluded that President Clinton is the victim of "a political set-up job."
Mr. Granieri, whose speciality is European history, said he thought that Mr. Clinton was doing a good job, basically. Like many Americans, Mr. Granieri cited the healthy economy.
Professor Foner, the incoming president of the largest professional historical organization in the United States with about 15,000 members, conceded that some topics on the agenda could seem arcane to an outsider.
"We are, by definition, talking to ourselves," he said. Talking about the Argentine fingerprint system, the Neapolitan Revolution of 1799 and homemaking in fascist colonial Libya, to name topics that seem not only outside history's mainstream but away from its tiniest tributaries.
Such topics, and many others, explore the stuff of life throughout the world, Professor Foner said. They are a reminder, if any is needed, that history is so much more than battlefields and governmental intrigue and the deeds and misdeeds of the powerful.
Next year in Chicago, he said, there may be room on the annual meeting's agenda for a discussion of impeachment -- assuming that Mr. Clinton's fate is decided by then.
"We're not political pundits," he said without a trace of smugness. "We like to know how something turns out before we analyze it."

HEADLINE: Mexico City Journal;
Cocaine Doesn't Just 'Transit': Some of It Seeps

BYLINE: By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
If he could take control of the millions of dollars Mexico spends each year to combat drug trafficking, Miguel Gonzalez Espinosa would spend a little less of it on high-tech, heavily armed operations at airports and along the border, aimed at stopping the flow of drugs from Colombia on their way to the United States.
Mr. Gonzalez, who proudly calls himself a recovering alcoholic, directs a small drug rehabilitation center in the downtrodden neighborhood that surrounds the city's Basilica de Guadalupe. He sees firsthand the toll taken by a less-talked-about, but increasingly damaging problem: the rise in drug abuse -- especially cocaine and crack -- among Mexican youth. 
 In just the last two months, his residential treatment center, which relies entirely on private donations, has taken in 12 new clients and is running above capacity, with 40 residents.
One of them is Gloria Acevedo, 15, who had been living on the streets for two years, stealing and working as a prostitute to support her cocaine habit. Marco Antonio Salazar, 19, arrived stoned after he beat up his sister and was kicked out by his parents. And an addiction to crack led Isaac Perez, 22, to quit his job, sell all his belongings and steal cars.
"We are in a drug crisis up to our necks," said Mr. Gonzalez, president of the Fundacion Dr. Sergio Berumen, the residential treatment program, named for a philanthropist who gave seed money for the center. "When traffickers cannot get their drugs across the border, they sell it here."
Mexico has been recognized for years as a major transit station for drugs. More than half of the cocaine smuggled into the United States passes through Mexico, as well as much of the heroin and marijuana.
At a United Nations meeting about the drug trade last summer, President Ernesto Zedillo characterized his country's crisis as one that is generated by drug consumer nations, especially the United States. There are new signs, however, that the number of Mexican consumers is on the rise.
A 1997 report by the Ministry of Health says that in the last six years cocaine use has quadrupled among Mexicans aged from 12 to 19. Among patients at Government-run treatment centers in Mexico City, whose numbers have increased from 4,500 to 13,500 in the last six years, marijuana remains the drug of choice for most adolescents, health officials report. But cocaine, particularly crack, ranked second -- before cheaper choices like glue and paint thinner.
The Government has responded to the problem with increased funding to its own drug treatment centers. It has also created a public service campaign called Live Without Drugs. The campaign includes radio and television announcements, educational programs in schools and a Web site that answers questions about drug abuse.
In cities across the country, including Culiacan, Ciudad Victoria, San Luis Potosi and Hermosillo, the police have proposed a program known as Operation Backpack, which would allow them to search students for drugs and weapons, although some parents have expressed reservations. Parents have started community patrols around school playgrounds and parks.
Compared with the voracious consumption of drugs in the United States, Mexico's drug problem remains small. But to Mr. Gonzalez even one drug-addicted child is too many. "Every day I see how drugs are destroying young people," Mr. Gonzalez said.
As in the United States, drug abuse in Mexico is spreading fastest in poor communities where unemployment is high and education levels are low, Mr. Gonzalez said.
Ms. Acevedo, a flirtatious girl who dyes her hair strawberry blond and wears sparkly pink lipstick, ran away from a shattered family. She said her mother, a waitress, and her father, a street vendor, began using drugs when she was just an infant. Both would stay away from home for days at a time, leaving her to beg for food from neighbors for herself and her three younger brothers.
At 11, she said, she began stealing her parents' drugs and hiding in the cluster of fruit trees in her backyard to get high.
"The first time I ever got high, I thought, this is what life is supposed to be," she said. "I had found something that would fill the emptiness."
She ran away at 12 and lived in train stations or abandoned offices. Last October she nearly died from an overdose.
"All I wanted was drugs," she recalled. "Suffering for me was when I didn't have anything to get to make me high."
When it opened 10 years ago, the Fundacion Dr. Sergio Berumen primarily served alcoholic adults, who needed a place to dry out so they could go home to their families. During the last five years, Mr. Gonzalez said, younger people started coming for help, and they were addicted to drugs, not alcohol.
Today, Mr. Gonzalez said, more than 80 percent of the residents are drug addicts between 13 and 20. The white metal front door is almost always left open, Mr. Gonzalez said. Residents are free to leave anytime they please.
Group meetings are held five times a day for the residents to talk with one another about their addictions and any other distress.
At a recent meeting, Mr. Salazar spoke from the podium for more than 15 minutes. This time of year is especially hard for him, he said, echoing the feelings of many in the room.
It hurt, he said, that he could not celebrate the holidays with his 8-month-old son.
"I want to be with my family," he said. "But I am afraid of what I would do if someone offered me drugs.
"I wonder if I will ever feel ready to go home."

HEADLINE: Iraq's Parliament Puts Off Vote of Defiance Against U.N.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 10

 BODY:
After more than a month of rising defiance, the Iraqi Government postponed a vote today in which its Parliament had appeared ready to take further steps along a collision course with its Western foes.
Instead, Parliament issued only a mild statement critical of the American-led air strikes against Iraq last month. Those attacks prompted calls from some legislators for measures that would have been a direct challenge to the United Nations. 
 No reason was given for the postponement, which came at the end of a special two-day session. But the legislative body is an instrument of President Saddam Hussein's Government, and it appears that Baghdad decided skirt a further confrontation.
Only hours before today's vote, a majority of the 250-member Parliament appeared ready to formally reject several of the United Nations resolutions that were imposed on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait in 1990.
Instead, Parliament adopted a resolution calling only for Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, which have served as bases for Western military operations against Iraq, to pay reparations for the damage caused by the air strikes last month.
Still, members of Parliament said consideration of tougher measures, including the possible repudiation of Iraq's border with Kuwait, could resume by the end of the month.
And the legislators did reinforce the Government's rejection of Western-imposed no-flight zones over large parts of the country.
Until today the Iraqi reaction to the American and British air strikes followed an increasingly confrontational path. Since the attacks ended on Dec. 19, the Iraqi Government has zeroed in its air defenses on American warplanes and called on Arabs to rise up against governments in the region aligned with the United States.
Such steps have prompted renewed warnings from the West, including a statement this weekend by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, on an official visit to Kuwait, that warned of further military action if Iraq once again appeared to be threatening its neighbors.
By setting aside a more confrontational message, Iraq may have been trying to limit hostility from the Arab world.
Since the air strikes ended last month, Iraqi frustration over a lack of Arab backing has been mounting. While Arab governments remain opposed to the air strikes, they have more than at any time since the Persian Gulf war of 1991 expressed outright hostility toward Mr. Hussein, whom they distinguish from the Iraqi people.
A meeting of Arab foreign ministers has been scheduled for Jan. 24, and the tensions over Iraq are expected to be high on the agenda.
Despite their recent criticism of Mr. Hussein, even some countries critical of Iraq have hinted that they might use the session to push for an easing of the economic sanctions that the United Nations has imposed on Iraq since its invasion of Kuwait.
Reports in several Saudi-owned newspapers said today that Saudi Arabia was ready to press for such a move as long as military pressure against Baghdad continued.
Foreign Minister Mohammed Said al-Sahaf of Iraq sought at a news conference this evening in Baghdad to make the most of such sentiment.
He called on Saudi Arabia to end its cooperation with the American and British enforcement of the no-flight zone over southern Iraq, and on Arab countries to lift economic sanctions unilaterally at the coming meeting.

HEADLINE: Vice President Sounds Presidential Themes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
While still months away from officially declaring himself a Presidential candidate, Vice President Al Gore is scheduled to announce a series of initiatives this week that his aides say will be major themes of his campaign.
On Monday, Mr. Gore will unveil the Administration's budget request for community planning programs. On Tuesday, he will propose tax incentives for education and job training programs. On Wednesday, he will award Empowerment Zone grants and speak to a Jewish group in New York in support of the Israeli peace process. On Thursday and Friday, he will be the host for officials from 45 countries at a conference to promote open trade. 
 These issues may sound familiar, as they have been hallmarks of the Clinton Administration. But as the backbone of Mr. Gore's campaign, they clearly define him as an extension of Mr. Clinton, a calculation that suggests the Vice President is confident voters will reward him for the Administration's successes but not blame him for the President's personal failings.
But by offering only mild criticism of the behavior threatening to drive Mr. Clinton from office, Mr. Gore seems willing to endure some criticism. Already, two Republican Presidential hopefuls, Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, and Senator John McCain of Arizona, have denounced Mr. Gore as an apologist for the President.
"Even though the electoral clock is ticking, we are still more than two years away from the term of the next President," Mr. Gore said today in an interview. "So while political speculation is understandable and omnipresent, for my part, I'm going to continue to focus on my work as Vice President and put off for quite some time into the future a formal announcement of my candidacy."
Mr. Gore's aides say he is betting that with the stars aligned as they are -- a robust national economy, an enormously popular President and a Clinton-Gore fund-raising apparatus already tapping Democratic donors for the $20 million Mr. Gore expects to raise by December -- the Vice President risks nothing by not stepping out from behind Mr. Clinton, even with the impeachment trial set to begin this week.
That means that people waiting to learn more about Al Gore, the Presidential aspirant, had better settle in for Al Gore, the Vice President, for many months to come. For now, he is not willing to articulate so much as a sentence about his own personal values or priorities, beyond the work at hand.
"The question is, how I define my campaign and myself as a candidate," Mr. Gore said. "With all due respect, I would like to defer a discussion of my candidacy until I have formally announced as a candidate. I am well aware that the work which the President and I do has all manner of political resonance, and that's as it should be in this system. But I'm going to focus on the substance of that work and on the impact it has on the American people."
Mr. Gore's unwillingness to begin defining himself as a candidate may have had an impact at least on potential opponents. Two potential Democratic contenders, Senators Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, have decided not to run, and it appears more likely that Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, will not try.
Bill Bradley, the former Senator from New Jersey, has formed an exploratory committee. And Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts and the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson say they are considering a run.
But none seems to have the fund-raising power or grass-roots organization that Mr. Gore has built in recent years as an active campaigner for other Democrats. He has built especially strong contacts in the four states that will have a large influence in producing the party nominees by virtue of their early caucuses and primaries: Iowa, New Hampshire, New York and California.
The impeachment trial remains an uncertainty. Even so, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said today in an interview that he did not believe that anything that happened to Mr. Clinton "would have any effect at all on the Vice President."
Others are not entirely sure.
"My guess is that he would not much be affected," Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, one of the first Democrats to criticize the President's moral judgment, said in an interview. "But I'm only guessing."

HEADLINE: THE TRIAL OF THE PRESIDENT: POLITICAL MEMO;
Focus on Impeachment Casts a Shadow on the Goals of Both Parties

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
In a city that seems to be all impeachment all the time, the question now is whether there is any hope of Congress's working with the Clinton Administration to address the full plate of other issues facing the country.
Social Security and Medicare need to be overhauled before they are driven into bankruptcy by the aging of the baby boom generation. Military leaders say the Pentagon needs more money to insure national security. 
 Both parties have ideas for improving schools. Republicans are pressing for big tax cuts, Democrats for more spending on health and child care. The shortcomings in the laws governing political fund-raising remain unaddressed.
Democrats and Republicans alike have powerful motivations to prove to the electorate that they have not been consumed by the impeachment process, especially given that the Senate trial of President Clinton now seems likely to stretch into next month and perhaps longer.
In that sense, some members of both parties think the White House and the Republican leadership in Congress will be eager to strike deals on big issues like Social Security once the impeachment trial is over.
"This trial has obviously knocked everything off the agenda for a period of time, but as a practical matter, this is a time of year when Congress does very little anyway," said Senator Judd Gregg, a Republican from New Hampshire.
"It could end up having a positive impact because after we come out of the trial there's going to be a desire on both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue to show constructive action," Mr. Gregg said. "The issue that's sitting there ready to go is Social Security."
But such an outcome presumes that there is enough trust between two parties who have been savaging each other for months that they will be willing to wade hand-in-hand into issues that are easy targets for demagoguery. Trust may prove to be an especially scarce commodity since Republicans and Democrats are thinking as much in terms of positioning themselves for the 2000 elections as in terms of what they might accomplish legislatively this year.
"Bitter partisanship in the past has not prevented us from getting things done," said Representative Jim Kolbe, a Republican from Arizona. "We did it with welfare reform and with the balanced budget agreement. But both sides will have to believe they are getting something from it. If both sides think they're better off by doing nothing and blaming the other, we'll get nowhere."
A complex and subtle political calculus is at work. Mr. Clinton would clearly like to leave a legacy of accomplishment to offset the stain of impeachment. But doing so -- whether on big issues like Social Security and health care or on specific programs like building more classrooms -- will require him to compromise with Republicans, a prospect that is not appealing to many Congressional Democrats.
Liberal Democrats in particular think their best chance of recapturing control of the House in 2000 is to paint Republicans as right-wing zealots who have accomplished nothing of importance to the American people. The dynamic could also be affected in the increasingly unlikely event that Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, chooses to challenge Vice President Al Gore for the party's Presidential nomination, leading to an open battle between the party's centrist and liberal factions.
"The question for a lot of Congressional Democrats is why we should do anything to help build a record of accomplishment for the Republican Congress," a senior Democratic aide in the House said.
Among Republicans, too, there are widely varying views on how to proceed at a time when their party's standing in the polls is plummeting.
In the Senate, 13 of the 19 Republicans up for re-election in 2000 are from states Mr. Clinton carried in 1996, suggesting some willingness to move to the center. Senate Republicans are increasingly eager to reach a deal on Social Security so they can turn the agenda to an issue they believe is the most proven political winner available to them, tax cuts.
In the House, Speaker Dennis Hastert of Illinois has promised to steer Republicans in a more pragmatic direction and to work with Democrats. But any substantive compromises he makes are likely to expose him to the same furious response from his right wing that helped bring down Newt Gingrich.
"Denny Hastert has got to be able to tell the far right of his party to knock it off, that he's going to govern from the center," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a Democrat from California. "It's possible, though, that if he tries he'll get run over."
On the other hand, Mr. Matsui said, if the Republican leadership and the White House prove willing to work with each other, "the left of our party won't be happy because then you'll see bills getting passed."
There is also some question as to how much pressure the electorate will put on Washington to get down to business. Stephen Moore of the Cato Institute, a research organization influential with conservative Republicans, said that with the economy humming along nicely and the country lacking any sense of urgency about big policy changes, the electorate may find gridlock in Washington to be an acceptable or even appealing outcome.
Still, Mr. Clinton, at least, is determined to show the voters an activist Administration at work.
"Will we rest on our laurels, become diverted in our energies, or keep working together?" Mr. Clinton asked in a speech in Detroit on Friday. "If we work together, there are no limits to 21st-century America."
White House officials continue to work on a wide variety of relatively small-bore policy initiatives to include in the budget proposal Mr. Clinton will send to Capitol Hill on Feb. 1. And they are considering whether to make a renewed push starting with the State of the Union address, scheduled for Jan. 19, for a bipartisan agreement on shoring up the Social Security system.
In the last week, White House officials have been floating the idea of leaving the current retirement system more or less intact, with its financial problems addressed through a package of benefit cuts and tax increases.
To make that approach more palatable to Republicans who have been demanding that Social Security be remade to include private investment accounts, the White House would then call for the creation of retirement accounts that would not technically be linked to Social Security but would use the Federal budget surplus to give individuals tax breaks or other incentives to save for old age.
With Republicans arguing that future budget surpluses will be big enough both to fix Social Security and to finance a big tax cut, the Administration is also considering whether to lay out explicitly how it would use the surplus beyond dealing with Social Security.
"What the President believes is that the agenda-setting function is vital to the Presidency," said Paul Begala, senior adviser to the President. "Last year he was quite innovative in using the coalescence of the State of the Union and the budget and the absence of Congress in early January to dominate the agenda and set the policy agenda for the year. He intends to do the same thing this year."
Mr. Begala bristled at the idea that the policy proposals Mr. Clinton announced last week -- long-term care, after-school programs, drug treatment for inmates -- were intended to divert attention from impeachment.
"This is not a diversion, this is the Presidency, this is our job, it's leading the only superpower on God's earth," Mr. Begala said. "It's what we did last year before anyone had heard of Monica Lewinsky."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Beating the Yanquis at Their Game

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
Cuban and American leaders are pondering the issue of whether a Baltimore Orioles visit to Cuba would strengthen or weaken the regime of Fidel Castro. The question seems improbable, yet governments have long used baseball to promote their values and politics. When the Sandinistas took power in beisbol-crazed Nicaragua in 1979, they considered banning the sport. Instead, they decided they could use it to help build the New Socialist Man. They began with Managua's 30,000-seat stadium, called "Anastasio Somoza Garcia" after the father of the dynasty the Sandinistas overthrew. They renamed the stadium for the man who shot him.
Anti-American governments love to use the symbol of America as a political canvas. Baseball was exported to Mexico by American railroad engineers, to Japan by missionaries and to Panama by canal builders. An American consul created the first Nicaraguan team in 1905. Baseball's empire encompasses mainly countries that have spent long periods in America's grip. Resentment and revolution also flower in these environments, one reason Cuba, Nicaragua and the Dominican Republic have all had governments that might want the Yankees to win, but certainly want the Yanquis to lose. And although foreign fans, especially Dominicans, treat their Major League players as national heroes, many also resent a baseball relationship that has mirrored America's economic and political practices abroad, with the gringos raiding the best players and then claiming their tournament as the World Series. 
 In Japan, besuboru is designed to reinforce the values of selflessness, obedience to authority, hard work and loyalty. Robert Whiting, who has written books on Japanese ball, notes that players practice to near-collapse. A players' strike is inconceivable, and few players even change teams or demand high salaries. A superstar American player who took leave from his Japanese team when his 8-year-old son had brain surgery was fired.
Baseball stadiums in Nicaragua in the mid-1980's looked like American ballparks before the days of Beanie Baby giveaways and exploding scoreboards. In the Heroes and Martyrs of September stadium in Leon, Nicaragua's second-largest city, signs advertised Coke and beer, vendors sold hot dogs and the announcers hawked local restaurants.
Nicaragua's best player was Julio Medina, captain of the national team and Sandinista icon. Before the revolution, Medina had grown up cheering for the Cincinnati Reds, but when a scout for the Reds offered Medina a contract in 1984, he said, essentially, no thanks, I'd rather be an agronomist.
"The leaders of the revolution and in sports want to form a new man, both as a professional and as a sportsman," he told me at the time. Biology student by day, member of the Sandinista Youth, Medina even turned down the per diem players received when traveling abroad. When I watched him play, he shook hands with the opposing players when he reached their bases. At one point he tagged out a player trying to steal second, and as the player walked away, Medina shook his hand.
For Havana, the Olympic gold medals won by Cuba's baseball players help show the superiority of socialism. Players who want to pitch for the Yankees must come to America by raft. But pre-revolutionary Cuba had minor-league teams. One American scout, Joe Cambria of the Washington Senators, lived in Havana. Mr. Castro, who pitched (right-handed) at the University of Havana, had two tryouts with the Senators but was rejected -- good slider, mediocre fastball. Baseball will not bring Mr. Castro's regime to an end. But had Mr. Cambria been more patient with a developing prospect, baseball might have prevented it. TINA ROSENBERG

HEADLINE: Auction Plan For Gardens Stirs Tensions

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER 

 BODY:
In its latest move to get vacant land back on the tax rolls, the Giuliani administration has announced plans to auction off more than 100 of the abandoned lots that have been reclaimed as gardens by community groups throughout the city. Notice of the auction appeared in three recent issues of The City Record, the city's daily journal of public transactions.
The planned sale of the properties, expected in May, has renewed tensions between the city and community gardeners, who protested last fall when the city began razing some gardens to make way for housing developments. 
 Unlike those gardens, the ones to be auctioned in the spring are to be sold to the highest bidder, for any use allowed by zoning.
An official with the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the agency that oversees community gardens, confirmed yesterday that 112 lots were on the auction block. They are among more than 300 vacant lots the city wants to sell.
"The Giuliani administration is trying to dispose of property not slated for housing development, economic development and so forth," said Hector Batista, first deputy commissioner at the agency. "We are trying to privatize as many city-owned properties as we can."
Mr. Batista said community gardeners had known all along that they would have only temporary access to these public plots. "People are there on an interim basis," he said. "People that administer the gardens know that at some point or another, the city is going to take some sort of action." Of the more than 500 city lots that are now used as community gardens, only 36 have been designated as permanent gardens, he said.
The Mayor's office at first denied the intention to sell. "They're on the list of properties being assessed," Jake Menges, chief of staff to Deputy Mayor Joseph Lhota, said when reached on Dec. 29. "It doesn't mean they're being sold." Mr. Menges said the Mayor's office had asked "every single agency to give us a rundown of their properties." He added that "it's an asset evaluation program."
Mr. Lhota and Mr. Menges were not available for comment yesterday, the Mayor's office said.
The list of lots for sale includes 20-year-old gardens like Parque de Tranquilidad and the All People's Garden, on the Lower East Side, which are graced with mature trees and wrought-iron fences. Another is the Garden of Eden, started by Lucy and Percy Heron, on a troubled block in Queens. It was featured three years ago in National Geographic magazine in an article celebrating the 25th anniversary of Earth Day.
"It's unbelievable," said Andrew Stone, director of the New York chapter of Trust for Public Land, a land conservancy and open-space advocacy group. "That garden is a source of stability for a neighborhood that has experienced a lot of problems. It's a model for a small community garden that functions as a community center. They run a children's program there every summer."
The city's community gardening agency, Greenthumb, which was set up in the early 1970's to lease vacant spaces to gardeners on a temporary basis, would not comment on the planned sale. The director referred all questions to the Parks Department.
The gardens for sale are listed in the Jan. 8, Dec. 21 and Dec. 9 issues of The City Record. There are to be public hearings on Wednesday at 10 A.M. at 22 Reade Street, and on Jan. 27 and Feb. 10 at 10 A.M. in City Hall. There is also to be a hearing on Friday at 10 A.M. in the City Council chambers of City Hall to discuss the proposed sale, sponsored by the Committee on Parks, Recreation, Cultural Affairs and International Intergroup Relations.
In addition, 23 gardens were listed last fall on the city's request for development qualifications sent out to developers to participate in the Partnership for New Homes and Neighborhood Builder Programs.
The city is required to give community boards notice of requests for development qualifications, in order to review the properties in question, but none was given.
The city has repeatedly said that the formerly vacant lots were for interim use only, but over the years, the Greenthumb program started more than 750 gardens. Of those, 37 have been given permanent status by the Department of Parks and Recreation. Some of the others were bulldozed this fall, sometimes without notice.
Over the last three months, about 20 community gardens have been bulldozed to make way for housing and commercial development. And an additional 58 are scheduled for destruction.
Since all of these lots have been through the Uniform Land Use Review Process, the city can dispose of them as it sees fit, regardless of how long ago they underwent the review process.
Steven Frillman, executive director of the Green Guerrillas, a group that has organized and tended hundreds of community gardens since 1973, said more than half of the gardens to be auctioned went through the review process more than 15 years ago. "If the sites haven't been reviewed on the local level for 10 years," he asked, "doesn't the city have an obligation to go back and review these sites?"
Borough presidents have also protested the sale of the gardens. "They said these lots were for housing, and it's a lie," said the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, whose borough has 19 gardens on the auction list. "What they're having is a cake sale."
"They're trying to sell out from under the community some of the award-winning gardens of this city," he said. "And they'll end up being parking lots, or flat-fix shops. It doesn't deal with housing needs, and worse than that, it just degrades the neighborhoods they insist they want to protect. And it returns next to nothing for the city."
Brooklyn has 36 gardens on the auction list.
"Did anybody go out to these sites and look at them before determining the sale, or did somebody just say, 'Here's the first batch,' " asked Greg Brooks, chief of staff for the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden. "When the portfolio of property is as large as this city has, one would hope there would be planning before there are land sales."
Manhattan has 21 gardens on the list. Its Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, also called on the city to reopen the review process. "So many things change in a community, it would be worthwhile to reconsider those sites," she said.
The Department of Citywide Administrative Services has about 11,000 vacant lots in its inventory, and the Giuliani administration has vowed to get any nonrevenue producing properties on the auction block.
The office of the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said it would review the remaining 600 gardens "on an individual basis, and determine the appropriate disposition."
The Trust for Public Land has lobbied city agencies for two years now to have gardens worthy of permanent status released to a private land trust. "We'll take the gardens and find the appropriate stewards for them," Mr. Stone said. "We have proposed that to the city and never gotten an answer."
Gardeners have been nervous since last April, when community gardens were transferred from the Parks Department to the housing agency.
"We've been waiting for the other shoe to drop," Mr. Frillman said. "But this feels like the whole shoe store. The entire inventory of gardens could be auctioned off."

HEADLINE: Once More, Schumer Is Sworn In As Senator

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
In a day of pomp and celebration by a political party that has little to cheer about this decade, thousands of New York Democrats assembled at Lincoln Center yesterday to whoop and cheer as Charles E. Schumer was sworn in -- for a second time -- as New York State's new junior Senator.
"Senator Chuck Schumer -- doesn't that have a nice ring to it?" said Vice President Al Gore, who flew to Manhattan to administer the oath to Mr. Schumer at Avery Fisher Hall for an audience that commemorated the moment with a 30-second burst of flashbulbs. The state's Democratic leaders, many of whom are beginning to consider Mr. Gore's own political future as he steps up his Presidential bid this year, responded to the Vice President with warm applause as Mr. Schumer's wife, Iris, and daughters, Jessica, 14, and Alison, 9, laughed and clapped on the stage. 
 There was a certain familiarity to the event for anyone who has been following the recent career of the former nine-term Congressman from Brooklyn. Mr. Schumer was, in fact, sworn in at a ceremony in Washington just last week -- placing his left hand on the same Bible, which he had saved from his bar mitzvah, as he used yesterday, and taking the oath from the same Vice President of United States.
The event's moderator, Robin MacNeil, the retired television journalist, referred to it as Mr. Schumer's "second annual inauguration."
But there were some differences. Last week's event on Capitol Hill was attended by 50 or so people and was sponsored by the National Soft Drink Association. Yesterday's was attended by more than 2,000, and was sponsored by the state Democratic Committee. The crowd at Avery Fisher Hall heard performances by the Boys Choir of Harlem, T. S. Monk Jr. (the son of the jazz pianist and composer), and Itzhak Perlman, the violinist, who played American standards. William Kennedy, the Albany novelist, gave a reading.
And Mr. Schumer, speaking to an audience that clearly was unhappy with events in Washington -- Representative Jerrold Nadler, among President Clinton's most public defenders on the House Judiciary Committee, received a standing ovation as he walked into the room -- warned against what he described as a "corrosive partisanship" that he said was making young voters cynical.
"What began 25 years ago with Watergate as a solemn and necessary endeavor to restore the public trust has now grown beyond our control," Mr. Schumer said. "We are in danger of criminalizing our differences -- of using scandal and innuendo to win at the gavel what we can not settle at the ballot box. Instead of great debates about the future of our Republic we have new politics of fear and smear, where the loyal opposition is too often bent on personal destruction."
Mr. Schumer made only an indirect mention of Alfonse M. D'Amato, the three-term Republican he handily defeated last year, and the Senate campaign. It came when, in listing his priorities as Senator, he stressed the need to unify the state.
"Upstaters must not let politicians demonize downstate -- such attacks do not create one new job," Mr. Schumer said. Mr. D'Amato sought to portray Mr. Schumer as hostile to upstate interests.
Mr. Schumer went out of his way in the speech to telegraph his concern about the problems of upstate New Yorkers. "I know the pain you feel because the nation's economic boom has left you behind," he said.
The swearing in drew a wide representation of Democrats from across the state, including most of the Congressional delegation, with the exception of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, and even some Democrats who had not supported Mr. Schumer, including Edward I. Koch, the former Mayor of New York. "They invited me, so I came," Mr. Koch said last night.

HEADLINE: N.F.L. DIVISIONAL PLAYOFFS;
The Redskins Said to Be Sold for $800 Million

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The Washington Redskins and their new stadium were sold yesterday to a group headed by Howard Milstein, co-owner of the New York Islanders hockey team, for $800 million, a record price for a domestic sports franchise, according to two people involved in the sale.
The sum to be paid to the estate of the late Jack Kent Cooke, the former owner of the team, by Milstein and his partner, Daniel Snyder, exceeds the $530 million paid by Al Lerner last August for the expansion Cleveland Browns football team, the previous record sales price. The Browns' price tag included a $54 million contribution toward building the team's new municipally-owned stadium . 
 The price paid for the Redskins reflects the cash flow generated by Jack Kent Cooke Stadium, which just completed its second season of operation. Cooke Stadium has 15,044 club seats, which cost $995 to $2,500 each annually, and 280 luxury suites that rent for between $45,000 and $160,000 each per season. The Browns' stadium will have fewer luxury suites and club seats.
The Redskins receive revenue from all tickets sold, parking and concessions.
Their sale will be formally announced today.
Milstein, who bid unsuccessfully for the Browns, will have to sell all or part of the 45 percent stake in the Islanders that he owns with his brother, Edward, to comply with the National Football League's cross-ownership rules.
When he sought to buy the Browns, Milstein said that if he got the team, he would sell his family's ownership in the Islanders to the team's co-owner, Steven Gluckstern. He was expected to follow that course now.
Milstein's family is worth billions of dollars, from New York-based real estate and banking empires. Snyder owns a Washington, D.C., communications firm.
In addition to reflecting the cash flow at Jack Kent Cooke Stadium, the $800 million purchase price was influenced by the Browns' sale price, the $70-million-a-year guaranteed to each N.F.L. team owner from the new television contracts, and the size and influence of the Washington market, which is nearly one-third bigger than Cleveland's.
The amount of money produced by a stadium is the economic factor that divides the richest teams from the rest and makes franchises leap in value. It was why a successful team like the Minnesota Vikings, which does not generate huge wealth from the municipally-owned Metrodome, sold for a modest $250 million last year to Red McCombs.
The Milstein-Snyder group defeated three others, including one formed by John Kent Cooke, the son of the late owner, that was described as very strong by the people involved in the sale process. Other bidders included John McMullen, the owner of the Devils; Charles F. Dolan, chairman of Cablevision Systems, and Sam Grossman, an Arizona shopping center magnate.
By the terms established by the Cooke estate, Milstein and Snyder are acquiring the team's stock, a transaction that will funnel the proceeds tax free to a charitable foundation set up by the estate. The $800 payment includes $161 million for the estate to pay the remaining debt on the stadium.
The Browns' sale, by comparison, was an asset purchase. The Redskin process, compared with that of the Browns, was quiet. The estate imposed severe confidentiality restrictions, rules that were stern enough so that bidders like McMullen and Dolan denied they were bidding. With the Browns, the league controlled the process, inviting the bidders to meetings covered by the news media.
League approval of Milstein and Snyder should take 60 to 90 days, but the time span could be shorter because N.F.L. owners are already familiar with Milstein. It is not known whether that time frame will preserve the job of Redskins Coach Norv Turner, whose team was 6-10 this season. Had John Kent Cooke acquired the team, Turner's future was believed to be more secure.
