HEADLINE: 2 More Antiaircraft Incidents in North Iraq

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
American fighter jets attacked antiaircraft batteries in northern Iraq in two skirmishes today as Baghdad continued its defiance of American and British control of its skies.
The Pentagon said the American fighters had attacked after the batteries had tracked them with radar, apparently in preparation to fire. But the Iraqi antiaircraft forces did not fire, and the jets returned safely to their base at Incirlik, Turkey. 
 It was not clear whether the strikes destroyed the batteries, the Pentagon said, because of clouds.
Today's incidents fit an increasingly familiar pattern. Almost every day now, Iraqi aircraft or antiaircraft weapons are challenging American and British jets patrolling the northern and southern no-flight zones established after the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
Two more Iraqi MIG jets entered the southern zone today but quickly left, Pentagon officials said.
The challenges follow a series of defiant threats, and some retreats, from President Saddam Hussein's Government, which has vowed to end all cooperation with United Nations, including weapons inspections and efforts by international relief agencies.
On Sunday the Iraqi Parliament postponed a vote to reject United Nations resolutions, including one that established its border with Kuwait and those that the United States cited to create the no-flight zones to protect Kurds in Iraq's north and Shiite Muslims in its south.
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, traveling to Japan, warned today that any move by Iraq to withdraw recognition of Kuwait would be "a flagrant violation" of resolutions that have stood for nearly eight years.
He also said the United States would strike again if President Hussein threatened Kuwait or Saudi Arabia or used force to crack down on Iraqi Kurds. "What we have said is that to the extent that he poses a threat or moves against Kuwait or Saudi Arabia or the Kurds in the north, that we are prepared to respond," Mr. Cohen said.
Administration officials say they believe that Mr. Hussein is trying to find and exploit international divisions over how to enforce the United Nations resolutions.
But so far, the challenges to American and British aircraft have done little except invite strikes on Iraq's antiaircraft weapons. And Baghdad's public statements have exposed its isolation from important Arab countries like Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is to visit those two countries this month.
Both of today's incidents occurred this morning near the city of Mosul, Pentagon officials said. In one instance, two F-15E fighter jets fired guided missiles at an antiaircraft battery after detecting that the Iraqis had targeted them with radar, Pentagon officials said. An F-16 fired a radar-seeking missile at an SA-6 surface-to-air missile launcher, the officials said.
On Friday, the commander of American forces in the region, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, announced that the United States would bolster its force in the region. Eight more F-16's and four aerial refuelers will join 182 aircraft now enforcing the southern no-flight zone.

HEADLINE: Plenty of Snow in Detroit, But Hardly a Plow in Sight

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Every city reacts in its own way to snow. Atlantans panic and drive badly. Washington closes Government offices early and sends everyone home. Chicagoans expect their politicians to have the streets plowed immediately -- or face the consequences at the next election.
Detroit has another, more surprising approach to snow: ignore it. 
 For as far back as this city has been able to check its records, close to half a century, it has had a policy of not plowing residential streets. As a result, it has just 59 snowplows, compared with 750 in Chicago, whose area is just slightly larger. Only large avenues, highways and the streets in front of schools are plowed here, and even those are done slowly.
But with many Detroit neighborhoods still impassable from the foot of snow that fell on Jan. 2, and with three more snowfalls since then having added a half-foot, a lot of people here are suddenly angry about the policy. To make matters worse, the temperature has seldom climbed even into the 20's since the first of the year, and never above the freezing mark, while nighttime temperatures have dropped as low as 10 below zero, unusually cold for southeastern Michigan.
In short, there is no thaw in sight, and the snow is turning to ice.
Workers have had trouble reaching their jobs. Schools were closed for most of last week, and few children have been able to reach them since they reopened on Friday. Food distributors' trucks have had trouble supplying corner grocery stores, which remain common here because the city's poverty and crime have scared off most supermarket chains.
The heavy snowfall nine days ago caused particular trouble at Detroit's airport, where dozens of arriving Northwest Airlines flights waited for hours before unloading passengers because the airline did not have ground crews available. The airline, the city and Wayne County have been trading accusations ever since over whether Northwest should have diverted the flights to other cities or whether Detroit's snow removal policies prevented the airline's workers from reaching the airport.
Gwendolyn Johnson, 23, has been unable to walk her 6-year-old son, Demar, to school because the snow is too deep for his short legs.
"You'd have to walk in the streets," Ms. Johnson said angrily, "and the streets are no better."
One of her neighbors, James E. Barksdale, 75, has lived at his home for 50 years, and in all that time the street in front of it has never been plowed, he said as he stood in 3-degree weather late this morning. He was digging a path down his driveway to the road, where the snow had been tamped down by the repeated passing of sport utility vehicles.
Mayor Dennis Archer has taken the brunt of the criticism. He waited five days to start paying suburban governments to send 17 snowplows here to help clear the streets. Then the suburbs, most of which try to plow all their streets, quickly recalled their trucks when more snow began falling last Friday.
Mayor Archer has asked for a citywide volunteer effort to shovel streets and sidewalks. But that has had limited effect in a sprawling city that is six times the size of Manhattan and has less than half the population.
By coincidence, the city had been planning to improve its snow removal efforts this winter, having ordered 42 new trucks with snowplows for delivery last autumn. But the trucks have not arrived, because, Mayor Archer said in an interview, the manufacturer of the trucks' transmissions is behind schedule.
The policy of letting residential neighborhoods fend for themselves isrooted in the city's peculiar combination of climate and history.
Unlike other Great Lakes ports like Cleveland and Buffalo, Detroit gets little "lake effect" snow, because it is situated on the Detroit River, 20 miles upwind of Lake Erie and across the state from Lake Michigan. So the city usually gets its snow three or four inches at a time; in a city of self-reliant auto workers, driving over a little snow is not viewed as a problem.
Detroit's population has also plummeted, from a peak of 2.2 million in the mid-1950's to some 950,000 now. Four-fifths of the city's white population moved to the suburbs, mainly after the riots of 1967. While there have been recent hints of an economic recovery, the city remains among the poorest in the nation, with thousands of abandoned houses on which no taxes are paid. What tax revenue there is brings many demands other than snow removal.
Beyond all that is the fact that Detroit, though largely a city of single-family homes, has a scarcity of home garages. Few residents have anywhere to park their cars except on the street, which would make snow removal a headache in any case.
Mayor Michael A. Bilandic of Chicago lost an election in 1979 because of his city's difficulties in cleaning up after a blizzard that year, and Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York had trouble winning re-election in 1969 after streets in Queens were not cleared quickly following a snowstorm.
But Mayor Archer, a Democrat, said he believed that Detroit voters would not hold the current problems against him. In any event, he is only one year into his second four-year term.
The conventional wisdom is that even as several more inches of snow fell tonight, the Mayor's reputation was suffering but might yet recover.
"Politically he's damaged," said Mario Morrow, a political analyst here. "I wouldn't say he's buried at this point."

HEADLINE: Smoking Ban Has Not Hurt Restaurants, Analysts Say

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Since the city banned smoking in restaurants in 1995, restaurateurs have complained that the prohibition is bad for business. Yesterday, a group of academic researchers, admittedly anti-smoking ones, released a series of six analyses suggesting that the ban has not hurt.
The studies indicated that the anti-smoking law, which took effect on April 10, 1995, has had no effect on local sales, job growth or income. The studies, which were financed by the Substance Abuse Policy Research Program, which receives money from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, showed that restaurant industry jobs rose 18 percent from 1993 to 1997, to 19,347. 
 During the same period, sales tax receipts rose 2 percent at restaurants in the city but dropped 4 percent in the rest of the state. The number of restaurants in the city during that period increased 6 percent.
At a news conference, the researchers characterized their work as the first comprehensive look at the city's ban on smoking in restaurants with 35 or more seats. They said earlier studies suggesting economic harm were smaller and were financed by the tobacco industry.
"Local officials can now go about their business of protecting the public from the toxins in second-hand smoke without worrying about this phony issue," said Dr. Stanton A. Glantz, who wrote an editorial accompanying the articles, which are published in the January issue of Public Health Management and Practice.
Mike O'Neal, who owns O'Neal's restaurant on West 64th Street, near Lincoln Center, supported the ban, saying it has helped his business. "If 75 percent of people don't smoke and 25 percent do, that means 75 percent are going to eat out more and 25 percent are going to eat out less," he said at the news conference.
Others in the restaurant industry took sharp issue with the studies' methodology and conclusions. Scott Wexler, executive director of the Empire State Restaurant and Tavern Association, a trade group, said in an interview that his group sponsored a study in 1996 that showed jobs at city restaurants declining 4 percent. He said that since his group's study examined statistics for the months just before and after the law took effect, it could isolate more fairly the "cataclysmic" influence of the smoking ban on business.
Mr. Wexler said his group's study showed retail jobs going up 2 percent at the same time that restaurant jobs dropped 4 percent, suggesting that something beyond general economic trends was at work, he said.
Dan Tubridy, who owns Pier 92, a restaurant in Rockaway Beach, Queens, said in an interview that he lost customers immediately. "They said that if they couldn't eat at my place they were going to Nassau County, pure and simple," he said. "And you know what happens? They don't come back."
Mr. Wexler also pointed out that 8,000 of 15,000 restaurants included in the overall sales tax figures were small enough to allow smoking or were primarily bars, where smoking is also allowed. The study conducted by Dr. Andrew Hyland, a biostatistician, and two colleagues at Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, acknowledged this limitation.
The restaurant trade group is heavily supported by the Tobacco Institute, which recently admitted funneling $443,072 to the group, after earlier claiming a far lower amount. The money was used to lobby the State Legislature for less stringent laws than the city's.
The studies also concluded that the law has been enforced very effectively. An examination of city records, one study said, showed that city health inspectors found smoking at only 2 percent of the 251 restaurants they visited. Another study indicated that 90 percent of restaurant owners reported that their indoor areas were smoke-free. Three out of four restaurateurs reported that complying with the law cost them no money.
Several researchers said the next step would be a dual effort: to pass laws like the city's in other counties, and to extend the city law to bars, both those within restaurants and free-standing ones. "A bar is a workplace," said Dr. John R. Seffin, chief executive of the American Cancer Society. "You should not be allowed to smoke in a workplace."

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
U.S. More Isolated In Policy Toward Iraq
A growing number of Security Council members and Arab nations support lifting an embargo on Iraqi oil sales or otherwise relaxing sanctions to relieve the suffering in Iraq. But there is also solid agreement that long-term international supervision is needed to prevent Iraq from acquiring prohibited weapons. A1 

American fighter jets attacked Iraqi antiaircraft batteries after the batteries tracked them with radar, apparently in preparation to fire, the Pentagon said. But the Iraqi antiaircraft forces did not fire, and the American jets returned safely to their base at Incirlik, Turkey. A8

The Congo war seems to be changing Africa's old rules, as soldiers from no fewer than six foreign nations fight a war that has as much to do with problems outside of Congo as inside it. Many experts say the war may become a point of departure from which African nations begin to re-imagine themselves in ways not possible under the old rules. A1

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares End Mixed as Nasdaq Rallies but Blue Chips Falter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday, with many issues pulling back after last week's rally to record highs raised investors' concerns that the market was getting too expensive.
The Intel Corporation was among the prominent exceptions, rallying on expectations that its earnings, which are scheduled for release today, will exceed forecasts. 
 "Shares rose too far too fast in a remarkable week in the market," said Franklin Morton, research chief at Ariel Capital Management in Chicago, which oversees about $3 billion. A week into the year, the Nasdaq composite index is already up 7.3 percent, the Dow Jones industrial average is up 4.1 percent, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 2.3 percent.
Yesterday, the Dow average closed down 23.43 points, or nearly a quarter of 1 percent, to 9,619.89, though it rebounded from a deficit earlier in the session that reached 111 points. The S.& P. index declined 11.21 points, or about nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,263.88.
Intel helped the Nasdaq set a closing high for a seventh consecutive session. The index jumped 40.18 points, or 1.7 percent, to 2,384.59.
Declining issues outpaced advancers, 1,970 to 1,118, on the New York Stock Exchange; trading volume was 818.1 million shares.
The S.& P. telephone index led the decline in the S.& P. 500, retreating 4 percent after a 5.3 percent gain in four days. BellSouth lost 3 1/16 a share, to 47 7/16; SBC Communications dropped 2 9/16, to 55 1/8, and Bell Atlantic fell 1 11/16, to 54 15/16.
Intel climbed 10 1/16 a share, to set a closing high of 139 3/4. After a surge in computer-buying during the holiday season, Intel, the world's biggest manufacturer of computer chips, is expected to report earnings of $1.07 a share, up from 96 cents a year earlier, based on the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. That would surpass Intel's own optimistic forecasts.
Internet shares surged, led by issues like E*Trade Group, an on-line brokerage firm, which jumped 20 7/8, to 88 1/2, after posting a smaller-than-expected loss for its first quarter.
Campbell Soup fell 6 7/8, to 45 3/8, its biggest decline since 1980, after the company, world's largest maker of soup, said fiscal year 1999 earnings would probably fall short of analyst expectations, as the company cuts costs and reduces shipments of condensed soup in the United States.
Pharmaceutical shares, among the top performers last year, fell for a third consecutive session. Pfizer Inc. declined 4 1/2 a share, to 117 3/4; Schering-Plough lost 2 1/8, to 52 3/4.
Ascend Communications Inc., a telecommunications equipment maker, gained 5 1/4, to 761 1/16, on speculation that Lucent Technologies, the world's biggest telephone-equipment maker, offered to buy it for more than $16 billion. Lucent and Ascend officials declined to comment. Lucent shares fell 2 5/16, to 112 15/16.
General Motors rallied 6, to 86 1/16, after David Bradley, an analyst at J. P. Morgan, raised his 1999 earnings estimate for the auto maker to $8.75 a share, from $8.40. Individual and institutional investors have been betting in recent days that G.M.'s earnings prospects would rise.
Some investors interpreted the G.M. rally and Friday's stronger-than-expected employment report from the Labor Department as signs that the economy remains buoyant. They are concerned, though, that the Federal Reserve -- which helped contribute to the market's strength by lowering benchmark borrowing costs three times starting Sept. 29 -- may be through cutting rates.
"If interest rates have bottomed, or if we get an uptick in rates, that's it for the market," said Frank Curzio, president of FXC Investment Group in Queens.
Concern that Brazil's debt and currency problems will crimp economic and corporate-profit growth in the United States also weighed on stocks.
Brazil's Bovespa index fell 5.6 percent, as a call by the second-most- populous state in Brazil to withhold debt payments to the Federal Government prompted investors to pull money out of the country.
That raised concern that Brazil might eventually default on its foreign debt, causing shock waves in the United States similar to those set off by Russia's default in August.

Bond Prices Fall
By The Associated Press
Bond prices slipped yesterday as the dollar fell further against the Japanese yen, making Treasuries less attractive to international investors.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 8/32, to a price of 98 22/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 5.30 percent, from 5.27 percent on Friday.
Bond prices were hurt partly by the continued decline of the dollar against the yen. The dollar fell to a 28-month low against the yen yesterday, extending a slump from last summer's highs despite continued strength in the American economy.

HEADLINE: THE TRIAL OF THE PRESIDENT: THE PROSECUTORS;
Managers Offer the Details Of the Case Against Clinton

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Representative Henry J. Hyde and the 12 other impeachment managers today presented a road map of the case for removing President Clinton that they plan to make to the Senate beginning on Thursday.
The 105-page document, with 250 pages of supporting evidence, offers a highly circumstantial case that relies on persuading two-thirds of the Senate that a chain of events, read in its entirety, demonstrates a compelling argument for the President's ouster. Each senator will receive a loose-leaf binder containing the material. 
 "The evidence contained in the record, when viewed as a unified whole, overwhelmingly supports both charges," the document states. The President is accused of perjury before a grand jury and obstruction of justice.
The filing tracks the closing arguments made last month by David P. Schippers, the chief House investigative counsel, and the House Judiciary Committee's final report. Those presentations led the full House to approve along party lines the two articles of impeachment against Mr. Clinton.
In its brief, the House managers adopted a tone that was alternately derisive and unyielding as they restated much of the voluminous record that Mr. Hyde and the Judiciary Committee compiled in their inquiry. In salting their brief with words like "sinister" and "plot," the prosecutors were clearly trying to guide their readers to make a dire judgment of the evidence.
Although they were restricted to the House record, the managers' outline also goes beyond bolstering the two articles of impeachment. The prosecutors included in their brief some of the allegations made by the Judiciary Committee in the two proposed articles of impeachment that were not approved by the full House. For example, they refer to the President's failure to respond fully to some of the 81 questions posed by the Judiciary Committee in its inquiry, an offense that was defeated as part of an article of impeachment defining abuse of office.
They complain that Mr. Clinton "elected to follow the pattern of selective memory, reference to other testimony, blatant untruths, artful distortions, outright lies and half truths."
"When he did answer," they added, "he engaged in legalistic hair-splitting in an obvious attempt to skirt the whole truth and to deceive and obstruct the due proceedings of the Committee."
At another point, they cite some of Mr. Clinton's grand jury answers and note that it is illegal to "insert unstated premises or mental reservations into the question to make it technically true, if factually false. The essence of lying is in deception, not in words."
And even as the prosecutors say they need not go into sexual details at the trial, they list the number of sexual encounters the President had with Ms. Lewinsky and the number of times they had phone sex.
"This case is not about sex or private conduct," the brief states. "It is about multiple obstructions of justice, perjury, false and misleading statements, and witness tampering -- all committed or orchestrated by the President of the United States."
At the heart of the managers' case is the charge that President Clinton, in his deposition in the sexual harassment suit brought by Paula C. Jones, offered a cleverly worded lie about his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky and then schemed to cover up the affair.
In doing so, the House managers argued, Mr. Clinton "deliberately and willfully testified falsely under oath" before a Federal grand jury on Aug. 17. Mr. Clinton engaged in the scheme, the managers asserted, to obstruct both the grand jury and the Jones civil case.
Mr. Clinton, the House managers said, obstructed justice in these ways:
*Trying to influence the testimony of his secretary, Betty Currie;
*Providing several of his top aides with "elaborate lies" about his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky;
*Orchestrating a campaign to discredit Ms. Lewinsky to undercut her credibility, and
*Using the power of the Presidency to help get Ms. Lewinsky a job in New York.
In dismissing a frequent defense raised by the White House that Ms. Lewinsky testified that no one told her to lie or bought her silence, the House managers argue that her words are not exculpatory if they are viewed in context along with a skein of events. "Of course no one said, 'Now Monica, you go in there and lie,' " the brief states. "They didn't have to. Ms. Lewinsky knew what was expected of her. Similary, nobody promised her a job, but once she signed the false affidavit she got one."
And the managers stressed what they consider the gravity of the President's offenses, saying they "have the effect of seriously compromising the integrity of the entire judicial system."
The President's misconduct has had "devastating" consequences, they state. "Make no mistake, the conduct of the President is inextricably bound to the welfare of the people of the United States," the managers said. "Not only does it affect economic and national defense, but even more directly, it affects the moral and law-abiding fiber of the commonwealth."
The filing today was the first step in a carefully scripted but still fragile schedule the Senate unanimously adopted on Friday, which postpones a decision on the polarizing issue of whether to call witnesses.
When asked to comment on the Senate's plan, Mr. Hyde told reporters: "I'm in a difficult position. Now is not the time to get angry at the Senate. At the same time, this is a strange process, one we're not familiar with in terms of making a case. When we reach the point of asking for witnesses, we feel that senators will be in more generous mood."
The House managers have a total of 24 hours to present their case, to be followed by a rebuttal from the President of up to 24 hours. Representative Charles T. Canady of Florida, one of the managers, said they faced a "strategic decision" on whether to use all their time because the Republicans don't want to "test the patience of those listening." House aides said tonight, though, that it appeared likely that the managers' presentation would spill over to Saturday.
Under the managers' current plan, subject to change, Mr. Hyde would make brief introductory remarks. Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr. of Wisconsin would then spend 40 to 50 minutes giving an overview of the House's case.
From there, the managers' case would be divided into three parts. One team of managers, which includes several former Federal prosecutors, would present the factual record, drawing heavily on the independent counsel's report.
This presentation, which would include Representatives Ed Bryant of Tennessee, Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas, James E. Rogan of California and Bob Barr of Georgia, would last several hours.
Following that, Representative Bill McCollum of Florida would lead a team laying out the legal basis for the two articles of impeachment.
Once the managers linked the factual record to a legal framework, Mr. Canady and a group of managers would then argue that the charges against the President rise to offenses impeachable under the Constitution.
Finally, Mr. Rogan, Mr. Hyde and Representative George W. Gekas of Pennsylvania, will deliver the managers' closing arguments, with Mr. Hyde wrapping up.
 In each of these parts, but especially in factual presentation, the managers will highlight conflicting testimony that they believe requires the calling of witnesses for clarity.
The managers last week spoke of summoning as many as 18 witnesses, but lawmakers say they have narrowed that list to six or so. At the top of the list, managers say, are Ms. Lewinsky, Mrs. Curry and Vernon E. Jordan Jr., one of the President's confidants, who helped Ms. Lewinsky get a job in New York.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
REVLON TO ELIMINATE AT LEAST 1,000 JOBS WORLDWIDE

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Revlon Inc., the largest United States maker of cosmetics sold in discount chains and drugstores, said yesterday that it would cut 1,000 to 1,200 jobs worldwide, or about 7 percent of its work force, to lower costs as sales decline. Revlon, which also sells Colorstay and Almay makeup, also said that lenders had agreed to waive terms in its credit agreement and that it would take a charge of about $80 million, including $40 million for the fourth quarter of 1998. Revlon, based in New York, is 83 percent owned by the New York investor Ronald O. Perelman. The company's sales have been hurt by loss of consumer buying power in Asia, Russia and Latin America as well as inventory cutbacks at American drugstores.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Jobs in Salt Lake City Questioned by I.O.C.

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
Relatives of International Olympic Committee members from Ecuador and Finland were employed by the Salt Lake City bid committee while it pursued the 2002 Winter Games, Olympic officials said yesterday.
A daughter of Agustin Carlos Arroyo, an I.O.C. member from Ecuador, and the husband of Pirjo Haggman, an I.O.C. member from Finland, worked briefly for the bid committee, Olympic officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. These revelations were the latest in a growing scandal involving cash payments, tuition aid and lavish gifts in which vote-buying by Salt Lake City officials has been alleged by Marc Hodler, a senior I.O.C. member from Switzerland. 
 Arroyo's daughter worked for a couple of weeks for the Utah Department of Economic Development as a commercial artist, but her skills were found to be lacking, an Olympic official said. She was then hired to answer phones for the Salt Lake City bid committee for a month and was eventually given tuition aid to attend school in Texas for about six months and might have received living expenses, the Olympic official said. The official said that the daughter was hired without her father's urging or apparent knowledge.
Reached by telephone yesterday in Guayaquil, Ecuador, Arroyo said that his stepdaughter, Nancy Rignault, who is an American citizen, had worked briefly in Salt Lake City a restoration project before returning to Texas, but that he was positive she had not worked for the bid committee. He later said he was not sure and would check on the matter "because I have nothing to hide."
Arroyo, 75, a lawyer and industrialist and an I.O.C. member since 1968, also said that he might have received cash from the bid committee, but that it would have been as reimbursement for travel expenses he and his wife, Raquel, incurred when they visited Salt Lake City before the June 1995 vote in which it was awarded the 2002 Games.
It is customary for Olympic bid cities to provide first-class air fare for I.O.C. members and a guest when they make three-day inspection visits. Arroyo said that the total cost of the two first-class tickets might have been $5,000. He said it was his habit to buy his own tickets when traveling and then to be reimbursed.
"That's the only thing that could have been given to me in cash," he said, adding that he had received nothing else from Salt Lake City officials other than customary hotel accommodations, meals and small gifts like a watch and a necktie.
Also during the bid process, Haggman's husband was hired to do an environmental study for the Salt Lake City committee, an Olympic official said. The official said the couple were separated at the time. Haggman, 47, an I.O.C. member since 1981, did not respond to a fax seeking comment.
Also yesterday, Salt Lake City Mayor Deedee Corradini said that she would not seek a third term in office. Corradini, who was active in securing the 2002 Winter Games, has denied knowing of any wrongdoing in the mushrooming Olympic scandal and said it played no role in her decision not to seek re-election.
Hodler told The Associated Press yesterday that public and corporate discontent could force the 2002 Games to be moved from Salt Lake City or canceled. However, the I.O.C. leadership has stated firmly that it does not intend to move the Games from Salt Lake City. Officials of the United States Olympic Committee have said they can raise enough money to satisfy a $1.45 billion budget for the Games.
"We fully anticipate the Winter Games of 2002 will be held in Salt Lake City," said Bill Hybl, president of the U.S.O.C.
Tom Welch, who was president of the Salt Lake City bid committee, has acknowledged paying $50,000 in cash to Jean-Claude Ganga, an I.O.C. member from Congo Republic, to be used for children there. Investigators have said that Ganga received payments totaling $70,000. One Olympic official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said yesterday that $20,000 paid to Ganga had been claimed by the bid committee as reimbursement for travel expenses.
Welch has repeatedly denied any attempt to bribe I.O.C. members. In a weekend interview with French radio, Ganga denied any wrongdoing.
Ganga said that a profitable land deal arranged for him by Bennie Smith, a member of the Salt Lake City bid committee, several months after Salt Lake City won the Games, was normal. Because the land deal occurred after the vote on the site, Ganga told French radio, "it couldn't have influenced me."
Ganga said Salt Lake City won the 2002 Games, not by bribery, but "because they were the best."
 
 
Bribery Charge Denied
 SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 11 (Agence France-Presse) -- Sergio Santander Fantini, the president of the Chilean Olympic Committee and a member of the International Olympic Committee, denied today that he had accepted bribes from the Salt Lake City bid committee in connection with the awarding of the 2002 Winter Games.
In The Deseret News of Salt Lake City today, Tom Welch, who headed the bid committee, said that he contributed $10,000 to Santander's mayoral campaign, but "we never bribed anybody." Santander said, "I never received any money, nothing."

HEADLINE: U.S. More Isolated In U.N. on Keeping The Iraq Sanctions

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The United States is finding itself increasingly isolated in its Iraq policy as a growing number of Security Council members and Arab nations support lifting an embargo on Iraqi oil sales or significantly relaxing sanctions in other ways to relieve the suffering of the Iraqi people.
But contrary to what the Iraqis may hope, there is also solid agreement that long-term international supervision is needed to prevent Iraq from acquiring or developing prohibited weapons. Among proposals to be discussed are the creation of a new inspection system and ways to monitor money that Iraq would earn if it sold oil freely. 
 The Clinton Administration wants to retain the existing system and the right to use the military to enforce it, although a majority of Security Council members oppose further use of force without Council approval.
Washington has focused on keeping sanctions in force until Iraq complies with all disarmament requirements. The United States would be willing only to expand a program that allows Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil to buy food, medicine and other necessities.
Peter Burleigh, the American representative on the Council, said in an interview tonight that undoing existing resolutions that govern those policies would not be easy and that no other delegation has proposed a concrete way to make the changes.
"The whole body of what I think everyone would agree is international law can't just be wished away," he said. "The disarmament issue is the key to the lifting of sanctions."
"I am not convinced that the proposals for the lifting of sanctions are actually gaining a wide momentum," he said. "While there are various delegations and governments that are making comments about the lifting of sanctions or the modification of sanctions, how those would relate to the body of resolutions pertaining to Iraq is not at all clear."
Although any change in Security Council policies could be blocked by an American veto, Washingtonwants the backing of the Council and does not want to find itself alone. Administration officials have also acknowledged that if the United States uses its veto to keep sanctions in force, over time they could erode.
Some Council members say the debate is an urgent one because there are no inspectors in Iraq now and no work is being done there. Today the chief arms inspector, Richard Butler, said that he had suspended surveillance flights by American U-2's and French aircraft while the Security Council discusses the crisis. But the Council has no timetable for the discussions, which could take weeks or even months.
The United States is finding that the core group opposed to its policies on Iraq -- formed around Russia, China, France and sometimes Brazil -- has strengthened with the entry of at least two new Council members, Malaysia and Namibia, which will hold two-year seats.
American diplomats are also watching Canada and the Netherlands, two other new members, for signs of where they will stand. In Amsterdam today, the Dutch representative on the United Nations Special Commission to disarm Iraq supported the view that sanctions could be rewritten while the arms inspections system remained in place.
The commissioner, Koos Ooms, said this would rebuild unity in the Security Council and "would at least snatch away from Saddam Hussein the weapon of being able to say that the Iraqi people are suffering because of the sanctions."
The French Government says it is preparing new proposals for the Council to end the oil embargo but institute other controls. Lifting the embargo could change Iraqi lives in many ways, depending on the terms of any agreement. It would put money back into the economy, which could, for instance, increase purchasing power or allow imports of consumer goods.
Even the British, the strongest ally of the United States on Iraq policy, now favor a new inspection system, Prime Minister Tony Blair said today in an open letter to the French newspaper Liberation.
Mr. Butler, the chief arms inspector, acknowledged today that a change in the inspection system seems inevitable. Speaking at an arms control conference in Washington, he said whatever system emerges from the Council "would be a bit different from the past."
Today in Moscow, Russia's Foreign Ministry called again for the dismissal of Mr. Butler, the executive chairman of the Special Commission, after reports last week that the United States used the commission for espionage. The commission, known as Unscom, has been responsible for disarming Iraq since 1991. The sanctions, imposed in 1990 after Iraq invaded Kuwait, were linked to arms inspections at the end of the Persian Gulf war.
Secretary General Kofi Annan defended Mr. Butler today. "I don't think the issue is Butler," he told reporters, after repeating that he had no evidence that Mr. Butler had cooperated with United States in spying on Iraq. "I don't think the issue is Unscom. We are dealing with much larger issues about compliance of Iraq and stability in the region."
Mr. Blair, in his letter to Liberation, wrote that Britain agreed with the United States that an expansion of the "oil for food" program would be the best way to aid Iraqi civilians. Iraq is now permitted to sell up to $5.2 billion in oil every six months.
"We are holding talks with France and other eminent members of the Security Council to find a formula allowing monitoring to resume in Iraq," he wrote, "but under a new system that would avoid the inspectors' presence creating a new crisis every three months."
For the Council, the problem is how to separate sanctions issues from disarmament without giving any ground, real or psychological, to President Hussein, whom even some Arab nations now openly condemn. Furthermore, no one has put forward a plan for winning Iraq's cooperation or creating an enforcement system.
The Council will meet on Tuesday to look at the relief situation in Iraq, its president for January, Celso L. N. Amorim of Brazil, said today. "Before we're able to address the broader political issues of Iraq," he said, "we have to address some concrete steps that can be taken both on the humanitarian file and the disarmament file."
For the Arabs, the moment is particularly delicate, said Clovis Maksoud, a former Arab League representative at the United Nations who is now director of the Center for the Global South at American University in Washington. He said recent American and British actions -- including the December air strikes and possible misuse of the Special Commission for spying by Washington -- have created crises in both the United Nations and the Arab League.
While there are Arab leaders who would like to see Mr. Hussein out of power, they would have trouble supporting more American attacks and could not back an overthrow from outside, Mr. Maksoud said.
But among the Arabs, Mr. Maksoud said, there would be great support for a change in sanctions that helped free, at least economically, the Iraqi middle class while arms control inspections remained.

HEADLINE: '98 Medicare Growth Slowest Since Program Began in '65

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The growth of Medicare slowed to a virtual halt last year as spending in the giant health insurance program for the elderly rose by just 1.5 percent, the smallest increase since the beginning of the program in 1965, new Government data show.
The slower rate of growth will probably add a few years to the life of the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills for the elderly. And it may temporarily relax the pressure on Congress to redesign the program. But, officials said, it does not fundamentally alter the long-term outlook for Medicare, which will incur immense new costs as baby boomers become eligible after 2010. 
 For the first time, Medicare spending last year grew more slowly than the Federal budget as a whole, which increased by 3 percent.
The slowdown shows the effects of Congressional curbs on payments to hospitals and home health care agencies, and the results of a Federal crusade against Medicare fraud.
In the last decade, Medicare spending rose by an average of $12.8 billion, or 10 percent, a year. But in 1998, it grew just $3.1 billion, to a total of $213.6 billion, according to recent statements of Federal spending from the Treasury Department.
"While we are all rightly concerned about the growth of future costs, Medicare right now is amazingly well behaved," said Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office. "Nobody is really sure why Medicare spending has slowed down quite as much as it has. The only thing we can be sure of is that it won't last."
The number of Medicare beneficiaries grew last year by slightly more than 1 percent, to 39 million. So the average increase in Medicare spending for each beneficiary was close to zero, budget experts said.
The experts offer several explanations. Congress intentionally curbed payments to hospitals, home health agencies and other health care providers in the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, and the savings so far have exceeded expectations.
Doctors and hospitals have historically absorbed cutbacks without reducing services to patients, but there is evidence that some beneficiaries are having difficulty gaining or keeping access to home health care.
In an interview today, William A. Dombi, vice president of the National Association for Home Care, said, "To stay within their Medicare budgets, home health agencies are avoiding higher-cost patients, chronically ill patients and those who need the most care."
Federal efforts to curb fraud and abuse also appear to have slowed the growth of Medicare. Health care executives said the Federal investigation of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation had sent a chill through the hospital industry and encouraged greater compliance by health care providers of all types, including doctors, who fear prosecution for submitting false claims.
Congress has pumped money into such investigations for several years, and June Gibbs Brown, inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services, has led a crackdown on Medicare fraud.
Thomas A. Scully, president of the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents 1,400 for-profit hospitals, said: "People in hospitals, the billing clerks and their supervisors, are generally scared to death of being investigated for billing errors, accidental or intentional. Revenues are dropping because hospitals are being ultraconservative in their billing practices."
Medicare's growth last year was significantly slower than that of private health insurance plans. In a recent survey of 207 large employers, Towers Perrin, a management consulting concern, found that the cost of employee health benefits increased 4 percent on average last year, with an increase of 7 percent forecast for this year.
In January 1998, the Congressional Budget Office predicted that Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, which pays hospital bills for the elderly, would run out of money in 2010. But health policy experts now say the trust fund will probably not be depleted until after 2012.
The trust fund had been expected to lose $4 billion in 1998, but instead it posted a surplus of nearly $1 billion, according to the Treasury statements. The trust fund's revenues, mainly from payroll taxes, were $2 billion higher than expected, thanks to a strong economy, and spending was $3 billion less than projected by the Congressional Budget Office.
Spending from the hospital trust fund declined last year by one-half of one percent, to $136.7 billion. Spending for doctors' services and other items covered by a separate fund rose by 5.1 percent, to $76.3 billion.
Marilyn Moon, a public trustee of the Medicare trust funds, said, "The 1997 Balanced Budget Act will do more than people thought to hold down Medicare costs." For example, she said, "spending on home health care declined from 1997 to 1998."
Delays in the payment of claims may also have slowed the growth of Medicare spending last year. Federal officials and Government contractors are taking more time to scrutinize claims for errors and fraud, and these delays may have been exacerbated by changes in Medicare computer systems, needed to get ready for the year 2000.
Small amounts of Medicare spending may thus have been shifted from 1998 to 1999. Government data show a greater lag between the time patients are treated and the time Medicare pays hospitals, nursing homes and home health agencies. It is unclear whether delays will continue.
In tracking spending, the Government measures the average complexity, or cost, of all the Medicare cases at each hospital. This "case mix index," which rose every year from 1983 to 1997, declined last year, Medicare officials said.
Federal spending on Medicaid, the health program for poor people, which also pays for large amounts of nursing home care, rose last year by 5.9 percent, to $101 billion, larger than the rises of an average of 3.6 percent a year in 1995 and 1996. But, apart from those years, it was the smallest increase since 1984.
The steep decline in welfare rolls has contributed to a decline in the number of Medicaid recipients, holding down Medicaid costs.

HEADLINE: WHITMAN EXPECTS TO OFFER REBATES ON PROPERTY TAX

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Under pressure to address New Jersey's high property taxes, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was expected to outline a five-year, $1 billion plan on Tuesday that would eventually provide average rebates of $600 to homeowners.
The plan would use money from the state's general fund to cover part of the homeowners' local school taxes, which now make up 55 to 65 percent of the average property tax bill. The proposal would not change how much money local school districts receive, because it would provide the rebates using state tax revenue. 
 While lawmakers, both Democrats and Republicans, say they embrace efforts to reduce the property tax burden on homeowners, some expressed concern about whether the state would be able to afford rebates if an economic slowdown occurred. The state's strong economy has helped produce a projected $800 million budget surplus that would cover the $200 million cost of the program in the first year. The cost of the program would rise to $1 billion in 2004.
"It certainly is an intriguing proposal," said Assemblyman Anthony N. Impreveduto, a Democrat from Secaucus. "The question is, how are we paying for it? The economy is robust now. Unfortunately, the economy is like hemlines. It rises and it falls. But I am glad that she has finally listened to us to do something about property taxes. I think Democrats would certainly consider being supportive of this."
Although Mrs. Whitman won national attention for cutting the state's income taxes when she first took office five years ago, she nearly lost her re-election bid in 1997 because of voter anger over paying the nation's highest auto insurance and property taxes. The average property tax bill in New Jersey is $4,000.
Governor Whitman and state lawmakers already took steps last year to ease auto insurance rates for some drivers. On Tuesday, Mrs. Whitman will make the property tax plan the centerpiece of her annual address to a joint session of the State Legislature. In the speech, she was expected to ask state officials to recommit themselves to what she describes as the core Republican values of cutting taxes and controlling spending.
Mrs. Whitman was also expected to embrace a proposal by the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, that would provide more state aid to municipalities to help them keep up with rising costs caused by inflation. Mr. DiFrancesco, a Republican, is widely expected to seek the gubernatorial nomination in three years. The Governor was also expected to announce her support for a proposal by Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, a Republican who is also considering making a gubernatorial bid. Mr. Collins's plan would eliminate state income taxes for residents earning $13,000 annually or less.
On property taxes, Mrs. Whitman has already taken some steps to reduce the state's high rates. She is encouraging school districts to share costs and has also signed legislation that freezes the amount of property taxes that low-income elderly and disabled homeowners now pay. She also signed legislation that once again allows New Jerseyans to deduct part of their property taxes from their state income tax bills.
Although critics warned that the 30 percent income tax cut in early 1994 would significantly reduce state aid to local governments and drive up property taxes, Mrs. Whitman points out that the overall property tax collection statewide has slowed.
But homeowners and local officials have continued to put pressure on Mrs. Whitman and lawmakers to take more aggressive steps, because property tax rates are still sharply rising in some towns. Under the proposal, tenants would receive average rebates of $20 this year, increasing to $100 by the fifth year, Whitman administration officials said.
"This is the most sweeping property tax reform that this state has ever experienced," said Pete McDonough, Mrs. Whitman's spokesman. "It will cut the average school tax bill by more than a third."
The tax rebate proposal is by far the most extensive effort that the Governor has taken to address a longstanding complaint of New Jersey property owners. It is similar to a $2.7 billion property tax program that Gov. George E. Pataki, a fellow Republican, proposed and signed into law in 1997. But the major difference is that property owners in New Jersey would get a check directly from the state.
In New York, homeowners can see the reduction on their property tax bill, but the state writes the check to the local school district to make up the difference. The Pataki administration's plan is scheduled to be fully phased in by the 2001-2002 school year. In New Jersey, the rebates would be fully in place in 2004.
Both plans are intended to recalculate the school-tax portion of the local property tax bills but keep school spending levels the same. Both plans exempt part of the assessed value of a home from the school tax rate to calculate rebates. In New York, it is the first $30,000 of assessed value for all homeowners. In New Jersey, the first $45,000 of assessed value would be removed from the formula for the school district tax rate.
For several years, many New Jersey homeowners did receive rebate checks to cover a portion of their property tax bills until the program was scaled back by lawmakers in 1992 to help pay for a cut in the sales tax. The state still maintains what is called a homestead rebate program for disabled and low-income homeowners and tenants.
When Mrs. Whitman's program is fully phased in after five years, the rebate checks would average about $600 and would be available to property owners regardless of income. Starting this year, the proposal would phase in the rebates at 20 percent a year. The first rebates would average $120.
By 2004, homeowners in Livingston, Essex County, where the average assessed value of a home is $75,000, would receive an average rebate check of $624 from the state. In Montclair, where the average home is assessed at $247,000, the average rebate check would amount to $778.
Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, said that local school district officials were likely to embrace the plan because it would not adversely affect their budgets. "Our position has always been that the state has to increase its share of public school spending if we are going to have true property tax relief," he said. "This is a direct approach."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Residential Property Shows Loss in Value

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Manhattan residential real estate prices dipped in the fourth quarter -- the first decline in more than a year -- amid concern about the stock market, according to a study by Halstead Property Company.
The average price per room for Halstead's Manhattan Index of residential properties below 96th Street fell 2 percent to $158,601 in the quarter that ended Dec. 31. The price per room in the Silk Stocking section of Manhattan, which the company defines as Fifth Avenue, Central Park West and Park Avenue, fell 1.4 percent to $322,665, the company said. 
 "The stock market volatility at the end of the third quarter had buyers thinking the great bull market in property values was coming to an end," said Clark Halstead, founder of the New York-based real estate brokerage. "With economic indicators actually stronger than they've been in a year or so, we're likely to have a robust year through this winter."
Mr. Halstead said the fourth-quarter numbers reflected a delayed response to the stock market rout in the third quarter, when the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 10 percent. The index has since recovered, rising 21 percent in the fourth quarter.
Over all, 1998 was a good year for residential real estate in Manhattan. The average price per room rose 16 percent for the year. For the Silk Stocking district, the average price per room rose 13.5 percent.
Studio apartments witnessed the greatest price appreciation, rising 21 percent in the year.
At the end of 1998, the most expensive residential real estate in Manhattan was Fifth Avenue, at $404,669 per room.

HEADLINE: Where Indulgence Grows on Trees

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

DATELINE: HILO, Hawaii

 BODY:
THE coast of Hawaii's Big Island is dotted with groves of stately trees, their shiny, dark green leaves forming shady canopies over the rich volcanic soil. They stand in lush contrast to the white-capped blue waters of the Pacific. From late fall to early winter, these trees, descendants of a species imported from Australia in the 1870's as an ornamental, produce graceful sprays of white blossoms that have a gentle perfume, like privet hedges in bloom.
But the trees give off much more than shade and fragrance: from July through January they yield macadamias, the world's richest tasting, most expensive nut, a food as closely associated with Hawaii as the pineapple. The discovery that the trees were more than just ornamental had to be sheer happenstance, because the luxury they produce is one hard nut to crack. Still, once the secret was out, every effort was made to turn the trees into tidy profit centers. 
 It took a long, long time. And now, growers are worried that macadamia farms, like sugar cane and pineapple plantations before them, are facing demise. Until the early 1990's macadamia acreage was expanding into farmland that had once grown those earlier crops. Today the acreage, much of it between Hilo and Kailua-Kona, is either static or in slight decline, depending on whom you ask.
Macadamia nuts -- macnuts to Hawaiians -- do not share the American culinary tradition of walnuts or pecans. It was not until the 1920's that anyone tried to raise them commercially in Hawaii. Mainland America didn't really hear about them until the 1970's, and that was mostly by word of mouth, after visitors to Hawaii discovered the macadamias' charms and brought them home as gifts.
Their cachet reached its peak in the 1980's when John Hillerman, who acted in the television series "Magnum, P.I.," became a spokesman for Mauna Loa, the state's largest grower and processor: "Mauna Loa macadamia nuts -- almost too good to share."
Maybe chefs took that motto to heart; they are not as freewheeling with macadamias as they are with other nuts. What appeals to them about macadamias is not so much the subtle flavor, which is at its best when the nuts are not lost in a tangle of competing ingredients, but the texture, the crunchiness, the butteriness.
At his restaurants in Honolulu, Sam Choy uses crushed macadamias in dozens of dishes, including baked Brie and as breading for chicken. Michel Richard of Citronelle in Washington likes them in pies. In Manhattan, Claudia Fleming, the pastry chef at Gramercy Tavern, serves a macadamia nut tartlet with roasted pineapple and vanilla rum ice cream, while Florian Bellanger of Le Bernardin combines them with pistachios and pecans in a pineapple crumble.
But mostly, macadamia nuts are eaten as an extravagant snack -- on their own, in cookies, coated with milk or dark chocolate, in nut brittle and truffles, honey roasted and flavored with Maui onion or garlic. Yet, they remain a relatively exotic ingredient.
Outside Hawaii, few Americans would even recognize a macadamia in its shell -- the nut resembles a rock-hard malted-milk ball. Today, Hawaii, with 700 farms on 20,200 acres, produces 99 percent of the macadamia nuts grown in the United States (California produces the rest); last year 65 million pounds were harvested.
Macadamias can be found in almost any large supermarket, but they are usually a special-occasion purchase because they have two strikes against them: their price and their richness. Richard Vidgen, the president of Macfarms of Hawaii, the second-largest grower and processor, is well aware of that problem.
"After enough people said, 'They are my favorite nut; they are terribly expensive; they are terribly fattening,' I realized we had an image problem," he said. "People thought the nuts were sinful."
Hawaiian growers have been working to improve the nutritional image for several years, capitalizing on the increasing awareness that not all fat is bad fat. Much to their chagrin, though, growers in other countries have been working to reduce the price, to the point where Hawaiians have lost their lock on the market as foreign nuts undercut them.
It took Australia more than a century to realize the profitability of its native tree, but over the last 10 years it has become a major exporter, especially to Southeast Asia. South Africa, China, Malaysia, Guatemala, Brazil and other countries have also been cashing in.
Between 1992 and 1997, Hawaii's 50 percent share of the world market declined to 36 percent, while Australia's share rose to 38 percent, from 27 percent. Since the market in Southeast Asia collapsed, amid the Asian economic troubles, Australian growers have been selling their nuts in the United States below the price of Hawaiian nuts. Some island growers fear they may go out of business.
Hawaiians naturally insist their nuts are the best -- "the beluga of macadamia nuts," said Richard Schnitzler, the president of the Hamakua Macadamia Nut Company in Kailua-Kona. Many Hawaiian chefs agree, and after tasting nuts from Australia and Malaysia, so do I. But most consumers from the American mainland to Europe and Asia don't know a Hawaiian macadamia nut from a Guatemalan and don't care. And that is not good for growers in Hawaii.
"We thought it was glamorous in 1985 to grow macadamia nuts," said Midge Mebane, who with her husband, John, is one of the many small growers. Six of their 12 acres overlooking Hilo are planted with macadamia trees because the agricultural use of the land gives them a large tax break.
"Otherwise, it would have been prohibitive," said Mrs. Mebane, a disarmingly direct woman, who moved from Pennsylvania with her husband 27 years ago.
"When we started, the price of macadamia nuts was 92 cents a pound, but now it's 50 cents a pound," she said. "I did not envision the costs. Our trees are now 11 years old, and we are sort of breaking even. I thought it was a good investment, but we really haven't made any money because we have to bring in so many people to pick."
Like most small growers, the Mebanes have another source of income: John Mebane is a physician in Hilo.
The road from tree to table is long and complicated. A grower who plants a tree has to wait seven years before it will produce enough nuts to sell; it will not be profitable for five to eight more years.
The trees, which grow to 30 feet, were originally described scientifically in the mid-19th century by an Australian botanist, Baron Ferdinand von Mueller, who named them in honor of a friend, Dr. John Macadam. In 1921, the first macadamia plantation was started near Honolulu, but it was not very successful. It took 20 years of research to select and graft the varieties that reliably produce a desirable nut.
Today, there are seven varieties grown at different elevations in various climates, almost all of them on the Big Island. Macadamia trees live 45 or 50 years, although some are at least 110 and still fruitful.
Once the rock-hard nuts are ripe, they still have to be shelled, which growers used to do by laying a board over them, then running a car over that. Unlike other nuts, which are picked at one time of the year, macadamias ripen in waves and have to be harvested five or six times.
Growers wait until they fall to the ground in their green husks, then gather them either mechanically or by hand. Mrs. Mebane described the latter method as "an amazing sight."
"The pickers walk around on kneepads for hours at a time," she said. They also have to be sure to get to the nuts ahead of the rats and wild pigs, which figured out how to crack them long before humans did.
At the processing plants, each load of nuts is weighed and then husked, sorted, washed and put in air drying tanks. The shells are removed mechanically, in a crusher using 300 pounds of pressure per square inch. The meats are sorted first by machines, then by humans. The last steps are dry-roasting and grading. The larger the nut, the higher the grade.
Along with Mauna Loa and Macfarms, Island Princess and Hamakua Macadamia Nut Farms account for 80 percent of the nuts grown in Hawaii. Most of the other farms are small; only 200 farms are 20 acres or more.
"There are people with only two trees who call themselves growers," said David Rietow, the president of the Hawaiian Macadamia Nut Association, whose membership produces most of the nuts grown in Hawaii. "We call them shade-tree growers." Only 10 percent of these small growers farm full time.
Like many growers, Yoshitaka Takashiba has acreage in both coffee and nuts on the coast near Kona. Born and raised on a coffee farm, Mr. Takashiba, who is 85 and still drives a tractor, was a macadamia pioneer in the 1970's. "At that time there weren't too many buyers," he said. "But I made better money than farmers who had coffee."
The father of three daughters, Mr. Takashiba, who may be slow of foot but is quick of wit, said, "When the girls left home, they vowed they would never come back because I abused them." Read: They had to do farm chores.
Now that he is older and his children do his tax returns, he said, they know how much his land is worth and have told him not to sell it, because they are coming back. Like many farmers, his riches are in land, land that others want to turn into housing tracts.
Mr. Vidgen, of Macfarms, is optimistic about the competition Hawaiian growers face.
"We can overcome higher labor costs by being smarter with technology," he said. "Land costs are not that high. We get yields similar to Australia but higher than other countries. We'll keep coming up with new ideas."
One way has been to try to improve the "too fattening" image of macadamias, which contain 200 calories and 19 grams of fat per ounce, while an ounce of pecans has 167 calories and 15 grams of fat. Peanuts have slightly less.
But much of the scientific research sponsored by the International Tree Nut Council has been directed at proving that nuts in general are beneficial for health because they contain the "good" kinds of fat, mono unsaturated or polyunsaturated. Several recent studies suggest that nuts help reduce "bad" cholesterol. To reinforce a more healthful image, Macfarms sponsors an Ironman triathlete from Hawaii.
The costly image is harder to battle, especially when labels don't distiguish between Hawaiian and Australian macadamias. Even Rocco Damato, whose company, A. L. Bazzini in New York, has been selling nuts since 1886, says he would have a hard time telling the two apart. He usually sells Australian, but sometimes Hawaiian or Costa Rican.
One of his clients, Bill Yosses, the pastry chef at Bouley Bakery, had no idea where the nuts he uses in a dacquoise come from.
He assumed they were Hawaiian.
As recently as the late the 1980's, he would have been right. "Eight or 10 years ago prices were so good we felt we had it made," said Sotero Agoot, the director of Kona Pacific Farmers Cooperative in Captain Cook. "We quit advertising; we quit marketing. We've dropped the ball."
 
The Proof Is in the Tasting
 AFTER sampling macadamia nuts from Hawaii, Malaysia and Australia, I'll go along with the Hawaiians, who think theirs are best.
The Hawaiian nuts had a subtle, sweet taste. The ones from Malaysia were rancid. Two samplings of Australian nuts provided different results: one bag was slightly rancid; the other was good, but still not as sweet or as full-flavored as the Hawaiian nuts. They were almost as crunchy but a trifle oilier.
When Florian Bellanger, the pastry chef at Le Bernardin, tasted Australian and Hawaiian macadamias side by side, he, too, preferred the Hawaiian.
So how can you be sure you are getting Hawaiian nuts? It's difficult. If the label on the can says "product of Hawaii" or "Hawaiian grown," chances are fairly good, though not 100 percent, that they will be Hawaiian. If there is nothing on the label -- even if the packaging looks as if it comes from Hawaii -- there is absolutely no way to be sure.
When buying nuts in bulk you have to trust what the store people tell you, if in fact they know. Be sure to sample one before purchasing.
At Balducci's, Dean & DeLuca, Eli's Manhattan, Eli's Vinegar Factory and Grace's Marketplace, the unsalted macadamia nuts are usually from Australia, sometimes from Costa Rica and sometimes from Hawaii. Prices vary. A pound of whole macadamia nuts is $13 at Dean & DeLuca and $10.95 at the Vinegar Factory. Cans of nuts in smaller amounts cost more.
You can buy excellent fresh unsalted Hawaiian macadamias by mail from Island Bakery and Grocery Supply. P.O. Box 1798, Kaunakakai, Hawaii 96748; (808) 567-6517; checks, money orders and Visa accepted. A pound of whole nuts is $8, halves are $7 and diced are $6 plus shipping by priority mail: $2 for one pound, but the more you buy, the cheaper the cost per pound. MARIAN BURROS
 
Making the Most of Macadamias
 MACADAMIA nuts are best used in cooking for their crunch and their rich butteriness rather than for their subtle flavor, which actually disappears when the nuts are mixed with too many other ingredients.
Crushed macadamias do make an excellent coating for rack of lamb, especially when combined with herbs de Provence, and for skinless chicken breasts, pork tenderloin and lean fish.
Substituting macadamia nuts for pecans in a pie brings out their flavor, as does a coating of a superb dark chocolate.
Toasting the nuts at 300 degrees until they are very lightly browned intensifies the flavor. If they get too brown, they lose their sweetness.
 
BAKED BRIE WITH MACADAMIA NUTS
Adapted from "Sam Choy's Island Flavors," by Sam Choy (Hyperion, 1999)
Time: 20 minutes plus 30 minutes chilling time
1/2 cup finely chopped toasted macadamia nuts
 1/2 cup panko (Japanese bread crumbs) or fine dry bread crumbs
1 tablespoon all-purpose flour
1 large egg, lightly beaten
2 small rounds of Brie, 4 1/2 ounces each (leave rind on)
Spicy mango chutney (see recipe)
Lavash, toasted pita or other crisp bread for garnish
1 apple, thinly sliced, for garnish.
 1. Combine the macadamia nuts and panko in a shallow dish. Place the flour in another shallow dish, and the beaten egg in a third.
2. Cut each round of Brie into quarters. Dip each piece first into the flour, turning to coat the cheese evenly, then into the egg, letting any excess drip away, and finally into the macadamia mixture, patting it on to help it adhere. Chill the cheese for 30 minutes.
3. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Put the cheese quarters in a baking pan, and bake for 10 minutes, or until the crust is golden brown. Transfer carefully to a platter, and serve hot with the chutney, lavash and apple slices.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
SPICY MANGO CHUTNEY
Time: 45 minutes
 
 1/2 cup packed dark brown sugar
2 tablespoons cider vinegar
2 teaspoons minced garlic
2 teaspoons minced fresh ginger
2 ripe mangoes, 1 pound each
 1/2 cup golden raisins
1 tablespoon fresh lime juice
2 teaspoons coarse-grain mustard
 1/4 teaspoon salt
 1/4 teaspoon hot Asian chili paste like sambal oelek.
1. In a medium saucepan, combine the sugar, vinegar, garlic and ginger, and simmer for 10 minutes. Meanwhile, peel the mangoes, and dice into 1/2-inch cubes.
2. Add the mango and remaining ingredients to the saucepan, and simmer for 20 minutes more. Let cool. The chutney can be refrigerated for up to 1 week. Bring to room temperature before serving.
Yield: 2 cups.
 
ROASTED PINEAPPLE CRUMBLE WITH MACADAMIA NUTS
Adapted from Florian Bellanger, Le Bernadin
Time: 1 hour 45 minutes
 
For the pineapple:
1 cup granulated sugar
 
1 vanilla bean, sliced lengthwise, seeds scraped
6 quarter-size slices fresh ginger ( 1/2 ounce)
5 whole cloves, chopped
 1/4 cup mashed banana ( 1/2 large banana)
2 tablespoons dark rum
1 fresh pineapple, peeled
 
For the topping:
 3/4 cup macadamia nuts (3 ounces)
1 heaping tablespoon pecans
1 tablespoon pistachio nuts
1 cup all-purpose flour
6 tablespoons unsalted butter, cold, cut into pieces
3 tablespoons packed dark brown sugar
3 tablespoons granulated sugar
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1/8 teaspoon ground cinnamon
 1/8 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg.
1. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. To prepare the pineapple, in a medium saucepan, combine the sugar, 1/4 cup hot water, the vanilla bean and scrapings, ginger and cloves. Stir the mixture over medium heat until the sugar dissolves. Increase the heat to medium-high, and cook the mixture until it is caramelized and dark golden brown, about 10 minutes.
2. Carefully add 1 1/4 cups hot water (the caramel will seize and bubble up, so stand back), banana and rum. Stir the mixture over low heat until the caramel is smooth.
3. Pour the caramel into a 9-by-9-by-2-inch pan. Add the pineapple, and roast it, turning it every 10 minutes, for a total of 50 minutes. Remove the pan to a wire rack, and let the pineapple cool in the caramel. Reduce the oven temperature to 350 degrees.
4. While the pineapple is roasting, prepare the topping. Place the nuts on a baking sheet with a rim, and toast them in the oven with the pineapple for 8 to 10 minutes, until pale golden brown. Reserve 18 macadamia nuts, then coarsely chop the rest of the nuts.
5. In the bowl of a mixer set with the paddle attachment, combine the flour, butter, brown sugar, granulated sugar, salt, cinnamon and nutmeg. Stir the mixture on low speed until it resembles pebbles (do not overmix). Add the chopped nuts, and briefly mix them in.
6. When the pineapple is cool enough to handle, cut two 1/2-inch-thick slices from it, and cut the slices into quarters. Reserve for garnish. Cut the remaining pineapple lengthwise into quarters, and cut away the core. Dice the pineapple into 1/2-inch cubes.
7. Divide the pineapple among six 8-ounce ramekins. Drizzle 1 tablespoon of the caramel over each. Top with the crumble mixture, filling the ramekins to the top.
8. Bake the ramekins for about 17 minutes, or until the tops are golden brown. Serve warm, garnished with the reserved macadamia nuts and pineapple slices.
Yield: 6 servings.

HEADLINE: Gavin Relly, 72, Dies; Helped End Apartheid

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Gavin W. H. Relly, the retired chairman of the Anglo American Corporation who in 1985 led a delegation of business leaders to meet the banned African National Congress in Zambia, died on Sunday in Hermanus, South Africa. He was 72.
The cause of death was complications of cardiac surgery, a spokeswoman for the company said. 
 Mr. Relly's meeting with exiled leaders of the congress was important in efforts to end apartheid and the world sanctions that were slowly strangling the economy. Anglo American, then as now, was the largest conglomerate in South Africa and at the time accounted for more than half the market capitalization of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.
Its eagerness to talk to the congress signaled that business here was tentatively willing to defy the white Government and pursue a negotiated transition to black power and majority rule. At the time the National Party Government was killing A.N.C. advocates at home and abroad.
Mr. Relly, following the lead of the Oppenheimer family, which founded Anglo American and its sister companies De Beers Consolidated Mines and Minorco, was a critic of apartheid and endorsed creating opportunities for black South Africans, who were barred by law from the better-paying mine jobs.
At the same time he could be a tough executive. Beginning in the 1970's the Oppenheimers and their companies favored recognizing black trade unions. But in 1987, when the National Union of Mineworkers struck Anglo, whose gold, diamond, platinum and coal mines employed nearly 40 percent of the miners here, Mr. Relly dismissed 20,000 workers. Some were later rehired.
His successor as chairman, Julian Ogilvie Thompson, noted this week that Mr. Relly had run Anglo's copper interests in Zambia from 1965 to 1970, building up a relationship with President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, who became the chief protector of the A.N.C. in exile. After that Mr. Relly worked for three years in Toronto as North American chief of Anglo.
"I think he brought back a clear understanding that South Africa was on the wrong course and ought to be on the right course," Mr. Thompson said.
After Nelson Mandela was released from prison in early 1990, Mr. Relly spent 40 minutes talking with him at his house in Soweto. In May 1990 the two led a joint business-A.N.C. conference on the economic shape of South Africa.
Mr. Relly had opposed sanctions in the apartheid era, arguing that they hurt blacks, as well as business, a view that the A.N.C. opposed. But Mr. Relly, who had watched Mr. Kaunda seize the company's rich copper mines and bleed them dry, also argued forcefully against nationalization as a means of redistributing wealth.
By 1994 the A.N.C. had dropped its socialist platform in favor of aggressive free-market capitalism, fiscal prudence and privatization as the engines of job creation.
Mr. Relly was born in Cape Town in 1926. He attended private schools there. In World War II he served with the South African Army in Italy. Like many Anglo executives, he then studied at Oxford.
After working for Sir de Villiers Graaff, leader of the opposition United Party, he joined Anglo American in 1949. He was private secretary to Harry Oppenheimer, the heir apparent, and then to the company founder, Sir Ernest Oppenheimer.
Mr. Relly helped develop gold mines so far south of Johannesburg that the company built a whole city, Welkom, to support. He oversaw the creation of the Highveld Steel and Vanadium subsidiary. After running other divisions at home and overseas, he succeeded Harry Oppenheimer as chairman in 1983 and retired in 1990.
He was a trustee of several South African universities, as well as a board member of the Worldwide Fund for Nature.
He is survived by his wife, Jane; three children, Janis, Georgina and Giles, and four grandsons.
