HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
What Will the Internet Economy Look Like?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Internet is the wonder of the era, the tool that is expected to change everything. On Wall Street, Internet stocks are superstars. Amazon.com, the bookseller, now trades for more than 50 times the price at which it went public in 1997. Ebay, an auction house, is valued at 13 times what investors paid four months ago.
These prices reflect huge amounts of money. Amazon.com is valued at around $26 billion, about the same as CBS and nearly three times as much as Federated Department Stores, the largest department store chain. Yahoo, the Internet search engine that went public almost three years ago, is valued at about $39 billion, nearly 100 times its valuation when it went public and more than Boeing or Anheuser-Busch.
There are two possible explanations for those valuations. The market might be telling us that economic activity will soon come to be dominated by the Internet. Or the market moves could be evidence of speculation gone wild, of a great bubble that will inevitably burst. Those two explanations are not mutually exclusive. The Internet could be all that its fans expect, and some stocks could still be ridiculously overvalued.
But what would the 21st-century economy look like if only the first explanation proves accurate?
Retail activity would increasingly be dominated by Internet sales, to an extent hard to imagine. Federal Express would be an immediate beneficiary, assuming that Star Trek technology -- "Beam me up, Scotty" -- will not be perfected for packages. But while its stock did well last year, FedEx has slipped a bit this year, even as Internet stocks have zoomed. While Amazon.com fell 12 percent yesterday, it is up 53 percent for 1999.
Deflation would be likely in the new Internet economy. It is much easier to compare prices on the Internet, a fact that will tend to force prices -- and profit margins -- down on items that are easily comparable. One of the wonders of the performance of Amazon.com is that it specializes in just such products. A book from one store is no different than a book from another.
To be sure, service will also count. Getting a great price on something that does not get delivered for months is hardly a bargain. Brand-name images of quality could, if anything, become more important in a world where shoppers cannot examine the item before buying.
Some stores no doubt will continue to prosper. Lettuce does not age well, so food stores are an obvious candidate. For clothes, where fit is important, many will prefer to shop where they can try on before buying. No one will want to wait for mail delivery of a new car battery.
But over all the demand for stores would fall, creating a glut of retail space and falling rents as Internet sales represent transactions not made in stores.
So far, the stock market does not seem to have anticipated that. While companies that own shopping malls have seen their stock prices slip a bit, the falls have been nowhere near the magnitude that would be expected in the Internet economy.
Nor has the market anticipated the economic dislocations that would come along with such a huge change. A recession could easily result just from the upheavals created by failing retailers and plunging commercial real estate values. To say the least, the overall level of stock prices now does not reflect a recession risk.
The most likely outcome is that the Internet will grow to be a much larger economic force than it now is, but that the stocks of Internet companies will nonetheless prove to be horrid investments for those who buy at current prices. Those who are buying do not really expect such an economy. They are just betting that this mania will not end soon.
There is a precedent. In the 1920's, the great speculative stock was Radio Corporation of America, which took six years to rise 100-fold, twice the time Yahoo required. As the bulls forecast, R.C.A. became a dominant player in an industry that revolutionized American life. But those who bought the stock in 1929 still lost nearly all the money they invested.

HEADLINE: U.S. and China Discuss Human Rights

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that she is very disturbed by the crackdown on pro-democracy activists in China but that the administration must seek cooperation with China on strategic and other issues.
She spoke during a photo session with the Argentine Foreign Minister, Guido di Tella, as American and Chinese officials were holding a second and final day of talks on human rights issues. 
 Ms. Albright alluded to the increasing number of Chinese dissidents arrested in recent weeks.
She expressed concern about the trend and said Assistant Secretary of State Harold Koh was raising the issue with the Chinese delegation. But she said she expected Prime Minister Zhu Rongi of China to visit Washington this spring as planned.
"We expect the Prime Minister's visit to deal with very important issues that we have in the area of economic issues as well as the strategic dialogue," she said.
On Monday, the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said that during the human rights talks, Mr. Koh planned to encourage the Chinese to ratify and abide by the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
China signed the covenant last fall. Critics charge that repression has increased since then.

HEADLINE: Issue du Jour at Microsoft Trial: Are Consumers Harmed?

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
An economist testifying for the Government conceded today that there was scant evidence consumers had been harmed by practices that are central to the Justice Department's antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation.
In antitrust doctrine, the damage to consumers from anticompetitive conduct is generally measured in higher prices and fewer choices of products. When asked whether consumers were being harmed by Microsoft's practices in the Internet software market, Franklin M. Fisher, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, replied that the question was difficult to answer. But after hesitating for a moment, he added, "On balance, I'd think that the answer is no, up to this point." 
Microsoft quickly seized on the comment by Mr. Fisher, the last Government witness, as support for the contention that the Justice Department and 19 states suing the company have been unable to show that consumers are being damaged by Microsoft's actions. William H. Neukom, the senior vice president for law and corporate affairs, said the Government's case was inspired by Microsoft competitors and based on the "raw speculation" that consumers might be harmed in some distant future if the company was not reined in.
But the Justice Department argues that it is sound public policy to intervene early in fast-moving high-technology industries when the predatory acts of a monopolist threaten to stifle innovation and consumer welfare in the long run -- and such, it contends, is the case with Microsoft.
With the prosecution case about to close, Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division, appeared on the courthouse steps today to declare that the Government had presented "compelling evidence that Microsoft has engaged in a pattern of practices to crush any threat to its operating system monopoly."
The Government says that Microsoft bundled its Internet browser with its industry-standard Windows operating system, gave the browser away and unfairly used its market power to force personal computer makers and Internet service suppliers to agree to anticompetitive contracts. All this was done, the Government asserts, to thwart the challenge posed to Microsoft's dominance of the software industry by rivals led by the Netscape Communications Corporation, the early leader in browsing software, and Sun Microsystems Inc., creator of Java, an Internet programming language.
Microsoft replies that its contracts are routine business deals and that its product decisions have been guided mainly by its desire to improve its Windows operating system.
Mr. Fisher was still on the stand as court recessed today, even though the written testimony of the first defense witness for Microsoft was released Monday. That witness is Richard L. Schmalensee, an economist who is dean of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management. To speed up the trial, the court decided that the direct testimony of witnesses should be submitted in written form and released the afternoon before the witness is expected to take the stand for cross-examination.
In the afternoon, Mr. Fisher elaborated on his earlier remark about the effect of Microsoft's practices on consumers. He said consumers might suffer now from reduced choice because Microsoft's contracts make it more difficult for a rival's software to be distributed.
Still, the real problem, he argued, lies in the future, because Microsoft's monopoly in operating systems -- its Windows is shipped with 90 percent of all computers sold -- makes it a de facto gatekeeper on new technology in the personal computer market.
"Microsoft has shown that it will decide how innovation takes place in this industry," Mr. Fisher testified. The lesson from examining Microsoft's conduct in the browser market, he said, is that rivals "will be squashed."
Then, Mr. Fisher testified, "I don't think that's good for consumers, but those effects have only just begun."
The difficult-to-measure danger, he said, is largely prospective. "It won't be a consumer-driven society," Mr. Fisher declared. "It will be a Microsoft-driven society."
Under questioning from David Boies, the Justice Department's lead trial lawyer, Mr. Fisher sought to explain what some economists regard as an unanswered question in the Government's case: why the price of Windows is not higher.
Mr. Fisher replied that Microsoft was taking its "monopoly profits" not solely from the pricing of Windows but also from increased sales of Microsoft products that run on the Windows operating system -- its Office suite of business software, including word processing and spreadsheets, for example. The Windows pricing, he added, can also be explained as a discount to increase sales and thus strengthen the Microsoft monopoly.
At one point, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson interrupted to ask whether it was a "valid concept" that a monopolist might logically pursue a pricing strategy of "delayed gratification" to maximize its long-run gains.
"Oh, I think so," Mr. Fisher replied.
The Government will begin its cross-examination of Mr. Schmalensee, the lead-off defense witness, on Wednesday, a day later than anticipated.
Before it rests its case, the Government plans to introduce further excerpts from deposition testimony by William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, and several other industry executives as supporting evidence that Microsoft planned and executed a strategy to thwart competition.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: State Politics With a National Spin

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 12

 BODY:
The Texas Legislature, which meets every other year for only 140 days, cranked up for business today with the prospect of a particularly lively stretch, even by Texas standards, of political theater.
Legislators assembled beneath the pink granite Capitol dome and were faced not only with a deliciously tempting budget surplus but also an extremely popular Republican Governor who, many believe, has a reasonable chance of becoming the country's next President. Even the outgoing Lieutenant Governor, Bob Bullock, a Democrat, introduced Gov. George W. Bush to the legislators today as "the future President of the United States." 
 Texas is far from alone in having a budget surplus. Building on a strong economy and a steady migration off the welfare rolls, states from the Atlantic to the Pacific find themselves with coffers bulging. The National Conference of State Legislators figures that state budgets are in their best shape since 1980.
How Texas may be different is that the struggle over what to do with that money -- how much will go to tax cuts and how much to education, as the argument has nearly always broken down when states have had surpluses in recent years -- will be played out through the prism of a Presidential campaign. And as Governors like Ronald Reagan, Michael S. Dukakis and Bill Clinton discovered, actions taken at the statehouse level can cast a disproportionately large shadow when refracted onto the national stage.
"I have not decided if I'm running yet; I'm still thinking about it," Governor Bush said this morning, sipping coffee and trying to shake the flu before his inaugural address next Tuesday. One foot was resting on the edge of his desk in the south wing of the Capitol, a working copy of the address on top of the stack of papers before him.
Yes, he said, he understands that the shadow of his potential Presidential bid will color much of what happens in Austin this spring. But rather than trying to calculate how to capitalize on it, he insists he is more concerned with minimizing the disruption.
"I ask myself, Will it disrupt the session?" Governor Bush said. "It will only disrupt the session if I'm not around, if the head of the appropriations committee wants to come meet with me and I'm off somewhere campaigning. So that's not going to happen."
The session is likely to end sometime in May, and he may well make his decision about the Presidency before then. But whatever the decision, the Governor said, he will not campaign until the session has ended.
"I'm not saying I'm not going to leave the state, but I'm not going to be campaigning," he said. "I'm going to stay here and get the job done."
Mr. Bush sometimes deflects questions about national issues by saying, as he did today, that he has no opinion to offer because "I'm not running for national office." But some national issues he does not mind talking about.
He was particularly glad, he said, to see Republican and Democratic senators standing side by side last week to announce their compromise on the handling of President Clinton's impeachment trial.
"First and foremost, the Senate has got to fulfill its duty, and they seem to be doing that in a very serious and proper way," he said.
The President's actions must be accounted for, he said, because the country will not be able to get out of its sex-and-scandal morass "as long as the current embarrassment is still on the national scene."
But he is not optimistic that, even if the trial is handled fairly and fully, the country and its elected leaders will immediately move on.
"I doubt it," the Governor said. "It's a cynical world. This will just be step one."
What is needed, he said, is a way to break the cycle of charges and counter charges involving sexual indiscretions and other tabloid topics.
"I think it's time for everyone to take a step back and say, Is this really what we want to put our country through?" the Governor said.
Several state legislators gathering today in the Capitol said they thought a potential Bush Presidential bid would have a marked effect on the outcome of the session, as political opponents try to make the Governor stumble or saddle him with a political albatross or as supporters bend over backward to provide him with a strong springboard for national office.
"I think a lot of people are interested in making the Governor look good," said Senator Bill Ratliff, a Republican from Mount Pleasant.
Last year, when Governor Bush was running for re-election, a race that he won handily, he and other statewide candidates made promises based on a projected budget surplus of $6.3 billion. Revised estimates place the surplus at $5.6 billion, so the Governor said some of those promises may have to be trimmed.
The problem, Mr. Ratliff said, is that the candidates raised expectations too high. A significant chunk of that $5.6 billion -- about $3.3 billion -- will need to pay for the 70,000 new public school students who arrive in Texas every year, before the remainder can be allocated for new programs or tax cuts.
"If you say it real fast, $2 billion sounds like a lot of money, but when you talk about a state the size of Texas, that's not as much money as you might think," Mr. Ratliff said.
Other potentially contentious subjects in the session include utility deregulation, school vouchers and limits on suburban expansion. But most in the Capitol said they thought the argument over the budget surplus would dominate the discussion.
"This will be a budget session," Governor Bush said. "And what happens when you have this kind of a budget, with a surplus, is that people start putting together a wish list. But there's not enough money to make everyone's wish come true."
In the campaign last year, he proposed sending $1 billion back to local school districts, with the "hope it goes for teachers salaries." Some opponents now are pushing for a direct, state-mandated raise.
"There is a suspicion in some people's minds that the money will turn into Astroturf and administrators' salaries," said Senator Teel Bivins, an Amarillo Republican and the new president pro tempore of the Senate.
Nevertheless, the Governor said, he does not want to bypass the local districts.
Mr. Bush said he also wanted to commit $200 million to help pay for the construction of new schools and for new textbooks and programs to fulfill his goal of teaching every child to read by the third grade.
While some are pushing for a drop in the state's 6.25 percent sales tax, Mr. Bush said he was more interested in property tax cuts (he advocated $2 billion for that during the election), state incentives for research and development, tax cuts for small businesses and an end to sales taxes for diapers and over-the-counter medications.
Despite the lower surplus projections, Mr. Bush said he thought there would be enough to address all of these promises, but maybe with less money.
"I got elected on the basis of a tax cut," he said, although "all of the numbers I campaigned on may need to change."
The lower surplus projections should be taken as a warning, he said, that perhaps the state's economy is not as strong as some had hoped.
"My feeling is that in times of plenty, we should not overspend," he said. "We should do a few things and do them well. We need to stay focused. This is no time to create a lot of government programs."
The Governor said his inaugural speech next week would not be "a long-winded affair." He will try to use it to set the tone for his second term rather than offer specific proposals. That can wait for his State of the State speech to legislators later this month, he said.
"I think my tone will be just about the same as it was in my first inaugural address: optimistic and upbeat," Mr. Bush said. "What I am looking forward to is remembering this inauguration. The last one went by so fast it was kind of a blur."

HEADLINE: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS;
For Bronco Fever, Treatment Is Sunday

BYLINE: By CHARLIE NOBLES 

DATELINE: DENVER, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Todd Tilghman is just starting to get his voice back. The Denver real estate broker says he went overboard last Saturday cheering as the Broncos overwhelmed the Miami Dolphins.
"The day after the game, people thought I was sick," Tilghman said. "They said, 'What's wrong with you?' I said, 'Broncos fever.' I can't wait till Sunday." 
 Terri Reid, a bartender at the Denver Chop House and Brewery, a popular hangout for Broncos players, is also particularly excited about Sunday's American Football Conference championship game between the Broncos and the Jets. Monday night a co-worker whose wife works for the Broncos came through with two tickets to the game.
"I've been a Broncos fan since I was 5 years old, when my father sat me in front of the television and told me about football," Reid said. "I feel so lucky to have gotten tickets."
And well she should. The 2,700 tickets not swallowed up by season ticket-holders disappeared in six minutes on Sunday, according to the Broncos publicist Jim Saccomano.
That means the Broncos will have their 232d straight nonstrike sellout at Mile High Stadium. Two replacement games during the 1987 strike are the only blips on Denver's attendance screen.
Mayor Wellington Webb will be at Mile High. He describes himself as an avid Broncos fan.
"There's probably a dent in the hotel room credenza where the TV happened to be when I was watching that regular-season game against Miami," he said today, referring to Denver's 31-21 defeat in Miami on Dec. 21.
Webb likes to think he is part of a new, winning regime here.
"Last year the Mayor of Green Bay called to remind me that we'd lost two Super Bowls," Webb said. "I told him I wasn't Mayor then."
The Barrel Man will undoubtedly be taking some bows of his own for the Broncos' success. He shows up in the south stands at Mile High, where the rowdies sit, wearing only an orange barrel. He stokes the fans around him with his yells and gestures, a visible symbol of Bronco Mania.
After a pause to reflect on Denver's crush on the team, Webb said: "We're a smaller city, but we have a first-class team and first-class people. We have a lot to be thankful for."
The Jets' presence in this game, compounded by the distinct possibility that this could be John Elway's final home game after 17 seasons as Denver's quarterback, has increased the premium some people are willing to pay for tickets.
"In the 13 years I've been here, this is the biggest I've ever seen it," a ticket broker named Steve, who declined to give his surname, said at Center Stage, a company in Englewood, Colo. "The demand is crazy."
All that demand and all those fans figure to rattle the girders. "There was a consistency to the loudness for the whole game last week," said Steve Antonopulos, the Broncos' trainer for 23 years. "But I think Sunday could be even louder."
Denver embraces all its professional teams, except perhaps the hapless Nuggets in basketball. But the Broncos enjoy a special distinction. Almost everywhere you go, the Broncos are visible. On clothing. On cars. On storefronts.
"The fact we've won one Super Bowl and have the potential of winning another one right away has made this city just electric," said Andrew Hudson, the Mayor's press liaison. "And there's a lot more about the dynamic of the city that lends itself to that. When you talk about how well things are going in the city, from employment to the economy, an overall sense of satisfaction and opportunity, the Broncos just play right into that."
In response to a question, Hudson said he did not know how many transplanted New Yorkers were living here. Nor, he said, did he particularly care. "Five is too many," Hudson said. Then he chuckled softly. "Just kidding."
Webb, voicing the confidence of a defending Super Bowl champion city, said, "The only celebration we'd have is after winning the Super Bowl."
"Anything less," the Mayor said, "would mean we didn't complete our agenda."

PUB-DATE: January 13, 1999

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 880 words

HEADLINE: Beware of the Kyoto Compromise

BYLINE: By Jack Kemp and Fred L. Smith Jr.; Jack Kemp is a co-director of Empower America. Fred L. Smith Jr. is president of the Competitive Enterprise Institute.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In November the Clinton Administration signed a treaty, negotiated in Kyoto, Japan, that purports to temper "global warming" by imposing a schedule of emissions reductions on so-called greenhouse gases. The action was widely regarded as a public relations move, pure and simple, because the Senate has voted overwhelmingly -- 95 to 0 -- to reject the treaty as written.
But if there is no chance of the treaty's protocols going into effect, why are large blocs of corporate America booking seats on the Kyoto Express? The explanation is that they are being seduced by the promise of getting credits for any reductions in emissions they achieve before the Kyoto treaty would take effect in 2008, and in some cases for reductions already achieved. 
 For some companies, the emissions credits earned now could be applied against the strict limits they would face later. And corporations able to make even deeper cuts in emissions now could sell their surplus credits for billions of dollars under a trading system that the Clinton Administration wants to set up. Some large utilities, for example, would benefit, while the petroleum industry would be hurt.
The emissions-credit plan is the brainchild of John Chafee of Rhode Island, the leading Republican environmentalist in the Senate, who worked with Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut, a Democrat, and Senator Connie Mack of Florida, a Republican.
These three Senators, honorable men all, seem to believe they have found a "third way" between pro-Kyoto and anti-Kyoto forces.
The stated rationale for their approach is clear enough. Awarding early credits to companies that reduce emissions might encourage a trend toward cutting back on greenhouse gas production. This would win points with the global warming crowd. And the plan also looks attractive to industries, which would find it advantageous to reduce in advance the long-term costs of the Kyoto treaty, or some domestic version of it, and to secure some tangible gain in return.
As usual, though, there is no real third way. Proposals like the one introduced by Senator Chafee and his colleagues will inevitably divide the business community between winners, who can achieve large windfalls, and losers, who will face the full brunt of any emissions controls. The result will be to push the pendulum toward a plan closer to that drawn up in Kyoto.
Unfortunately, this dynamic of giving special breaks to individual companies is all too familiar. It explains why, for example, we have a Federal tax code with rates much higher than they need to be, but with many exemptions, privileges and special rules accorded to favored industries and activities in the form of credits, deductions, exclusions from income and the like.
It represents a cynical bargain between big business and the Federal Government, with the corporations acceding to unreasonably high rates in exchange for special benefits. In 1996, the National Commission on Economic Growth and Tax Reform, also known as the Kemp Commission, a private organization created at the request of then Senator Bob Dole and House Speaker Newt Gingrich, found that "the history of our tax code, in economic terms, mirrors the course of most addictions: advancing dependence, diminished returns and deteriorating health of the afflicted."
The Kyoto treaty and its progeny portend a repetition of that experience, only on a global scale. The treaty would create a vast array of bureaucrats, at home and abroad, who would employ vague standards, arbitrary conditions and dubious science to allocate economic rights and privileges.
Bad as the existing tax system is, most of us agree the Government must have some mechanism for raising revenue. But it's not clear at all that we need any regulatory structure for limiting "greenhouse gases," so shaky is the science on which the treaty is based. There is little hard evidence that internationally enforceable emissions limits, implicitly intended to wean us away from use of fossil fuels, will actually slow global warming.
What is more, the Kyoto treaty has not yet devised clear-cut rules governing emissions trading. They are still being negotiated.
The Kyoto treaty is unlikely to be approved by the Senate because control over much of the American economy would be forfeited to international bureaucrats. It would also impose huge new costs on that same economy and cost jobs. This would have the result of transferring wealth from country to country, industry to industry and company to company. The accord's strictures would apply to developed nations but not, conspicuously, to developing nations like China and Paraguay.
Ceding power to unelected global authorities would be a hard sell, even if the science behind Kyoto were compelling. Surrendering power on that scale for the sake of a vague, arbitrary promise of modest financial relief doesn't make sense for any American business.
We must therefore guard against a milder version of the Kyoto treaty that would serve the same purpose, offering concessions to companies that acquiesce in creating the biggest global regulatory regime yet conceived.
Let's not put a more appealing face on a treaty that cannot possibly help our economy and is likely to do it immense harm.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 4510 words

HEADLINE: For New York, 25-Year Losing Streak

SERIES: DROPPING THE BALL: The Decline Of School Sports -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Hipolito Burgos, a 17-year-old senior at Queens Vocational High School, is an immigrant from the Dominican Republic, co-captain of his school's baseball team and an all-round threat as a catcher, outfielder and batter.
And he's a good man with a bilge pump, said his coach, Rob Schimenz. That's an important skill for a ballplayer at Queens Vocational. The team's home field, at a public park about two miles from the school, takes on water like a leaky barge because of a pronounced depression near second base. Shovels, rakes and pumps -- along with bats and balls -- are part of the team's equipment, and making the field playable before games has become part of a captain's job. 
 "This is the hand you're dealt, you try and keep a positive attitude, you try to work with it and the kids," Mr. Schimenz said of his school's sports program, which has no gymnasium, no athletic fields of its own, no money at all for uniforms, and not much more for equipment. Mr. Schimenz even paid for the bilge pump himself. "I don't know what the baseball budget is because I don't have one," he said.
Organizing high school sports in a city like New York -- a crowded concrete landscape -- has never been easy. But for most of this century, the idea of high school sports at least had a firm place in the roster of what public schools were meant to do. Funds were sufficient, if not lavish. Schools like Erasmus Hall in Brooklyn and DeWitt Clinton in the Bronx were nationally recognized powerhouses and vibrant, vital local institutions.
But over the last quarter century, public school sports in the city, and the physical education programs that helped underpin them, have been devalued and cast adrift.
Budgets for sports programs were slashed in the 1970's and were never fully restored; sports facilities, from football fields to basketball gyms, decayed along with many of the rest of the city's school buildings and then always seemed to become the last priority for repair; physical education classes were cut in half in the early 1990's at most schools; demands by the teachers union that coaches be fairly compensated for the many hours they worked led school administrators to control costs by cutting sports. Concerns about legal liability cast a shadow of caution, from the Board of Education down, about physical activity and its inherent risks of injury.
Indeed, interviews with more than 200 current and former coaches, teachers, administrators and students, as well as an examination of 25 years of school system budgets and staffing levels, lay bare what happened: at a time when medicine and sociology were establishing as never before the benefits of physical activity for young people and as obsession with sports was growing across much of the rest of America, the nation's largest public school system all but walked off the field.
Today, despite modest spending increases in the last few years, the city's public high school system offers only a handful of teams for freshmen, provides schools with no money for uniforms, asks varsity football and other coaches to run their programs on budgets of $100, and does not give any school -- from elementary through high school -- a dime for gym equipment. For the 40,000 students who play a sport in a New York high school -- about one in eight -- athletics has become an extra, lumped with all the other categories of experience that would be nice to offer in a perfect world, but that cannot be maintained in this one.
 
A Long Decline
Political Expedience And Parental Apathy
 The 25-year decline and disinvestment in public high school sports happened because politicians either did not pay attention or looked away, as the lesson was absorbed that, because parents and educators rarely objected, there was a minimal political price. The city's 1970's fiscal crisis sapped will and material. Pressure to improve academic performance and reduce overcrowding swallowed resources in the 1980's and 1990's, with other programs such as art and music diminished or erased along with sports. A new policy that allowed students to travel across the city to the high schools of their choosing undermined the concept of the local high school -- and its sports teams -- as the anchors of a neighborhood.
And the apathy of parents matched that of the politicians. Attendance at games and meets, which once helped to pay for sports programs and to reinforce their importance, has all but collapsed. National education experts say that school sports in many major urban centers have struggled to survive, but that in New York both the dimensions and consequences of the decline were magnified by the huge size of the school system, the vast gulfs of wealth and poverty between neighborhoods and the many athletic traditions that were fostered or invented here in years past.
"What we used to consider the standard for school sports is now nostalgic," said Frank J. Macchiarola, who was New York City Schools Chancellor from 1978 to 1983, and who was credited then with trying to rebuild the athletics program. "I don't think the city has the commitment anymore."
It is not easy to precisely measure the consequences of the school system's diminished interest in providing quality sports programs. But educators, coaches, parents and students say the results range from missed opportunities for college athletic scholarships to poorer general health of students to the loss of an educational tool for teaching self-esteem and teamwork to the erosion of what many once saw as a bridge that could connect young people divided by race and income and culture.
"I think that in many cases that road was very shortsighted," said Rudy Crew, who took over as the New York City Schools Chancellor in late 1995 and who has restored some financing to the sports programs since then. Dr. Crew said he believed the damage from the years of budget cuts and the resulting decline in facilities and commitment was largely invisible, and irreparable, measured in the lives of students who passed through the system untouched by the benefits that athletic activity can bring. "We lost a lot of kids," he said.
The picture of public high school sports is grim when compared to much of the rest of the nation:
*In the 1990's, as enrollment in the school system surged, spending on extracurricular sports in New York City high schools fell by more than 19 percent, according to the New York State Department of Education, from $10.8 million in 1989-90, in inflation-adjusted dollars, to $8.7 million last year. New York spent more for interscholastic high school sports in the 1974-75 school year, when the city was on the brink of bankruptcy -- about $9.1 million -- than it did last year at the height of an economic boom, the state said.
*The city spends less per pupil on extracurricular athletics than other major cities in New York or around the nation. The amount provided to schools for sports materials, equipment and supplies has also fallen sharply -- down more than 29 percent since 1974, according to state figures -- compounded by a dramatic increase in the number of high schools and new teams, especially for girls. School teams now get an average of about $100 for a whole school year -- or about the price of a single new football helmet. And unlike their counterparts in many large cities in the nation, or in New York's suburbs, teams get nothing at all for uniforms or transportation.
*The percentage of New York high school students participating in a sport is now at the very bottom among the nation's largest cities, according to a 1997 survey by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. Of the 15 cities surveyed, New York was tied with Miami for the lowest rate of sports participation.
*Physical education efforts have been decimated. System wide there were fewer than two gym teachers for every 1000 students in kindergarten through 12th grade in New York City last year, according to analysis by The New York Times, using state data. That is less than half as many gym teachers, measured against enrollment, as schools have in Westchester, Nassau or Suffolk counties or across the rest of the state.
*Many students are overweight and inactive. More than half of the 1,500 New York City public high school students randomly tested in the 1990's in a study by Queens College already had one major risk factor for heart disease, mainly excess weight and lack of physical activity. Almost half of the girls and one in five of the boys were overweight to a level considered medically obese, the study said. Figures from the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also suggest that obesity rates among teen-agers may be higher in New York. Nationally, only about one in eight of the teen-agers tested by the Centers in the most recent period, from 1988 to 1994, were overweight.
 
The Cheering Stopped
From a Model System To a Cautionary Tale
 New York, to a great degree, helped invent many of the 20th century forms of public school sports, historians say, through the Public Schools Athletic League, created in 1903. The P.S.A.L., as it is known -- an arm of the Board of Education charged with scheduling, monitoring and assigning funds for interscholastic sports -- was copied by cities all over the country early in the century. By the 1920's, P.S.A.L. track and field events were held that attracted tens of thousands of boys and girls from elementary school age on up to compete for medals in exercises such as situps and pullups.
Public school sports got more money and resources then, but also more attention and respect. In the 1950's and early 1960's, generally considered the heyday of New York City high school sports -- at least for boys, since girls' sports barely existed in those years -- football rivalries like Samuel J. Tilden against Thomas Jefferson were often played out in front of 15,000 fans or more at Ebbets Field. Players for major sports schools like Bayside in Queens, or Abraham Lincoln in Brooklyn, got hero treatment: warm-up parkas, trophies, championship rings. Just about every school had a pep band and a parents booster club that could mobilize resources when the city's contribution fell short.
"There was a lot of community spirit, a lot of school spirit that you don't see now -- it all held together," said Moe Finkelstein, the football coach at Thomas Jefferson from 1955 until his retirement in 1987. "And all the schools were loaded with clubs and activities besides sports. There were lectures, clubs -- you never wanted to leave."
To be sure, school administrators have faced wrenching choices in distributing their resources. But sports, even if they were never formally disavowed by any administrator or mayor, almost always lost out to something deemed more important. At the same time, whether to have sports at all -- or what emphasis to give them -- has become a matter of debate. Many teachers and coaches say, for example, that they believe that professional sports no longer send positive images to young people, who see only the money and ego and greed, and that tales about high schools and colleges where sports have become perhaps too important -- to the detriment of students -- have made athletics harder to defend.
But many others say that the deterioration and disappearance of the city's public high school sports -- and a diminished emphasis on physical activity in general -- flew in the face of a growing body of evidence about their positive impact on young people. That evidence indicated that athletic participation could be a crucial element in keeping students in school and improving academic performance. There are educators who have held onto sports, and schools where meaningful athletics programs exist in the city, but they are rare and scattered. The odds were against them.
The first body blow to school sports came in the mid-1960's, when the school system's teachers began protesting that the old loosely structured work rules about after-school duties -- for athletics as well as arts and clubs -- were exploiting their good will. Successive contracts with the union that included formalized rules about pay and seniority then followed, pushing costs up and resulting in decisions to scale back sports, among other things. At the same time, fear of violence at school sports events encouraged school officials to play down the importance of interschool contests.
 The 1970's then brought outright financial setbacks for sports programs that had already been weakened. In 1975 alone, the P.S.A.L. program, which administered virtually all sports, was cut by nearly 41 percent. More important, the cuts also marked the beginning of a pattern: silent acquiescence. Sports slid away more or less quietly.
"You keep doing it, it gets easier -- it becomes part of the protocol," said Edward I. Koch, the city's Mayor from 1978 to 1989. "Like any budget, you have to make a decision as to what's important, and if you decide, as many did, that, 'most important,' didn't cover sports and cultural subjects, then that's what got cut."
In the 1980's and 1990's, the athletic program came under stress from internal forces in the education system itself as the system sharply grew and changed. Federal law mandated equal treatment for girls' sports, but without more spending by the city, that simply meant a further stretching of limited resources.
The number of high schools offering sports also grew from 107 to 165 as the city began experimenting with smaller, specialized schools. Such schools, unlike traditional high schools, draw students from all over the city, and many school officials and parents say that has muted one of the traditional pressure points of local school politics: organized, vocal parents who live in defined geographic areas, and to whom a single City Council member or community board representative had to answer. About one in five of the city's 312,000 high school students now attends one of these specialty academies.
Physical education requirements for high school students, meanwhile, fell. New York City for many years -- by tradition if not requirement -- gave high school students gym five days a week, a level that was twice the minimum state requirement. But in the early 1990's, that tradition died as most schools went to the lower standard of two days one week, three days in the next. Coming at a time of other budget cuts, that furthered the downward spiral for athletics, teachers say, by making many students physically unfit to play sports, or predisposed toward not wanting to. But more crucial for the system, administrators say, it sharply reduced lobbying pressure for physical education from the United Federation of Teachers, because that part of the union's membership declined.
Internal changes at the Board of Education -- mainly a result of cost cutting and streamlining -- also altered the political balance. In the early 1990's, for example, the Bureau of Physical Education, which had been part of the Division of Curriculum and Instruction, was dismantled. An agency with a vested self-interest in defending gym at budget time was silenced.
"There was no longer a single point of advocacy for that area of the New York City school system," said the former head of the city's high schools division from 1991 until 1997, John J. Ferrandino.
Meanwhile, the support of parents -- considered by most coaches to be the most important element of a program's success -- withered. Schools that could once draw thousands or hundreds of fans -- buying tickets that helped pay expenses -- saw the numbers fall into the hundreds, even dozens.
"The parents don't support children the way they did years ago, the city doesn't support them, some of the heads of the school don't support them," said Ann Davis, who was one of about two dozen people in the stands to watch Thomas Jefferson High School's football team play its first home game in early September. Ms. Davis and her husband, Ray, still come even though their son, Rashan, graduated last year. "Do you see a principal here, a dean?" Ms. Davis said. "They're not even here to support the team. And that is sad, that is sad."

Rock-Hard Neglect
So Few Fields, So Many Dreams
 Even getting former New York City politicians to remember what happened to sports is hard. David N. Dinkins, the Mayor from 1990 to 1993, said that he had always been a supporter of school athletics, but that without a search of his administration's archives, he could not recall or comment on what his record had been.
Mr. Koch confessed that he didn't know what the Public Schools Athletic League even was. "What is the P.S.A.L? Are they private sector?" Mr. Koch said.
Money was not the only thing to dry up. Where there was less money, there was also less attention, less energy and less emphasis on getting things done or making them better, school officials say. Where getting by is the rule, school officials say that improvement or repair to sports facilities has become almost impossible.
Brooklyn Technical High School, for example, has been playing on a vacant industrial lot near Fort Greene Park for more than 15 years. The city spent about $250,000 in the mid-1980's on engineering studies, but the $3.2 million plan to convert the rock-strewn lot into a real ball field foundered during the recession at the decade's close.
"I've got a field outside that's totally useless -- a soccer field, it's all dirt -- but there's no plan or no method for me to say, 'Look guys, I need you to upgrade my field here,' " said Bill Belfi, the chairman of the physical education department at Benjamin N. Cardozo High School in Bayside, Queens. "You get on a list and you wait 10, 15 years -- then it's still maybe."
Top school system administrators say they now believe that the worst of the imbalances against athletics are over. Financing has increased in the last several years, particularly in middle school athletics and for high school junior varsity teams, both of which had been completely eliminated.
New private alternatives have also emerged, like the Ivy League, which organizes girls' softball in Washington Heights and is financed by private donations. And there have always been other ways children in the city have found a way to play sports -- at Y.M.C.A.'s or in church leagues.
Some school coaches have even turned the city's neglect of athletics into a motivational tool. Athletes in New York, they say, have to be tougher and more dedicated to put up with what the city throws at them: crumbling facilities, apathy, incompetence.
Places like the Rock, as South Shore High School's rubble-strewn football field has been dubbed, or the Iron Cage, that the basketball team from East Side Community High School sometimes practices in -- the ceiling so low that you can't take a jump shot without banking it off the ceiling -- are held out by players and coaches like badges of honor. "It makes us mad, so we're tougher," said Alex Figueroa, a 17-year-old co-captain and quarterback of the Brooklyn Technical High School football team as he showed off the scars that snaked up his forearms from playing for four years on the school's rocky field.

Separate, and Unequal
Can't Afford It, Just Drop It
 At Stuyvesant High School, a gleaming new showplace of the city's education system in lower Manhattan, the athletic program spends $2,000 a week during the football season for a bus to carry the team and its equipment three miles across town to its practice field.
At Bronx Regional High School in the South Bronx, the assistant principal, Wade Williams, was reduced, literally, to passing around a hat to raise enough money to get his girls' volleyball team home from a rough neighborhood in Brooklyn last year.
Williams did what he said he had to do at least once a year: He went to the faculty and told them the athletics department had gone broke again.
"The girls have to walk through the projects to get to the train station, and God forbid something happens to these young ladies," Mr. Williams said, recounting his story to the teachers. " 'You've got to help me out here,' I said, then I took off my hat."
The fact is, both schools live by the kindness of strangers and friends. The city provides no money for Stuyvesant's buses or for Bronx Regional's carfares -- school sports teams in New York get no money for uniforms, no money for transportation and little money for equipment. The city pays salary stipends for coaches and athletic directors and for officials at games and meets, leaving just about everything else to the discretion, and fund-raising ability, of the schools. Stuyvesant, with an illustrious alumni list and a solid middle-class base of students, simply has better sources to beg from than can be found in the South Bronx.
The city's contribution to the schools is equal per team, but since that contribution leaves school officials with the need to make up 80 percent or more of a sports program themselves, it has separated the city into socioeconomic haves and have-nots, and created what school sports experts say is, in effect, a pay-for-play sports system.
"The P.S.A.L. will tell you if you can't fund it, drop it," said Nick Ragusa, the athletic director at Chelsea High School in Manhattan.
The unevenness of the system has also highlighted the differences between the city's schools and the large system of private and parochial schools, many of which have thrived by cultivating their images as places where sports in New York still work the way they used to.
"It becomes a social and political issue," said David S. Liebschutz, the associate director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute of Government. "If you don't have the wherewithal to get access to stuff, as people do in the suburbs, where do you go?"
Sometimes it simply means children are left out. Claude Robinson, the athletic director at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, had two great baseball players in the building last year, but they didn't play because neither one of them had money for cleats. Robinson said he wanted to pay for the cleats himself, but couldn't.
"If you give to one, you have to give to all," he said. "And there wasn't money for that."
When it comes to physical education, school regulations require that every child below high school age get at least three days a week of gym. The reality is more like Public School 310 in the Bronx, where Sonia Menendez, the principal, struggles to give her nearly 1,100 students even one gym class a week.
Ms. Menendez lost about half of her playground in the 1980's to a temporary classroom annex. The school has a small gym, and half again as many students as it was designed for.
"We're making do, that's what's happening," she said.
There are no reliable statistics about gym because many teachers and principals say it has become a lie. Things can be called gym to satisfy the paper requirements. Overcrowded schools like 310, including many in Queens and the Bronx, cannot meet the requirements because of limited space. In other schools, there is just not enough money to make it work.
"When I came here, we had five gym teachers," said Hank Whitney, who has been the principal of Intermediate School 49 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn since 1977. "Now I have three. I had to sacrifice gym because I don't have the personnel."
That gap, between what is required and what is possible, has left administrators and coaches all grappling to make do -- some in corrosive cynicism about the system's hypocrisy, some in idealism as they try to make their resources stretch. School administrators say that since they never see any school reprimanded for not providing enough physical activity, the inevitable message is that it doesn't really matter.
"Physical education is dying in New York City," said Hector Martinez, the athletic director at West Side High in midtown Manhattan, as he showed a reporter the school's gym, essentially a classroom with weight-lifting machines. Mr. Martinez admitted that he had to cheat a little, by borrowing money from the school's health department budget, to get even this secondhand equipment. "That's what you have to do," he said.
Some school officials also said that formal structured gym had in fact been tacitly discouraged in a system where lawsuits and liability are a constant concern. They say that less formal gym instruction means less exposure to lawsuits from possible injuries.
"I know that schools are not in compliance, and nothing is being done -- I have not heard of one school being written up," said Maria Rodriguez, the director of East Harlem Technical Junior High School, which reinstituted physical education classes several years ago after about a decade without organized gym.
Many students say that gym has become something to be ignored.
"A lot of times, you just sit there in your sweats or your T-shirt for 45 minutes on the floor or against the wall or whatever, the teachers take attendance, and that would be it," said Kerly Suffren, a 17-year-old junior at Martin Luther King High School in Manhattan. "Then the bell rings, and you change and go back to your regular class -- so a lot of kids feel that it's not necessary or that it's irrelevant."
Ed Beller, West Side High School's basketball coach and an English teacher, said he thought that for all the talk about broader educational horizons, New York has actually narrowed its vision -- so much so that everything beyond academic performance has become almost invisible. As he talked, he watched his basketball team thread down Eighth Avenue in the garment district, weaving around men with their beers in paper bags and the racks of suits being trundled through the crosswalks. His team, lacking a gym, was in search of a park to practice in.
"There was a period of time when the whole child, the whole development -- all that stuff had currency, had some, I don't know what the word is, validity in the minds of the Board of Education," he said. "Now it seems to have no validity with them at all."
 
Dropping the Ball

HEADLINE: Pataki Inaugural Team Told to Disclose Costs

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 12

 BODY:
A ruling today by the state's highest court forces Gov. George E. Pataki's supporters to disclose detailed expenses paid by his 1995 inaugural and transition organizations, information they have fought for four years to keep secret.
The decision, by the Court of Appeals, is the latest in a long string of court losses for associates of the Governor, who have opposed a bid by the majority Democrats in the State Assembly to learn how the two organizations raised and spent more than $2.5 million. 
 The Court of Appeals refused to hear the Pataki team's appeal, meaning that orders by two lower courts to turn over the information stand. With no higher state court to appeal to, the transition and inaugural organizations have 15 days to provide the information to the Assembly Democrats.
Today's decision deals specifically with $60,000 in credit card charges. The two groups had given only a general description of the charges and had not said who made each one. The Assembly Democrats won the right today to see the credit card receipts.
The Democrats said today they had no idea what they would find in the data. "What we've been trying to do for four years now is just plain public disclosure, and this is a big step in that direction," said Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat.
The ruling also gives the Democrats the right to take sworn testimony from Charles A. Gargano, who was Mr. Pataki's chief fund-raiser in 1994 and headed the inaugural team. He is now the State Commissioner of Economic Development. Ms. Lynch said it was not clear whether the Assembly would call Mr. Gargano to testify.
Michael McKeon, the Governor's press secretary, said of today's ruling: "This has been a politically motivated case from the very beginning, and it still is today. Nevertheless, we will comply."
In late 1994, after Mr. Pataki defeated Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Governor-elect's aides and supporters formed a corporation to pay for his lavish, three-day inaugural festivities, which cost $1.6 million, and another to finance a transition team, which spent $900,000.
Aides to Mr. Pataki said the organizations would make full disclosure of their finances and would abide by the rules governing campaign fund-raising, although there was no legal requirement that they do so. But after he took office, the two corporations declined to make their records public, and it was disclosed that some corporate sponsors gave far more than the $5,000 limit on corporate campaign contributions.
Not until July 1996 did the organizations, under court order, release the names of contributors and the amounts they gave, which showed that the total raised was much higher than administration officials had said.
Most of the money came from corporations and business people whose interests were regulated by the state or who were seeking state contracts, and the records showed that many corporate sponsors had given far more than the $5,000 limit on corporate campaign contributions.
It was also disclosed that many of the Governor's advisers collected salaries from the transition fund, including some who failed to disclose the income on the forms they filed with the State Ethics Commission, as required by law.
Later court rulings forced the release of most information on how the money was spent.

HEADLINE: Whitman Sets April 15 For Property Tax Plan

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman asked state lawmakers today to enact her proposed five-year, $1 billion property tax relief package by April 15 so homeowners can get their first rebate check by Labor Day.
Republican and Democratic lawmakers applauded the plan, which Governor Whitman outlined today in her fifth annual address to a joint session of the State Legislature. The proposal would provide an average rebate check of $120 to homeowners this year and an average of $600 annually beginning in the fifth year. Tenants would receive an average of $100 annually under the program when it is fully phased in. 
 But Mrs. Whitman acknowledged that using state budget dollars to pay for property tax rebates in future years would require "fiscal discipline from those of us in Trenton."
"Fiscal discipline means being very cautious about any new spending programs," she said. "Fiscal discipline means constantly reminding ourselves that the No. 1 priority is helping you, the taxpayer. The fiscal discipline we show today will deliver a check to you tomorrow."
Most of the other new initiatives that Governor Whitman presented today as her top legislative priorities for the coming year focused on education, health care and open space, as well as an issue that is a concern of a growing number of middle-class families: caring for chronically ill elderly relatives.
Although the state is expected to end the current fiscal year with a budget surplus between $800 million and $1 billion, most of the Governor's plans would require modest or no spending increases or would be paid for from existing funds or windfalls, like the tobacco settlement.
In her 35-minute address at the recently renovated War Memorial building here, Mrs. Whitman called for imposing tougher standards on new teachers, offering cash incentives to landowners who donate open space or farmland to the state or private land trusts, hiring more park maintenance workers, and expanding the program providing health insurance to uninsured children.
For the state's elderly residents and those who care for them, Mrs. Whitman proposed a $60 million spending increase over the next three years, using state and Federal funds for a program that would seek to help elderly people remain in their homes by providing easier access to long-term home care services. The plan would also offer financial assistance, training programs and counseling to caregivers.
State health officials said that the Governor's plan to assist those families caring for disabled and chronically ill relatives would be in addition to Federal financing that President Clinton proposed earlier this month. Mr. Clinton included the new dollars for states when he proposed a $1,000 tax credit for people who need long-term care.
Although Governor Whitman defeated former Gov. Jim Florio with the enthusiastic support of the National Rifle Association, she disappointed some gun owners and the gun lobby today. She announced that she would propose legislation requiring that every gun sold in New Jersey include either a safety lock or the new "smart gun" technology, preventing anyone other than the gun's owner from firing the weapon.
"Those school shootings last week and last year happened in other states," Mrs. Whitman said. "Next time, it could be our state, our kids, our tragedy. I don't want one more gun sold in this state without built-in protection for our children."
But Mrs. Whitman is likely to face a battle from some lawmakers over the gun legislation, particularly from Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, a fellow Republican. He was among a handful of lawmakers who did not applaud when she talked about the gun bill. He said later that he would be reluctant to impose requirements on gun owners before the "smart gun" technology was widely available.
Mr. Collins said that Mrs. Whitman's speech addressed the top concerns of New Jerseyans, and he added that he believed lawmakers would enact Mrs. Whitman's property tax plan by the April 15 deadline that she set today. He also said that he supported most of the Governor's other legislative initiatives, but that he would reject her recommendation imposing tougher standards for new teachers.
Graduates from New Jersey colleges must now carry a C plus average to qualify as a candidate for teacher certification in the state. Mrs. Whitman said today in her speech that "C plus is not good enough" and that she wants the State Board of Education to require all new graduates who apply for certification to carry at least a B average.
Mr. Collins, a lawyer and college professor, disagreed with Mrs. Whitman's approach, noting that he had had a "little less" than a C plus average and was a "damn good teacher."
Although most Democratic lawmakers are expected to go along with the property tax rebate plan, some expressed concern about the long-term fiscal implications. Others questioned the fairness of making the rebates available even to the state's wealthiest residents.
Several Democrats took credit today for Governor Whitman's decision to make property tax relief the centerpiece of her address. Five years ago, Mrs. Whitman cut state income tax rates by 30 percent, but polls showed that voters did not give her much credit for the tax cuts during her hard-fought 1997 re-election campaign. Mrs. Whitman won re-election, but narrowly, in part because voters complained that she did not do enough to bring down the state's property tax rates, the highest in the nation. They also complained about auto insurance, which Mrs. Whitman addressed last year but did not mention today.
"Welcome to the Democratic neighborhood of fighting for property tax relief," said State Senator Richard J. Codey, the Democratic leader in the Senate. "This surplus from the economic boom belongs to the people, so it is only right to give it back to them. Democrats will fight to make sure the Republicans don't get weak knees about property tax relief when the times get tough."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil Stocks Fall Steeply Amid Currency and Capital Fears

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Brazilian stocks plunged yesterday as rumors about devaluation and concern about capital flight undermined efforts by the Government to calm investors.
It was the fourth day in a row that the stock market fell, a selloff set in motion by the decision of one of Brazil's biggest states not to make its debt payments to the central Government for 90 days. 
 Other Latin American stocks markets fell, too, and emerging-market bonds declined. In Sao Paulo, the benchmark Bovespa stock index fell 7.6 percent and is off 19 percent since last Wednesday. In Mexico City, the Bolsa index dropped 3.7 percent and in dollar terms has lost 15 percent since the start of 1999. Argentina's Merval index fell 3.5 percent.
Investors are again facing the worries of last fall: Will Brazil fail in its efforts to reduce spending and the budget deficit and be forced to devalue its currency, the real? And if that happens, how bad would the fallout be elsewhere in the world, especially the United States?
Brazil received a $41.5 billion rescue package a few months ago, backed by the International Monetary Fund and the United States. Tensions were also eased by interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve and European central banks.
But with the refusal of the state of Minas Gerais to make debt payments for 90 days, doubts have intensified about the ability of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso to achieve Brazil's spending and deficit goals. "Things in the market are not good," said Desmond Lachman, director of emerging markets economic research at Salomon Smith Barney. "If they don't turn things around quickly it will be hard to restore investor confidence."
Arturo C. Porzecanski, chief economist for the Americas at ING Barings, said the Government had not been able to regain the initiative since the state debt moratorium was announced.
One sign of investor fear is the pace of money leaving the country. On Monday, according to the Government, $200 million flowed out. But yesterday, traders were reporting that as much as $1 billion might have left the country. "They are losing reserves at a faster pace than before," Mr. Lachman said, referring to the dollars the Government can use to defend the nation's currency by buying it.
Another problem is a series of rumors, which seemed to intensify with a drop in the value of the Brazilian currency yesterday, that the Government would devalue.
As the stock market was plunging, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin gave President Cardoso a vote of confidence. After a meeting in Washington with the Argentine President, Carlos Saul Menem, Mr. Rubin said: "I start from the view that the Brazilian program should work. It was a good program that was announced. President Cardoso is deeply committed to getting this done. The politics obviously are the key. There are a lot of reasons to be hopeful."
At the same time, a group of 17 governors from other Brazilian states met and said that while they would like to renegotiate their debt obligations with the central Government, they did not support the moratorium on payments by Minas Gerais. However, other states may still choose to join Minas Gerais.
Another calming effort was made by the World Bank country director for Brazil. In an interview with Bloomberg News, Gobind Nankani said, "Hopefully, markets will begin to look again at the behavior of the executive, the behavior of the Congress, the behavior of other governors and not overreact to the Minas state" situation.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Intel Reports Solid Earnings In Its Fourth Quarter
Buoyed by strong sales of its high-end microprocessors and increased operating efficiencies, Intel reported fourth-quarter financial results that substantially exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates. But Intel advised analysts that sales for the first quarter of 1999 are likely to fall, following a normal seasonal pattern. 
 For the fourth quarter, Intel reported earnings of $2.1 billion, or $1.19 a share, up 18 percent from $1.7 billion, or 98 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 17 percent, to $7.6 billion, from $6.5 billion. Analysts expected Intel to earn $1.07 a share. Page C4.
 
Seagate Technology, the No. 1 independent maker of computer disk drives, posted net income for its fiscal second quarter that beat expectations as the company benefited from a surge in sales of personal computers. C4.
 
Suit Against Coltec Dismissed
A Federal Judge dismissed a lawsuit by the Crane Company seeking to block Coltec Industries from merging with B.F. Goodrich in a deal that gives Coltec shareholders substantially less than Crane had offered to pay. The ruling by United States District Judge Barbara S. Jones in White Plains allows Coltec and Goodrich to proceed with their deal. It is unclear whether Crane will appeal. C6.
 
Marketers Ponder Life Without Mike
With the second and apparently final retirement of Michael Jordan from basketball, which is expected to be announced today, will Madison Avenue lose the most prolific, most richly compensated and perhaps most effective endorser ever? Or can Mr. Jordan continue to be a world champion pitchman in retirement? Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.
 
Fewer Choices for Health Insurance
The health insurance industry is rapidly whittling itself down to a few giant companies that dominate the health systems of some of the country's biggest cities. Doctors and hospitals are increasingly concerned, and the trend is also raising questions about the cost and availability of care to millions of patients and their employers. A1.
 
Testimony Backs Microsoft Position
An economist testifying for the Government conceded that there was scant evidence consumers had been harmed by practices that are central to the Justice Department's antitrust case against Microsoft. C5.
 
U.S. Markets Off Sharply

HEADLINE: Tax Relief Proposal Attracts Criticism and Praise

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ROXBURY, N.J., Jan. 12

 BODY:
Try as he may to muster enthusiasm for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed property tax rebates for homeowners, Donald Dyrness kept sliding into cynicism today, because he has also heard from his local school board that the district stands to lose $2.4 million in state aid this year.
"It's a charade," said Mr. Dyrness, 34, the president of a family-owned custom-building company, as he did the math. 
 Mr. Dyrness, who supported Mrs. Whitman, a fellow Republican, in the last two elections, said: "The rebate will mean from $120 to $200 a home for us, but the loss of the aid will mean a $440-a-home increase. She's giving with one hand and taking away with the other, and I think she just wants to be able to say that she cut taxes again."
While others around the state were critical of the plan today, some local officials enthusiastically greeted the Governor's five-year, $1 billion rebate plan. Still others modulated their reaction, saying that they welcomed the tax relief but that it fell far short of the structural reforms needed to ease the heavy burden of financing schools and services.
Bill Dressel, executive director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, was one of those who moderated his enthusiasm. While the rebates represented the Governor's commitment in flush times to some sort of relief, he said, a permanent constitutional change is needed to reduce the reliance on property taxes.
"We are not home free yet, and I'm not ready to say that this will meet our concerns completely," he said. "But it is an infusion of money, and the bigger hurdle of convincing the administration and the Legislature that we need alternatives to the property tax is still there."
But among other officials, the praise was unrestrained. They said they were also grateful for Mrs. Whitman's announcement today that she supported indexing state aid to inflation and eliminating state income taxes for those earning less than $13,000 a year.
"As an urban Republican, I am excited about this with all of the different pieces," said Martin G. Barnes, the Mayor of Paterson. "All together, it is something that helps everyone and not just the suburban areas, and if one of these pieces disappears, there will be a perception problem with it all."
While Mayor Carl W. Block of Stafford Township in Ocean County lamented that the Governor's proposal did little to alter dependence on property taxes, he praised her for responding to the clamor from school and municipal officials to ease the local tax burden.
In Elizabeth, Mayor Chris Bollwage, a Democrat, theorized that the Governor's tax proposals were political moves intended to keep the Legislature in Republican hands in this year's elections. "But it was also the right thing to do, and so the motive isn't that important," he said.
Most of the local elected officials said it was politically difficult to oppose any kind of tax relief, however flawed. They said they would have preferred the state to grant the relief directly to them so that they could pass on the savings to local taxpayers, but some conceded that the Governor was right to be concerned that would not happen.
In Roxbury -- where 83.9 percent of the residents own their homes -- the average home costs $185,000 and the average property tax mirrors the state average of $4,000 a year. Mrs. Whitman is popular in Roxbury, where she won by more than a two-to-one vote in 1997. But there also is great sensitivity among the estimated 27,000 residents about the ballooning growth in school spending.
Donald Dyrness's father, Dan, who moved to Roxbury as a child in the 1950's, when the township was mostly farmland, said the rapid increase in local taxes was creating fear that his son and other younger people would not be able to afford to stay in the area. For the elder Mr. Dyrness, who like his son is both a Republican and a Whitman supporter, the rebate is an attempt at "a quick fix."
The Rev. Sue Ellis Melrose, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Succasunna and a Roxbury school board member, said school enrollment was growing so rapidly in the district that the board faced a shortfall of six classrooms for next fall.
Recalculations of the education aid formula two years ago had hurt the district, but stopgap aid last year eased the problem. But now the district again faces the problem, with a possible $2.4 million loss in state aid from its $41 million budget, she said.
Ms. Melrose, a Democrat, said she would not send her rebate check back to the state, but she added: "It will be enough to take us out to dinner, maybe twice, and that's it. What we really need here is something to stabilize state aid and deliver us from the Catch 22 of providing a quality education while reducing spending."
Richard Zoschak, a Republican who owns a photography business in Roxbury and is a Planning Board member, echoed those concerns, noting that the elderly residents of the town were being hit particularly hard by the increasing local tax burden and would be helped little by the small rebates being proposed.
Donald Dyrness recalled that past state rebate programs involved complex calculations and a costly bureaucracy. His common sense told him, he said, that direct grants to school districts would cost less to administer but would have less direct political benefit for the Governor.
"I think she wants to be Senator, President or Vice President," he said. "But I'm not too impressed."
