HEADLINE: The Japanese Intervene To Drive Down A Surging Yen

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Japanese central bank intervened in the currency markets yesterday, selling yen for dollars and sending the currency down 3 percent, its biggest one-day loss in more than three years.
The intervention was an acknowledgment by Japan that the rising value of the yen, up 31 percent since August, is making its faltering effort to turn the economy around even more difficult. A strong yen is damaging because it makes Japanese exports, a possible engine of recovery, much more expensive, and therefore, less competitive abroad. 
 But whether the intervention is going to stop the yen's rise and the dollar's decline is unclear. Many traders think that the yen will have to rally a little further -- and the dollar slip lower -- before there is a turnaround. That means the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, will probably have to intervene again. Whether the United States will join in, as it did this past June, is open to debate.
Asked about the Japanese currency intervention after a meeting with President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin would not comment directly. But he did say, "I'll just repeat what I've said so often, which is a strong dollar has served us well and our dollar policy is absolutely unchanged."
Avinash Persaud, global head of currency research at J. P Morgan Securities in London, said that two forces were moving the two currencies and that they were both generally negative for the dollar and positive for the yen.
One is Japan's current-account surplus with the United States, reflecting trade in merchandise and services. The surplus has Japanese businesses turning more dollars from trade back into yen, strengthening the Japanese currency.
The other factor is that large institutional investors are sitting on their hands, refusing to take a position against the yen even though the economic fundamentals, including Japan's weak economy, low interest rates and poor prospects, point to a weaker currency.
"As long as investors stay away, the current account will push the yen higher and the central bank will still have to intervene," Mr. Persaud said, adding that he expected the yen to reach 105 to the dollar.
Japanese officials did not confirm the intervention publicly but made comments that seemed to indicate they had intervened. Several currency traders, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the central bank did intervene. The total sales, they said, ranged from $2 billion to $3 billion.
They said the intervention began in Tokyo trading and carried over into London dealings. It came after the dollar fell to a longtime low against the yen of 108.93 on Monday. But in late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose 3.2 percent, to 112.43. Early today in Tokyo, the dollar was trading at 112.45 yen.
The intervention, some traders said, was done through foreign banks, which might have been intended to send a stronger signal about the Government's desire to at least slow the yen's rally.
This was the first time that the Bank of Japan had intervened to reduce the value of the yen since April 1996. Along with the Federal Reserve system, the bank pulled off a surprise intervention in June to support the yen when it was approaching a level of 150. At the time, many analysts were worried that a weaker yen would cause a currency devaluation by China, aggravating an already troubling international economic crisis.
China held its ground, but the yen did not really begin to rally until August, when Russia effectively defaulted on its debt and devalued its currency, setting off fears of a wider and deeper financial crisis. Hedge funds and others who had lost money in Russia and other emerging markets began selling dollars and buying yen to lock in the big profits they had made betting against the yen. This selling snowballed, forcing others to sell and all of a sudden the yen was too strong, not too weak.
Mr. Persaud said there were now signs of the selling of dollars for yen by long-term institutional investors, like pension funds, which had held on during the speculative selling by hedge funds. This selling by long-term investors, Mr. Persaud said, may have been one of the factors that truly worried Japanese officials.
Jeremy P. Fand, senior foreign exchange strategist at BankBoston, expects the yen to lose value against the dollar over the next several months because Japan's economy is so weak and its rescue process is so haphazard.
But he also acknowledged that in the short term the yen would most likely rally and the dollar would fall. "We are expecting another test of 110 yen and below," he said. "People want to see some action" from the Japanese before changing their view.
In trading in Europe, the dollar slipped slightly against the new euro, although the euro is proving to have a weaker start than many analysts had expected. The euro was worth $1.15550 yesterday, compared with $1.15420 on Monday.

HEADLINE: Concern Rising About Mergers In Health Plans

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The health insurance industry is rapidly whittling itself down to a few giant companies that dominate the health systems of some of the country's biggest cities.
Doctors and hospitals are increasingly concerned, and the trend is also raising questions about the cost and availability of care to millions of patients and their employers. 
 The criticism sharpened after the recent announcements of two billion-dollar deals that would propel Aetna Inc. to first place among the nation's health insurers. Last month, Aetna agreed to buy Prudential Health Care, the No. 5 for-profit managed care company, while it was still digesting its July purchase of NYLCare, No. 11.
Prudential Health Care, a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, would thus join a pantheon of insurers swallowed in the last few years, including the health care divisions of Metropolitan Life, Travelers, New York Life and John Hancock. In only five years, a dozen companies have been scooped up by six survivors: Aetna, Cigna, United Healthcare, Foundation Health Systems, Pacificare and Wellpoint Health Networks.
Some health policy experts say they do not worry about big companies becoming bigger at the national level, if customers are thinly scattered. But with the acquisition of Prudential, Aetna would have 39 percent of the Philadelphia market and would take similarly potent positions in numerous other markets. It would have nearly 60 percent of managed care members in Houston, nearly half in Dallas and more than 30 percent in Atlanta, Philadelphia and the New York area, according to estimates by Sanford C. Bernstein, a Wall Street investment firm.
The Prudential deal quickly drew expressions of concern from groups monitoring patients' rights and doctors' groups like the American Medical Association and medical societies in a half-dozen states. Executives of large employers said they worried about the impact on cost and quality of care.
One worry is that payments to doctors will be trimmed, leading them to spend less time with each patient, which could hurt the quality of care. And patients fear that they will be forced to switch doctors.
For doctors and hospitals, the concern is not only that insurers dictate prices, but that if one or two insurers dominate a market, some doctors and hospitals will be left out in the cold. And employers worry about having fewer plans competing for their business, a trend already translating into higher premiums.
"The marriage of Aetna and Prucare will result in one company controlling over one-third of the New Jersey market," said Dr. David Swee, a New Brunswick family practitioner who is an official of the Medical Society of New Jersey.
And with about three of every 10 managed care members in Atlanta, Aetna "will be in a position to start dictating reimbursement rates," said David Harrell, chief executive of the Georgia Baptist Health Care System. "That is extremely dangerous. It ultimately has the potential of driving down quality" by pressing hospitals to discharge patients prematurely and skimp on supplies.
The insurance industry insists that these concerns are groundless, assuring critics that small regional insurers, as well as the hospitals' own H.M.O.'s, will always be around to provide competition. And they must be big in a given market, they say, to keep costs from spiraling out of control -- and to afford extensive information systems that may someday help improve patient care.
Critics dismiss such arguments. The New Jersey medical society has called for "appropriate action" by state and Federal antitrust authorities "to protect consumers, assure a vigorous market, and protect the patient-physician relationship." The New Jersey Citizen Action Group has also asked the state's insurance regulators to investigate the Aetna-Prudential deal.
The Prudential deal "could endanger patient choices and impair patient care," said Dr. Swee of the New Jersey society. The American Medical Association made the same point in a letter last month to the Justice Department's antitrust division.
In Philadelphia, even before the Prudential purchase, Aetna and a local Blue Cross company, Keystone Health Plan East, together controlled about four of every five members of H.M.O.'s and similar networks. With Prudential, Aetna would be even bigger.
"A marketplace this large should not be subject to a near monopoly," said Dr. Alan L. Hillman, director of the University of Pennsylvania health policy center. "If one of the two starts to gain a larger foothold, or the other one slips, we are going to have a true monopoly situation."
Ron Pollack, executive director of Families USA, a national health care consumers organization, said consumers "would have good reason to be concerned" in markets where Aetna, which has adamantly opposed patient protection legislation, took a dominant position. "Other H.M.O.'s have been much more forthcoming in trying to be patient-sensitive and consumer-sensitive," he said.
Many employers are also frustrated, said Charles Blankensteen, a health care expert at the William Mercer consulting firm. "Choice in the marketplace is rapidly diminishing, customer service and value for the dollar are less than spectacular," he said. "Who bears the costs of these acquisitions? My bet is, it's the people who buy the services."
But insurance executives said plenty of competition remained.
"It's still a very fragmented industry," Richard L. Huber, Aetna's chief executive, said in a recent interview. "There's lots of competition" from Blue Cross plans and nonprofit H.M.O.'s. "The smaller regional guys will do just fine."
Mr. Huber predicted there would be "no more than three truly national players" -- Aetna, Cigna and Unitedhealth Group, until recently called United Healthcare. "We will compete with each other and against the Harvard Pilgrims," a big nonprofit H.M.O. with 1.3 million members in New England, he said.
"There will be fewer, bigger players and always an awful lot of local and regional players," said Leonard D. Schaeffer, chairman of Wellpoint Health Networks. Hundreds of hospitals have their own H.M.O.'s.
"Size matters," said Edward Hanway, president of Cigna Healthcare. "You need to have sufficient mass in major marketplaces." But he said he was "not convinced that there is a significant difference between 12 million members" -- Cigna's customers -- "and 20 million" -- Aetna's and Prudential's.
Industry executives said more consolidations were likely. Cigna, No. 4 in managed care, has just agreed to sell its property-and-casualty business to focus on health care and will soon have $4 billion available for acquisitions. Humana Inc., No. 6, has also been seeking a merger partner.
Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, already the largest insurers in many cities, have also been consolidating, with mergers and alliances in Connecticut and Indiana, central and western Pennsylvania, California and Georgia and Texas and Illinois.
"The health system is stumbling toward a bilateral monopoly of insurance companies and provider groups in every market," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University.
If only one insurer is left to deal with local doctors and hospitals, Professor Reinhardt said, "they will send the bill to the consumer" by raising premiums. "Then the Government will say: 'You have converted health care into a public utility. We are going to regulate you.' "
Blue Cross plans are closely controlled in some states. For instance, the Michigan plan, which has two-thirds of the private insurance market in Lansing, is "regulated by the state and purchasers and unions on its board," said Paul B. Ginsburg, president of the Center for Health System Change in Washington.
Insurance executives reject Professor Reinhardt's argument, saying that statistics commonly used on Wall Street do not give the full picture, which should include not only managed care customers but also fee-for-service insurance and employers that self-insure.
By the more inclusive definition, Aetna is "still only a minority player, even in markets like New Jersey where we are the largest," said Joyce Oberdorf, an Aetna spokeswoman.
Size may be a mixed blessing in some states. "H.M.O.'s are struggling in Texas," said Margaret Jordan, a hospital consultant in Dallas, where hospital executives and doctors have loudly criticized H.M.O.'s, starting with Aetna.
The A.M.A., which has jousted with Aetna for months over harsh restrictions in doctors' contracts, said the acquisition would "create a dominant entity" that would "further diminish the ability of patients to receive the quality of care they seek."
In a letter to the Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and state insurance officials in New Jersey and Connecticut, Consumers for Quality Care, a patients' advocacy group in Santa Monica, Calif., urged regulators to "disallow the proposed buyout."
"With greater market share in key cities and states," it said, "Aetna will have put itself in a position to offer more patients less coverage for ever higher premiums."
A.M.A. officials said on Friday that they had had preliminary discussions with Justice Department officials and would provide data to the Government this week to support the doctors' charges. In a rare indication of Government concern three years ago, Justice Department and F.T.C. antitrust officials asked a Federal appeals judge in Chicago to leave the door open for future cases against H.M.O.'s. Judge Richard A. Posner did so, remarking in his ruling that health plans "may vary in respects crucial to antitrust liability."
Federal antitrust officials declined to comment.
Robert Leibenluft, a health care lawyer in Washington who specializes in antitrust matters, said the Federal agencies had rarely, if ever, challenged H.M.O. mergers. Two years ago, the Justice Department cleared the acquisition of Metrahealth by United Healthcare, after United, at Missouri's insistence, agreed to sell a Metrahealth unit in St. Louis.
Mr. Leibenluft said it was unclear whether the managed care consolidations were "such that the H.M.O.'s would be able to raise their prices, and the buyers would not have an alternative." Even if an H.M.O. dominated a market, he said, the buyers might be able to switch to other types of insurance.
A "more serious issue," he said, would be whether doctors were locked into exclusive arrangements with a particular H.M.O. In a 1995 ruling, Judge Posner held that although an H.M.O. affiliated with the Marshfield Clinic in rural Wisconsin was "the dominant provider of medical services" in its region, the H.M.O. was not a monopoly because patients could consult the same doctors through other plans.
Several large employers said the merger trend had not paid off in better care.
Bruce Bradley, director of managed care plans at the General Motors Corporation, said he was "very concerned that the health care industry is moving away from local delivery systems and H.M.O.'s are becoming more and more like insurance companies," which mainly pay bills without focusing on providing appropriate care.
Mr. Bradley said the managed care companies had the potential to improve their information systems, attract "good local physician leaders" and press them to treat patients according to "best" practices. "The opportunities are good, but I haven't seen it happen yet," he said.
Alan Peres, manager of benefit planning for the Ameritech Corporation, said employers would be concerned to see if Aetna could "mesh these organizations together without creating employee relations nightmares" involving poor service to customers and angering doctors and hospitals by delaying payments.
J. Randall McDonald, an executive vice president of the GTE Corporation, said GTE would consider the quality of service and costs in judging the merged companies. "If it works to our standard, we'll be a good customer," he said. "If it doesn't, as we have done with others, we'll say they don't meet our criteria, and we'll move on."

HEADLINE: Report Issued Early Shows Rise in ProducerPrices

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Prices paid to producers rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month after a record surge in cigarette prices more than offset declines in energy and food costs, the Labor Department said in a report that was posted by mistake on the Internet today, a day early.
For all of 1998, the Producer Price Index fell one-tenth of 1 percent; in 1997, the index declined 1.2 percent. This is the first instance since the Government began compiling the data in 1947 that the index has fallen for two consecutive years. 
 Wholesale cigarette prices rose 30.7 percent last month as tobacco companies began passing on the cost of a $206 billion settlement reached with 46 states to cover health care claims. Without those increases, the December index would have fallen four-tenths of a percent.
The index's core rate, which excludes food and energy costs, rose 1 percent in December. Producer energy prices fell 2.3 percent, and food prices dropped one-tenth of 1 percent. Without the cigarette price increase, the core rate would have fallen one-tenth of 1 percent.
The premature release of the report was the second such recent episode. The Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics said on Nov. 6 that it was reviewing its procedures after some of the October employment figures were accidentally posted on the Internet.
Scott Sager, a spokesman for the bureau, said today's report was posted on the department Web site about 2 P.M. because of a computer error. He said the department deleted the information within an hour but later decided to release the data because some people had seen the posting.

HEADLINE: AIDS Is Still Here, But Donors Drift Off;
As Disease Lingers, Public Interest Wanes and Service Groups Falter

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
When the Gay Men's Health Crisis announced last month that it would no longer hold a popular annual fund-raising event on Fire Island, the move did more than end the public relations nightmare that the Morning Party had become.
While the spectacle of merrymakers collapsing from overdoses and being arrested on drug charges had caused embarrassment for G.M.H.C., the nation's largest AIDS service organization, the cancellation of the summertime dance party highlighted a more serious fund-raising problem. 
 Faced with a decline in private contributions, the agency has eliminated more than a quarter of its staff positions in 15 months. It has also dissolved a research department and consolidated two other divisions. More cuts could be ahead for the agency, which relies on donations for 80 percent of its $22.4 million operating expense budget, a budget that has declined nearly $5 million from two years ago.
"It has been painful," said Ronald S. Johnson, the agency's managing director for public policy. "We're potentially chipping to the bone."
The decline in donations is not confined to G.M.H.C. With the advent of life-prolonging treatments and a significant drop in AIDS-related deaths, AIDS groups in New York and across the country are struggling. Donor fatigue has set in, even though H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, continues to infect 40,000 new people a year in the United States.
"AIDS in America is no longer considered a problem; everybody thinks it's gone away," said Larry Kramer, a writer who is one of the six co-founders of G.M.H.C. "Aside from that, it's happening to people who nobody wants to give any money to, poor people, people of color, drug users. In the beginning, when gays were threatened, gays gave money. But gays don't feel so threatened anymore. They are giving money to fight for gay marriage and other gay issues."
As donations migrate to other causes, AIDS groups are trying to reinvent fund-raising approaches and to devise fresh ones that might compel potential contributors. Some struggling groups are even considering mergers or pairing up with non-AIDS organizations.
For the first time, G.M.H.C. is taking part in the kind of fund-raising events that might have seemed ridiculously arduous a decade ago. Staff workers and volunteers, some of whom are H.I.V.-positive, will solicit pledges to run in the Marine Corps Marathon this fall in Washington. They will join contingents from AIDS Project Los Angeles and the Whitman-Walker Clinic in Washington, another AIDS organization.
Some AIDS groups are finding that they must venture further afield to find support. The 15 AIDS service organizations that are part of the Harlem Directors Group, for instance, are being encouraged to approach cancer groups for joint projects and financing.
"People are beginning to feel like they've probably given enough to H.I.V. and AIDS," said Ravinia Hayes-Cozier, the group's executive director. "For AIDS organizations, the ability to go beyond H.I.V. and AIDS is going to be important. Seven or eight years ago, I would have said you could not do it because of the emergency of the epidemic, but we cannot afford to just be a singular focus disease entity."
Raising money has become so difficult for the People With AIDS Coalition of New York, which offers informational phone lines, support groups and forums, that it is considering a merger with other AIDS service groups. Its executive director, Doug Wirth, said a quarter of the coalition's $1 million annual budget used to come from the bequests of AIDS patients. Now the amount is less than 5 percent because many people with AIDS are living longer.
As the coalition tries to replace those funds, it has also faced a drop in grants by the Government, which is directing more financing to outpatient health care and drug costs. "It's been a dramatic challenge and the question is, 'How long can that be sustained?' " Mr. Wirth said of the effort to maintain the coalition's budget.
By virtue of its name, G.M.H.C. is more closely linked to a gay donor base than most AIDS service organizations, and it has long been the most politically and economically connected group in the world of nonprofit AIDS service. Even so, G.M.H.C. has had to cut back, and it is seeking tenants to help it fill its 12-story headquarters in Chelsea.
With the cancellation of the Morning Party, the agency has lost its second largest fund-raising event after the AIDS Walk, which made $4.24 million last year, slightly down from the previous year. The dance party attracted 4,500 people and raised $464,000 in 1998.
"There's no way to say it's not a tough hit," said Mr. Johnson, the agency's managing director for public policy. "It will have an impact on the operation."
The Morning Party became a symbol of the agency's roots because the same community that gave rise to G.M.H.C. summered in Fire Island Pines, off the south shore of Long Island. Though the party began as a modest affair in 1983, it evolved over time into a swank event that attracted hordes of gay men.
"It was a huge piece of revenue and speaks directly to the core constituency of G.M.H.C., their leadership, their board," said Rodger McFarlane, a former executive director of the agency. "Those white upper-middle-class gay men are really important to G.M.H.C. and always have been."
In recent years, the gay dance party on the edge of the Atlantic lent cachet to a growing number of similar parties around the nation, known as "circuit parties." It also became increasingly associated with illegal drug use and unsafe sex.
Last year, in the predawn hours leading up to the Morning Party, a 35-year-old man from Bronxville, N.Y., overdosed and died. During the event, a party producer hired to oversee security and to weed out drug use was among 21 men picked up on charges of illegal drug possession. The year before, the same number of drug arrests occurred. And in 1996, a man slipped into a drug-induced coma and had to be evacuated by helicopter.
In recent years, as critics complained that the party was out of control, G.M.H.C. officials cited educating partygoers about the dangers of illegal drugs as one of the main reasons the organization remained committed to the event. The agency started holding drug counseling workshops on Fire Island around the party, and distributed fliers warning partygoers that illicit drugs would not be tolerated.
Now, in an effort to recoup the loss of revenue from the Morning Party, the agency is considering playing host at a series of smaller house parties in the Pines.
For some gay-rights advocates, the demise of the Morning Party signals the loss of a part of history.
"It's the only fund-raiser that G.M.H.C. had that was still gay, born in the gay community and targeting the gay community," said Randy Wojcak, a former organizer of the Morning Party who serves on G.M.H.C.'s education and program committee. "With the AIDS Walk, you see people with baby strollers, wives, husbands, brothers and sisters."
But Mr. Kramer, the co-founder of G.M.H.C., said gay men have never contributed as substantially to the agency as people might believe.
"The Morning Party was an old and tired idea, good riddance as far as I'm concerned," he said. "It's a drop in the bucket compared to what they need. They have a big building and a big staff and they haven't got the money to take care of all these things. There are a lot of wonderful programs that are really severely threatened."
During the last round of budget cuts, the talk was about which programs should stay and which ones might go. Among the programs that came under scrutiny was the buddy service, in which volunteers are paired up with sickly clients to do chores like shopping and laundry. The program, one of the agency's oldest, stays for now.
Meanwhile, volunteers like Dena Hammerstein hope the agency is through the worst. Mrs. Hammerstein devotes her time to the agency's Child Life program, which serves H.I.V.-positive women and their families.
Mrs. Hammerstein is also a longtime donor. She said she and her late husband, James Hammerstein, a producer who frequently directed the musicals of his father, Oscar Hammerstein 2d, raised about $10,000 for the program during the couple's silver anniversary celebration last year.
For five years now, Mrs. Hammerstein has volunteered twice a week. But because of the high staff turnover, she knows fewer of the staff workers these days.
"There's been a lot of upheaval all over," she said. "We volunteers have gotten more active. I think we felt a need to. We want to make sure we don't let our families down."

HEADLINE: ANXIETY GROWING OVER INDIAN CLAIM IN NEW YORK STATE

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
The Federal Government has joined the Oneida Indians in a lawsuit that contends the state and local governments unlawfully acquired 270,000 acres of land in central New York from the Indians nearly 200 years ago, whittling down what had been a sprawling reservation into a meager 32-acre plot.
Though the Oneidas' land claim has been wending its way through Federal courts since 1970, the subject of fruitless settlement negotiations between the Indians and two different governors, the Justice Department's intervention last year has galvanized state and local officials on the case as never before. 
 In particular, lawyers for the Justice Department and the Oneidas have provoked widespread anxiety and anger among private landowners by seeking to expand the suit to name not just the state, but also some 20,000 property owners in central New York as defendants.
The Justice Department and the Oneidas adamantly maintain that they have no interest in evicting people from their homes or forcing them to pay rent. They say the suit is intended to pressure the state into reaching a settlement. But such assurances have not stopped people from believing that their homes and farms are in danger, that they will be unable to buy or sell property or that banks will stop making loans.
"This is a very emotional issue and no amount of assurances are going to completely allay people's anxieties," said State Senator Raymond Meier, a Republican from Oneida County. "The only way to do that is to bring this to a rapid and complete conclusion."
The expansion of the suit to include individual landowners -- which would have to be approved by Judge Neal McCurn of Federal District Court in Syracuse -- comes at a time of simmering tensions between the Oneidas and some business owners, who contend that the Oneidas' tax-free status is putting them out of business. The Oneidas, who have become one of the region's largest employers, run a casino and hotel as well as several stores, restaurants and gas stations where customers do not pay sales tax.
"Ten or twelve family-owned businesses are now gone because the Indian businesses have an unfair advantage," said Assemblyman David Townsend, a Republican from Oriskany. "And they flaunt it in people's faces by advertising tax-free goods."
Now the Justice Department's involvement has also made the Federal Government a target of the anger. "It's amazing that they basically sided with a foreign nation against us," said Lisa Jensen, a 31-year-old landowner. "You hit yourself on the head and you ask where do my tax dollars go? Against me?"
Justice Department officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said yesterday that they decided to join the lawsuit last year at the request of the Oneidas, because their review of the case showed that the Indians had a right to the land and that negotiations with the state had clearly stalled.
The Oneidas contend that New York State violated the Federal Trade and Intercourse Act of 1790, which prohibited states from acquiring land from Indians without Federal approval. They argue that between 1795 and 1840, the state and local governments made 26 treaties and several purchase agreements with the Oneidas to acquire all but 32 of the 270,000 acres now in dispute.
Almost none of those transactions were approved by Congress, lawyers for the Justice Department and the Oneidas say, making the sales invalid.
In 1985, the Supreme Court upheld that argument in a "test case" filed by the Oneidas that named Oneida and Madison Counties as defendants and claimed just 900 acres. At that point, the state opened negotiations with the Oneidas, and the litigation was put on hold for the next 13 years, until the Oneidas and the Justice Department moved to expand the case in December.
The Justice Department's actions have prompted a spate of finger-pointing, with the Pataki administration and the Oneidas blaming each other for stonewalling the talks.
The Governor's office contends that negotiations have stalled largely because there are three groups of Oneidas who are parties to the lawsuit -- one in New York, one in Wisconsin and one in Ontario, Canada -- and that they have often feuded over strategy and goals. But aides to the Governor contended that even fractured talks with the Oneidas are preferable to the new legal tack chosen by the Justice Department.
"We think the Federal Government has turned its back on the people of central New York," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki. "We think it would be much more productive if they played a helpful role in negotiations rather than taking sides."
Responding to Mr. Pataki's criticisms yesterday, Justice Department officials said their goal is to reach a negotiated settlement, and they noted that they have agreed -- along with all the other parties -- to having a mediator appointed by the court to speed the talks.
Raymond Halbritter, the elected leader of the Oneida Indian Nation of New York, asserted that Mr. Pataki had been poorly served by his legal advisers, who did not recognize the Oneidas' frustration with the turtle's pace of the negotiations.
"We regret that we have to litigate," said Mr. Halbritter, whose grandmother, Mary Cornelius Winder, began advocating the land claim more than 70 years ago. "These are our neighbors and friends; we would like a future here. We know they are angry. But we think that most reasonable people, once they know the history, know we didn't want to sue so many property owners. But we really had no choice."
In addition to the Oneidas, New York State is embroiled in land claims cases with three other tribes: the Mohawk along the St. Lawrence River, the Senecas near Buffalo and the Cayugas in the Finger Lakes.
Over the past 25 years, the Federal Government has resolved at least 10 such Indian land claims in Connecticut, Maine and other states, usually by creating funds with state and Federal money that allow tribes to purchase land in a proscribed area from willing sellers, Justice Department officials said.
The lands acquired that way have then become part of their recognized reservations, exempt from local sales and property taxes and eligible for a variety of Federal services. Officials said they knew of no cases in which people who have purchased land in disputed areas have been forced to give it back to the Indians.
Officials in Oneida and Madison Counties, where the 270,000 acres are located, said there was no evidence yet that the suit had caused title insurance companies to stop issuing policies or banks to withhold mortgages. They also said there was no indication that property values had been affected or that people were having trouble selling land.
But Ralph J. Eannace, the Oneida County Executive, said he had heard of numerous cases of property owners canceling contracts to expand or improve their homes or commercial buildings.
"There is no question that the uncertainty raised by the possession claim is doing damage," Mr. Eannace said. "It has worried people, caused a great deal of anxiety and had a chilling affect on our economy."
Oneida officials have asserted that the land claim area has an assessed value of more than $1 billion. But they have signaled a willingness to accept less money than that in exchange for other concessions from the state. For instance, Mr. Halbritter has floated the idea of creating a large economic development zone where the Oneidas could use an array of tax incentives to attract large manufacturers to the region.
Last year, Mr. Halbritter also suggested that the suit could be resolved if the state allowed the Oneidas to open a casino at the Monticello Racetrack in Rockland County. But Mr. Halbritter said the Pataki administration demanded that 90 percent of the profits go to the state, which the Oneidas rejected.
State and Indian officials have also said privately that a land claims settlement could be used to resolve several long-standing issues between the Oneidas and the state.
For instance, the Oneidas have sought state approval to install slot machines and sell alcohol in their Turning Stone casino near Verona. And the state has been seeking Oneida approval for a system to collect sales taxes on gasoline and other products sold on Oneida land to non-Indians.
What is engendering some of the bitterness among property owners toward the Oneidas now is the Indians' new affluence. When the suit was first filed, the Oneidas had dwindled to a few hundred families, many of them living in trailer homes.
Today, the nation operates a successful casino, two hotels, a convention center, a T-shirt printing plant, five gasoline stations and eight restaurants. It employs 3,000 people.
But several local officials praised the Indians for bringing jobs to the economically struggling region. And they said the Oneidas' latest legal maneuver had at least forced public officials to focus on the problem.
"I was very unhappy with the suit the Oneidas filed," Representative Sherwood Boehlert, a Republican from Utica, said. "But the silver lining is that it has prompted everyone to pay attention."

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Bumper Crops in 1998, But Farmers Face Losses

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Corn and soybean farmers had bumper crops last year, but the loss of overseas markets and low prices brought economic trouble to many farm communities. Some analysts say this year will probably bring more of the same.
"We've got very large supplies but lackluster demand," said Mike Singer, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. "I think it would almost take some sort of weather problem that cuts production to really give a big boost to prices." 
 Wheat farmers have already responded to last year's record low prices by planting less of their winter wheat crop this year, making it the smallest since 1972, the Agriculture Department said today.
The look at this year's crops came as the department released its 1998 crop figures. In many cases, like soybeans and corn, farmers had bumper production years.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
After Russian Lesson, Bond Prices Remain Stable in Latest Crisis

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
This time investors were better prepared to absorb the shock.
In contrast to the aftermath of Russia's collapse in August, the initial flight to safety that followed the Brazilian currency devaluation yesterday did not turn to panic in American stock and bond markets. Big bettors learned their lesson: Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me. 
 Bond prices soared as soon as Brazil announced its devaluation; investors rushed to the immediate safety of the Treasury market. But bonds gave up much of their gain by the day's end, with the price of the 30-year Treasury bond rising 16/32 , to 10128/32 , and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, moving down to 5.13 percent, from 5.20 percent Tuesday.
In the corporate bond market, which froze up after the Russian collapse, big-name bonds rallied to trim their early losses by the end of the day.
There was even time for joking on trading floors once the American stock market began to recover. "How does Brazil solve its problems?" ran the big question of the day. The answer: "Change its name to Brazil.com, and it can take off like the Internet stocks."
When Russia suddenly devalued its currency and effectively defaulted on its debt in mid-August, investors around the world were stunned. Many refused to believe the United States and the International Monetary Fund would allow Russia to collapse until it actually happened.
But with that experience still fresh in the memories of market participants, Brazil's policy reversal -- which stopped far short of full-scale devaluation and default -- did not come as much of a surprise.
"A major lesson learned last summer was that there could be default on sovereign debt," said Denis Adler, the corporate bond strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. "People had forgotten that and discounted it as a risk then."
Meanwhile, investors have become much more risk averse, moving away from markets that they think are vulnerable. They are no longer borrowing so much, either, to make big bets -- known on Wall street as leveraging. That means they are not as vulnerable to outsized losses and panic selling to cover their loans. This kind of leverage was also at the heart of the near collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund whose losses spooked investors in September.
"Timing is very important," said Lawrence J. Brainard, the global head of emerging market research at Chase Securities. "The markets have had time to reduce leverage and exposure."
Jim Claire, the head of the taxable fixed-income trading desk at First Capital Group in Charlotte, N.C., said: "Everyone is saying it is not the end of the world. We have been down this road before."
Russia's collapse sent investors fleeing to the American Treasury market, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond down to 4.72 percent in early October. The fear of any risk effectively froze trading in the corporate and high-yield junk bond markets and even hindered the trading of older Treasury securities.
In response, the Federal Reserve, fearing that the smooth functioning of the world's financial system was threatened, cut its interest-rate target three times.
The Russian debacle also forced many money managers to sell profitable holdings they would normally have kept just because they had to offset huge losses in emerging markets like Russia, where selling was difficult.
Another factor that could contain the contagion this time is that there are very different players at the center of the trading action. In Russia, many of the losing bets were made by hedge funds that had put far too many of their investment eggs in one basket, forcing them to sell quickly. In Brazil, the big American and foreign banks are the main players in the currency market. They are bigger, more diversified and there is less pressure to sell, according to one executive at a major bank. And these institutions, after Russia, have trimmed their investments in Brazil and Latin America to lessen risk.
The situation is still delicate and the news from Brazil is far from positive for many investors. Uncertainty over what will happen next in Brazil is bound to hang over world financial markets for some time.
The cost of emerging-market debt rose sharply yesterday, although it, too, rallied a little by the end of the day. The J. P. Morgan emerging-market bond index, which shows the difference in the yield countries must pay to sell emerging market bonds and the yield on comparable United States Treasury securities, jumped to 14.26 percentage points yesterday. It is still below its peak of 17.05 percentage points in September but above its recent low of 9.44 percent in November.
Many of the problems in Brazil and other emerging markets "are still with us," said Desmond Lachman, the director of emerging markets economic research at Salomon Smith Barney. He said Brazil still had the potential to roil markets.
And Arturo C. Porzecanski, chief economist for the Americas at ING Barings, was worried that other shoes might still drop. The devaluation, he suggested, may be "too little and may be too soon."
"The other parts of the program are not in place yet," he said.
For all the nagging fears of the future, though, the reaction of American financial markets shows that the system is not as vulnerable to bad news as it was in August.

HEADLINE: Retailers' 3d-Quarter After-Tax Profits Off

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Profits after taxes at major United States retailers fell during the third quarter of 1998 to the lowest level in more than a year, the Commerce Department said today.
After-tax profits at major retailers with assets of $50 million or more averaged 1.9 cents a dollar of sales during the third quarter. That is down from the 2.3 cents in the second quarter and 2 cents in the third quarter of 1997. 
 Last year's third-quarter average was the lowest since an average of 1.5 cents a dollar of sales for the second quarter of 1997, the Government said.
Retailers' after-tax profits totaled $5.1 billion during the third quarter, compared with the second quarter's $6.1 billion. Profits after taxes totaled $5 billion in the third quarter of 1997.
After-tax return on stockholders' equity in the companies totaled 10.8 percent at an annual rate in the third quarter, down from a 12.8 percent rate in the second quarter and a 11.1 percent rate in the third quarter of 1997, the Government said.
The Commerce Department's estimates were based on quarterly financial reports from 503 retailers.

HEADLINE: A Test Case for Investing Inclusion

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
When the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson opens up the Wall Street Project conference on minorities and investment today, one of the central players is expected to be Mel Farr, who heads the nation's largest black-owned auto dealership.
Mr. Farr, who operates dealerships in Michigan, Ohio and Texas, has been held up by Mr. Jackson as one of the nation's leading minority entrepreneurs, a prime candidate for Wall Street to look to if it is going to invest in minority businesses and neighborhoods. 
 But Wall Street has not yet embraced Mr. Farr's effort to raise $45 million in a private placement of asset-backed securities to expand his Mel Farr Automotive Group dealerships.
"I don't have anything concrete yet," said Mr. Farr, who plans to meet this week with officials at Citigroup and Goldman, Sachs & Company. "This is a test. We want inclusion. I've got a portfolio of investment grade, and now I want to see if they're going to invest in an African-American business that does business in the African-American community."
In some ways, Mr. Farr, 54, might be seen as a test case for the Wall Street Project, which Mr. Jackson and Mr. Farr say is all about investing in the "emerging markets of urban areas."
"He comes to Wall Street looking for access to capital," Mr. Jackson said last night. "And we're going to work hard for him." Of Wall Street, he added: "They can't say they can't find a guy. They have a guy. He comes to the plate with all the qualities."
Indeed, over the last few decades, Mr. Farr, a former pro football player, says he has turned a bunch of failing dealerships in the Detroit area into a business with more than $600 million in revenue. He built his business selling and leasing cars in poor neighborhoods, to minorities with little or no credit, often at high interest rates. He says that for many it is their only way to get transportation for some jobs.
Although he caters primarily to minorities, he also has dealerships in largely white neighborhoods. His sales are often bolstered by television ads aimed at blacks that feature "Superstar Mel Farr" with Mr. Farr in a suit and a red cape. And until recently, there were also television ads that spotlighted a white actor in commercials done for a dealership in Fairfield, Ohio, which Mr. Farr says illustrates how difficult it is to cross over in some areas. "It's a market that is primarily white Americans, and I didn't want to turn off those customers because I am black," he said.

HEADLINE: France, in Break With U.S., Urges End to Iraq Embargo

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 13

 BODY:
France, making a formal break with the United States and Britain, proposed today that the Security Council lift the oil embargo on Iraq and institute a new weapons monitoring system to prevent Saddam Hussein from rearming.
"The embargo has become the wrong tool to achieve the goals of the Security Council," said the French proposal, which circulated today to all Council members. "It needs to be lifted." 
 The United States rejected most major points in the French proposal in advance at a Council discussion last month on Iraq. Keeping Iraq under tight sanctions, including forbidding the country to sell oil freely to raise money for arms, has been central to American policy.
The State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said today that the French proposals had "some positive elements," including the calls for continued arms monitoring and some supervision of oil earnings. But he reiterated the American position that sanctions could not be lifted until Iraqi arms programs had been rendered harmless.
"We have a number of questions and concerns that we are going to address to France about the proposal," Mr. Rubin said.
The initial reaction from Iraq, which would have to agree to a new monitoring system, was largely negative. Vice President Taha Yassin Ramadan said at a news conference such proposals, including similar ideas floated by Saudi Arabia, "carry conditions that lead to exchanging eight-year-old sanctions with a new embargo."
The French said in their plan that the oil embargo could no longer be defended, because "it hurts the people of Iraq and keeps them hostages of their authorities."
France would lift solely the oil embargo initially, leaving in place other sanctions like a ban on international air travel. Other sanctions would be removed only if the Iraqis demonstrate cooperation and compliance with new rules. Conversely, additional sanctions could be imposed "should Iraq not comply with its undertakings and obligations."
The French propose replacing the arms inspection commission with a "renewed control commission" that would have a preventive rather than investigative role, watching for signs of illegal arms use from existing stocks or attempts to buy or produce new prohibited weapons. Long-term monitoring would replace intrusive searches for evidence of past programs.
Many tons of Iraqi weapons and ammunition have been destroyed since the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991. But questions remain about unaccounted materiel like biological and chemical stocks and the missiles to deliver them.
Iraq was also found to have had a secret nuclear-weapons program. But the International Atomic Energy Agency has said it can find no evidence of arms or components to assemble them, a conclusion that independent American arms experts challenge.
Using language heard frequently from Iraq and Russia, the French proposal said that the control commission should "have its independence insured and it professionalism strengthened." In the past those have been code words for shielding the inspections from American influence or pressure and putting them under the United Nations international Civil Service structure.
Under the French proposal, which was first outlined on Tuesday to other permanent members of the Security Council -- Britain, China, Russia and the United States -- a financial surveillance system would be devised to watch Iraqi expenditures from oil profits.
The plan does not call for an escrow account to keep the money under supervision, as is now the case under the program that allows Iraq to sell limited amounts of oil to buy food, medicine and other goods needed to improve living standards.
Buyers of Iraqi oil and the Iraqi Government would have to notify the United Nations Secretariat, not the Security Council, of each sale. "Oil flows should be controlled on the ground," the proposal says.
The aim of financial surveillance would be to compel Iraq to meet its obligations to pay outstanding war claims and pay for a new monitoring system from oil earnings without "diverting these resources for the reconstitution of weapons of mass destruction."
The French are suggesting that all arms sales to Iraq be prohibited and imports of other materials that could be used in weapons development be policed and restricted. All other Iraqi purchases could be made freely without surveillance.
The United States has repeatedly said the oil embargo, the most important of numerous economic sanctions imposed after the invasion of Kuwait in 1990, cannot be lifted until the Iraqis have been judged to have met all disarmament requirements set out in the 1991 cease-fire resolution after the gulf war.
Those requirements have not been met. Existing resolutions governing them would, in effect, have to be annulled, a step that could paralyze the Security Council.
Although offering no proposals on salvaging the arms inspection system carried out by the United Nations Special Commission, the American delegation is expected to oppose monitoring methods that do not allow intrusive inspections, even though the Clinton Administration did not press for them for much of last year.
The French emphasize that their proposals are meant to generate debate and some action in the Security Council, which has been largely inert on the subject of Iraq since American and British bombing raids last month effectively killed the existing inspection system.
President Hussein has made it clear that the inspectors of the Special Commission, who were withdrawn hours before the air strikes, will never be allowed to return. Diplomats say they do not see how force can reimpose the work of the commission.
Today Vice President Ramadan was unequivocal, saying, "Any talk about the future of the commission, whether it has to do with beautifying its ugliness or to change one of its spies, its makeup or the role of one of its members, we say, is a waste of time."
In Paris the French Foreign Ministry said it was impossible to resurrect the Special Commission. "France thinks that it is time for the U.N. Security Council to consider that no progress can be made by an illusory resumption of previous methods," a statement from the ministry said.
The executive chairman of the commission, Richard Butler, continues to argue that the agency, known as Unscom, is not dead, and will have a new role to play in whatever system is ultimately devised.
The Iraqis will have to accept any plan imposed on them, however. Mr. Hussein has always chafed at international controls, and the French proposal maintains some significant ones.

HEADLINE: Fujimori's Burden in Peru: The Magic's Missing

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: CORPACANCHA, Peru, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Claudencia Martin Gustavo cheered when President Alberto K. Fujimori, defying the thin mountain air in this remote village 12,000 feet above sea level, took two women into his arms and twirled them in a vigorous Indian folk dance.
He cheered as the President passed out pink blouses and beige pants to local llama and alpaca herders. And he cheered again when the Peruvian leader, already in campaign mode, donned a rather unpresidential poncho, and talked about bringing telephones and electricity to this settlement of 1,000 people. 
 But Mr. Gustavo said he doubted he would vote a third time for Mr. Fujimori because "we don't have enough food and our incomes are not enough for our families."
A recession caused by stormy weather and the Asian economic crisis has swung Peru's political mood against the President, who has dominated this country for nearly a decade. Once widely popular for rescuing Peru from terrorism, cocaine trafficking and hyperinflation, Mr. Fujimori is struggling to recapture the magic that brought him two election victories. Whether he can regain it will determine if he will run again next year.
The son of Japanese immigrants, Mr. Fujimori bolted out of nowhere as an independent populist to win the presidency in 1990.
But he governed as a tough-minded free-market conservative. Faced with a spreading wave of terrorism, he unleashed the military and intelligence services and quickly captured the most important rebel leaders. He even ordered the air force to shoot down planes loaded with Peruvian coca paste destined for Colombia, leading to a rapid decline in trafficking and coca cultivation.
His "Fuji-shock" treatment yielded a wave of privatizations of inefficient state enterprises and attracted foreign capital.
And with crucial military support, he replaced the Congress and Supreme Court in 1992 with like-minded officials. His actions drew heavy criticism from the United States and human rights activists, but the terrorists lost ground and President Fujimori won re-election overwhelmingly in 1995.
But now support for the 60-year-old President in the polls has dwindled to about 35 percent. His popularity declined even after he negotiated a peace treaty with Ecuador late last year, forcing him to replace his Prime Minister and shuffle his Cabinet last week.
While Mr. Fujimori has not signaled his political intentions, his supporters say he is gearing up to run again. But some analysts say that if his poll ratings do not improve in the next six to eight months, he may decide to forgo the election.
His standing has deteriorated mainly because of a recession that resulted first from El Nino, which caused major flood damage and pushed important varieties of fish from Peru's shoreline, causing hardship for the country's substantial fish-meal industry.
A decline in commodities prices brought on by the Asian crisis, especially for Peru's copper and tin, has reduced economic growth. The Peruvian economy, which registered double-digit growth rates in the early 90's, stalled to zero growth in the last quarter. The unemployment and underemployment rate has risen in recent months from 40 percent to 50 percent.
"The people are hungry, unemployed and tired of Fujimori," said Javier Valle Riestra, who was Prime Minister for two months last year. "He can only make it to re-election by fraud and blood."
Mr. Fujimori has been buffeted by widespread criticism that he manipulated the courts and electoral tribunals to sidestep a constitutional ban on a third term. His claim that his 1992 "self-coup" improved the justice system has been tarnished in recent months by scandals, including the case of two judges filmed taking bribes from drug traffickers.
And a new book about Vladimiro Montesinos, Mr. Fujimori's unofficial chief of intelligence, describes the President as a virtual prisoner of a sinister, power-hungry spy. The book has become an instant best seller.
Mr. Fujimori cannot be counted out, however. The Ministry of the Presidency controls 40 percent of the national budget, and it is already turning on a pork-barrel spigot for bridges and roads. And the opposition remains splintered.
Nevertheless, opinion polls and political analysts suggest that the surge President Fujimori received in 1997 with the rescue of 71 hostages held by terrorists in the Japanese Ambassador's residence has faded.
"I would say re-election is possible, but very difficult," said Alfredo Torres, a leading Lima poll taker. "The question is whether the recuperation of the Peruvian and world economy will come fast enough."
In a recent interview, Mr. Fujimori predicted that his new Cabinet would help his Government recover much of its luster. He said he would be able to crank up economic growth by better than 5 percent this year -- far higher than the consensus 2 percent of independent economists -- unless neighboring Brazil suffers a complete economic meltdown.
Mr. Fujimori made many promises as he doodled on a piece of paper in a wood-paneled office in the Government Palace. He pledged to further reduce Peru's coca-growing area -- already cut by more than half in three years thanks partly to eradication -- by an additional 20 to 30 percent this year. He predicted that the new treaty with Ecuador would lead to yearly savings of $400 million in military spending. And he promised to hunt down the handful of rebels left in the mountains.
"Before there was terrorism, now there is stability," Mr. Fujimori said, as if practicing a campaign speech. "Before we had economic chaos, now we have order. Before we were isolated internationally, now we have friends again. Before we had conflict with Ecuador, now we live in peace."
He refused to rule out a re-election bid, adding, "I don't have to decide yet." But for the last two years, Mr. Fujimori and his allies who form a majority in Congress have been acting as if he intends to run in 2000.
The 1993 Peruvian Constitution prohibits the President from running for a consecutive third term. But in 1996 Mr. Fujimori's supporters in Congress passed a law that granted him an exception, arguing that his first term did not count since it began before the new Constitution was written.
Members of the opposition appealed to the seven-member Constitutional Tribunal, saying the exemption was unconstitutional. Three of the judges agreed, three abstained, and the head judge upheld the 3-to-0 decision against Mr. Fujimori. In May 1997, Congress dismissed the three judges who opposed their law on the ground that they had exceeded their authority, opening the way for a third Fujimori campaign.
The opposition mounted a signature drive to petition Congress to hold a referendum on the issue of a third term. By July 1998 it had collected enough signatures, but the Congress ruled that two-thirds of its members would have to clear the way for any referendum, and President Fujimori's majority blocked it.
"They do not trust civilian, democratic institutions," said Lourdes Flores Nano, an opposition Congresswoman. "The polls say he can't win, but if the group at the head of the army insists on Fujimori, the possibility of fraud is very high."
Mr. Fujimori denied that he had manipulated the system and said Congress was doing its democratic duty.
He underscored how much Peru has changed on his trip to Corpacancha. He would not have dared come to this Andean village 85 miles northeast of Lima without an army battalion when he first took office in 1990. In those days, Shining Path terrorists played soccer with the skulls of their victims in these highlands.
But this Sunday, Mr. Fujimori dropped by this settlement in a helicopter with only a light escort of bodyguards to enjoy a mountainside picnic, pass out gifts and promise new roads, tourism projects and credits to expand the villagers' production of llamas, alpacas and sheep.
As the peasants swelled around him as they received their gifts, he cried out: "Order! Order! This country needs order, no?" The peasants dutifully obeyed and the chaos gave way to three neat lines.
In appreciation for the presidential gifts, the peasants gave Mr. Fujimori a sheep with the Peruvian flag tied around its neck and a hunk of barbecued alpaca to go with the French wine and Polish vodka he brought along on the trip.
Then Mr. Fujimori assembled the reporters traveling with him, and via satellite telephone gave a nationally broadcast news conference.
"This Government gets results," President Fujimori told his people.

HEADLINE: Ex-Aide to Reagan Will Head the Congressional Budget Office

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Dan L. Crippen, who worked for President Ronald Reagan and for Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader in the early 1980's, was chosen today to be director of the Congressional Budget Office, a powerful agency with an influential voice in debates on economic and social policy.
Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, announced the selection, after getting agreement from the Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, and the chairman of the House Budget Committee, John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio. 
 Mr. Crippen, 46, is more clearly identified with a political party than any of his predecessors. But he is expected to continue the agency's tradition as an independent, nonpartisan source of information.
The budget office estimates the cost of every significant bill that goes to the floor of the House or the Senate; makes projections of Federal spending and tax revenues, and forecasts how the economy will perform. The Congressional Budget Office can, in effect, kill legislative proposals if it estimates that they will significantly increase the deficit or reduce the surplus.
Mr. Crippen worked on economic and domestic policy on Capitol Hill and at the White House. He went to the White House with Mr. Baker in 1987, when Mr. Baker became chief of staff for Mr. Reagan. Since leaving the White House in February 1989, Mr. Crippen has been a Washington lobbyist. His current clients include the Ford Motor Company, General Electric, Merrill Lynch and the Baxter Healthcare Corporation.
Kenneth M. Duberstein, former deputy chief of staff in the Reagan White House, described Mr. Crippen as "a pragmatic conservative."
Mr. Crippen would be the fifth director of the budget office. Democratic members of Congress say they see him as a mainstream Republican, but worry that he does not have as much formal training in economic theory as his predecessors. He received a bachelor's degree from the University of South Dakota and a Ph.D. in public administration and economics from Ohio State University in 1981.
The budget office director serves a four-year term and is jointly appointed by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tem of the Senate.
Republicans chose the agency's current director, June E. O'Neill, but House Republican leaders harshly criticized her last June. In a letter, they said that the budget office had been "consistently wrong" and had repeatedly understated economic growth and overstated budget deficits.
In a meeting with Mr. Crippen this week, Senator Lott made clear that he saw plenty of room for improvements. Some conservative Republicans have complained that the agency is dominated by what they see as the old-fashioned liberal views of career civil servants in senior positions.
Prof. William H. Oakland, who advised Mr. Crippen on his doctoral dissertation, described him as "a low-key but tenacious guy" and said he was "one of my favorite students in 35 years of teaching." In an interview, Mr. Oakland said: "Dan's training in economic theory is not as rigorous as that of some people with a Ph.D. in economics, but he has more training in areas directly germane to the operation of government, like budgeting, management and the legislative process."
From 1989 to 1996, Mr. Crippen was senior vice president of the Duberstein Group, a consulting firm. Since 1996, Mr. Crippen has been a principal in Washington Counsel, a law and lobbying firm.

HEADLINE: Progress Is a Slow Train for Girls' Teams

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
Oshto Edobor-Osula, 17, plays basketball.
At the school she attends, Jamaica High School in Queens, there is a girls' team. But the team plays home games in a third-floor gymnasium that has no bleachers and, until recently, no time clock. Students who attend games either stand for four quarters or drag chairs in from nearby classrooms. 
 "The downstairs gym where the boys' basketball team plays has bleachers, so they usually get a larger crowd than us," Oshto said softly. "I don't think the girls' team gets the support of the student body. But that's understandable. Nobody wants to stand for an hour to watch a basketball game."
Oshto stands as a 6-foot-3-inch reflection of sports programs for girls in the New York city public school system: although there is growing awareness of the need to improve and expand athletic opportunities for girls, inequities still exist between boys' and girls' programs. That the facilities are meager, and often worse than the boys', is par for the course. That girls like Oshto are playing team sports at all counts as significant progress. Consider this: today, 155 of 165 high schools have some girls' sports programs, but 45 of them offer 3 or fewer.
Although more girls than ever are now playing high school sports -- about 18,000 of the system's 40,000 student athletes are girls -- there are 134,000 girls who may still be missing out, whether by design or choice. Many may have interpreted the meager resources, the drastic cutbacks in physical education and an overall environment that fails to actively encourage girls to participate, as indications that sports are not important.
"If you ask some of the girls here to play basketball, it's like you're trying to teach them something from Mars," said Susan Sucreta, a physical education teacher at Jamaica.
While all things may never be equal when it comes to the games boys and girls play, this past year, the Public Schools Athletic League, the Board of Education agency responsible for administering high school sports, increased funds for girls' sports programs by more than $1 million and approved requests for nearly a third more girls' varsity and junior varsity teams.
"Obviously, we've done a complete turnaround, in terms of the numbers of sports programs offered boys and the numbers offered girls," said Thomas Hemans, director of the P.S.A.L.
Whatever gains girls have achieved, however, they often came through court mandates or public advocacy, and typically amount to little more than the bare necessities.
"The reality is that sports programs are shortchanged," said Kenneth Trell, assistant principal and athletic director at Jamaica. Trell acknowledged that his attitude was shaped not only by his role as educator, but also as the parent of a 10-year-old daughter. "In order to get the extras, a lot of student athletes have to fund-raise. As a parent, I resent that."
Besides, the extras usually go to the boys. Girls are lucky to get the leftover leftovers. It may not be fair, but in some financially strapped school districts, it's not even an issue: parents just aren't prepared to spend hard-earned money on candy or greeting cards to pay for new protective vests for the fencing team. "Because it's such an institutionalized setup that sports is for boys and girls are on the fringe, it's taken a very long time to overcome sexual discrimination in the sports programs provided through the P.S.A.L.," said Barbara T. Rochman, whose 1994 Board of Education task force found widespread discrepancies in spending on girls and boys programs.
Nationwide, the number of girls attending college on sports scholarships has risen from 19,203 in 1992-93 to 25,284 in 1996-97, the National Collegiate Athletic Association says. It can't be determined whether the city has maximized girls' chances for scholarships. That responsibility rests mainly with school administrators, coaches and athletes. The P.S.A.L. and the Board of Education don't keep scholarship data.
 Nearly everyone acknowledges that, had the city spent more money and had concentrated more effort at promoting sports for girls, and making it easier for them to play, many of the chances for scholarships that are out there for the begging might have been gained.
Schools such as Jamaica, at least, are making an honest effort and have succeeded more than most in giving girls a fair shot at athletics, be it competitively or through physical education. Yet Jamaica, like so many other schools, struggles daily to change the athletic ethos within the school and beyond.
There are also intangibles to consider, things such as the ethnic and cultural traditions that often shape girls' attitudes about femininity, competition and aggression. Even with opportunities, black and Hispanic girls are less likely to play on a sports team than whites, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.
The reasons for such discrepancies vary, say experts like Dr. Mary Jo Kane, director of the Tucker Center for Research on Girls and Women in Sports at the University of Minnesota. "Economics, family priorities," she noted, adding that her observations were rooted chiefly in anecdotal evidence. "When you have groups who historically have been marginalized and stigmatized with respect to certain issues like sports, for females in general and blacks in particular, it's not enough to put a sign up and say come play. It takes progressive outreach."
Tiehise Shell and Shawana Wilson, members of Jamaica's girls' track team, are black teen-age girls who have managed to excel, academically and athletically, in spite of the system.
The two seniors have received several scholarship offers from colleges and universities and their parents scraped together the money to pay for outside coaches. "The city should be doing more for us," said Tiehise as Shawana nodded in approval. "They don't even pay for our transportation to meets."
 At the least, they said, some support from top city officials would help. "Each year, we have a Mayor's Trophy meet, but the Mayor doesn't come," Tiehise said. "Why do we have a meet for him, and he doesn't come. We're not asking him to stay. Just come, wish us good luck and then he can say, 'Goodbye.' "
