HEADLINE: Separate but Unequal: 2 Schools' Tales

SERIES: DROPPING THE BALL: The Decline Of School Sports -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Tottenville High School, at the southern tip of Staten Island, has one of largest expanses of artificial turf in the world, a sprawling $7.3 million hyper-green carpet on which it can conduct three major sporting events at once without conflict. At Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, the sports program went broke last spring, forcing the school's principal, Lena B. Medley, to beg the P.T.A. for a handout.
Students and alumni at Tottenville raised most of the cost of a $5 million field house last year through donations of cash, labor and material. Coaches at Jefferson raise $20, on a good day, selling coffee and doughnuts outside the school office to buy uniforms for the track and soccer teams. 
 Both schools get the same funds from the city: about $2,500 for all their teams for a whole year, not counting stipends for coaches. And while Tottenville, with 3,800 students, raised about $75,000 from the local community to make its program the envy of the city, Jefferson, with 1,500 students, struggled to raise $10,000 to try to get by.
Neither school gets enough money or support from the city for even a minimal athletic program. Where they differ is in how they face that problem, and in the consequences that play out in the lives of students and teachers and coaches in two deeply dissimilar corners of New York. Sports at Tottenville and Jefferson, in their individual stories of scramble and struggle, reflect the economic health of their communities and the apathy or enthusiasm of coaches and parents. And the city's school sports program makes no attempt to even things out.
"Some got it, some don't -- that's essentially it," said Jefferson's head football coach, Keith A. Merriman, who had to tell his team this year -- for the first time in a 22-year coaching career -- that there wasn't even enough money to buy new football jerseys, and that last year's would have to be used. "In a lot of instances, you're paying for where your school happens to be located, not for what you can do as a coach, or even what kind of kids you have in your program," Mr. Merriman said.
Sports in the New York City public schools once offered a mechanism for bridging the lives of young people from different backgrounds. A team traveling to another school for a game could be reminded that kids are kids, and that there are often more similarities that unite than differences than divide. But that bridge has become harder and harder to provide. As the burden of maintaining school athletics has been shifted to the schools over the last two decades, places like Tottenville and Jefferson really have become independent and different.
The stark differences in New York's neighborhoods -- economic as well as cultural -- have been underlined and emphasized by its public school sports programs, rather than diminished. School sports, under such conditions, are evolving differently in each place, as schools search for a path forward.
At Tottenville, for example, about one out of four students this year is participating in a school sport -- more than 1,000 teen-agers on 41 different teams, from freshman baseball to handball and fencing. At Jefferson, 22 miles away and in the heart of East New York, only one student out of eight participates -- 180 boys and girls on 18 teams. At Tottenville, students ride buses to events. At Jefferson, they mostly take public transportation or ride with their coaches -- violating school-system rules -- because chartered buses are not an option.
There were always differences between New York high schools, of course -- some had good teams, some didn't. But the new inequality extends beyond final scores and good and bad teams. Now, there are the haves and the have-nots. Some schools have access to the money needed to run a high-quality athletic program. Others are frozen out. Some schools can get nice uniforms, and others are reduced, as was the Brooklyn girls' volleyball team that visited Tottenville for a game earlier this year, to taping their numbers on old T-shirts.
Some schools have playing fields in good repair; others go to practice with coaches and players holding their breath as to who might turn an ankle in a rut, or fall on a jagged rock.
But Tottenville and Jefferson also share certain haunting similarities.
Jefferson, known to generations of New York students as simply, "Jeff," occupies a massive brick-and-stone building that dominates its neighborhood. Its tiled hallways and 70-year-old honor roll plaques resonate with a weighty grandeur, echoing the decades when its name was associated with all that high school -- both in sports and schooling -- meant in New York.
Stories are still told here about Jefferson legends like the football coach Moe Finkelstein. He retired 12 years ago, but coaches still remember, even today, how he took his coffee: black. And if you took it any other way yourself, you were a wimp.
Tottenville's grandeur is different, but just as evident. Designed in the 1960's to look more like a college campus than an old-style urban school fortress, it sprawls across the land, languid in its dominance. There are no metal detectors, no guards patrolling the halls. Tottenville is about as relaxed as a high school can be in New York City.
Yet both schools are isolated: Jefferson by poverty, Tottenville by geography. There are no grocery stores or movie theaters or shopping malls near either one. As institutions, they are both still powerful landmarks and symbols, but the roles they play in their very different worlds have diverged.
 
Community Anchor
'Small-Town' Lives Focused on Sports
In the early 1990's, when the rest of the New York City school system was being transformed by an innovation called "educational options," in which a student could choose a high school other than the one in his or her own neighborhood, Staten Island held itself apart. Parents groups came forward, saying they liked the old ways. The Board of Education created a system called "internal choice" for the Staten Island schools that allowed them to keep their traditional roles as community anchors, schools that students in a given geographic area were expected to attend.
The superintendent in charge of high schools in Staten Island and Western Brooklyn then, Noel Kriftcher, said he thought that allowed Tottenville High School to keep its role as the centerpiece of life on the southern edge of Staten Island. And that, in turn, has fed back on the school's sports teams, which still stand for and captivate community and student spirit in a way that much of New York City has forgot.
"Schools in Staten Island are still largely tied to communities," Mr. Kriftcher said. "You don't have that in a lot of areas of New York City anymore, where schools are smaller or newer or are no longer identified with a particular community."
Tottenville is not, by any measure, New York City's richest neighborhood. The annual income per person in the school's zone is just slightly higher than that of the city as a whole. But the winding, often wooded thoroughfares like Hylan Boulevard feel more like Westchester County or New Jersey. Unemployment is lower than in the rest of the city, at about 5 percent, and home ownership rates are higher -- with about three of four residents in the district owning their own homes, according to the United States Census Bureau.
But the bigger force is stability, residents say. It's easy to find people whose grandfathers and grandmothers grew up in Tottenville and never left. More than half of the teachers at the school have been there for more than 20 years.
"Usually a generation picks up and goes, but people here didn't pull out," said Bill Leyes, owner of Tottenville Trading, an antique shop. "A lot of us are still together, that's all. I've been here 40 years."
That stability has also created, or preserved, a kind of cloistered world. In a vast city where people often barely even know their neighbors, Tottenville is a small town.
"When I see someone I don't know," said Rabiye Tala, a 17-year old soccer player at Tottenville, "I think, 'How come I don't know them?' "
And sports -- focused through Tottenville High, like light through a lens -- is the mechanism that gives small-town Tottenville its identity and its passion. It's what people have in common.
At a time when the Board of Education is distancing itself from the daily operations of high schools sports, Tottenville's stubborn retention of old-fashioned sports boosterism has become an overwhelming trump card that connects directly to money and student participation and, many coaches in and out of the school say, to victories. In the last six years, the school has won more than a dozen city championships in football, baseball, soccer and track.
Indeed, sports is not so much an extracurricular activity in this school as it is an embrace. Local residents, including many former Tottenville athletes, volunteer to help coach. The annual sports parade through the center of Tottenville every April is one of the biggest events of the year.
Janet Mosscuzza, Tottenville's girls' volleyball coach and assistant athletic director, said she was approached last year after a game by a little girl -- maybe 6 years old -- probably some 10 years away from high school, but already hooked by the school's mystique. "She said, 'I want to play for Tottenville one day,' " Ms. Mosscuzza said.
And parents are involved -- sometimes, almost too involved, coaches say. Their interest is constant, a blanket of sometimes almost smothering attention that coaches say they value and respect and can't ever ignore. Parents who work as stockbrokers and crane operators adjust their schedules to watch their children play. One father said he left the company he worked for so he could be a self-employed consultant who could attend his son's football games.
"I get calls all of the time," said Alan Blanc, Tottenville's athletic director. "I get calls from parents on freshman teams wondering why their son isn't playing." Sometimes, he added, "The parents care more than the kids."
Of all Tottenville sports, baseball is where that passion rises to its fever pitch. Parents even come to practices. "We enjoy a cup of coffee and watch them practice," said Linda Maklari, who has two sons on the team. "We eat, drink and sleep baseball here."
The Tottenville baseball parents club holds monthly meetings where guest speakers, including professional players and school alumni, talk to team members about hitting, training and schoolwork. When report cards come out, parents and the coach discuss the player's grades. "It's like one giant baseball family," Ms. Maklari said.
Many parents become so close through baseball that they even take a winter cruise together, a family affair where baseball remains a topic of discussion. "The boys even bring their gloves," she said.
 
The Cruelest Truth
Jefferson's Enemies Are Close at Hand
Michael Tucker, a wisp of a 15-year-old who looked all the skinnier for his oversize jeans, walked slowly across the field early last fall, a bag slung over his shoulder. He arrived, still without speaking a word, in front of Keith A. Merriman, Jefferson's head football coach, and methodically unpacked a scuffed pair of cleats, a set of worn shoulder pads, a faded practice jersey. He placed them carefully on the grass and rezipped the bag.
Only when he stood back up did he speak, and only then was it clear why he had waited. Speaking softly, he told the coach he was sorry, but he couldn't play football anymore because his mother had just kicked him out of the house and he was, as of that morning in late August, 10 days before the start of the school year and the football season, homeless. Making sports work in New York, more than ever, depends on the enthusiasm and support of families and communities -- money is just a reflection and expression of that fact.
And at Thomas Jefferson that is in many ways the cruelest truth. As much as the coaches and teachers might criticize the city's sports structure for abandoning the old ideals and standards of financing, the greater enemy is closer to hand, they say: apathy, poverty, the collapse of the family and the erosion of what holds a neighborhood together -- that's what really did in the Orange Wave.
Mr. Merriman and the junior varsity coach, Ernie General, glanced at each other with a deep, familiar weariness as Michael stood before them that day. What was the story, they asked. Where did his mother live? Did he have any other relatives? Mr. General wrote down names. Mr. Merriman said he would call Michael's mother.
"Kids shouldn't have to deal with this," Mr. Merriman said, shaking his head as he watched Michael fade into the distance.
On Jefferson's football squad of 28 boys, only 3 have both parents at home. And at the team's opening game, coaches said, only one parent came. The team was unable to raise the money for new jerseys this year, partly because of the crushing poverty in this part of the city, but also because the parents' booster club fell apart.
Attendance at Jefferson games has also nearly collapsed. Even as recently as the early 1990's, Saturday football games would attract 500 or more paying fans. Recent games, even with a winning team, have drawn only a few dozen fans at most games.
And fewer fans, coaches say, have reinforced the desolation of the school's field on Flatlands Avenue. Prostitutes who troll the streets of a nearby industrial zone sometimes bring their customers behind the field. Homeless people have erected lean-to shelters against a back fence. Even the cheerleaders, who don't have real uniforms anyway, don't seem to want to come -- they were only seen at Homecoming.
 Holding together a sports program here means a constant search, coaches and administrators say, for ways to connect to a disconnected community. In the school zone that surrounds Jefferson, nearly half of the adult residents are not in the labor force; they have given up looking for jobs.
East New York had the highest homicide rate in the city last year. Two-thirds of the residents have no cars, and poverty is enduring and deep -- more than one in eight of the households in the school's district earned less than $5,000 in 1997, according to United States Census Bureau figures.
Claude Robinson, Jefferson's athletic director, almost cries when he tells some of the sports stories that he says result from such conditions. They are not tales of financial woe for the most part, but of aborted hope. Last year, for example, a girl entered the school who made every coach's head turn, Mr. Robinson said. She was 6 feet 5 inches. She had never played basketball even once in her life, she said. But Mr. Robinson knew that didn't matter, and he went to see her parents, anyway.
"She was from a poor family, and we tried to explain to her father that this was a means of getting her through college," Mr. Robinson said. "We guaranteed her scholarships -- there was no doubt."
But the father said no. "His attitude was that she should come home and cook dinner," Mr. Robinson said of the girl's father.
Sometimes, though, there are small victories. Michael Tucker's mother changed her mind after a visit from the Jefferson coaching staff. She took her son back in and he resumed his spot as a guard and linebacker on the football team -- never missing a game.
 
Coffee and Sympathy
$10 to $20 Daily Lets Students Play
Bill Sioukas teaches gym every day for his living. But he sells coffee and doughnuts every morning so that Jefferson High can have soccer and track. Mr. Sioukas and Claudel Martin, Jefferson's track coach, came up with the idea about three years ago -- a mini-business that kicks out about $10 to $20 a day in profits for the combined fund that the coaches and friends call their war chest. The coffee cart helps pay for uniforms and transportation.
But it has also come to mean more than that. It has become a vehicle and a rallying point, a new social connection and a way of making a statement about perseverance and resourcefulness. Teachers who never talked to each other before say that they now routinely gather for a moment before the day begins. Students have volunteered to help with the business, Mr. Sioukas said, and have contributed helpful ideas.
"The kids see you working hard, they want to work hard too," Mr. Sioukas said.
Fund-raising for high school sports in New York is not an end in itself, but rather a mirror that shows how things work. And in the life of this one coach, stopping at Krispy Kreme every morning at 6:20, pouring cups of coffee and collecting coins -- all the while reminding himself of why he's doing it -- there is a deep reflection of values.
Jefferson raises about $8,000 to $10,000 a year to run its sports program. It does get some external support: A nearby church, St. Paul's Community Baptist, has become involved, local politicians, including the local Congressman, Representative Edolphus Towns, are occasionally enlisted for help, and the P.T.A. can be squeezed.
But in a poor neighborhood full of parents who are either struggling financially or uninvolved with the life of the school -- or both -- Jefferson's coaches and administrators say they have to depend on themselves to make sports happen. As with the school itself, with its uniformed officers patrolling the hallways and its metal detectors -- a legacy of violence in and out of the building -- sports here exists in a kind siege mentality. Surrounded by apathy, it lives or dies by what can be cultivated inside school walls. Things like the coffee cart, in which most of the proceeds come from the faculty, reflect and reinforce the school's isolation.
Mr. Martin, the track coach, has a whole closet full of old sweatsuits in the gym -- collected and saved, tattered but still usable for athletes who have no other recourse. They're free for the asking for those who have no other choice but to ask.
"My coach never had a closet like this," he said. "But now you have to because some kids just don't have them."
Fund-raising at Tottenville includes categories that just don't exist in East New York: advertising revenue, for example. Local businesses support the school's sports teams, taking out ads in regularly published sports guides and game programs. Other stores provide goods at a discount to the school or to athletes, or donate them. Free labor and building supplies for construction or repair projects are abundant.
Money for sports is so available that supply can sometimes outstrip demand. The Tottenville Little League -- a main feeder for the school teams -- is so big and such a visible marketing opportunity that local businesses must put their names on a waiting list if they want to sponsor a team.
There are cake sales at sports events, and raffles, and alumni fund drives -- a humming network of parents and businesses and residents that looks to the school as its natural nexus for donations of time and money. Tottenville even gets more money per ticket at its football games than Jefferson: $4 a ticket, compared to $1 to $3 in East New York. "We're in the catbird seat here," said George Kaplan, the girls' soccer coach. "If we haven't raised enough money for something, then the parents just pay for it. There's a lot of support for the sports teams here, and that's what it's all about. That makes a big difference."
 
Success Stories
Colleges Come Calling For 2 Hard Workers
Mike Martinez's success on the football field -- he plays both defense and offense and was voted last month to the New York City Coach's All-City team as a tight end -- and his satisfactory performance in the classroom at Jefferson are celebrated in a school that has struggled in so many ways over the years. He's good enough to get major recruiting attention from some of the best and biggest Division I colleges in the nation, and competent enough academically, in his S.A.T. scores and grades, to qualify.
But his distinctiveness also shows the long dark road that sports has traveled through at the school. The last time an athlete won a major college football scholarship was the year Mike was born, 1982.
The school's attitude about sports has changed as well. What sports are here, what they mean, and what function they are meant to perform in the lives of students, is evolving and changing. Athletics for its own sake is not celebrated the way it once was.
Four years ago, when she came to Jefferson as principal, Ms. Medley, unilaterally raised the school's academic standards for eligibility to play sports. The Public Schools Athletic League, which regulates public school sports, mandates that a student must have a 65 percent average in his or her classes, but Medley boosted it to 75, and laid down other new rules, as well. Student athletes have to attend daily mandatory homework sessions with their coach and S.A.T. test-taking workshops on Saturdays during their sport's season -- miss either one, the new rules say, and you don't play.
"Years ago it was felt that the only way for certain people to get out of certain circumstances and situations was for them to go into sports," Ms. Medley said. "But today you can get on a computer and get out of the ghetto a lot quicker than you can running down the field with a football under your arm. Sports is being downsized to a certain degree, but that's all right."
For Mike Martinez, however, the passion for sports is utterly undiluted. He is shy, soft-spoken and fiercely driven. He does 500 pushups every day in his room, all yearlong, except during football season, when he slacks off to 100. His parents, Blanca Martinez and Michael Stewart, say they have no ready explanation for the way he is -- unstoppable and relentless -- except that he just seems to have been born that way.
Mr. Stewart said that when Mike was little, that he used to pick him up and hold him to look out the window at all the kids running wild around their housing project.
"I'd say, 'See that? Their parents don't care about them because they're letting them run around,' " he said. "You should be home, or in school, somewhere where you're parents know where you're at -- I guess that instilled something in him. Pride I guess."
But Mike has also been affected by the environment of a school, and neighborhood, where luxuries and frills are rare. Asked whether it bothered him, in his triumphal, pivotal senior year -- the year he was being watched by college coaches and recruiters -- to be wearing last year's scuffed old jersey, he instantly shook his head no.
"It doesn't matter what you wear -- it's how you wear it," he said.
When Kerri Lynn Piznak was in eighth grade -- on the eve of heading to Tottenville High -- she went into sports overload.
"I was doing everything," she said. "One weekend we went to Connecticut for a traveling basketball tournament, and my traveling soccer team was having a tournament there, too -- so I'd play one basketball game, go to a soccer game, then play another basketball game and go back to soccer. 'It was crazy,' everybody said, 'you'll have to decide what you're really going to do in high school.' "
At Tottenville, Kerri said, the sacrifice of narrowing the field meant focusing on her three greatest loves: basketball, soccer and cross-country.
Like Mike Martinez, she is now 17, a senior, and like him, she is being recruited by colleges around the nation -- for basketball in her case. They also seem kindred on another level. They don't let up. Whatever it is that makes Mike do his pushups is the same mysterious elixir that drives her to go the gym every Saturday morning with her father, John, with whom she has trained since she was in second grade.
Always, she said, the goal was the same: to learn how to go up and over his outstretched arm in their ritual no-holds-barred game of one-on-one. And finally, about three years ago, she found a way to do it. She has now beaten her father every Saturday morning without fail since Fathers Day 1995.
Kerri, whose schedule is jammed with school activities, awards and clubs in addition to sports, is also driven by a sense of injustice. Even at Tottenville, a school that would seem to have it all, there are imbalances and inequities, she said.
Last year, Kerri decided that the girl's basketball uniforms were shabby compared to the boys' outfits. The girls also got no warm-ups as part of their kit, and this, too, rankled. So Kerri entered an essay contest sponsored by the Women's Sports Foundation, a national research group, and won $2,500 for her school, and used just 250 words to do it.
"We've come a long way," she wrote in her essay. "But all is not yet equal."
 
Dropping the Ball

TODAY -- The story of how two schools, working with the same meager financing from the city, have wound up with two very different and unequal sports programs.
 
TOMORROW -- Moving to improve the state of public high school sports, the Board of Education has decided to give control of athletic programs to school principals. Not everyone thinks that is the right solution.

HEADLINE: The $10 Billion Man?

BYLINE: By Steven E. Landsburg; Steven E. Landsburg, a professor of economics at the University of Rochester, is the author of "Fair Play."

DATELINE: ROCHESTER

 BODY:
Legend has it that when Michael Jordan was in elementary school, a teacher advised him to study mathematics because "that's where the money is." The money turned out to be elsewhere. After accounting for Jordan's impact on everything from game attendance to Nike's sneaker sales, Fortune magazine labeled Jordan the "$10 Billion Man."
Ordinarily, when a man's activities command $10 billion in a free market, it's a safe bet that he's enriched the world economy by at least $10 billion. To behold a supremely confident Jordan soaring toward a monster dunk is surely an enriching experience. But does all that enrichment really add up to $10 billion? Let me suggest a couple of reasons to be skeptical. 
 First, the attendance figures. Every National Basketball Association team knows that attendance at home games was higher when Jordan's team, the Chicago Bulls, came to town. But there's more than one way to interpret that evidence. You could say that if it weren't for Jordan a lot of fans would have stayed home. Or that if it weren't for Jordan, a lot of fans would have gone to see other teams instead.
I have two friends who attended Knicks games only when the Bulls were visiting. Robert doesn't care much for basketball generally, but Jordan made his heart go pit-a-pat. Abby, on the other hand, would have season tickets if she could afford them. But she can't, so she stuck to the Bulls games, because Michael Jordan was her favorite. With Jordan gone, she'll go to see her next favorite team and have almost as much fun.
If most fans are like Robert, Jordan's economic contribution was as huge as his talent. If most fans are like Abby, estimates of Jordan's effect on tickets vastly overstate his value. Which theory is right? Two bits of evidence bear on that question, and they point in opposite directions. When he came into the league, attendance rose. During his first (temporary) retirement, attendance rose again.
Television revenue is equally hard to interpret. With Jordan's help, the N.B.A. gave us what many people found to be the most entertaining show on television. Entertainment has real economic value, and the league is rewarded for providing it. But is the reward a good measure of economic value? It's not as if the only alternative to basketball is C-Span; if basketball disappeared entirely, we might find something almost equally entertaining to watch. Then some television producer would get very rich, and not much economic value would be sacrificed.
As for crediting Jordan with a ten-fold increase in the value of the Bulls franchise over his career, that's mostly double-counting (the franchise value goes up because of ticket sales and television revenue, which we've already accounted for) and partly a failure to give credit where credit is due (to the providers of the Bulls' snazzy new arena).
Finally, does all that endorsement income represent true economic value? The answer depends on why endorsements are effective in the first place. One business theory is that by hiring an expensive celebrity, a company is saying: "Look, these ads are costing us a fortune. It's going to take us a long time to earn back that cost. So you can be sure our reputation matters to us, and we're not going to sell you a shoddy product."
In other words, Nike hires Jordan for the same reason law firms put expensive artwork on the walls. Admittedly, it's a theory that seems to cry out for derision. It predicts, for example, that Air Woody Allens could have been as successful as Air Jordans. But what is the alternative? Do millions of consumers believe a sneaker is somehow imbued with the spirit of their hero? That seems to be conventional wisdom, but as with much conventional wisdom, it gets harder to believe the harder you think about it.
I am forced to conclude that I have no idea why Michael Jordan sells so many sneakers, and therefore I have no idea whether he is the $10 billion man or the $1 billion man or something else altogether. Still, when it comes to his economic impact, a multitude of people will be tempted to believe that they can do the impossible: gather a few scraps of evidence, give them a dazzling spin, use them to drive a relentless argument, and jump, seemingly effortlessly, to an inevitable conclusion. It's a temptation best resisted. We can't all be Michael Jordan.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers in Both Parties Are Weighing Compromise Plans to Revamp Social Security

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
For the first time since President Clinton put Social Security's financial problems at the top of the national agenda, key members of both parties are seriously examining compromise proposals that could be acceptable both to Democrats who want to keep the retirement system intact and to Republicans pushing for a shift to private investment accounts.
The proposals center on investment accounts that would supplement Social Security rather than replace part of it. In the versions that are getting the most attention, the accounts would be voluntary but would carry incentives, in the form of matching Government contributions or tax breaks, to encourage people to save. 
 Such plans would also have to include some combination of tax increases and benefit cuts to deal with Social Security's looming financial shortfall, although some would try to solve most of the problem by allowing the Government to invest Social Security's excess cash in the stock market.
The proposals would basically leave the current Social Security system intact, in an effort to make the outcome palatable to liberals, while giving supporters of individualized investment a limited form of the private accounts they seek.
The effort to find a middle ground is at an early stage, and neither the White House nor the Republican leadership is openly supporting any particular compromise. Many of the ideas are in sketchy form.
White House officials have discussed one variant of the voluntary account approach with House Democrats, who say they are open to the idea. A moderate Democrat in the House who has worked across the aisle on a number of contentious issues, Representative Benjamin L. Cardin of Maryland, says he is drafting a similar plan and has gotten encouraging responses from Republicans with whom he has consulted.
Gene Sperling, the White House economic adviser, declined to discuss details of the plans the Clinton Administration is considering. But he said today that the President would work closely with members of Congress in the next few months to develop "a strong sense of where the basis for support and ultimately bipartisan consensus can be."
Even some of the strongest backers of private investment accounts said they were open to a deal built around voluntary accounts, although they cautioned that much would depend on the details.
"The most we can hope for as reformers is a very small incremental set of changes, given the political environment we're in," said Representative Mark Sanford, a Republican from South Carolina who is an aggressive advocate of private accounts. "With that in mind, I look more favorably on the idea of tax-incentivized savings."
Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who heads the Finance Committee, is pushing another approach built around individual accounts into which the Government would make contributions for the next five years, using half of the Federal budget surplus.
Under Senator Roth's approach, the accounts would not technically be part of the Social Security system. But the Senator said his plan provided "a means of moving ahead on a matter that has a direct relation to Social Security," and seemed to be similar to ideas being considered by the Administration.
"I'm hopeful that we're seeing the beginning of a consensus that could be very helpful," Mr. Roth said.
But other Republicans said they would continue to push for a fundamental overhaul of Social Security under which mandatory private accounts would be financed out of the 12.4 percent payroll tax assessed on workers and their employers.
And members of both parties said the real question was whether both sides would determine that they were better off reaching a deal on Social Security now rather than leaving the issue on the table for use as a political weapon in the 2000 elections.
Mr. Clinton has made it clear that he favors seeking higher investment returns in some way to help cover a financial gap that will leave Social Security unable to pay all beneficiaries fully, starting in 2032. So far he has deflected pressure from Republicans for a specific plan.
But his advisers have recently broached several possibilities, including one under which retirement accounts would be set up outside Social Security as a way to reassure liberal Democrats that a revamped program need not involve dismantling the guaranteed-benefit system.
Under the plan, contributions by workers would be matched by the Government in the same way that employers match contributions to 401(k) plans, and could be set up to give the greatest incentives to low and moderate income workers.
Mr. Cardin's plan would establish voluntary accounts within the Social Security system. The Government would give a tax rebate or make a direct payment into accounts to workers up to a certain income level, probably about $40,000, Mr. Cardin said.

HEADLINE: Mayor Tells Non-New Yorkers That City's Trash Is Price for What They Reap

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Facing growing resistance from other states to New York City's garbage, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the rest of the nation was obligated to take it in return for the many cultural and financial benefits reaped from the city.
Mr. Giuliani's comments came in the wake of growing opposition in Virginia. Concerned that a major disposal company is preparing to increase its shipments of trash from New York, Gov. James S. Gilmore 3d called for limits to prevent his state from becoming "a dumping ground for East Coast garbage." 
 Mr. Giuliani, at his daily news conference yesterday, elaborated on his philosophy of waste disposal.
"New York City has a specialized problem," he said. "It comes from the fact that we're so crowded and our land mass is very small, and that brings great benefits to the rest of the country, like Virginia. People in Virginia like to utilize New York because we're a cultural center, because we're a business center. What goes along with being a cultural and a business center is you're very crowded.
"We don't have the room here to handle the garbage that's produced not just by New Yorkers," he continued, "but by the three million more people that come here that utilize the place every day. So this is a reciprocal relationship."
As a result of that relationship, the Mayor continued, the rest of the country should help the city with waste disposal. "We don't do it because we're profligate, we don't do it because we're wasteful," he said of exporting the city's trash. "We do it because there are a lot of people in the city and that brings great benefits to the American economy."
Governor Gilmore, in a text of his state of the state message last night, continued his opposition to out-of-state trash. "I believe the Commonwealth has a right -- and I would say a duty -- to ban the use of barges for the transportation of garbage on Virginia's waterways," he said.
The latest criticism arose when Waste Management Inc., a major national disposal company, recently signed a contract with a barge company that would enable up to 4,000 tons a day to be shipped to a new port in Charles City, Va., on the James River. Waste Management already transfers 2,400 tons of New York City garbage a day to Virginia and other destinations.
The criticism from Virginia came a month after the Mayor surprised and infuriated Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey with a proposal to ship residential trash to transfer stations in her state. She issued a news release with the headline, "Whitman to New York's Garbage Plan: Drop Dead" and called the plan "a direct assault on the beaches of New Jersey."
Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani dismissed such criticism as a "knee-jerk political issue" and said a "counterforce" of communities supports the garbage industry for the business and jobs it creates.
"When people move beyond just a sort of knee-jerk political issue here," he said, "there's a whole industry out there, and this will continue and it will be part of waste disposal for the next 50 or 100 years."
The Mayor raised the possibility of litigation to force other states to accept the city's waste. "They can be challenged," he said of proposed restrictions on waste export. A suit could be filed by the city or a disposal company, the Mayor said, based on the United States Constitution's provision against interfering with interstate commerce.
Although the Mayor said that the city is increasing recycling to reduce the amount of garbage, the City Council and environmental groups have accused him of thwarting that effort, including delaying the expansion of weekly pickups.
Pressure is growing on the city's garbage-disposal system as the legal deadline for closing the city's Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island at the end of 2001 approaches.

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN BRAZIL: THE RIPPLE EFFECTS;
Argentina May Suffer Most From Neighbor's Ills

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 13

 BODY:
As shock waves from Brazil's devaluation of its currency reverberated across Latin America today, analysts said Argentina was likely to be rattled the most severely and that other countries bordering Brazil would be shaken more than Mexico, where ties to the United States economy would cushion the shock.
The news from Brazil battered all Latin American markets and several currencies today as panicked investors sold securities and rushed to buy dollars. Argentina's market index fell 10.37 percent. The Mexican peso, which floats freely, fell to a historic low, worth 9.34 American cents. 
 But analysts said that when the panic subsided, some economies in the region would prove more resilient that others.
For example, Argentina can expect to see its interest rates soar, exports drop and unemployment rise, analysts said, adding that the country, which is Brazil's closest trading partner, was likely to slide into recession. But at the other extreme, Mexico will also suffer from volatile interest rates and double-digit inflation, but with its economic fundamentals in good shape, it should eke out at least modest growth this year, despite the Brazilian crisis.
"Argentina is most vulnerable to the Brazilian crisis, and Mexico is the least," said Luis R. Luis, managing director at Scudder Kemper Investments in Boston.
Argentina's stock market drop was the worst today. In Peru, stocks fell 5.45 percent, in Brazil 5.05 percent, in Mexico 4.6 percent, in Chile 3.25 percent and in Venezuela 3.01 percent.
Tuesday's 9 percent devaluation of the Brazilian real also led to speculative pressures on other Latin currencies. Peru's sol slid 2.1 percent to a record low, worth 30.6 American cents. The Chilean peso dropped less than 1 percent. However, the Argentine peso, which is pegged at one-to-one with the dollar, did not budge, and the country's economic planning secretary, Rogelio Frigerio, vowed to defend the currency.
"One-to-one parity is not a matter for government, but a requirement and demand of the people," Mr. Frigerio told Reuters. "We are not going to change that position for anything in the world." Argentina currently appears to have the muscle to back that vow: $24 billion in reserves.
Still, the Argentine economy is headed for trouble, analysts said. They had predicted that Argentina's economy would grow 2 percent this year; now they predict zero or negative growth.
About one-third of Argentina's exports go to its huge northern neighbor, and given the revised economic forecasts, they are likely to drop sharply.
That could lead to social unrest during a presidential election year. During the regional crisis that followed Mexico's 1994 devaluation, Argentine unemployment rose to 18 percent from 12 percent, but it has since returned to 12 percent, said Luis R. Secco, an economist at Estudio Broda Consultores in Buenos Aires. Now as the Argentine economy shrinks, unemployment could easily surge to 18 percent again, he said. Argentines are to choose President Carlos Saul Menem's successor in October.
International lending to Latin America has all but stopped since Russia's default last fall started a stampede from emerging markets, and a crucial factor for Argentina will be how long it is until foreign credits begin to flow again, Mr. Secco said. Argentina has a current account deficit of 4.5 percent of its gross domestic product, and needs to borrow some $7.8 billion this year, about half of that from overseas, he said.
"Whether international credit will flow to Argentina is going to be a crucial question," Mr. Secco said.
Peru, which has an annual current account deficit of about $4 billion, will also suffer if international lenders remain nervous about Latin America.
Venezuela's public finances are even more disorderly, with a budget deficit of about 7.5 percent of gross domestic product, and its economy is largely dependent on oil revenues, which have plunged because of depressed world petroleum prices.
But President-elect Hugo Chavez, whose populist speeches last year alarmed foreign investors, has so far surprised analysts by adopting a conciliatory approach to business. Because Venezuela has little trade with Brazil and its petroleum economy tends to follow its own dynamics, the outlook is unsettled, but the country is not likely to suffer greatly from Brazil's devaluation, analysts said.
In Mexico, President Ernesto Zedillo's economic team has for months been preparing carefully for a potential devaluation in Brazil, and its economy shows few signs of vulnerability.
Mexico's central bank auctioned $200 million today to slow the peso's depreciation and tightened the money supply by 30 million pesos, about $3 million.
Interest rates rose in reaction to the Brazilian devaluation, but they remained far below the chaotic 50 percent rates reached during the emerging markets crisis last September.
"Mexico's economic program is designed to reduce the vulnerability of our economy to these sorts of foreign financial shocks," the central bank said in a statement today. Independent analysts agreed.
"In the sea of bad news, Mexico doesn't have much to fear because nobody's tried to protect anything that shouldn't be protected," said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, an economic consultant here. "They cut the budget, let the exchange rate take its knocks and interest rates rise. So our picture is better than what the Brazilians or the Argentines are looking at now."

HEADLINE: Project for Minorities Aims to Show Its Broader Mandate

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Senior executives from several dozen blue-chip corporations will gather in New York today with hundreds of their counterparts at minority-owned companies for the second annual economic conference organized by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson's advocacy initiative, the Wall Street Project.
Like last year's event, the two-day conference has a high-kilowatt guest list that includes C. Michael Armstrong, chairman of AT&T, and Sanford I. Weill, the co-chief executive of Citigroup -- and, by the way, President Clinton, three Cabinet members and other officials. 
 Once again, Mr. Jackson will use the occasion to exhort corporate America to expand its "trade relationships" with the "emerging markets" in inner cities and rural backwaters, through employment, capital investment and the purchase of goods and services.
But this year, Mr. Jackson will also be trying to demonstrate persuasively that the Wall Street Project is operating with a broader mandate and a clearer focus than it demonstrated at its debut conference last year.
Despite its name, the project is aimed at expanding opportunities for women and minorities all across corporate America, not just on Wall Street. "The term 'Wall Street' is simply symbolic of the entire finance and business culture," Mr. Jackson said in a recent interview.
When he met with local groups over the last year, he said, he frequently asked them to name five top political leaders, and "they all could.
"Then I asked them to name five top corporate C.E.O.'s, and there was dead silence," he continued. "We've got to change that."
The Wall Street Project still has much of the fervor and facets of a grass-roots political organization. It relies heavily on its founder's charisma and access to top executives. And while Mr. Jackson says he prefers private negotiations, in the last year he has also led marches, visited picket lines and attended rallies -- proving that the fledgling project is, at the very least, a bully pulpit for the economic agenda that he has promoted through his Rainbow/ PUSH Coalition for many years.
And, like the grass-roots civil rights movement that first brought Mr. Jackson to prominence as a top aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the Wall Street project is emerging as a first-class networking arena for minority business leaders, introducing them not only to mainstream executives like Mr. Weill at Citigroup but also to one another.
Emma C. Chappell, the founder and chairman of the United Bank of Philadelphia, cites her encounter with Vernon Duckrey, who owns more than 100 Burger King and Pizza Hut franchises in southern New Jersey. The two black entrepreneurs have built their businesses a short distance away from each other, "But I had no idea he existed until the Wall Street Project referred him to me," Ms. Chappell said. "Now we are getting ready to finance some of his new construction, and I've got a good new customer."
A new element added to the project's grass-roots format, Mr. Jackson said, is shareholder activism. The project has purchased stock in 107 American corporations, and it intends to be an active shareholder. Mr. Jackson has attended annual meetings to urge corporations to resolve existing disputes with minority employees and to expand the business they do with minority-owned suppliers, professionals and banks.
"This has always been part of Jesse Jackson's broader rhetorical agenda, but now they're putting it into action," said Timothy H. Smith, the director of the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility in New York. "I don't think any company could ignore him. He can jawbone or encourage or praise -- and he also has the ability to launch a major campaign against you if you don't respond."
The Wall Street Project already claims some successes. Several companies have added minority directors to their boards at the group's urging, and others, like the Boeing Company, have begun to resolve longstanding employee disputes after Mr. Jackson intervened.
The project persuaded the General Motors Corporation to undertake a yearlong independent review of its minority dealer development program. That review resulted in a blueprint to improve the program, which is now being carried out. The project also encouraged MCI Worldcom Inc. and six other companies to include minority-owned banks in their securities sales last year.
Mr. Jackson's effort has emboldened some minority business leaders to promote his agenda. In one example, analysts from Ariel Capital Management, a black-controlled mutual fund and money-management company in Chicago, now routinely ask executives about the diversity of their boards and senior management, said John W. Rogers Jr., Ariel's president. "The Wall Street Project has made it easier to ask the question," he added. "And it is a great way to see whether top management at a corporation gets it."
The project's leaders have lobbied for improvements in Federal Communications Commission rules about minority ownership of media outlets and Small Business Administration programs aimed at financing less affluent entrepreneurs. And it has pushed for new public-private programs to steer capital to the inner cities and Appalachia.
But in a departure from both traditional shareholder activism and grass-roots political work, the Wall Street project has as much to say to its supporters as it does to its adversaries. And its message, Mr. Jackson says, is that "casting a ballot to vote is not enough."
"We have to cast our proxy, too," he said. "We have to exercise our power as investors."
At least 30 corporations are helping to sponsor this year's conference events, up from barely a dozen last year. And while last year's sponsors were largely from the financial-services industry, this year's sponsors include Boeing, the Frito-Lay subsidiary of Pepsico, the Xerox Corporation and the Stop and Shop supermarket unit of Royal Ahold N.V.
The Wall Street Project is a program of the Citizenship Education Fund, an Ohio-chartered charitable foundation that Mr. Jackson formed 15 years ago. The fund has supported the project during its embryonic stages and monitors its finances, said Janice Mathis, an officer of the fund and general counsel of the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition in Chicago.
But most of the project's 1998 revenues consisted of the approximately $400,000 raised at last year's conference, Ms. Mathis said, and its 1999 budget relies heavily on tonight's benefit, at which the poet Maya Angelou and President Clinton will be the guests of honor.
The project's main office is in New York. Each of its new regional outposts -- in Chicago, Detroit and Los Angeles -- is expected to be self-sustaining through local fund-raising, Ms. Mathis said. These offices, in most cases, are built around "trade bureaus," the local minority business clubs that have been run for years by the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition. Trade bureau members contribute a minimum of $250 to join; their dues now entitle them to receive the Wall Street Project's monthly newsletter, which says it has 3,500 subscribers.
The Wall Street Project will be constantly tempted to expand beyond its shoestring budget simply because the needs are so great, said Chee Chee Williams, who directs the New York office. And Mr. Jackson has often been criticized for spreading himself too thin and not following through on his ambitious agenda.
But his supporters do not seem worried. "I don't think we should expect him to do the follow-through," said Ms. Chappell, the Philadelphia banker. "It is up to all of us to do that."

HEADLINE: Dueling M.I.T. Economists Testify at Micro soft Trial

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY and STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In the Microsoft trial today, a Justice Department lawyer opened cross-examination of the company's first witness by asking him to concede that Microsoft held a monopoly in personal-computer operating systems.
But although the witness, Richard L. Schmalensee, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, had submitted 328 pages of written testimony addressing every aspect of the Government's antitrust case, he said he had never studied the market for personal-computer operating systems, because "I didn't see any particular purpose in investigating that question." 
 Three months after the trial opened, Microsoft finished questioning the Government's final witness, Franklin M. Fisher, another M.I.T economist. With that, David Boies, the Government's lead trial lawyer, rested his case -- but not before entering into evidence a raft of new documents and depositions.
One of those was an internal E-mail in which an executive of the Walt Disney Company said, referring to contract restrictions imposed by Microsoft, "We are being roughed up by the 1,000-pound gorilla of the industry."
But Mr. Schmalensee depicted Microsoft today as a company striving to hold onto a fragile lock on the market, at one point even suggesting that the operating system used in the Palm Pilot personal organizer posed a serious potential threat to Microsoft's Windows.
That prompted incredulity from Mr. Boies, leading Mr. Schmalensee to say: "Is it a significant competitor today? No. But it is a germ of a potential competitor."
Mr. Schmalensee has served as a paid consultant and expert witness for Microsoft since 1992, leading Mr. Boies to suggest that he was Microsoft's "house economist." Mr. Boies offered excerpts from Mr. Schmalensee's testimony in a previous case as evidence, attempting to show that Mr. Schmalensee offered whatever position best served the case at hand.
Testifying last fall in a suit in which Bristol Technology, a software company based in Danbury, Conn., was trying to establish that it competed with Microsoft, Mr. Schmalensee had said: "In that view of the world, essentially everybody that is writing software is competing with everybody else. And I just don't think that's useful."
That apparent contradiction stirred Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to tell the witness, "What I'm trying to determine here is whether what you say here is consistent with what you said in that case."
Mr. Schmalensee said it was consistent because the issues were different. Bristol, he said, made a program for software programmers that did not compete with Windows.
But Mr. Schmalensee listed two small niche operating systems that he argued posed a threat to Microsoft: Linux and Be-OS.
"I think these are important not because they are a competitive threat today, but because they show that entering the operating system market is possible," he said. "And there will be others."
The judge then asked him if the tiny companies that make these systems were making any money.
"I would be stunned if they were making any serious money," Mr. Schmalensee responded.
In his written testimony, Mr. Schmalensee said: "A firm with monopoly power over the operating system would charge at least 16 times over what Microsoft charges."
Under that formula, Microsoft would charge computer makers about $800 for each copy of Windows -- the price of entire computers systems with Windows today.
In the final minutes of the Government's case, Mr. Fisher, who used to be Mr. Schmalensee's teacher, offered a long list of ways he said Microsoft's behavior had harmed consumers -- a key element of any antitrust case.
Prices for computer hardware and software have grown more than they otherwise would have, he said, and innovation has been stifled.
With the documents introduced today, the Government tried to bolster key themes of its case: that Microsoft viewed the Internet as a threat to its dominance, that it used its operating-system monopoly to bully personal computer makers and others, and that it bundled its browser with Windows to stifle competition.
Microsoft said the documents had been chosen to embarrass it but instead depicted a vigorous competitor striving to improve its products.
In an E-mail to company executives on April 10, 1995, William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, wrote, "We are looking at the Internet destroying our position as the setter of standards," adding that it was "taking away our power every day."
The Government says Microsoft merged its Internet Explorer browser with its Windows operating system to assure universal distribution and thwart competition in Internet software. To support that charge, the Government released a March 1997 E-mail in which a Microsoft executive wrote that the "only real chance Internet Explorer has of getting them to switch" from Netscape came when users upgraded a Windows operating system, purchased a new personal computer loaded with Microsoft's browser or signed up with an Internet service provider that promoted Internet Explorer.

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN BRAZIL: THE MISTAKES -- Economic Scene;
Brazil Swallows Another Bitter Pill

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Brazil's surprise devaluation was anything but surprising.
That is not Monday morning quarterbacking. Devaluation has been the prediction of many economists even after the International Monetary Fund, backed by the Clinton Administration, provided a $40 billion credit line several months ago that Brazil was to use to defend the value of its currency as well as help it plug a huge hole in its federal deficit. 
 The problem with the I.M.F. bailout, independent economists argued repeatedly, was that it allowed Brazil to cling to an overvalued exchange rate -- by some estimates, 30 percent above sustainable levels. At the same time, its policy became increasingly dependent on short-term loans. That combination -- overvalued currency and huge short-term loans -- said Jeffrey Sachs of the Harvard Institute for International Development, "is anywhere and everywhere an invitation for financial chaos."
But now that Brazil has devalued, what happens next? One possibility is that limited devaluation works. Investors may decide that the currency will remain stable hereafter and that Brazil will stick close to its commitments to close its budget deficit. If that happens, domestic interest rates could fall and Brazil could begin to recover.
More likely, limited devaluation will need to be backed by stiff interest rate increases to persuade lenders to stay put. Indeed, the new president of the central bank seemed to anticipate that possibility yesterday when he vowed to use Brazil's billions of dollars in reserves to intervene in the markets. He also suggested he might "raise interest rates to defend our foreign exchange regime."
If that happens, the economy could go into a tailspin. The immediate victims would, of course, be Brazilian workers and their families. But nearby trading partners, especially Argentina, would be hit hard as they lose Brazil's large export market.
The problem with an overvalued currency is that it makes imports cheap and exports dear, leading to a drain on the country's dollar reserves. At some point lenders grow fearful that the country will run out of dollars. They cash in their loans before someone else lays claim to the dwindling dollars, forcing the country to squander the rest of its reserves defending its exchange rate.
Countries can postpone the inevitable by jacking up interest rates to sky-high levels -- over 30 percent in Brazil's case -- to attract new loans. But high interest rates throw the economy into recession, sapping political support. Eventually, the country chooses to stop defending the currency, which, after the dust settles on foreign exchange markets, can allow it to cut its interest rates.
An overvalued currency and large short-term debt buried the Mexican currency in 1995, the currencies of Thailand, Indonesia, Korea and Russia last year. Now comes Brazil.
"Misaligned currencies cannot be defended by high interest rates," Rudiger Dornbusch, a leading international economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said yesterday. He said the same thing in October.
The devaluation was predictable, Mr. Sachs said yesterday, echoing statements he made in October. "Falsely pegged currencies -- currency pegs that lack political and economic commitment -- cannot last," Gary Hufbauer of the Institute for International Economics said yesterday. He made the same prediction last year.
So if economists could see disaster coming, why couldn't Brazil? In part, its obstinacy can be traced to President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who as Finance Minister gained credit earlier in the decade stamping out Brazil's hyperinflation by tying its currency rigidly to the dollar. In effect, Mr. Cardoso solved Brazil's inflation problem by turning control of its money supply over to the United States.
But his monetary crackdown produced a sharp recession, which Mr. Cardosa has no stomach for repeating. For him, severing his currency's tie to the dollar invites a return to an undisciplined past. Mr. Sachs suggests that the pegged rate was a terrific way to handle a financial emergency, but Mr. Cardoso stuck with the rigid policy way too long.
Buttressing Mr. Cardoso's recent resolve was pressure from the international financial community to take a hard stand against devaluation. The wave of devaluations that started in Asia last year spread quickly to Russia and threatened Latin America. Brazil emerged as the place where monetary authorities vowed to stanch the contagion.
But the I.M.F.-backed package was never credible, economists say. Had it been fully adopted, it would have crushed the economy. For that reason it was never embraced by Brazil's politicians. The Parliament rejected some of the budget cutbacks. This week one of the state governments defaulted on its debt. Both events eroded investor confidence, driving some to flee. One day earlier this week, Brazil lost close to a billion dollars of reserves.
Something had to give. Yesterday, Brazil undertook a limited devaluation of about 8 percent. The idea was to ease investors' fears of a larger devaluation, thereby taking some pressure off its currency. The fallout in Brazil and around the world depends heavily on what policy options are followed.
The difficulty with Brazil's current plan is that limited devaluation may not hold even if bolstered with large interest rate rises. Mexico tried the policy in 1994, but investors fled and forced the country within a few days to let its currency float free.
If, as many economists predict, Brazil follows Mexico's lead, the economic fallout is hard to predict. For starters, Brazil has incurred large dollar denominated debt. A devaluation raises the cost of debt repayment, putting additional pressure on an already bloated fiscal deficit. "Devaluation could do Brazil more harm than good," Mr. Dornbusch says. And there is the additional risk that devaluation in Brazil will scare investors throughout Latin America and beyond, leading to successive rounds of devaluation and economic free fall in Colombia, Hong Kong, even China. Jittery investors might even exit the American stock market that many believe is overpriced.
But what can the I.M.F. and the United States do? Prof. Richard Cooper of Harvard suggests that this question -- the obvious one to policy makers in Washington -- is the wrong question. He says that Brazil's problems are overwhelmingly domestic -- its fiscal deficit is ominously large -- and that problems with its exchange rate are secondary. Last year's I.M.F.-backed package is about all the international world can do. The rest is up to the Brazilians.
Mr. Sachs thinks the correct answer is for Brazil to float the currency. Freed from the need to defend its currency, Brazil's crushing interest rates could return to normal. He would use money from the I.M.F., along with credit from international banks, to smooth the transition, reassuring investors that there will be no default and the currency would be worth holding.
Mr. Dornbusch says the answer to Brazil's problems, as well as those of many emerging economies, is a currency board. A limited devaluation would maintain the same policy that has produced stagnant per capita income for two decades. A floating currency is no answer because of the problem of dollar-denominated loans. But a currency board, like that adopted by Argentina, would tie the value of Brazil's currency to the dollar, but in a way that largely removes the option of devaluation. That is the best guarantee that the dollar link is permanent. The hope is that confident investors will flock to Brazil, push down its interest rates and jump-start growth.
Economists agree on one issue: More than ever, help from the I.M.F. is crucial. Devaluation raises the cost of imports and could spook investors. Fiscal cuts will depress economic activity. For all these reasons, Brazil could use an injection of cash, assuming it adopts prudent monetary and budget policies.
Mr. Sachs adds that Brazil is the latest in a series of countries whose economies collapsed under I.M.F. programs. "After matters settle down," he said, "we need to take a serious look at fundamentally changing that institution."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Wall Street Recoils From Brazil's Turmoil, Then Collects Itself

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Stock markets around the world shuddered yesterday in response to another dose of emerging-market turmoil.
Brazil's plan to effectively devalue its currency initially deflated the confidence of stock investors in the United States and abroad. But after a sharp selloff in the first half-hour of trading, American stocks rebounded steadily through the day. 
 As the morning light seeped into the canyons of Wall Street, indications were that stocks would take a huge hit. Some analysts said that the Dow Jones industrial average might lose as many as 400 points.
In early trading, the prices of financial futures dropped as far as regulators allowed, and when equity trading started at 9:30 A.M., the bleak forecasts seemed on the mark. The Dow plunged more than 250 points, or nearly 3 percent, in the first 30 minutes, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 115 points, almost 5 percent.
Then, as quickly as it came, the calamity passed; the panic seemed to evaporate as stocks collectively began to reverse course and recover. Recalling that previous plunges spurred by currency crises -- in Asia in 1997 and in Russia last summer -- proved to be buying opportunities in United States stocks, investors dived in.
"Once again, the mentality is to buy the dips," said Byron Wien, chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "When it looked like this was not the beginning of a bear market, people saw that Yahoo was down 70 points and decided to take advantage of it."
The Dow finished the session down 125.12 points, or 1.3 percent, at 9,349.56. Other American gauges posted smaller losses; at one point, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was even up more than 8 points. It finished down 5.11 points at 1,234.40.
"I think U.S. investors saw Brazil's actions as inevitable, and now that it's behind us we can move forward," Mr. Wien said. "Markets have a funny way of reacting positively to reality once they think it through."
Foreign markets did not fare as well. European markets fell sharply as Brazil disclosed its plan to loosen the trading range for its currency, the real; they were closed by the time the Brazilian Congress adopted reform measures that to American investors looked promising.
Investors in the United States shunned shares of auto makers, heavy-equipment companies and banks with business links to Brazil. But they snapped up stocks like Intel, Microsoft and Sun Microsystems, whose earnings are not expected to be disrupted.
Yahoo, which ended the day down 34 a share at 368, has no operations in Brazil, but the stocks of companies that do finished mostly lower yesterday. Shares of Ford Motor, General Motors and DaimlerChrysler each fell 2 percent or more, while those of Caterpillar, the equipment maker, International Paper and Coca-Cola also fell.
Banking stocks suffered even more, as investors recalled that the last Latin American debt crisis caused nagging problems for money-center banks. J. P. Morgan's shares fell almost 5 percent, Citigroup's declined 6 percent and those of American Express slumped nearly 4 percent.
Over all, investment analysts and portfolio managers said that while they expect neither an extended nor a deep downturn from Brazil's crisis, much uncertainty remains about that country's fiscal plans.
"I think this is not the last adjustment that we will see to the currency regime in Brazil," said Thomas Haslett, chief investment officer for emerging market equities at Putnam Investments, the mutual fund company. He noted, though, that foreign companies doing business there have had plenty of warning to hedge against a currency decline.
Less certain is the effect that Brazil's problems will have on other markets in Latin America, Europe and the Far East. Stocks in those regions fell sharply yesterday, though they could stabilize today following the rebound in the United States.
Brazil's Bovespa stock-market index fell 5 percent, with shares of the 12 companies created by the breakup of Telebras, the giant telecommunications concern, among the market's biggest losers. Four of the largest Telebras spinoffs operate with pricing discretion that could offer them some protection from the inflation that is now expected to rise in Brazil.
Mexico's Bolsa index fell 4.6 percent, and the Argentina general index tumbled 10 percent. Investors are likely to watch those countries -- two of the region's other big economies -- closely for signs of weakness.
"Because of the uncertainty, Latin America is going to have a higher cost of capital," Mr. Haslett said. "A relatively small amount of support should be able to carry Argentina through 1999." And Mexico should benefit from a continued strong economy in the United States.
In Europe, stock prices fell sharply, 3 percent in Britain and 4 percent in Germany. The region's economy has already suffered from slowing exports to Asia and Eastern Europe, and could feel a further pinch from Brazil's trouble. Volkswagen A.G., for example, is among the biggest car producers in Brazil. Spanish banks have also lent heavily in Brazil, which led investors to push Spanish stocks down nearly 7 percent.
Stocks also fell in Asia, but those losses came well before Brazil announced its currency plans. Stocks in Hong Kong fell 4 percent yesterday, while Tokyo ended slightly higher.
Unlike the Asian currency crisis of 1997 or last year's economic emergency in Russia, the situation in Brazil carries more immediate impact for investors in the United States. Brazil dominates the economies of South America, accounting for 40 percent of the continent's output. And investors can watch any effects of the crisis unfold in real time.
Since Asia's currency crisis began in the summer of 1997, analysts have suggested that Brazil -- which, like Thailand, Indonesia and other emerging-market nations, had pegged the value of its currency to the American dollar -- might come under pressure to devalue the real.
That concern was tempered somewhat when the International Monetary Fund assembled a $41 billion "precautionary" loan package in November. The I.M.F. has been criticized for responding too slowly in Asia and for attaching overly harsh conditions to its loans there.
Now Brazil could benefit from what has been learned elsewhere. "There is a very strong possibility that this will be one of the turning points," said David Herro, manager of the Oakmark International fund, a $800 million fund with about 9 percent of its assets invested in Brazil.
Mr. Herro also dismissed parallels between Brazil's woes and last year's turmoil in Russia.
"Brazil is free-market oriented and is run by some smart people," Mr. Herro said. "And unlike Mexico's crisis in 1994, Brazil has no problem with short-term debt or its currency reserves."
Judging by the reaction of American investors, the crisis in Brazil appeared over almost before it started. Some stocks rose from the opening bell: Ascend Communications gained 5 3/8, to 80 5/16, after Lucent Technologies agreed to buy it for about $19.7 billion in stock.
Shares of Intel fell at the opening even though the company reported fourth-quarter earnings late Tuesday that beat analyst estimates. Investors soon decided that the drop was unwarranted and sent the shares up 3 7/16, to 139.
Investors bid up several other technology stocks as well. Sun Microsystems gained 3 7/16, to 96 13/16, and traded as high as 104 1/2. Microsoft, which started its defense in the Federal antitrust trial after losing a bid to get the charges dismissed, rose 1 5/8, to 143 13/16.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
In a Year of Acrimony, Giuliani Is Defined by the Economy

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani formally began the first year of his second administration last January with a State of the City speech that chronicled past accomplishments and made bold promises of more to come. He urged the people of New York City to take personal responsibility for this moment in time, and implicitly presented himself as the person to lead the metropolis to continued greatness.
But he ended the year in a manner decidedly less grand: threatening to place a homeless shelter in the district of a Brooklyn City Council member whose legislation on homelessness he found offensive. Whatever substantive problems he had with the legislation were largely overshadowed by his mano a mano approach. 
 Those two moments serve as appropriate bookends to a year that often reflected the essence of Giuliani the Mayor and Giuliani the man. Now, with the Mayor poised to deliver another State of the City Message today, political scientists and others who monitor city government are struggling to get beyond the mayoral hyperbole to assess the success of Mr. Giuliani's agenda last year.
In the end, they say, Mr. Giuliani may have stumbled on some matters and caused distraction with his tendency to marry assertiveness with nastiness. There is also a sense that his second term is relying heavily on the successes of the first. But in the end, they say, he succeeded -- some say by default -- on the big-ticket issues of crime and the economy.
"The criteria by which Rudy is judged is not whether he wins or loses his battles," said Mitchell L. Moss, the director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. "The longterm impact is that the homicide rate continues to be low. And he continues to benefit from a terrific economy."
Fred Siegel, a political scientist at Cooper Union in New York, said that the Mayor was "milking the bull of already achieved successes."
"It wasn't a year where any new agenda was laid out," Mr. Siegel said. "But job growth continues, inflation stays low, crime keeps dropping. The bottom line is when you talk to people they say that New York City is well-run, prosperous, and they're not feeling any pain right now. The problems to come are around the bend."
Still, the course of city politics last year also demonstrates that the Mayor does not always win. For example, last year the Mayor praised the City Council and its Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, for the cooperative atmosphere permeating City Hall. A few months later, the two leaders were battling over the fate of Yankee Stadium, with the Mayor proposing a plan for a stadium in Manhattan and the Speaker insisting that the team remain in the Bronx. That dispute consumed the city's budget process; it ended with the Council passing its own $34 billion budget and the Mayor quietly setting aside, at least for now, his vision of a Manhattan stadium.
Nor could the Mayor have predicted that the one labor leader he praised -- Stanley Hill, the president of District Council 37, the largest municipal union -- would be removed from office while various corruption investigations centered on a fixed union vote in 1996 on a contract that was favorable to the Giuliani administration.
For whatever reasons, the Mayor did not achieve some of the goals he laid out in last year's state-of-the-city speech. He talked about addressing domestic violence; incidents of domestic violence increased. He said that he wanted to unseal the records of juvenile offenders; that went nowhere. He talked about extending the school year and ending principal tenure; those ambitious goals were not realized.
But he had some successes. He spoke out against remedial education in the four-year colleges of the City University of New York, prompting a movement in that direction. Against strong opposition, he managed to have the police assume responsibility for security in the city's school system. He also followed through on a promise to dedicate funds to drug enforcement and drug treatment.
Myron Magnet, the editor of City Journal -- a magazine published by the generally conservative Manhattan Institute -- said that he thought Mr. Giuliani had done very well in 1998. He pointed in particular to the Mayor's success in reducing the welfare rolls by as many as 400,000 people, and in emphasizing the value of workfare.
"That's remarkable," Mr. Magnet said. "One of things that Giuliani has demonstrated is that things that seem impossible -- reducing crime significantly in New York -- can happen overnight if you have the will to do it."
The Public Advocate, Mark Green, for whom Mr. Giuliani rarely hides his disdain, said that the Mayor deserved a lot of credit for the crime reduction, the tourism boom and some of the job growth. But he predicted that today's State of the City speech would probably be a "Panglossian analysis of good news about 1998," leaving unmentioned more troubling matters.
Among them, he said, were the Mayor's failed efforts to undermine watchdog agencies like the Citizens Budget Commission and the Independent Budget Office, his unsuccessful attempt to curtail the number of street vendors, and the Federal inquiries into allegations of police brutality and unlawful delay in access to Medicaid and food stamps to the eligible poor.
Mr. Green also touched on Mr. Giuliani's management style. "In 1998 the Mayor had a relatively small-bore agenda," he said, "based largely on the thesis of: be civil or I'll put a homeless shelter in your district."
Mr. Giuliani recently indicated that he recognized what is remembered in the long run about any mayor. "If my city doesn't work, I don't like the Mayor," he said. "It doesn't matter if I like him or don't like him, I don't want him as the Mayor. If my city is getting better, and my life is getting better, and my children's lives are getting better, then I don't really care whether I like the Mayor or don't like the Mayor. He's a good mayor."
