HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Argentine Rates Jump And the Market Tumbles

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Argentine interest rates surged as the local stock market tumbled for a second day in response to the devaluation of Brazil's currency. But several senior Argentine officials pledged that they would not budge the peso from its one-to-one linkage to the dollar or veer from other free-market policies.
President Carlos Saul Menem projected calm as he returned from a state visit in the United States, appearing on national television smiling and dressed in a sport shirt and slacks. "This will pass quickly," he said, even as he summoned his Cabinet for an emergency meeting. 
 Argentines did not panic despite alarming headlines in the local financial press, with economists reporting almost no withdrawal of deposits from local banks over the last two days. But foreign investors continued to sell Argentine stocks heavily, with Argentina's Merval index opening the day sharply lower even as Brazil's Bovespa was showing early, tentative signs of recovery.
The Merval, which plunged 10.2 percent Wednesday, fell another 4.3 percent today.
Argentina's economy is closely linked to Brazil's because 30 percent of its exports go to its northern neighbor. With the devaluation of the Brazilian currency, the real, Argentine goods will become less competitive on the Brazilian market and high interest rates are likely to further limit the buying power of Brazilian consumers. Private economists predicted that a coming economic contraction -- particularly in the auto, steel and cement industries -- would lower corporate earnings, squeeze tax receipts, and force the Government to reduce spending in the coming months.
The impact of the Brazilian crisis has been immediate, with the prime interest rate for private businesses rising from 11 percent to more than 13 percent overnight. Meanwhile, even as Government officials spoke optimistically of the future, they held off plans to issue a new global bond and privatize part of the National Mortgage Bank until international capital markets calmed.
"The Argentine economy will react with a deep recession," predicted Dario Lizzano, head of equity research at Santander Investments in Buenos Aires. "There will be a lack of credit and that will generate a strong increase in interest rates at least in the short term." Gustavo Canonero, a senior economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in Buenos Aires, said, "In this volatile economy, you will see the Merval continue to be weak."
But, in an interview, Deputy Economy Minister Pablo Guidotti sketched out a brighter scenario. "At this point, it is still early to say the current situation in Brazil will delay our recovery," he said. "Brazil's problems now mean a closing of capital markets and increasing our country risk premium, but this will have no lasting affect if the situation in Brazil is short-lived."
As a result of Brazil's devaluation, many Wall Street and local economists have revised their forecasts for the Argentine economy in 1999, from 2.5 percent growth to zero or even a contraction after nearly a decade of almost uninterrupted expansion. Most economists say the 12.4 percent unemployment rate is likely to go higher.
Nevertheless, independent economists and political analysts said they believed President Menem would not veer off his free-market course, in part because it now appeared certain that he would not be a candidate for re-election later this year. And since Mr. Menem is a sworn enemy of the likely presidential candidate of the ruling Justicialist Party, the Buenos Aires Governor, Eduardo Duhalde, most observers feel it is unlikely he will be tempted to return to old populist policies.
The linchpin of Mr. Menem's economic policy has been the peg of the peso to the dollar, known to economists as "convertibility." The currency peg is set by law and prohibits the Government from issuing new money unless new pesos are backed by dollars or gold reserves in the central bank.
The peg, instituted in 1991, reduced Argentina's inflation rate from more than 2,000 percent to single digits almost immediately. The peg withstood intense pressure after the devaluation of the Mexican peso in December 1994. Economists also noted that the Argentine economy had been strengthened in recent years by tighter Government banking regulations that raised mandatory bank reserve requirements.

HEADLINE: Internet Company Has a Strong Share Sale

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Marketwatch.com Inc., which runs a popular World Wide Web site covering financial news, raised $46.8 million in an offering to institutional investors today.
The San Francisco-based company sold 2.75 million shares, a 23 percent stake, at $17 each. That was $1 more than the top of the expected range of $14 to $16, which had been raised from $10 to $12 on Wednesday by the lead underwriters BT Alex. Brown and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities. The sale gave Marketwatch.com a market capitalization of $199.8 million. 
 Based on the rise in the sale price and strong investor demand before the sale, the shares are expected to increase sharply when public trading begins on Friday.
The institutional sale follows three days of declines for most Internet stocks and broad market indexes. The Dow Jones industrial average has fallen 5.2 percent since Monday, led by concerns that Brazil's economic problems will hurt profits at many United States companies, while the Interactive Week Internet index fell 9.3 percent on concern that Internet stocks are overvalued.
The expectations that shares of Marketwatch.com shares will soar have caused the stock price of the Data Broadcasting Corporation to more than triple in the last month. Data Broadcasting, which sells financial market data to individuals via satellite and cable, owns Marketwatch.com with the CBS Corporation, and will own 38 percent of the Internet company after the sale.
Shares of Data Broadcasting fell $1.4375 today, to $31.1875; those of CBS fell $1, to $34.125.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Continue to Fall; The Dow Drops 228.63

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks fell for a fourth consecutive session yesterday as fears intensifed that Brazil's financial turmoil, reflected in the devaluation of its currency, might spread to other Latin economies and dampen business with the United States.
Unlike Wednesday's session, when blue-chip stocks recovered more than half of their losses during the day, prices rallied only mildly in late trading yesterday, not enough to keep the Dow Jones industrial average from slipping into negative territory for 1999. 
 "Brazil is on the brink and Argentina may follow," said Neil T. Eigen, managing director at J.& W. Seligman. "The realization is taking hold that the United States doesn't go it on our own."
As is usual on word of foreign distress, shares of banks and other financial companies were prominent casualties because of possibly soured loans and losses in securities trading. J. P. Morgan lost 4 9/16 a share, to 102; Suntrust fell 3 9/16 , to 72 11/16 ; Chase Manhattan was down 3 3/8, to 68 1/4; Mellon dropped 3 1/4, to 65 1/8, and Citigroup fell 1 5/16 , to 50 7/8.
Analysts also said the start of the impeachment trial of President Clinton contributed to the wider market decline, noting that the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which had stabilized for more than 90 minutes, resumed its slump as television coverage began at 1 P.M.
"It took buyers away and brought in some nervous selling," said Fane Lozman of Scanshift, a research company in Chicago.
At the close, the Dow was at 9,120.93, down 228.63 points, or 2.45 percent, its worst point loss since Sept. 30. That brought the two-day damage to 353.75 points, or 3.7 percent. The Dow is now down six-tenths of 1 percent for the year.
The S.& P. 500 fell 22.21 points yesterday, or 1.8 percent, to 1,212.19, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 39.99 points, or 1.73 percent, to 2,276.82. The S.& P. 500 is down 1.39 percent for the year, but Nasdaq is still up 3.84 percent.
Foreign markets, which were severely battered on Wednesday, ended mixed, but Brazil's Bovespa suffered much of its pounding -- nearly 10 percent -- after European markets had closed.
Market analysts said that high valuations had made the market particularly susceptible to shocks, especially one with the potential to do a lot of damage, like Brazil.
"This is a market correction inspired by the Brazilian crisis, added to by the Presidential impeachment," said John H. Shaughnessy, chief investment strategist at Advest Inc. in Boston. But he said the pullback was probably healthy, "squeezing euphoria out of the market" while not seriously threatening American business.
Analysts also took note of the very solid United States economy, confirmed in yesterday's Government reports of a surprisingly big rise in retail sales for December and almost nonexistent consumer inflation.
Among the 30 component stocks of Dow industrials, the biggest loser by far was Eastman Kodak, which plunged 8 3/16 a share, to 70 1/2, as the company reported fourth-quarter profits that were lower than expected. Kodak accounted for more than 30 points of the drop in the Dow, whose only gainer was General Electric, which rose 1/2, to 97 1/16 .
No major sectors escaped punishment, but some analysts said they were impressed that high-flying Internet stocks, which have become increasingly difficult to trade, held up relatively well.
While Yahoo fell 23 15/16 a share, to 344 1/16 , and Amazon.com fell 10, to 138, other Internet stocks surged. Ebay and Ubid, two auction companies, climbed; Ebay jumped 9 13/16 a share, to 225 5/16 ; Ubid rose 3 7/16 , to 91 1/2. America Online, another recent star, eased 1 1/4, to 144 1/2.
And the Russell 2000, an index comprising small-company stocks, was 1.12 percent lower, less than half the decline of the Dow.
On the New York Stock Exchange, declining issues outnumbered advancers by 2,161 to 903.
Despite Brazil's meltdown, stocks in Mexico rose 1.7 percent yesterday after nine consecutive sessions of declines. Markets also rose in Tokyo, by 2.5 percent, and Paris by nearly 1 percent. Stocks fell 1.6 percent in Frankfurt, five-tenths of 1 percent in London and eight-tenths of 1 percent in Hong Kong.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasuries Gain Sharply
 (By Bridge News) -- Treasury prices posted big gains yesterday for the third consecutive session as Brazil's problems continued to encourage flight-to-quality buying of United States Government securities.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 5/32 , to 103 1/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.05 percent, from 5.13 percent on Wednesday.
Stock market losses contributed to yesterday's bond gains, as did large Treasuries purchases by hedge funds. Treasuries also benefited from the release of economic data, including a lower-than-expected rise in December consumer prices.
Jack Ablin, a managing director at Colonial Asset Management in Jacksonville, Fla., said he thought that Brazil's problems and the United States stock market's losses were encouraging the bond market's hopes for another cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.

PUB-DATE: January 15, 1999

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1429 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
CRISIS IS DEEPENING IN BRAZIL MARKETS

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Propelled by a drop in Brazil's international credit rating and growing doubts about the Government's ability to defend the newly devalued currency, the Brazilian stock market was forced to suspend trading again today and closed down nearly 10 percent.
Adding to a sense of crisis here, interest rates soared and investors continued to withdraw money from Brazil. The International Monetary Fund and senior Clinton Administration officials said they had warned Brazil's President that his Government was unlikely to be able to prevent the currency, the real, from sinking below the exchange rate announced on Wednesday. Page C1. 
 Continued uncertainty about Brazil's prospects contributed to a second day of weak performances on world stock markets, and spread fear that the problems of Latin America's largest economy could soon spread to other countries in a region that accounts for 20 percent of United States exports.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 228.63 points, or 2.45 percent, and major stock markets in Europe and Asia declined slightly. Exchanges throughout Latin America fell sharply.
As Brazilian stocks dropped in Sao Paulo, the nation's financial center, pressure on the real intensified. After a de facto devaluation of more than 8 percent announced on Wednesday, the currency managed to hold steady today at the very top of a new official trading band established by the central bank -- 1.32 to the dollar, compared with 1.21 to the dollar before.
But through the day, nervous consumers and financial speculators tested the new rate, forcing the central bank to use its reserves to defend it. These have shrunk to less than half the $75 billion that Brazil had on hand before Russia devalued and defaulted last summer.
Investors, both foreigners and Brazilians, sent more than $1.25 billion abroad today, bringing the total for the month to about $3.5 billion.
At private currency exchanges, with more reliable supplies of dollars than at many banks, the real traded around 5 percent above the official rate. Middle-class Brazilians with memories of the currency instability that prevailed until recent years sought their traditional refuge in times of crisis -- United States dollars.
"I don't know if we are going to go back to the days when our currency lost value every single day," said Jose Dirceu Amaral Chaves, a salesman who was waiting to buy dollars this afternoon at a currency exchange in Ipanema. "But I need to protect myself and my family if things get worse."
Wednesday's decision to allow the real to slide in value against the dollar came after months of protestations by Brazilian officials that such a step was not only unnecessary but would also damage their efforts to stabilize the economy, the world's eighth largest, after years of high inflation.
But that policy drove interest rates to intolerable levels last fall -- nearly 50 percent -- which in turn dampened consumer purchases and business expansion and sent the country into recession. Interest-rate futures, after declining to 33 percent late last year, rose today to record levels. Contracts maturing in February closed at 71.65 percent, compared with 38.70 percent on Wednesday, while those for March climbed to 59.41 percent from 42.78 percent.
The Government has allowed interest rates to rise so high as part of its strategy to keep the currency stable. Officials have reasoned that the lure of extraordinarily high interest rates would encourage investors to leave their money in accounts in the local currency, rather than deposit billions in dollars overseas for a lower rate of return.
Over the years, though, the Government's defense of the currency made Brazilian exports more expensive than those of many competitors, and made imports artificially cheap, encouraging Brazilians to binge on consumer goods and foreign travel. That, in turn, accelerated the drain of reserves of foreign currency, adding to the pressure for a devaluation of the real.
Brazilian officials say they expect that once investors accept that a realistic exchange rate has been achieved, interest rates will gradually fall. They say that rate spikes like today's are an expectable but short-lived phenomenon, the result of the market testing their resolve to maintain the new exchange rate. They are reluctant to let the currency drop much further because such a step would drastically increase the cost of repaying foreign debt and buying essential imports.
In addition, some foreign officials have feared that uncontrolled devaluation in Brazil could set off destabilizing currency wars in other emerging economies.
Critics, though, argue that Brazil's currency is still overvalued by as much as 30 percent, and that President Francisco Henrique Cardoso and his advisers will only waste additional reserves and prolong the country's crisis by attempting to defend the new rate. Many of those critics maintain that Brazil can only resolve its troubles by allowing the market to determine the currency's true value.
Indeed, rumors that Brazil will soon abandon the new rate altogether and allow the real to float freely were so strong today that the central bank was compelled to issue a statement this afternoon denying that any such plan was under consideration.
At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, futures contracts for the real reached their maximum daily fluctuation, with contracts for the end of this month hitting 1.396 to the dollar.
Concerns about the viability of the new exchange rate and the likelihood of continued high interest rates led Standard & Poor's today to lower its rating on $58.1 billion of Brazilian foreign debt to BB- from B+. The downgrading, which left Brazil with Venezuela as the lowest-rated countries in South America, was widely publicized on television, radio and other news outlets here. An overall "outlook negative" rating accompanied the assessment.
"The downgrade and negative outlook," the rating service explained in a press release, "reflect the heightened risks to financial recovery posed by yesterday's shift in exchange-rate policy in the context of an unfinished reform agenda and extremely fragile market confidence. Pressure on the exchange rate is unlikely to abate, and net capital flows are expected to remain negative for months."
Some discouraging economic statistics announced by the central bank today also appeared to have fed the stock market plunge. Public-sector debt, for instance, rose by $7 billion in October and now amounts to 40.9 percent of the gross domestic product, a 1.2 percentage point increase in just one month.
Also contributing to the steep decline today, analysts said, was the resignation of Claudio Mauch, a key central bank official, a day after Gustavo Franco, the president of the bank, had stepped down. In his parting remarks, Mr. Mauch said that while one or two of Brazil's more than 200 banks might encounter some problems as a result of the change in exchange-rate policy, "there is nothing that is about to explode."
With the pressure against Brazil and its currency mounting, foreign governments and international lending institutions continued to issue statements of support for Mr. Cardoso and his economic team. In Washington, Enrique Iglesias, president of the Inter-American Development Bank, described international markets' reactions as irrational and praised the Brazilian Government's commitment to economic reform.
"I'm very surprised the markets have not appreciated the immense efforts Brazil is undertaking on fiscal reform," he said. In a separate statement, the bank, one of the principal contributors to the $41.5 billion I.M.F.-led bailout package for Brazil announced in November, argued that Brazil was moving to resolve the problems in its budget and social security system that the rescue plan addresses.
The nation's Congress on Wednesday approved four measures that will add more than $3 billion to Government revenue, helping to reduce the budget deficit and help satisfy the I.M.F. In a speech in Brasilia, the capital, Mr. Cardoso expressed confidence that resistance in Congress and by the governor of the country's second-most-populous state, which contributed to the current crisis, would soon be overcome.
Among ordinary Brazilians, however, confidence has clearly been shaken. "We have to recognize this morning that in a single day we have become nearly 10 percent poorer," Gazeta Mercantil, Brazil's principal business newspaper, glumly concluded in a front-page commentary that appeared in today's issue.

PUB-DATE: January 15, 1999

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1066 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. and I.M.F. Warn Brazil Not to Try to Prop Up Currency

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Senior Clinton Administration officials and the International Monetary Fund today warned Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, that his Government was unlikely to hold the devaluation of its currency to 8 percent, and might waste billions of dollars of its precious foreign currency reserves attempting to do so.
The warning came as the Brazilian stock market fell 10 percent before it was shut down, and as currency speculators forced Brazil to spend more than $1 billion -- for the third day running -- in an attempt to keep its currency, the real, from falling further. 
 American officials said they were in constant communication today with officials in other countries in the region, particularly Argentina and Mexico, in an effort to keep Brazil's action from touching off panics that many fear could drag down other Latin American nations.
Today those concerns deepened on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 228.63 points, or 2.45 percent, partly because of fears that Brazil's problems could spread, hurting both American exports and the earnings of banks that while less exposed to Latin America than they were a few months ago found themselves on the wrong side of a bet about Brazil's prospects of recovery. The Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, a key strategist in the Clinton Administration's efforts to contain the global financial turmoil, postponed a long-scheduled trip to Asia next week.
According to officials in both countries who had been briefed about the high-level telephone conversations between Washington and Brasilia, it was unclear what Mr. Cardoso would do next. But as one official involved in the talks said, "Cardoso was told that the likelihood his current strategy will work is very low."
Mr. Cardoso now finds himself caught between two extraordinarily difficult political choices. He could continue to fight off the speculators who are selling reals, spending billions of dollars from his country's reserves to buy his own country's currency. That would deplete reserves estimated at about $32 billion, a figure that would soon fall to zero if money kept flowing out of Brazil at current rates. Some Brazilian officials, however, are still hoping that they can regain the confidence of investors, convincing them that Mr. Cardoso still has the power to push through painful economic reforms that have touched off enormous political opposition.
Alternatively, Brazil could take the route that the I.M.F. has suggested: abandon the "exchange rate band" that artificially keeps the real from rising or falling past predetermined limits, and let the currency find its own value in the foreign exchange market. The I.M.F. did not propose simply letting the currency spiral into an uncontrolled fall. Instead, it urged the Brazilians to temporarily raise interest rates -- which are already above 50 percent -- as an incentive for investors to keep money in Brazil. The I.M.F. officials told Brazil that in South Korea last year that strategy eventually arrested the fall of the Korean won.
But that could mean the currency would fall 20 percent or more, touching off inflation and a decline in the living standard of Brazil's middle class. Mr. Cardoso has staked his political career -- he just won re-election -- by stabilizing the economy after years of hyper-inflation, and is loath to see his legacy lost.
American officials, who say they were presented with Brazil's decision this week as a fait accompli, insist that they have avoided prescribing a next move to the Brazilians.
"We will not characterize the content of our discussions with Brazil and the I.M.F.," said Howard Schloss, spokesman for Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. "Other than to say that we have not outlined a detailed set of policy prescriptions to the Brazilians, including exchange rate regimes."
At the same time, Mr. Cardoso spoke at length on Wednesday with Mr. Rubin, and today with the first deputy managing director of the I.M.F., Stanley Fischer. The blunter-speaking Mr. Summers has conducted a series of talks with his Brazilian counterpart, Pedro Malan.
Those conversations take place in the strictest secrecy, and the accounts of them that leak out later are often shaded to fit the self-interest of the leaker.
Brazilian officials, for example, have argued repeatedly in recent days that the devaluation was not their fault, but was forced upon them by currency speculators seeking to exploit delays in the adoption of the reform program. American and I.M.F. officials blame the Brazilians for taking too long to execute their commitments, undermining investors' confidence that Mr. Cardoso has the power to ultimately get them through.
They may both be right. But the events of the last few days also exposed some enormous cracks in the approach taken to keep the Asian economic crisis from washing onto American shores.
Brazil assumed that the $41.5 billion package, which included a $5 billion commitment by the United States, would give it plenty of breathing room. Only a few months ago, officials expressed confidence that speculators would fear attacking the Brazilian currency as long as they knew the United States and the I.M.F. stood behind Brazil's reform efforts.
They were wrong.
For its part, the Clinton Administration bet that Mr. Cardoso, fresh from an election victory, had the power to fulfill his promises. That, too, proved a bad bet -- one reminiscent of the American and I.M.F. roll of the dice last summer in Russia. That bailout, suspended after $4.8 billion was sent to Moscow, was based on the assumption that President Boris N. Yeltsin would convince the Russian Parliament to pass extensive economic reforms. Mr. Cardoso delivered more in Brazil than Mr. Yeltsin delivered in Moscow. But neither did enough to convince the markets.
Brazil's decision on Wednesday to attempt a limited devaluation was an effort to mollify those markets -- bait thrown to the sharks to take them off course. The idea was to give something to investors who have long feared the real is overvalued. But investors concluded that any government willing to devalue once would devalue again. So they took even more money out of the country. And that, in turn, raises the chances that Brazil will have to devalue again. It is a downward cycle that once started is hard to stop.
